PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the ordinances of the City of Meridian, Mississippi of a general and permanent nature. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1962 Code, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the Comparative Tables appearing in the back of this volume, the reader can locate any section of the 1962 Code, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Footnotes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state laws have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this volume. 
Numbering System 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and municipal codes. Each section number consists of two component parts separated by a dash, the figure before the dash referring to the chapter number and the figure after the dash referring to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the first section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-1 and the twenty-first section of Chapter 15 is 15-21. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper place simply by using the decimal system for amendments. By way of illustration: If new material consisting of three sections that would logically come between sections 4-3 and 4-4 is desired to be added, such new sections would be numbered 4-3.1, 4-3.2 and 4-3.3, respectively. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 7 and 8, it will be designated as Chapter 7.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division. 
Index 
    The index of the Code has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by municipal officers and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this Code to which the attention of the user is especially directed is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing for the Code. With this system, the Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances, they will be properly edited and the appropriate page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the Code, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Successfully maintaining this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume. As revised sheets are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publishers that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    The publication of this Code was under the direct supervision of James S. Vaught, Supervising Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publishers are most grateful to Mr. L. E. Skipper, City Clerk/Director of Administration, Mr. Tom Goldman, City Attorney, and Mr. Larry Primeaux, Assistant City Attorney, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this Code. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publishers have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the City readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the City's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida 
ORDINANCE NO. 3789 
[AN] ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CITY OF MERIDIAN, MISSISSIPPI; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE MAYOR AND THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF MERIDIAN, MISSISSIPPI: 
    Section 1.  The Code entitled "Code of Ordinances, City of Meridian, Mississippi" published by Municipal Code Corporation consisting of Chapters 1 through 25, each inclusive, is adopted. 
    Section 2.  All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before July 15, 1986, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are repealed. 
    Section 3.  The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4.  Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment in the city jail not exceeding ninety (90) days or both. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any Code section whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5.  Additions or amendments to the Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city council to make the same a part of the Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6.  Ordinances adopted after July 15, 1986, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 7.  This ordinance shall become effective as is provided by the Laws of the State of Mississippi. 
    ORDERED, this the 6th day of October, 1987. 
Motion by Councilman Kornegay second by Councilman Williams. 
Yea: Frasier, Kornegay, Williams. 
Nay: Thomas. 
Absent: Wilson.

Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omits." 
    In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated, cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Meridian, Mississippi," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1962, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of cities to codify ordinances and adopt said codification, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-13-15. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and interpretation. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    Appointing authority. In all cases the "appointing authority" shall be deemed to be the mayor with the exception of the clerk of the council and the city auditor who shall be appointed by the council. 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of Meridian, Mississippi" followed it. 
    Computation of time. When process shall be required to be served or notice given any number of days, the day of serving the process or of giving the notice shall be excluded and the day of appearance included; and in all other cases when any number of days shall be prescribed, one day shall be excluded and the other included. When the last day falls on Sunday, it shall be excluded; but in other cases Sunday shall be reckoned in the computation of time. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 1-3-67. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Lauderdale. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision requires or authorizes an officer or employee of the city to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize the officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the act or duty unless the terms of the provision designate otherwise. 
    Gender. Words importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. 
    Land sections. Whenever any lot, block, survey, street, avenue, or other thing, is in any manner described by reference to any particular section of land, wherein the township and range are not specified, the section referred to shall be construed to mean the section, of the number specified, in which is located a portion of the corporate area of the city or the territory adjoining same, added thereto as a part of the Meridian separate school district. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month, unless otherwise expressed. 
    Number. Words used in the singular include the plural and the plural includes the singular number. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed". 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner", applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person," when used in any ordinance shall apply to artificial as well as natural persons; and when used to designate the party whose property may be the subject of offense, shall include the United States, this state, or any other state, territory, or country, and any county, city, town or village which may lawfully own property in this state; also all public and private corporations, as well as individuals. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 1-3-39. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property," when used in any ordinance shall include goods, chattels, effects, evidences of rights of action, and all written instruments by which any pecuniary obligation, or any right, title, or interest in any real or personal estate, shall be created, acknowledged, transferred, incurred, defeated, discharged, or diminished. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 1-3-41. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and the next after, respectively. 
    Property. The term "property," when used in any ordinance, includes personal property as defined in this section and also every estate, interest, and right, in lands, tenements, and hereditaments. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 1-3-45. 
    Real property shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of Mississippi. 
    Street. The word "street" shall mean and include any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley, lane, viaduct, bridge and the approaches thereto within the city. 
    Tenant. The word "tenant" or "occupant" applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Writing. The words "writing" and "written" shall include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year, unless a contrary intention be expressed. 
(Code 1962, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Construction of statutes, Miss. Code 1972, § 1-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Severability. 
    If any part or parts, section or subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code is for any reason declared to be unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 1-3) 
State Law reference- Severability of statutes, Miss. Code 1972, § 1-3-77. 
Sec. 1-4. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of such sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. 
(Code 1962, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - Effect of code on existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Meridian, Mississippi, 1962, effective August 1, 1962, and ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1962, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or matter covered under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1962, § 1-6) 
State Law reference- No revival of repealed laws, Miss. Code 1972, § 1-1-25. 
Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _______ of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Meridian, Mississippi, is hereby amended to read as follows: _______." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  If a new section not theretofore existing in the Code, is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of the City of Meridian, Mississippi, is hereby amended by adding a section, article or chapter to be numbered _______, which section reads as follows: _______." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1962, § 1-7) 
Cross reference- Provisions relative to style, enactment, publication of ordinances, § 2-1 et seq. 
Sec. 1-8. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 1-8) 
State Law reference- Style of ordinances, Miss. Code, 1972, § 21-13-7. 
Sec. 1-9. - General penalty. 
    Wherever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provisions of this Code or ordinance of the city shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or by imprisonment in the city jail not exceeding six (6) months or both. Every day any violation of this Code or any such ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1962, § 1-9; Ord. No. 3216, § 1, 4-7-64; Ord. No. 3520, § 1, 6-8-77; Ord. No. 3700, § 1, 9-4-84; Ord. No. 3843, § 1, 10-17-89) 
Cross reference- Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 16; police, Ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Penalty limitation, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-13-1. 
Sec. 1-10. - Seat of city government. 
    The seat of government of the city shall be in the municipal building located upon that certain plot or tract of ground in the city bounded on the north by Seventh Street, on the west by Twenty-fifth Avenue, on the south by Sixth Street, and on the east by Twenty-fourth Avenue. 
(Code 1962, § 1-10) 
Sec. 1-11. - City declared separate school district. 
    An ordinance adopted by the boards of councilmen and aldermen, approved by the mayor August 9, 1893, whereby the city was constituted a separate school district in accordance with the provisions of section 4011, of the annotated code of Mississippi of 1892, is hereby reenacted and its provisions continued in force, the city being hereby further declared to be a separate school district pursuant to Mississippi Code Annotated, 1972 §§ 37-7-601 to 37-7-639 and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1962, § 1-11) 
Sec. 1-12. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by city; 
(2)  Containing any administrative provisions of the city council not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code; 
(3)  Granting any right or franchise and establishing any rates therefor; 
(4)  Dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(5)  Making any appropriation; 
(6)  Levying or imposing taxes not inconsistent with this Code; 
(7)  Establishing or prescribing grades in the city; 
(8)  Providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(9)  Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city; 
(10)  Adopting, extending or contracting the boundaries of the city; 
(11)  Prescribing the number, classification or compensation of any city officers or employees, not inconsistent with this Code; 
(12)  Prescribing specific parking restrictions, no-parking zones, specific speed zones, parking meter zones and specific stop or yield intersections, not inconsistent with this Code; 
(13)  Pertaining to zoning; 
(14)  Any ordinance adopted after July 15, 1986; 
(15)  Any other ordinance, or part thereof, which is not of a general and permanent nature; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. Such ordinances are on file in the city clerk's office. 
Sec. 1-13. - Administrative costs. 
    There shall be filed with each petition made by a private citizen or citizens requesting the city council to perform an act for the benefit of that private citizen or citizens and not for the general public as a whole an amount of money sufficient to pay the administrative cost incident to a hearing on and adoption of an order, resolution or ordinance approving such petition. Such administrative cost includes, but is not limited to, all publication expenses, recordation expenses, appraisal fees, legal fees and any other fees directly incurred by the city in the administration and handling of such petition. 
(Ord. No. 3892, 10-2-90) 
Cross reference- City council procedures and meetings, § 2-35 et seq. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Fire chief, § 9-41 et seq.; planning commission, § 17-16 et seq.; taxation, Ch. 22; water and sewer department established, § 25-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - When legislation to be by ordinance. 
    The mode or method of expressing the will of the city council on any of the following subjects shall be by ordinance: 
(1)  Whenever the legislative purpose is to prescribe a rule of conduct or government more or less permanent and in the nature of a law of the municipality, as distinguished from a mere order of resolution of a special or temporary character; 
(2)  The amendment, alteration or repeal of any existing ordinance; 
(3)  The levying of any general or special tax; 
(4)  The granting of any franchise; 
(5)  Those matters defined by the laws of the state as ordinance. 
(Code 1962, § 2-1) 
Sec. 2-2. - Style of ordinances. 
    The style of all ordinances of the city shall be, "Be it ordained by the City Council of the City of Meridian." 
Cross reference- Amendatory language of ordinances amending Code, § 1-7. 
State Law reference- Style of ordinances, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-13-7. 
Sec. 2-3. - Procedure for enacting ordinances; writing required. 
    Every ordinance shall be read as required by the laws of the state and considered at a public and official session of the city council and the vote on the final passage of every ordinance shall be taken by the council by "yeas" and "nays" which shall be entered on the minutes by the city clerk. A vote shall never be taken on an ordinance not previously reduced to writing. 
(Code 1962, § 2-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-13-5. 
Sec. 2-4. - Publication or posting of ordinances required. 
(a)  Required. Except as otherwise provided in this section no ordinance of the city shall go into effect or be enforced until a correct copy of the same, duly certified by the city clerk shall have been published one (1) time within thirty (30) days after passage in some newspaper published in the city. 
(b)  Emergency ordinances. Any ordinance for the immediate and temporary preservation of the public peace, health and safety, which contains a statement of the reasons of its urgency shall become effective from and after its passage and approval by unanimous vote of the council. Such ordinance, however, shall nevertheless be published as required by this section for other ordinances. 
(c)  Proof. Proof of publication of ordinances shall be made in the manner provided by Mississippi Code 1972, section 13-1-153. 
(Code 1962, § 2-5) 
State Law reference- Publication or posting generally, Miss. Code 1972, § 2-13-11; for ordinances adopting codes by reference, § 21-19-25; ordinances creating or consolidating fire districts, §§ 21-25-21, 21-25-23, 21-25-25; ordinances authorizing parking facilities, §§ 21-37-23, 21-37-25; ordinances fixing salaries of mayor, councilmen, § 21-5-15. 
Sec. 2-5. - Departments created. 
    The following departments of the city government are hereby created: Administration; public works; parks, recreation and cultural affairs; community development; fire and police. 
Secs. 2-6-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-21-2-23. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The provisions of §§ 2-21-2-23 were deleted as being superseded by Ord. No. 3895, included as a new Div. 2 of this article. The deleted sections pertained to time and place of regular meetings, calling special meetings, and quorum and votes required, and derived from Code 1962, §§ 2-8, 2-10, and Ord. No. 3733, § I, II, adopted Jan. 7, 1986. 
Secs. 2-24-2-34. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RULES OF PROCEDURE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The provisions of Div. 2, §§ 2-35, 2-36, were deleted as being superseded by Ord. No. 3845, adopted Dec. 5, 1989, §§ 1-9 of which were included as a new Div. 2, §§ 2-35-2-49, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-35. - Time and place of meetings. 
(a)  Time-First regular meeting. The city council shall hold its first regular meeting on the first Tuesday of each month beginning at 9:00 a.m. The council may, by resolution adopted not less than one (1) week prior thereto, change its regular time of meeting. If the day fixed for any regular meeting of the council falls upon a day designated by law as a legal or national holiday, such meeting shall be held the same hour on the next succeeding day not a holiday. 
(b)  Same-Second regular meeting. The city council will hold its second regular meeting each month on the third Tuesday at 5:00 p.m. at the same place as set for the first regular meeting with the same provisions and exceptions as stated for the first regular meeting. 
(c)  Place. First regular meetings of the council shall be held in the council chambers; however, the council may adjourn any meeting to such other place as it may deem necessary, desirable or convenient for the meeting. If the meeting is adjourned to some other location, notice of said location shall be affixed to the door of the council chambers, and all news media shall be so advised. 
    The council chambers, and any such other place as the council may meet, shall be within the exclusive control and prerogative of the council. All facilities and arrangements for council meetings, including seating arrangements and positioning, placement of speakers' lecterns or tables, microphones, lighting, recording devices, cameras, public seating and conveniences, media space requirements and all other procedural matters relating to the facilities and rules pertaining to the regular or special meetings of the council, shall be subject to the concurrence and approval of a majority of the council members present and voting and at the request of the council carried out by the mayor. 
(d)  Recessed meetings. Any first or second regular meeting of the council may be recessed by appropriate action to reconvene on a day and time fixed by order of the council and duly entered in the minutes of the meeting which is recessed. 
(e)  Special meetings. Special meetings may be held upon recommendation of the president of the council, the mayor, or a majority of the members of the council. Written notice for all special meetings shall be delivered no later than seventy-two (72) hours in advance thereof by the clerk of council to each council member and to the mayor. Special meetings may be held earlier than the expiration of the seventy-two (72) notice period only upon written waiver of notice signed by all members of the council, which such waiver shall be entered into the minutes. The written notice (and any waiver in lieu thereof) shall specify the time and place for the meeting, the person or persons recommending the calling of the special meeting, and the specific purpose or purposes for which the special meeting is to be held. No matters not specifically identified in the written notice (or the waiver given in lieu thereof) shall be considered in order at the special meeting or taken up for discussion or for action at the special meeting, except by unanimous agreement of all council members. The written notice and/or waiver shall be read by the clerk of council and entered into the minutes at the outset of the special meeting. This section is subject to the provisions of state law. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. I, § 1, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. I, § 1, 6-2-98; Ord. No. 4230, § I, 8-5-2003; Ord. No. 4280, § 1, 3-17-2006) 
Sec. 2-36. - Order of meetings. 
(a)  Presiding officer. The presiding officer of the city council shall be the council president, or in his/her absence, the council vice president, or in the absence of both, a temporary presiding officer elected by those council members present and voting. The presiding officer shall preserve strict order and decorum at all regular and special meetings of the council. He/she shall state every question coming before the council, announce the decision of the council on all subjects, and decide all questions of order, subject, however, to an appeal to the council, in which event a majority vote of the council shall govern and conclusively determine such question of order. Such appeal shall be immediately presented and voted upon by the council. 
(b)  Calling of meetings to order. The presiding officer shall take the chair at the hour appointed for the council meeting, and shall immediately call the city council to order. In the absence of the presiding officer, a temporary presiding officer shall be elected by the members of the council present. Upon the arrival of the presiding officer, the temporary presiding officer shall immediately relinquish the chair upon the conclusion of the business immediately before the council. 
(c)  Roll call. Before proceeding with the business of the city council, the clerk of council or his/her deputy shall take the roll of the members. The names of those present shall be entered in the minutes. The clerk will announce those present and absent at the call of the presiding officer during the roll call order of business. 
(d)  Quorum. A majority of all members elected to the city council shall constitute a quorum at any regular or special meeting of the council. No official business may be transacted by the council in the absence of a quorum. 
(e)  Minutes. A copy of the minutes of the previous regular and any intervening meeting of the city council duly recorded and prepared according to the Mississippi Statutes shall be made available to all city council members and the mayor immediately upon being compiled by the clerk of council. 
(f)  Approval of minutes. The approval of the minutes of the previous city council meeting and any appropriate intervening special meetings may be approved as printed and distributed to the city council, unless their reading is requested by a member of the council. Corrections to the printed minutes will be requested and considered at the time of their approval on the council meeting agenda. 
(g)  Record of voting. All actions of the city council requiring a vote shall be recorded in the minutes for each council member with either "yea" or "nay" to the motion being recorded. Should the clerk of council or any council member be uncertain as to the individual disposition of the votes, a roll call vote may be called. The members introducing and seconding motions will also be recorded. Nothing in this section prevents a legal abstention. 
(h)  Robert's Rules of Order, Revised. Unless otherwise specified or unless changed by a specific provision of this division, the city council shall be governed in all matters of procedure by that compilation of rules of procedure known as "Robert's Rules of Order Revised". 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. I § 2, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. I, § 2, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-37. - Rules of debate. 
(a)  Rights of council members and recognition. The presiding officer and council members may debate and vote as allowed by Mississippi Statutes, and shall not be deprived of any of the rights and privileges of a councilman/woman by reason of his/her acting as the presiding officer, except as provided by Mississippi Statutes. 
    Every member desiring to speak shall address the chair, and upon recognition by the presiding officer, shall confine himself/herself to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language. The decision of the presiding officer will be final. 
(b)  Limitation on debate. Debate, discussion or the address of any matter by an individual council member, mayor or citizen will be limited to five (5) minutes per occasion of officially obtaining the floor. Limited extensions of specific allotments of additional time may be granted to the person who has the floor by the presiding officer upon request. Changes in the time limit on debate may be adopted by proper motion, second and vote of the council at any time. The clerk of council shall keep time and shall announce the expiration of any and all applicable time limits. 
    No person shall speak more than once on any subject under discussion until all other members of the council have had the opportunity to speak. 
    A council member or the mayor may request, through the presiding officer, that an abstract of his/her statement on any subject under consideration by the council be entered in the minutes. Any council member or mayor shall likewise have the right to have the reason for his/her dissent or protest against any action of the city council entered on the minutes. 
(c)  Interruptions. Council members or mayor, once recognized, shall not be interrupted when speaking, unless it is to call him/her to order as otherwise provided in this division. If a council member or mayor, while speaking, is called to order, he/she shall cease speaking until the question of order is determined, and if in order, he/she shall be permitted to proceed. The presiding officer will enforce such procedure as necessary to maintain order in discussion. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. I § 3, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. I, § 3, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-38. - Manner of addressing council. 
(a)  Recognition. Any citizen addressing the city council shall stand, request to be recognized, and, if recognized, shall give his/her name and address of residence for the records. All remarks shall be addressed to the council as a body and not to any member thereof. No person, other than the council or mayor and the person having the floor, shall be permitted to enter into any discussion or ask a question of a council member, either directly or through a member of the council, without the permission of the presiding officer. 
(b)  Time limit. Unless further time is granted by the council, each person shall limit their address to five (5) minutes. The clerk of council shall keep time and shall notify the citizen speaker when the allotted time has expired. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. I § 4, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. I, § 4, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-39. - Decorum. 
(a)  By council members. While the city council is in session, the members shall preserve decorum and order, and no member shall, by conversation or otherwise, delay or interrupt the proceedings or the peace of the council, nor disturb any member while speaking, nor refuse to obey the orders of the council or its presiding officer, except as otherwise provided in this division. 
(b)  By other persons. No person shall make personal, impertinent or slanderous remarks, nor otherwise disturb the order and decorum of any council meeting. The sergeant-at-arms, upon prior instructions by the mayor and at the direction of the presiding officer, shall remove any person violating the provisions of this subsection. 
(c)  Preservation. A member of the police department, as the mayor shall designate, named and identified as sergeant-at-arms shall be sergeant-at-arms of the city council meeting. Upon prior instructions by the mayor, he/she shall carry out all orders and directions given by the presiding officer for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at the council meetings. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. I § 5, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. I, § 5, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-40. - Committees. 
(a)  Special committees. All special committees shall be appointed by the presiding officer, unless otherwise directed by the city council. 
(b)  Committee meetings, generally. Meetings of all committees may be held at such time and place as the committee shall determine for its convenience. The committee, at its discretion, may determine who, besides its members, may be present. 
(c)  Committee reports. All committees of the city council shall make their reports in writing when so directed by the presiding officer. All reports shall be filed with the clerk of council and included in the agenda packet and entered on the minutes of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. I § 6, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. I, § 6, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-41. - Official agenda. 
    No matter may be considered by the council for action at regular meetings unless it has been placed on the official agenda as prescribed herein. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. II § 1, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. II, § 1, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-42. - Order of business. 
    The agenda as presented by the president of the council shall be arranged as follows: 
(1)  The agenda order. The confirmation of the agenda order is the first matter on the agenda and shall constitute the only period during which the agenda order may be adjusted. Any council member or the mayor may request the council add any item to the agenda, the consideration of which would relate to the city government provided that the need for action on the matter arises after 12:00 noon on the Tuesday immediately before the regular meeting or that conditions beyond their control made it impossible to meet the time requirements. 
(2)  The consent agenda. The consent agenda shall be considered second and consist of those items for council action that do not require discussion or question such as proclamations, minutes, transfer of funds, surplus items, taxi permits, and similar such matters. These items will be acted upon together without debate or amendment, however, they will be listed separately on the agenda. 
(3)  The routine agenda. The agenda of routine items shall be considered third and shall consist of all routine and administrative matters for which policy already exists, all orders, ordinances, resolutions and other matters of business as determined by the council president or majority of the council members. All matters to be considered on the routine agenda shall be listed separately on the routine agenda by title. Any reports shall be limited to fifteen (15) minutes unless such time be extended for an additional specific allotment of time at the discretion of the president of the council. The clerk of council shall keep time and shall signal the person giving the report when the allotted time has expired. 
(4)  The presentation agenda. The presentation agenda shall be considered fourth and shall consist of all presentations which do not require immediate council action, such as but not limited to reports, certificates and any mayor's report as may be requested by a majority of the council. All presentation agenda items will be scheduled for the council's regular monthly meetings prior to noon on Tuesday immediately before said meeting. Presentations shall be limited to five (5) minutes unless such time is extended for an additional specific allotment of time by the approval of a majority of the council. The clerk of council shall keep time and shall signal the person giving the report when the allotted time has expired. 
(5)  Public hearings. Public hearings shall be considered fifth. Public hearings shall be held on or as soon after the stated time as possible and shall have precedence over other matters. If specific law permits, council action may be taken by the usual vote immediately upon completion of such hearing. Where specific law does not apply, public hearings shall be conducted as follows: all council hearings shall be advertised at least six (6) calendar days in advance of the hearing. Comments from all persons shall be limited to five (5) minutes individually, and the length of the entire public hearing shall be limited by the president's judgment as to the best use of the council's time. The clerk of council shall keep time and shall announce the expiration of any applicable time period for comments. All public hearings shall be conducted according to the requirements of Mississippi law. 
Any citizen addressing the city council shall stand, request to be recognized, and, if granted, shall give his/her name and address of residence for the records. Unless further time is granted by the council, each person shall limit their address to five (5) minutes, which such time is to be kept by the clerk of council. All remarks shall be addressed to the council as a body and not to any member thereof. No person, other than the council and the person having the floor, shall be permitted to enter into any discussion or ask a question of a council member either directly or through a member of the council without the permission of the presiding officer. 
If a duly notice hearing was previously held before a municipal officer, board or advisory committee, then a second hearing may not be required, but the record of the hearing as made before such municipal officer, or board, or advisory committee and the recommendation of such municipal officer, board or advisory committee shall be filed and placed on the routine agenda for appropriate action. Provided, however, that only if a party is aggrieved with the recommendation of such municipal officer, or board, or advisory committee, such aggrieved party shall be entitled to a full public hearing before the council upon due notice thereof after publication of the time and date as provided in this section. Public hearings as advertised for a specific time as required by statute shall be held on or as soon after the stated time as possible and shall have precedence over other matters. 
(6)  The study agenda. The study agenda shall consist of all motions for staff and legal review and study of drafts of legislation submitted to the president of the council, or requests for legal opinions and research into ordinances. 
(7)  Executive session. Any executive session shall be limited to discussion of matters deemed eligible by the Mississippi "Open Meetings Law" and shall be conducted in accordance with such Law. 
(8)  Citizen comments. A maximum of fifteen (15) minutes shall be allotted at each council meeting for citizen comments. Citizen comments shall be limited to three (3) minutes per citizen. The city council reserves the right to either shorten or extend the three-minute time limit. The clerk of council shall keep the time and notify the speaker when the allotted time has expired. All remarks shall be addressed to the council as a body and not to any individual member thereof. The council shall not take official actions on any items presented during the citizens comments portion of the agenda, but may recommend that a matter discussed during the session be placed on a future agenda for official deliberation and action. 
Any citizen who wishes to address the city council during the citizen comments portion of the agenda must first pick up a "Request to Speak at City Council Meeting" form from the clerk of council. Said form must be turned in to the clerk of council no later than 4:00 p.m. on the Monday of the week prior to the city council meeting. Topics to be discussed are limited to the business of the City of Meridian. If it is deemed that the topic a citizen wants to discuss does not pertain to the business of the City of Meridian, then the citizen will not be placed on the agenda and will not be given the opportunity to address the city council. 
Violation(s) of the Code of Ordinances regarding citizen comments, rules of debate, manner of addressing council and/or decorum shall result in the citizen being denied the opportunity to speak at a city council meeting as follows: a first violation shall result in a suspension from addressing the council during a council meeting for a period of three (3) months from the date of the infraction; a second violation shall result in a suspension from addressing the council during a council meeting for a period of six (6) months from the date of the infraction; a third violation shall result in a suspension from addressing the council during a council meeting for a period of one (1) year from the date of the infraction; and the fourth violation shall result in the preclusion of said citizen to no longer address the city council at a city council meeting. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. II § 2, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 3952, § 1, 4-6-93; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. II, § 2, 6-2-98; Ord. No. 4320, § 1, 6-19-2007; Ord. No. 4353, § 1, 9-1-2009; Ord. No. 4370, § 1, 8-3-2010; Ord. No. 4417, § 1, 5-7-2013; Ord. No. 4424, § 1, 10-15-2013; Ord. No. 4426, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 2-43. - Responsibility and authority of council president and council; finalizing of agenda. 
    The council president shall be responsible for determining the initial order of each part of the agenda (each subagenda) for each meeting. All matters to be placed on the agenda by any member of the city council shall be authorized by the president of the council as provided herein. The council president shall be required to place all matters presented by a council member as prescribed herein on the agenda at the earliest possible opportunity for council action. All matters requested to be placed on the agenda by any member of the executive branch of government shall be first authorized by the mayor. The council president shall finalize the agenda for submission to the clerk of council no later than 12:00 noon Tuesday immediately prior to the next regular council meeting. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. II § 3, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. II, § 3, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-44. - Assembly and delivery of agenda package. 
    Council's clerk shall be responsible for posting the agenda in a public place at city hall and immediately outside of the council chambers, preparing and assembling the agenda package, and delivering the agenda package to council and the mayor as soon as practical after receipt of the agenda. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. II § 4, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. II, § 4, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-45. - Requests for legislative action. 
    Any member of the city council wishing to place a matter on the agenda shall provide a draft of his/her proposal and request for legislative action to the clerk of council or council president not later than 12:00 noon Tuesday the week prior to the council meeting. Nothing in this section is intended to prevent any member of the council from informally seeking the assistance of the city attorney, or through the mayor the assistance of the executive branch, in the preparation of draft legislation for the council member. All items initiated by a council member shall appear on the agenda by title and initiating author. Legislative action requested by the mayor shall be presented to the council president during the submission phase of the agenda. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. II § 5, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. II, § 5, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-46. - Agenda cycle. 
    The agenda cycle shall consist of the submission phase, the publication phase, the review phase, and the execution phase. 
(1)  Submission phase. The submission phase shall begin at the opening of business on Wednesday following the previous council meeting and end at 12:00 noon the Tuesday prior to the council meeting. Matters may be submitted for placement on the agenda only during the submission phase. All information on items to be placed on the agenda must be submitted during the submission phase. 
(2)  Publication phase. The publication phase shall begin at 12:00 noon Tuesday and end at 12:00 noon Thursday of the week prior to the council meeting. The council president shall be responsible for finalizing the agenda. The clerk of council shall be responsible for publishing the final agenda and delivery of the agenda packages. 
(3)  Review phase. The review phase shall begin with delivery of the agenda package and end with the beginning of the council meeting on Tuesday. The review phase is provided to give each council member adequate time to study the agenda package before opening of the official city council meeting. 
(4)  Execution phase. The execution phase shall begin with the opening of business of the council meeting and end with adjournment of the meeting. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. II § 6, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. II, § 6, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-47. - Emergency matters. 
    Upon recommendation by the president of the council, mayor, or upon motion duly adopted by the city council by a majority of members present and voting, emergency matters, not appearing on the regular agenda in the manner provided herein, may be considered by the council at any meeting. 
    Emergency matters shall constitute those matters which threaten the immediate safety and well being of the citizens of the community and/or employees of the city; would potentially disrupt the delivery of essential services; would result in substantial increased cost of operations of city government or increased cost in the purchase of necessary items for the administration of city government; would, if delayed, result in the loss of an opportunity for significant economic development in the city or would otherwise meet necessary standards as would require the aforementioned majority voting requirement. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. II § 7, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. II § 7, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-48. - Special meetings. 
    Special called meetings which comply with state law and contain all topics to be presented to council therein shall be subject to this division, and ordinances or amendments to ordinances considered at such special meetings shall be adopted as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. II § 8, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. II, § 8, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-49. - Division to supersede in cases of conflict. 
    Where in conflict, this division supersedes rules of order previously adopted by the council. This division shall take effect upon a unanimous vote of the council, otherwise it shall be effective in accordance with the laws of the State of Mississippi. 
(Ord. No. 3845, Pt. II § 9, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 4102, Pt. II § 9, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 2-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-51. - Employees' retirement system adopted. 
    All provisions of the Mississippi Code 1972, sections 21-29-1 through 21-29-55, and amendments thereto, known and cited as the "General Municipal Employees' Retirement Law," are hereby adopted and are to be considered as much a part of this Code as if every word, clause and section were set out herein. 
(Code 1962, § 2-18) 
Sec. 2-52. - Firemen's and policemen's disability and relief fund established. 
    There is hereby created and established a fund known as a disability and relief fund for firemen and policemen. Such fund is created and established in accordance with Mississippi Code 1972, sections 21-29-101 through 21-29-151. All provisions of Mississippi Code 1972, sections 21-29-101 through 21-29-151 are hereby adopted and are to be considered as much a part of this Code as if every word, clause and section were set out herein. 
(Code 1962, § 2-19) 
Sec. 2-53. - Bond of officers, employees-Required; exceptions. 
    The city clerk shall purchase, at the expense of the city, from some insurance company authorized to do business under the laws of the state, a blanket faithful performance position bond in the amount of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) payable to the city, which shall indemnify the city against any loss or losses sustained by the city through the failure of any officer or employee of the city acting alone or in collusion with others to perform faithfully his duties or to account properly for all moneys or property received by virtue of his position or employment; provided, however, that, there shall be excluded from such bond all patrolmen in the police department and all firemen in the fire department of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 2-20) 
State Law reference- Authority to require bond from officers and employees, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-15-3. 
Sec. 2-54. - Same-Custodian designated. 
    The bond or bonds required above shall be delivered to the city clerk where they shall be safely and securely kept during the term of such bonds. 
(Code 1962, § 2-22) 
Sec. 2-55. - Officers not to be surety on bonds in which city interested. 
    It shall be unlawful for a councilman, or any other officer of the city, to become a surety on the appeal bond of any person convicted in the municipal court, or on the bond of any person or employee, or of any contractor for city work or on any other bond made payable to the city. 
(Code 1962, § 2-23) 
Sec. 2-56. - Oath of office. 
    Every officer of the city shall, before entering upon the duties of his office take and subscribe an oath of office before some officer authorized to administer such oath. All oaths of office shall be filed and preserved by the city clerk. The oath of office required by this section shall be in the following form: 
    "I, _______ do hereby solemnly swear that I am not disqualified from holding the office of _______ to which I have been appointed, that I will support the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution and Laws of the State of Mississippi and the Laws and Ordinances of the City of Meridian during my continuance in office; that I will discharge the duties of my said office to the best of my skill and ability during my continuance therein; that I will not during my continuance in office engage or take part in any strike or threat of strike of officers or employees of said City, nor counsel nor advise any other officer or employee of said City so to do, nor will I voluntarily leave the service of the City or cease to perform the duties of my said office without giving ten days' previous written notice to the appointing authority of my intention so to do. 
_____
    Sworn to and subscribed before me this _______ day of _______, 19___." 
(Code 1962, § 2-24) 
State Law reference- Authority to prescribe oath by ordinance, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-15-3. 
Sec. 2-57. - Wages and salaries-Council to establish. 
    Every officer, assistant or employee, other than the mayor and councilmen, shall receive such salary or compensation as the mayor and council shall by ordinance provide, and such salaries or compensation shall be fixed by the council from time to time, as occasion may demand. 
(Code 1962, § 2-25) 
State Law reference- Authority, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-8-21(2). 
Sec. 2-58. - Same-Additional compensation for policemen, firemen authorized. 
    The city council shall have the power and authority to provide for and pay to any member of the police department or fire department additional compensation for services and duties performed by such member over and above the usual and regular number of days and hours per week or month ordinarily worked by such member. Any additional compensation so paid shall be computed on the basis of the compensation usually paid such member of the police or fire department. Nothing contained herein shall be construed to relieve any such member of the police or fire department from being subject to call for duty on a twenty-four-hour basis whether or not additional compensation is paid; provided, however, that, no policeman or fireman shall perform any duties or other work during regular working hours for any person or association, group or drive, or during hours for which he is being paid for the performance of official duties as policeman or fireman. 
(Code 1962, § 2-26) 
Cross reference- Fire department generally, § 9-21 et seq.; police, Ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-8-21(3). 
Sec. 2-59. - Same-Preservation of payrolls. 
    All payrolls for officers and employees of the city shall be carefully preserved by the city clerk. 
(Code 1962, § 2-32) 
Sec. 2-60. - Same-Time of payment. 
    The salary of the mayor, councilmen and all officers and assistants holding any office created by Mississippi Code 1972, sections 21-8-1 through 21-8-47 inclusive, or by ordinance, shall be paid in monthly installments on the last business day of each month and the salaries or wages of all other employees of the city shall be paid at such periods as may be fixed by the council; but no salaries or wages shall be paid to any officer or employee of the city until after the same shall have been earned. 
(Code 1962, § 2-27) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-8-21(2). 
Sec. 2-61. - Same-Method of payment. 
    All salaries shall be paid by check drawn on the appropriate fund. 
(Code 1962, § 2-28) 
Sec. 2-62. - Same-Departmental payrolls. 
    A payroll of each department, bearing the names of the officers and employees of the department for which it is prepared, shall be prepared by the chief officer thereof and filed with the city clerk at the end of each pay period. This payroll shall show the time served and the amount of salary due each officer and employee thereon for the period just ended. 
(Code 1962, § 2-29) 
Sec. 2-63. - Same-Nondepartmental payrolls. 
    At the end of each month there shall be prepared by the city clerk a payroll bearing the name of the mayor, councilmen, and all other city officials not appearing on any other payroll, who are paid a fixed monthly salary, showing the amount due each for services of the month just ended. 
(Code 1962, § 2-30) 
Sec. 2-64. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4134, adopted Oct. 5, 1999, repealed § 2-64 which pertained to residence requirements and derived from Ord. No. 3720, §§ 1-3, adopted July 16, 1985. 
Sec. 2-65. - Position classification plan adopted. 
    There are hereby created position classifications for all positions in the services of the city, in accordance with a copy of the Position Classification Plan, City of Meridian, Mississippi, on file in the office of the city clerk and identified by his signature. 
(Code 1962, § 2-33) 
Secs. 2-66-2-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICERS[3]

--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Airport manager, § 4-2 et seq.; tax collector, § 22-2 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to create position, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-8-25. 

Sec. 2-76. - Chief administrative officer. 
(a)  The chief administrative officer shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the council; such chief administrative officer shall serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor, shall be answerable solely to the mayor in the performance of his functions, and shall be subject to dismissal at the pleasure of the mayor. The chief administrative officer shall coordinate and direct the operations of the various departments and functions of municipal government, and may exercise any authority, power, or duty lawfully delegated to him by the mayor. The chief administrative officer shall be excluded from the coverage of any ordinance or general law providing for a civil service system in the municipality. 
(b)  The qualifications of the position of chief administrative officer shall include a law degree, or a degree in business, public administration, accounting, or a comparable discipline, or five (5) years of experience in business administration, municipal planning, municipal management, or a comparable administrative profession. 
(Ord. No. 3716, 7-2-85) 
Sec. 2-77. - City attorney-Duty to act as legal advisor. 
    The city attorney shall be the legal advisor for the city, and shall give his opinion, in writing, to the council upon any question of law relating to the interest of the city, and to the chief officials of the several departments of city government, upon any question of law relating to their respective offices and duties, when the same is requested of him in writing. He shall also give legal advice orally to the council, from time to time, when requested by them to do so. 
(Code 1962, § 2-46) 
Sec. 2-78. - Same-Duty to prosecute, defend suits, report on litigation. 
    The city attorney shall prosecute and defend all suits in which the city is interested, except in the municipal court, and there also when requested by the mayor in writing; and shall, from time to time, make such reports in relation to suits or other legal proceedings in which the city is interested, as may be required of him by the mayor. 
(Code 1962, § 2-47) 
Sec. 2-79. - Same-Duty to investigate property titles, prepare contracts, ordinances. 
    The city attorney shall investigate all titles to property in behalf of the city, and furnish reports thereof, reduce to writing any contract to which the city is a party, and any ordinance, when in either case requested so to do by the mayor. 
(Code 1962, § 2-48) 
Sec. 2-80. - Same-Employment of additional, special or substitute legal counsel. 
    Legal counsel may be employed in any case or matter, wherein the city council may deem advisable, to represent the interests of the city, or the interest of any board, commission or agency of the city, not already empowered by law to hire or retain its own legal counsel, and whenever the city council shall determine that the city attorney or his firm, for any reason, cannot or should not act as such counsel for them, then the city council may employ additional, special, substitute or assistant legal representation, it may deem advisable and to establish compensation therefor in compliance with section 21-15-25, Mississippi Code 1972, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 3834, § 2, 8-1-89) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 3834, adopted Aug. 1, 1989, repealed former § 2-80 which pertained to employment of assistant counsel and derived from Code 1962, § 2-49. Section 2 of the ordinance was included as a new § 2-80 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 2-81-2-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-96. - Appointment, duties generally. 
(a)  The city clerk shall be appointed by the city council to serve as clerk of the council, keep the minutes and records of its proceedings, maintain and compile its ordinances and resolutions. 
(b)  The city clerk shall be responsible to the council and answerable to the council in regard to his duties in the keeping of the minutes and records of the proceedings of the council and in maintaining and compiling the ordinances and resolutions of the city council as provided in section 21-8-13 Mississippi Code 1972. 
(c)  The city clerk shall be responsible and answerable solely to the mayor in the performance of the administrative functions of his office and shall perform all administrative duties assigned to him by the mayor, and he shall be subject to removal by the mayor, and relieved from the performance of any administrative duties not covered by section 21-8-13(1). 
(Ord. No. 3715, 7-2-85) 
Sec. 2-97. - Other duties. 
    The city clerk, in addition to those duties set out in section 2-96, shall have the duties and powers set out in Mississippi Code 1972, sections 21-15-17, 21-15-19, 21-15-21, 21-35-111, 21-35-13 and 21-35-17. 
Secs. 2-98-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CODES ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Airport and aircraft, Ch. 4; building code, § 7-16 et seq.; electrical code, § 7-111 et seq.; gas code, § 7-91 et seq.; plumbing code, § 7-71 et seq.; housing code, § 13-1 et seq.; subdivision regulations, Ch. 21; zoning regulations, App. A. 

Sec. 2-111. - Designation. 
    In addition to all other persons and officials heretofore or hereafter authorized to enforce such ordinances, the building official and the director of community development and such city employees as are specifically designated in writing by either shall be and they are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce all the provisions of the official zoning ordinances of the city, land subdivision regulations of the city, the official plumbing code of the city, the official building code of the city, the official gas code of the city, the official electrical code of the city, the official mechanical code of the city, the official housing code of the city, the ordinances and regulations governing airport zoning in the city, the ordinances governing mobile homes in the city and the ordinances which govern development, construction and uses in flood hazard areas in the city, and for such purposes they shall have the powers of a police officer. 
(Code 1962, § 2-71; Ord. No. 3593, § 1, 10-7-80; Ord. No. 3949, § 1, 2-16-93) 
Sec. 2-112. - Authorization to issue citations. 
    The building official and the director of community development and such city employees as are specifically designated in writing by either shall be and each of them are hereby granted authority to issue citations returnable to the city court or to other proper authority for violations of any of the ordinances listed or described in section 2-111 hereof, and such citations shall have the same full force and effect as if issued by the police department of the city or any of its officers. 
(Code 1962, § 2-72; Ord. No. 3593, § 2, 10-7-80; Ord. No. 3949, § 2, 2-16-93) 
Secs. 2-113-2-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-131. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall commence on the first day of October, and end on the thirtieth day of September, of each year. 
(Code 1962, § 2-78) 
State Law reference- Municipal fiscal year, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-35-3. 
Sec. 2-132. - Receipts to be in U.S. currency. 
    All fines and forfeitures collected in the municipal court, all privilege taxes and taxes of every description, together with damages thereon, all fees due the city on any other account whatever, shall be paid in lawful money of the United States. 
(Code 1962, § 2-79) 
Sec. 2-133. - Deposit of receipts. 
    All moneys, collected from any and all sources, must, at least once each week, be deposited by the officials collecting same in the official city depository, after the same shall have been reported to the city clerk and a receipt warrant issued therefor. 
(Code 1962, § 2-80) 
State Law reference- Designation of depositories, Miss. Code 1972, §§ 27-105-351-27-105-361; requirements that depository not receive any money until reported to clerk, audited and receipt warrant issued, § 21-15-21; general duties of depositories, § 21-39-19. 
Sec. 2-134. - Receipt and disbursement of city funds; reports to council; voucher required. 
(a)  All moneys belonging to the city and the Meridian separate school district shall be credited to the proper fund, by the city clerk, and all such funds shall be disbursed by the city clerk only by checks issued and signed by the city clerk and countersigned by the mayor; provided, however, that no disbursement shall be made out of any such funds without proper authority. 
(b)  The city clerk shall file with the city council, at least once each month, an itemized report showing all receipts and disbursements made by him for the preceding month. 
(c)  The city clerk shall keep an accurate record of all checks drawn on each fund in a well-bound book to be kept for that purpose, to be styled "voucher record." In such record he shall record the amount of money for which each was issued and to whom made payable. 
(Code 1962, § 2-81) 
Sec. 2-135. - Use of check signing machine authorized. 
    The mayor and city clerk are hereby authorized to use a check signing machine equipped with the facsimile signature of each in the signing of city checks. If the machine is not available because of being out of commission, or otherwise, the mayor and the clerk are authorized to personally sign all checks as in the past. 
(Code 1962, § 2-82) 
State Law reference- Authority, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-39-13. 
Sec. 2-136. - General fund created; sources, purposes. 
    There shall be kept a fund to be known as the general fund, to consist of the revenues derived from levy of taxes to be made each and every year on all the taxable property of the city for the purposes of such fund; and to consist also of revenues derived from the levy and collection of the privilege taxes; from the fines and costs and forfeitures in the municipal court; and the revenues from all other sources which are not specially designated and directed to be applied to some special fund for some specific purpose. The expenses of maintaining the streets and street department, the police department and public order, sanitation, fire department, street lighting, salaries of officers except salaries of water department personnel and employees, and all other expenses of city government not otherwise specially provided for, are to be paid out of the general fund. Money may also be paid out of such general fund to supplement any special fund, in the event such should at anytime become necessary, but only when so ordered by the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 2-83) 
Sec. 2-137. - Bond sinking funds required; purpose. 
    A special interest and sinking fund for all general obligation bonds of the city, shall be provided and kept, to consist of revenues derived for the specific purpose of same, and to be kept and used exclusively for the purpose of paying when due, the principal and interest of the bonds. 
(Code 1962, §§ 2-85, 2-86) 
Sec. 2-138. - Interest and sinking fund for street improvement bonds. 
    A special interest and sinking fund for each issue of street improvement bonds of the city shall be provided and kept by the city clerk to consist of all revenues derived from the collection of street improvement assessments. 
(Code 1962, § 2-87) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20. 
Sec. 2-139. - School fund. 
    The city clerk shall keep and maintain a separate and special school fund for the maintenance of the Meridian separate school district, to consist of the revenue received from the state common school fund, the state equalizing school fund, if any, and the amounts received from the separate school district tax levy or levies for maintenance purposes or any other sources. 
(Code 1962, § 2-88) 
Sec. 2-140. - Water and sewer fund. 
    A special fund shall be kept, to be known as a water and sewer fund to consist of revenue derived from the sale of water and other revenue derived in connection with the operation of the water and sewer department. 
(Code 1962, § 2-89) 
Cross reference- Water and sewers generally, Ch. 25. 
Sec. 2-141. - Other funds. 
    In addition to the funds enumerated, the city clerk shall maintain such additional funds as may be now or hereafter required by state law or ordinances or resolutions of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 2-90) 
Sec. 2-142. - Orders allowing payment of accounts and claims to specify fund. 
    In the allowance of accounts and claims against the city, the order of the city council approving and allowing same shall always specify the fund out of which the accounts and claims are respectively to be paid, to whom payable, and the amount of each, whether the order be by ordinance, resolution, or otherwise. Any order approving and directing payment of any account or claim, and not specifying the fund out of which same is to be paid, shall be construed as an order to pay same out of the general fund, and the check therefor must issue accordingly. 
(Code 1962, § 2-91) 
Secs. 2-143-2-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REVIEW PROCEDURE FOR GRANTING SUBSIDIES, CONTRIBUTIONS AND ADVERTISING[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3761, adopted Oct. 21, 1986, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-5 as §§ 2-146-2-150, comprising a new Art. IV, Div. 2, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-146. - Purpose of division. 
    The purpose of this division is to establish procedures to be used by the city for reviewing and granting subsidies, contributions and advertising requested by various individuals, organizations, agencies or groups as authorized by state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 3761, § 1, 10-21-86) 
Sec. 2-147. - Jurisdiction, compliance required. 
(a)  Subsidies, contribution. All subsidies and contributions must be provided for by specific amount in the annual municipal budget or as officially amended. No subsidies or contributions shall be authorized in the municipal budget without compliance with the application procedure, deadlines, review and recommendation provided for herein. 
(b)  Advertising. All advertising, which brings into favorable notice the opportunities, possibilities and resources of the city as authorized under section 17-3-1 of Mississippi Code Annotated 1972, shall comply with the requirements set forth herein. 
(c)  Requests not meeting requirements. Under exceptional circumstances requests not meeting requirements of this division may, after compliance with reasonable review by the city, be approved by the city council. Any such approval shall include a determination of the specific source of funding. 
(Ord. No. 3761, § 2, 10-21-86) 
Sec. 2-148. - Application procedure. 
(a)  Application forms; deadline for submission. All applications for subsidies, contributions and advertising to be included in the budget for the ensuing fiscal year shall be submitted to the city clerk on or before May 1 on official forms including the information outlined herein. 
(b)  Contents. A completed application form shall include the official title of the organization, a list of names and addresses of its officers and board of directors, if any, and be signed under penalty of perjury by its president or, if none, its managing director or other equivalent officer. The application shall further contain the following detailed information covering the most recently completed, present and next following calendar or fiscal years, of the applicant: A detailed description of the purposes, programs and activities of the organization; approximate costs of its programs; numbers of persons served; and sources and amounts of all revenues, including contributions in kind. 
(c)  Accompanying documents. Accompanying the sworn application shall be one (1) copy of the following, with the number of documents required to be based on the dollar value of the request: 
Dollar Value of Request Required Items$1.00 to $500.00 (1) A formal letter directed to the city council and mayor requesting funds and detailing the anticipated uses of the funds. $501.00 to $8,000.00 (1) A formal letter directed to the city council and mayor requesting funds and detailing the anticipated uses of the funds, (2) a current budget, (3) compiled financial statements for the entity's prior fiscal year. $8,001.00 and up (1) A formal letter directed to the city council and mayor requesting funds and detailing the anticipated uses of the funds, (2) a current budget, (3) compiled financial statements for the entity's prior fiscal year, and (4) complete audited financial statements at the end of each fiscal year during which funds are received from the city, at the receiving entity's expense, no later than 90 days after the entity's fiscal year ends, and (5) a copy of most current Federal Internal Revenue Code Exemption application under Section 501(c)(3), if mandated by U.S. Statute.  
    Other documents, verification and information may be required by the city clerk or his designate. 
(d)  Administrative review. After May 1 as the municipal budget process for the upcoming fiscal year continues, the city administration shall review the applications and documents for compliance with this division and the law, inform the applicants in writing of any deficiencies thereof, and receive supplementary statements and documents. All applicants for amounts in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be required to timely appear before a designated officer of the city to submit to oral examination unless waived. Such other applicants as the city may require shall so also appear before such designated officer for complete evaluation of the application. Failure to complete the application, provide accompanying documents, supplement application as directed, or timely appear as required, shall cause the application to be denied. 
(e)  Administrative recommendation. The administration may make recommendations concerning any request for subsidies contributions and advertising to be submitted to the city council based on consideration of type service provided, the public need and benefit, availability of similar government or private services, continued viability of the organization, administrative overhead expenses of applicant and municipal budgetary limitations. 
(Ord. No. 3761, § 3, 10-21-86) 
Sec. 2-149. - Payments. 
    All subsidies, contributions or advertising approved and budgeted herein in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall normally be paid in twelve (12) equal monthly installments, unless the city's budgetary restraints require otherwise. A contribution or subsidy, if so recommended, may be in the form of a purchase for a particular event, celebration, festival, competition or other activity to be conducted by the applicant, or a contribution of equipment or property use with appropriate insurance coverage thereon provided by applicant, in which such cases a contract shall be executed between the city and the applicant for that purpose and payment and use made according to the terms of the contract. All applicants receiving funds shall contract with the city to use funds in the manner approved, and to consent to all requirements, prohibitions and limitations of this division. 
(Ord. No. 3761, § 4, 10-21-86) 
Sec. 2-150. - Periodic review by city. 
(a)  Generally. The applicant approved for subsidy, contribution or advertising may be subject to periodic review by the city, such review consisting of monthly financial statements from the applicant, and reports of salary increases, relocation of officer, lawsuits pending, and criminal or financial investigations of its salaried officers and personnel.
