(b)  Rescission of approval of funds; legal action by city. If, during post-grant review or as the result of any investigation by the city or official report of any other governmental investigation, the city determines it is in its best interest that approval of funds should be rescinded, appropriate legal action may be initiated to recover any funds previously paid to the applicants and all funds appropriated, but not paid, shall be frozen by the city treasurer, until further official order. All applicants receiving contributions or advertising from the city shall pay all reasonable attorney's fees incurred by the city in connection with the collection or recovery of funds paid, including reasonable court costs. 
(Ord. No. 3761, § 5, 10-21-86) 
Secs. 2-151-2-154. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND AUTHORITIES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Airport zoning board, § 4-1; animal control advisory board, § 6-4; mechanical board established, § 7-32; board of adjustments and appeals for mechanical code, § 7-34; electrical examining board established, § 7-112; board of adjustments and appeals for unsafe buildings, § 7-197; street food vendor advisory board, § 14-72; duties of zoning board of appeals to mobile homes, § 15-48; tree commission, § 17-91 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-155. - Standards of attendance for members of city boards, commission and authorities. 
(a)  The tenure of every person appointed to any board, commission or authority of the city by the mayor, or by the city council, or by the mayor with confirmation of the city council, shall be subject to the attendance requirements provided herein. 
(b)  Any member appointed according to law to serve a term on any city board, commission or authority, who is absent from three (3) or more consecutive meetings without first being excused by the chairperson, of the body to which appointed, or who is absent from fifty (50) percent or more of all meetings without first being excused by the chairperson, in any given calendar year, shall be deemed to have vacated such position. Said excuse may be obtained by notifying the chairperson of the body to which appointed three (3) days before a scheduled meeting. 
(c)  The chairman of the body to whom the member was appointed, or the vice chairman, if the chairman is the member who has vacated the position, shall notify the president of the city council in writing immediately following the final absence amounting to vacation of the position. The president of the council shall direct the clerk of the council to send a certified letter to the member who has vacated the position, notifying that the member has vacated the position and further notifying the member of right to a hearing before the city council as provided herein. 
(d)  Any member who has failed to meet the attendance requirements provided for herein may, within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice provided for herein, request the opportunity to appear before the city council to present evidence to explain the member's absence, at which time the city council may, in its discretion, by majority vote, reinstate the member to his or her original position. Upon receipt of such request, the president of the city council shall set a date, during a regularly scheduled meeting of the city council, when the member may be heard, and shall notify the member of the date and time for the hearing. Should the member requesting a hearing not appear at the date and time provided in the notice of hearing, or if the member does not request a hearing within ten (10) days from the date of notice, then the vacation of the position shall be duly noted on the city council's minutes at the meeting scheduled for hearing, or at the next regularly scheduled meeting following notice to the member if no hearing is requested, and the vacant position shall be filled in the manner provided for by law or these ordinances. 
(e)  The terms of this section shall not apply to those certain ad hoc committees or commissions created for a limited purpose or a specified time and whose members are not appointed for a term of years. 
(Ord. No. 3879, §§ 1-4, 8-7-90; Ord. No. 3921, §§ 1, 2, 9-3-91) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3879, adopted Aug. 7, 1990, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-4 as § 2-155 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-156. - Civil service commission relieved of personal liability. 
    Members of the civil service commission appointed pursuant to Mississippi Code 1972, section 21-31-51 et seq. are hereby held harmless and are indemnified by the city from any and all personal liability in connection with or resulting from operations or functions of such commission, including the defense at the expense of the city of any and all suits and actions which may be instituted against such members of the commission, either jointly or severally, officially or personally. It is the intention of this section to cause the city to relieve the members of the civil service commission of all personal liability in connection with the performance of their duties as members of such commission and to hold them harmless as such. 
(Code 1962, § 2-98) 
Cross reference- Civil service commission, § 2-171 et seq. 
Sec. 2-157. - Appointment, term of school trustees. 
    At the first meeting of the city council held in the month of February of each year, the mayor shall select, subject to the approval of the council, a trustee of the Meridian Municipal Separate School District to serve for a term of five (5) years thereafter as provided by sections 37-7-201 through 37-7-207 of the Mississippi Code of 1972 as amended, and the term of office of the member of said board of trustees shall commence on the first Saturday of March following such election. 
(Code 1962, § 2-103) 
Sec. 2-158. - Library trustees-Appointment, terms, vacancies, compensation. 
    The management and control of the public libraries of the city shall be vested in a board of five (5) trustees. Such trustees shall be appointed by the mayor subject to approval by the city council. After the initial appointments, a trustee shall be appointed annually to serve for five (5) years. The vacancies shall be filled for unexpired terms as soon as possible in the same manner in which members of the board were regularly chosen. No trustee shall receive a salary or other compensation for his services. 
(Code 1962, § 2-104) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to maintain, regulate libraries, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-37-19. 
Sec. 2-159. - Same-Residence required. 
    Each member of the board of library trustees shall be a resident citizen of the city or of the area served by the public libraries of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 2-105) 
Sec. 2-160. - Same-Election, certification of officers. 
    The board of trustees shall, immediately after their appointment, meet and organize by the election of such officers as they deem necessary and advisable and shall certify to the city clerk the names and titles of such officers as are elected. 
(Code 1962, § 2-106) 
Sec. 2-161. - Same-Powers, duties. 
    The board of library trustees shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Rules, regulations. Adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their own guidance and for the government of the public libraries of the city as they deem expedient. 
(2)  Custody of library property. Have the supervision, care and custody of all properties of the public libraries of the city, including the buildings and grounds set apart therefor; 
(3)  Employ personnel. Employ a librarian, and upon his recommendation, employ such other assistants and employees as may be necessary, prescribe their duties, fix their compensation and remove them for cause; 
(4)  Budgets. Submit annually to the city council a budget containing estimates for the ensuing year; 
(5)  Library finance. Have exclusive control of the finances of the public libraries of the city; 
(6)  Accept gifts. Accept such gifts of money or property for library purposes as they deem expedient; 
(7)  Purchasing. On recommendation of the librarian, purchase books, periodicals, maps and supplies for the libraries; 
(8)  Contract with governmental agencies. Have authority to enter into contracts and agreements with the county or other governmental agency relative to the furtherance of library purposes; 
(9)  Other. Do all other acts necessary for the orderly and efficient management and control of the public libraries of the city; provided, however, that no expenditure made or contracted by such trustees shall be binding upon the city so as to require payment in excess of funds made available for library purposes. 
(Code 1962, § 2-107; Ord. No. 3704, § 1, 12-19-84) 
Sec. 2-162. - Same-Annual reports to council, state library commission. 
    The board of library trustees shall make a report to the city council at the close of each fiscal year of the city, showing the condition of their trust during the year, the sums of money received for the library fund from taxes and other sources, the sums of money expended and the purpose of the expenditures, the number of books and periodicals on hand, the number added during the year, the number withdrawn, the number loaned out and such other statistics and data and such suggestions as they deem of public interest. A copy of this report shall be filed with the state library commission. 
(Code 1962, § 2-108) 
DIVISION 2. - TRANSPORTATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-163. - Meridian Transportation Commission. 
(a)  Created. There is hereby created a commission to be called "The Meridian Transportation Commission". 
(b)  Compensation, qualifications; selection, terms of members. The commission shall consist of five (5) commissioners who shall possess such qualifications, be selected in such manner and serve for such terms as may be provided by law. 
(c)  Powers and duties. The commission shall have the power, authority and duty to control, manage and operate a motor vehicle transportation system in the city and in such additional territory as may be authorized by law and approved by the city council, and in doing the same it shall have all the powers, authority and duties conferred upon such commissioners by Mississippi Code 1972, section 21-27-13 et seq. 
(d)  Rights, powers, privileges of council. The city council shall have the right to require performance bonds, to fix compensation for the commissioners, and to exercise any and all of the other rights, powers and privileges conferred upon the governing authorities of municipalities by law, and all of such rights, powers and privileges may be exercised from time to time and as often as the city council may determine. 
(Code 1962, § 2-109; Ord. No. 3415, §§ 1-4, 11-7-72) 
DIVISION 3. - ADVISORY PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Parks, recreation and cultural affairs department created, § 2-5. 

Sec. 2-164. - Created. 
    There is hereby created an agency of the city to be called the "Meridian Advisory Parks and Recreation Commission." 
(Ord. No. 3824, § 1, 2-21-89) 
Sec. 2-165. - Composition. 
    The commission shall consist of seven (7) commissioners: one (1) "youth representative," one (1)" senior citizen representative," and one (1) from each ward, to be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. The commissioners who are first appointed shall be designated to serve as follows: one (1) for one (1) year, who shall be below the age of twenty-two (22) and designated the "youth representative"; one (1) for one (1) year, who shall be the age of sixty (60) or older designated the "senior citizen representative"; one (1) for one (1) year; one (1) for two (2) years; one (1) for three (3) years; and two (2) for four (4) years. Thereafter, each commissioner, except the "youth representative" and the "senior citizen representative," shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years, while the term of the "youth representative" and "senior citizen representative" shall be for one (1) year. Vacancies occurring otherwise than by expiration of terms of office shall be filled for the unexpired terms in the same manner as the original appointments. 
(Ord. No. 3824, § 2, 2-21-89) 
Sec. 2-166. - Compensation. 
    The commissioners shall serve without compensation except they shall be reimbursed for authorized expenses incurred in the performance of their advisory functions herein. No member of the commission shall engage financially, either directly or indirectly, in any commercial enterprise connected with the parks, recreation and cultural affairs department (hereinafter "PRCA department") of the city while a member of the commission and for one (1) year thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 3824, § 3, 2-21-89) 
Sec. 2-167. - Duties generally. 
(a)  The commission may, from time to time, consult with the director of the PRCA department concerning the budget of the department. 
(b)  The commission may make recommendations to the director concerning the general affairs and operation of the PRCA department. 
(c)  The commission may advise the director of the PRCA department regarding any property, whether real or personal, that should be obtained, modified, altered, disposed of or replaced through sale, purchase, gift, devise, lease, eminent domain or otherwise as necessary for the safe and efficient operations of the department. 
(d)  The commission may advise the director of the PRCA department concerning any proposed contracts, leases, or other arrangements granting the privilege or privileges of using or improving the department's facilities or any portion thereof or space therein for commercial purposes and conferring the privilege or privileges of supplying goods, commodities, things, services or facilities to the department. 
(e)  The commission may make recommendations to the director of the PRCA department regarding the charges, rentals or fees for the privileges or services, which shall be reasonable and uniform for the same class of privilege or service with due regard to the property and improvements used and the expenses of operation to the city. 
(f)  The commission may confer with the PRCA department director concerning the application of ordinances, resolutions, rules, and orders to the management, governance and use of the parks, fields, buildings and related facilities, all of which shall be in substantial, good faith compliance with the laws and regulations of the state and federal governments. 
(Ord. No. 3824, §§ 4-9, 2-21-89) 
Sec. 2-168. - Employment or termination of employment of department personnel. 
    The commission shall have no power or authority regarding employment or termination of employment of department personnel. 
(Ord. No. 3824, § 10, 2-21-89) 
Sec. 2-169. - Fund-raising activities, events and ceremonies. 
    The commission shall, from time to time, be called upon by the director to participate in fund-raising activities for the programs and improvements of the parks, to review and study and give their recommendations on new programs and shall represent the city in various events and ceremonies. 
(Ord. No. 3824, § 11, 2-21-89) 
Sec. 2-170. - Power to sue or be sued. 
    The commission shall not have the power to sue or be sued. 
(Ord. No. 3824, § 12, 2-21-89) 
DIVISION 4. - CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3903, adopted Jan. 22, 1991, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-3 as Div. 4 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Civil service commission relieved of personal liability, § 2-156. 

Sec. 2-171. - Perpetuated and merged. 
    There is hereby perpetuated and merged a single civil service commission for the City of Meridian. 
(Ord. No. 3903, § 1, 1-22-91) 
Sec. 2-172. - Rules and regulations. 
    The aforesaid council does hereby concur in the passage and utilization by the civil service commission of that certain set of rules and regulations entitled "Civil Service Code" and further so concurs concerning those certain "By-Laws and Standard Operating Procedures," copies of which are attached to Ordinance No. 3903 and incorporated herein by reference as if their contents were set forth herein verbatim. 
(Ord. No. 3903, § 2, 1-22-91) 
Sec. 2-173. - Applicability of provisions. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to all full paid employees of the city and all incumbents and future appointees now and hereafter serving, except however, those appointees now and hereafter serving as part time members, and except any elected officials and others as excluded by Mississippi law applicable to this form of government. 
    For the benefit of the public service and to prevent delay, injury or interruption therein by reason of the enactment of this division, all persons holding a position with the city, except any excluded by law or hereinabove, when this division takes effect, who shall have been previously covered by the civil service programs of the city or who are serving in Meridian employee positions, are hereby declared eligible for permanent appointment under civil service without examination or other act on their part. Every such person is hereby automatically adopted and inducted permanently into civil service, into such office, place, position or employment which such person then holds as completely and effectually to all intents and purposes as if said person had been permanently appointed thereto under civil service after examination and investigation. Provided, however, that those persons who have previously left their positions to participate in the Armed Forces of the United States shall have preference in reemployment and enjoy the rights and privileges of this division as if their service had not been terminated. Provided further that, relative to these employees who have been heretofore employed by Meridian to fill positions which are normally classified as positions covered by civil service but who have not been certified to so fill such positions, such city employee(s) shall be and are included in the induction into the civil service program above stated, unless, by affirmative investigation and due process hearing procedures by the commission, they are determined to be incompetent, guilty of dereliction in the performance of duties or for other good cause for which he or she is solely responsible. 
(Ord. No. 3903, § 3, 1-22-91) 
DIVISION 5. - RAILROAD MUSEUM ADVISORY BOARD[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4346, adopted Mar. 17, 2009, amended the former Div. 5, §§ 2-174-2-179.3, and enacted a new Div. 5 as set out herein. The former Div. 5 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 3930, §§ 1-11, adopted Feb. 18, 1992. 

Sec. 2-174. - Created. 
    There is hereby created an agency of the city to be called the "Meridian Railroad Museum Board". 
(Ord. No. 4346, 3-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-175. - Composition. 
(a)  Appointment of members; terms. The board shall consist of seven (7) members, who shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. Of the seven (7) members, at least four (4) should reside within Lauderdale County. The members who are first appointed shall be designated to serve as follows: one (1) for one (1) year; two (2) for two (2) years; two (2) for three (3) years; and two (2) for (4) years. Thereafter, each member shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years. Vacancies occurring otherwise than by expiration of terms of office shall be filled for the unexpired terms in the same manner as the original appointments. The existing board of directors shall furnish to the mayor a list of proposed board members which shall include no less than four (4) names for the mayor's consideration. 
(b)  Executive director. An executive director shall be elected by the board of directors. For the purposes of continuity, the first executive director shall be Matthew S. Nussbaum. The executive director shall serve at the will of the board. The executive director shall be a voting member of the board. The executive director shall devote his time to the work of the museum, using his endeavor to develop and build it up, so as to carry out the design of its creation and the wishes of the board. The executive director shall make the annual report to the mayor and the city council. 
(Ord. No. 4346, 3-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-176. - Compensation; conflict. 
    Members of the board shall serve without compensation; however, they shall be reimbursed for authorized expenses incurred in the performance of their duties as provided herein. No member of the board shall engage financially, either directly or indirectly, in any commercial enterprise connected with the parks and recreation department (hereinafter P&R Dept.) of the city while a member of said board, and for a period of one (1) year thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 4346, 3-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-177. - Organization; office. 
    The board shall, at its first organizational meeting, elect officers and adopt bylaws for its operation. Officers shall include, but not be limited to, president and vice president. The director of the city's P&R Dept., or his designee, shall serve as the board's secretary, and shall be responsible for maintaining minutes and distributing all notices to board members. 
(Ord. No. 4346, 3-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-178. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the board is to develop, improve, and promote the Meridian Railroad Museum. 
(Ord. No. 4346, 3-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-179. - Powers, duties, authority. 
    The duties of the board shall include all responsibilities necessary to carry out the purpose of the board as set forth in section 2-178, which duties shall include, but not limited to: 
(1)  Review and recommend short and long range planning for the museum; 
(2)  Review and recommend development of programs and services for the museum; 
(3)  Make recommendations concerning the general operation of the museum including the policies and procedures; 
(5)  Establish a group of volunteers to act as curators, office workers, docents, custodians and maintenance workers in connection with operation of the museum, and to accept and solicit contributions, donations and funds for benefit of the museum; and 
(5)  To perform such additional duties as identified by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 4346, 3-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-179.1. - Fund. 
    All funds raised, solicited or generated by the board from any source for benefit of the Meridian Railroad Museum shall be turned over to the P&R Dept. for deposit into a separate fund maintained by the city for the sole and exclusive use and benefit of the Meridian Railroad Museum. 
(Ord. No. 4346, 3-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-179.2. - Inventory. 
    The board shall maintain an accurate inventory showing each and every item donated or loaned to it, the location of each item, the donor or lender, date of the loan or donation, and any other pertinent information. All property of every kind and nature donated to the museum shall be the property of the city, subject to the statutes and laws of the State of Mississippi, and such property shall be kept by the city for the benefit of the Meridian Railroad Museum. 
(Ord. No. 4346, 3-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-179.3. - Record of meetings; annual report. 
    The board shall maintain an accurate and complete record of its meetings. The board shall prepare and complete a written report at the close of each fiscal year detailing operations of the board and the Meridian Railroad Museum, and displaying its inventory. The report shall be presented to the mayor and city council by the executive director. 
(Ord. No. 4346, 3-17-2009) 
DIVISION 6. - MERIDIAN HISTORICAL PRESERVATION COMMISSION PROCEDURES AND GUIDELINES FOR EXEMPTION FROM MUNICIPAL AD VALOREM TAX FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROJECTS 

Sec. 2-180. - Program overview. 
    The historic preservation tax exemption program is designed to promote revitalization of historic properties within the City of Meridian pursuant to section 17-21-5, Mississippi Code of 1972. The intent is to allow certain limited exemption from municipal ad valorem taxes on privately owned new structures and new renovations of and improvements to existing structures lying within a designated central business district, historic preservation district or on a historic landmark site, as determined by the Meridian Historical Preservation Commission and/or Meridian City Council, but only in the event such structures shall have been constructed, renovated or improved pursuant to the requirements of a project approved by the Meridian Historical Preservation Commission. 
(Ord. No. 4246, § 1, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 2-180.1. - Schedule of exemptions. 
    The tax exemption applies to all or any portion of the incremental increase in municipal ad valorem taxes resulting from construction or renovation, excluding ad valorem taxes for school district purposes, for a period of not more than seven (7) years for new structures that total one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or more in eligible project cost and fully renovated existing structures that total sixty thousand ($60,000.00) or more in eligible project cost and not more than four (4) years for improvements to exterior only or to interior only that total thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000.00) or more in eligible project cost. The land value and the prior value of the existing structure to which renovations are made is not exempt. Any structure granted this exemption shall not be eligible for additional exemption for a period of twenty (20) years beginning on the date of city council approval. 
(Ord. No. 4246, § 1, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 2-180.2. - Description of eligible improvement. 
    New construction. For the purposes of this program new construction shall mean the creation of an entire building or structure on a site on which no structure exists at the time of application. This term shall include the primary structure and all related construction such as accessory structures, parking facilities, utilities, landscaping and pedestrian amenities. It shall not include demolition or removal of material from the site in preparation for construction, or land value prior to construction. 
    Renovation. For the purposes of this program renovation shall mean repair, upgrade, or improvement to an existing structure the result of which is to: improve its appearance, prolong its usability, or achieve compliance with current standards and regulations. It shall not include demolition or the value of land and structures before renovation. 
    Fully renovated. For the purposes of this program fully renovated shall mean the complete upgrade of all critical building systems [CBS] including structural, plumbing, electrical, and mechanical needed to prolong the usefulness of a structure in addition to needed interior and exterior surface refinishing. All CBS and interior/exterior surfaces in need of improvement must be renovated to qualify the project as being "fully renovated." It shall not mean surface treatments only such as repainting, refinishing or remodeling of fixtures except as same is concurrent with CBS improvements. It shall not include demolition or the value of land and structures before renovation. 
    Exemption. The amount of any exemption resulting from this program is the difference between the before improvements taxes and the after improvements taxes as determined by the Lauderdale County Tax Assessor. Post improvement reappraisal and building permit values are some of the methods used for this assessment. The city only has the authority to approve an incremental exemption and the duration of same. It has no control over the value resulting therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 4246, § 1, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 2-180.3. - Eligible properties. 
    The following areas are eligible: properties within the Urban, Union Station, Mid-Town, Highlands, West End, East End, Merrehope and Poplar Springs Historic Districts, and Central Business District and individually listed historic sites listed on file in the City of Meridian Community Development Department or with Mississippi Department of Archives and History. 
(Ord. No. 4246, § 1, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 2-180.4. - Procedural guidelines. 
(a)  The applicant meets with the City of Meridian Community Development staff and receives application for tax exemption. 
(b)  Application, construction and/or renovation plans and a pro forma on the current and future taxes of the project are submitted to community development staff with nonrefundable fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per application. The fee will go to the Meridian Historic Preservation Commission account for MHPC projects. 
(c)  After adequate information has been received, the community development staff submits the application and plans to the Meridian Historic Preservation Commission. 
(d)  After historic preservation commission approval and completion of the approved work, the applicant must submit information in the form of invoices, receipts or bills to the community development department sufficient to verify that the required limit has been achieved. 
(e)  The application is submitted to the Meridian Historical Preservation Commission. 
(f)  After this meeting the applicant is notified in writing of the recommendation by the Meridian Historical Preservation Commission and the application is then submitted to the city council for approval or disapproval. The council shall have up to thirty (30) days to approve or disapprove an application. The city council will have the right to request additional information concerning the improvement project, but the thirty-day deadline shall apply unless the information furnished was inadequate to base a decision on. (The tax exemption does not go into effect until the project is completed and the exemption is terminated if the property ownership changes except as otherwise approved by the city council). 
(g)  If approved by city council, the community development department shall forward a copy of the order, the application showing estimated exemption per year, and applicable building permit information to the Tax Assessor Collector of Lauderdale County. 
(Ord. No. 4246, § 1, 5-4-2004; Ord. No. 4347, § 1, 4-7-2009) 
ARTICLE VI. - MUNICIPAL COURT[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-23-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-181. - Qualifications of judge. 
    The municipal judge shall be licensed to practice law in this state and shall also be a qualified elector of the county. 
(Code 1962, § 2-114) 
Sec. 2-182. - Powers and duties of judge. 
(a)  The municipal judge shall have the jurisdiction to hear and determine, without a jury and without a record of the testimony, all violations of the municipal ordinances and state misdemeanor laws made offenses against the municipality and to punish offenders therefor as may be prescribed by law. He may sit as a committing court in all felonies committed within the municipality, and he shall have the power to bind over the accused to the grand jury or to appear before the proper court having jurisdiction to try the same, and to refuse bail and commit the accused to jail in cases not bailable. The municipal judge is a conservator of the peace within the city and may conduct preliminary hearings in all violations of the criminal laws of this state occurring within the city, and any person arrested for a violation of law within the city may be brought before him for initial appearance. 
(b)  In the discretion of the court, where the objects of justice would be more likely met, as an alternative to imposition of fine and/or incarceration, the municipal judge shall have the power to sentence convicted offenders to work on a public service project where the court has established such a program of public service by written guidelines, filed with the clerk for public record. Such programs shall provide for reasonable supervision of the offender and the work shall be commensurate with the fine and/or incarceration that would have ordinarily been imposed. 
(c)  The municipal judge may solemnize marriages, take oaths, affidavits and acknowledgments, and issue orders, subpoenas, summonses, citations, warrants for arrest and other such process under seal of the court to any county or municipality, in a criminal case, to be executed by the lawful authority of the county or the municipality of the respondent, and enforce obedience thereto. The absence of a seal shall not invalidate the process. 
(d)  When a person shall be charged with an offense in municipal court punishable by confinement, the municipal judge, being satisfied that such person is an indigent person and is unable to employ counsel, may, in the discretion of the court, appoint counsel from the membership of the Mississippi State Bar residing in his county who shall represent him. Compensation for appointed counsel in criminal cases shall be approved and allowed by the municipal judge and shall be paid by the city. The maximum compensation shall not exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for any one (1) case. The mayor, subject to the approval of the council, may, in his discretion, appoint a public defender(s) who must be a licensed attorney, and who shall receive a salary to be fixed by the city council. 
(e)  The municipal judge is hereby authorized to suspend the sentence, and to suspend the execution of the sentence, or any part thereof, on such terms as may be imposed by the municipal judge. However, the suspension of imposition or execution of a sentence hereunder may not be revoked after a period of two (2) years. 
(f)  Upon prior notice to the city prosecuting attorney and upon a showing in open court of rehabilitation, good conduct for a period of two (2) years since the last conviction in any court and that the best interest of society would be served, the court, may, in its discretion, order the record of conviction of a person of any or all misdemeanors in that court expunged, and upon so doing such person thereafter legally stands as though he had never been convicted of such misdemeanor(s) and may lawfully so respond to any query of prior convictions. This order of expungment does not apply to the confidential records of law enforcement agencies and has no effect on the driving record of a person maintained under Title 63, Mississippi Code of 1972, or any other provision of such Title 63. 
(g)  In the discretion of the court, a plea of nolo contendre may be entered to any charge in municipal court. Upon the entry of a plea of nolo contendre the court shall convict the defendant of the offense charged and shall proceed to sentence the defendant according to law. The judgment of the court shall reflect that the conviction was on a plea of nolo contendre. An appeal may be made from a conviction on a plea of nolo contendre as in other cases. 
(h)  The municipal court shall have the power to make rules for the administration of the court's business, which rules, if any, shall be in writing filed with the clerk of the court. 
(Code 1962, § 2-115) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-23-7. 
Sec. 2-183. - Municipal judge pro tempore. 
    The mayor, subject to the approval of the city council, shall have the power and authority to appoint a municipal judge pro tempore, who shall have the same powers and qualifications for office as the municipal judge and shall perform all duties of the municipal judge in the absence of such municipal judge. In the event a municipal judge pro tempore is not appointed or is absent or unable for any reason to serve, any justice court judge of the county or municipal judge of another municipality may serve in his place with the same power and authority upon designation by the municipal judge. 
(Code 1962, § 2-116) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-23-9. 
Sec. 2-184. - Time, place court held. 
    The municipal court of the city, presided over by the municipal judge, shall be held in such building as designated by the city council from time to time, on Mondays and Thursdays, except legal holidays, if the business requires it. 
(Code 1962, § 2-117) 
Sec. 2-185. - Presence of police required during sessions. 
    The chief of police or at least one (1) policeman detailed for the purpose, shall be present every day throughout each session of the municipal court to preserve order and to execute the orders of the court. Whenever the municipal judge shall require it, the chief of police and such number of policemen as the municipal judge may deem necessary shall be present for the above purposes. 
(Code 1962, § 2-118) 
Cross reference- Police generally, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 2-186. - Trial docket required. 
    There shall be a trial docket kept by the clerk of the court on which shall be entered the true name of every person brought before him for the trial, the date of docketing, the offense with which each person is charged, the name of the person by whom the affidavit is made alleging the offense, the name of the policeman making the arrest, the names of the counsel appearing in the case, the names of all witnesses, and such other entries may be made as may be proper and convenient. After the case is disposed of, the municipal judge must enter on the docket his formal judgment at the proper place provided for same, and sign his name thereto. The cases on the trial docket shall be numbered consecutively and each case shall be properly numbered. 
(Code 1962, § 2-119) 
Sec. 2-187. - Procedure upon arrest. 
    When any person is arrested, with or without a warrant, for a violation of any of the laws of the state under the grade of felonies and ordinances, such person shall be admitted to bond and his case disposed of in accordance Mississippi Code 1972, sections 21-23-8, 21-23-17 and 21-23-19. 
(Code 1962, § 2-120) 
Sec. 2-188. - Rules of evidence, examination of witnesses. 
    The rules of evidence and the examination of witnesses in a trial in the municipal court shall be the same as that in state courts. 
(Code 1962, § 2-123) 
Sec. 2-189. - Right of accused to know charge, plead, have counsel, fair trail. 
(a)  Every person charged with an offense, before being put upon trial, shall be informed by affidavit in writing, made by some responsible person, of the nature and cause of the accusation, which, on arraignment, shall be read to the accused in open court, and opportunity given for the entering of such plea thereto as he may voluntarily wish or elect to do. 
(b)  Every person accused shall have the privilege of defending himself, by counsel or by himself, or both, as to him may seem proper; and no one shall be fined or punished without opportunity of being heard in his defense. 
(c)  On a plea of "not guilty" being entered, the court shall proceed with the trial of the cause, unless for reasons the cause be continued as provided in section 2-190. On the trial the accused shall be confronted by the witnesses against him and shall have the privilege of cross-examination, and shall have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his own behalf before and during the progress of the trial. 
(Code 1962, § 2-124) 
Sec. 2-190. - Continuances authorized. 
    The city shall announce first, if it is ready for trial. All applications for continuances shall be addressed to the sound discretion of the court; and where the ends of justice appear to require it, cases may be continued. 
(Code 1962, § 2-125) 
Sec. 2-191. - Determination of sentence. 
    If, after hearing the evidence, on a plea of not guilty, it is determined by the court that the defendant is guilty as charged, or if the defendant on arraignment enters a plea of guilty, the municipal judge shall impose such penalty, authorized by law, as in his discretion, may seem right and just under the circumstances. 
(Code 1962, § 2-126) 
Sec. 2-192. - Authority to dismiss petty offenders. 
    In prosecution for petty offenses, the municipal judge, if, in his discretion, the ends of justice will be conserved thereby, may, on motion, dismiss the proceedings and discharge the defendant, upon the payment of all or such part of the costs as the municipal judge, in his discretion, may require; provided, the party injured, if there be such party interested, shall acknowledge to have received satisfaction. 
(Code 1962, § 2-127) 
Sec. 2-193. - Authority to require peace bond. 
    In all cases where there is reason to apprehend any person for a breach of the peace, or violation of any ordinance, or where any person is convicted of any violation of any ordinance, the municipal judge may require bond, with good security, in such an amount as he may deem reasonable, that such person shall be of good behavior for a term not exceeding twelve (12) months. If the person shall neglect or refuse to give such bond, he shall be punished as the municipal judge may require, not to exceed the limits of section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 2-128) 
Sec. 2-194. - Disposition of funds collected by court. 
    All fines and costs and penalties for violations of law in cases tried in the municipal court, and all forfeitures on bonds and recognizances in such court, shall be for the use and benefit of the city, and when collected shall be immediately deposited in an official city depository after receiving a receipt warrant from the city clerk. The city treasurer shall place such moneys to the credit of the general fund. 
(Code 1962, § 2-130) 
Sec. 2-195. - Court costs. 
(a)  Court costs in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) are hereby imposed upon each person convicted in the municipal court upon a charge brought by sworn affidavit, where an arrest warrant is served upon such person by a police officer of the city. 
(b)  Court costs in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) are hereby imposed upon a person who, after citation or warrant is served upon him by a police officer of the city, is adjudged by the municipal court to be conducting or maintaining a nuisance and is ordered to abate the same. 
(c)  Court costs of ten dollars ($10.00) are hereby imposed upon each person found guilty of contempt of the municipal court, after issuance and service of a citation for contempt by a police officer of the city. 
(d)  Court costs of ten dollars ($10.00) are hereby imposed upon the convicted defendant or other nonprevailing respondent in municipal court for each witness subpoena that is issued by the court and served by a police officer of the city. 
(e)  Where an arrest warrant is issued for nonpayment of parking tickets and is served by a police officer of the city, the person named shall pay court costs in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(f)  Where any warrants or orders, not specified above, issue out of the municipal court and are served upon a person named as a defendant or other respondent therein and are served upon such person by a police officer of the city, there is hereby imposed against the party named in the action, if judgment be entered against him, court costs in the sum of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(g)  Where multiple warrants, citations or orders commanding a person to appear and defend or otherwise respond to a matter in municipal court are served upon an individual on a single occasion, only one (1) ten-dollar ($10.00) sum shall be imposed as court costs, for those services. 
(h)  No court costs herein shall be imposed or assessed against the city or any of its departments, divisions, commissions, boards, bureaus or authorities or any authorized agent acting on behalf of the same. 
(i)  When a warrant, citation or order is issued at the request of a private citizen and the complaining citizen subsequently requests dismissal of the warrant, then court costs in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be assessed against the complaining citizen. 
(j)  Warrants, citations or orders imposed upon the request of private citizens, which are not served by the police officer, after reasonable efforts for a period of thirty (30) days, may be dismissed by the municipal court upon the request of the police department. The complaining citizen shall be informed of this provision upon seeking a warrant, citation or order. 
(Ord. No. 3764, §§ 1-8, 12-2-86; Ord. No. 3769, §§ 1, 2, 3-10-87) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3764, adopted Dec. 2, 1986, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-8 as § 2-195 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Chapter 3 - ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Advertising light wine and beer near churches and schools, § 5-5; signs, § 7-241 et seq.; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 14; street food vendors distributing handbills, § 14-176(b); obstructing sidewalks with advertising, § 20-22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated in this section: 
    Advertising matter: Any written or printed card, poster, circular, coupon, pamphlet or folder intended for general distribution, except newspapers. 
    Sample: Any package or parcel of merchandise intended for general distribution, for which no charge is made. 
(Code 1962, § 3-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 3-2. - Distribution of advertising matter, samples. 
    No person shall throw, scatter or distribute, or cause to be thrown, scattered or distributed, any advertising matter or sample of merchandise upon any sidewalk, street, lane, alley, public ground or other public place or upon any private lot or porch within the corporate limits of the city; provided that, it shall not be unlawful to distribute advertising matter or samples to private residences, offices or mercantile establishments if the same are handed in at the door or securely fastened to prevent the same from being blown or scattered about. 
(Code 1962, § 3-2) 
Sec. 3-3. - Advertisements prohibited on public property, improvements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, paint, place or fasten in any manner any advertising or advertising matter onto any public sidewalk, curb or pavement, or onto any public buildings or other public improvement within the city. 
(Code 1962, § 3-3) 
Sec. 3-4. - Advertisements prohibited on trees, poles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to post, paste or in any way attach or affix any bill, notice, announcement or advertising matter to any tree located in any alley, street or other public place in the city, or upon or to any pole used for telegraph, telephone, electric light or any other purpose as authorized by the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 3-4) 
Secs. 3-5-3-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EYEGLASSES' ADVERTISING AND DISPLAYS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 12. 

Sec. 3-16. - Specific advertising prohibitions. 
    No person or any agent or employee thereof, engaged in or connected with the sale of ophthalmic lenses, eyeglasses or eyeglass frames and mountings, shall include in any advertisement by newspaper, radio, television, display or otherwise any statement which in any manner misrepresents any such lenses, eyeglasses, frames, mountings or other material, or services and credit terms with reference thereto. 
(Code 1962, § 3-22; Ord. No. 3448, § 1, 9-19-73) 
Sec. 3-17. - Exception to article's provisions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any television or radio broadcasting station or to any publisher or printer of a newspaper, magazine or other form of printed advertising which broadcasts, publishes or prints such advertisements in good faith, without knowledge of its misrepresentative character. 
(Code 1962, § 3-24; Ord. No. 3448, § 4, 9-19-73) 
Sec. 3-18. - Penalty; violations. 
    Any person or any agent or employee thereof, violating any provision of this article may upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code; and each such advertisement by newspaper, radio, television or otherwise, or each day such display may remain open to view in violation of this article, shall constitute a separate offense. Where any such offense shall be committed by a corporation, the charge shall be lodged against, and upon conviction the penalty shall be imposed upon, any resident officer or managing agent of such corporation. 
(Code 1962, § 3-25; Ord. No. 3448, § 3, 9-19-73) 
Chapter 4 - AIRPORT AND AIRCRAFT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal Airport Law, Miss. Code 1972, § 61-5-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Airport zoning board. 
(a)  Established; membership; chairman. There is hereby created a joint airport zoning board consisting of seven (7) members, two (2) of whom shall be appointed by the mayor of the city and confirmed by the city council of the city, from among the qualified electors of the city, two (2) of whom shall be appointed by majority vote of the Board of Supervisors of Lauderdale County, Mississippi, from among such qualified electors of Lauderdale County, Mississippi, as the Board of Supervisors of Lauderdale County, Mississippi, shall designate, two (2) of which shall be appointed by majority vote of the Meridian Airport Authority from among the qualified electors of the city or Lauderdale County, Mississippi, as they shall designate, and one (1) of whom shall be elected by a majority of the six (6) members appointed by the city, the Board of Supervisors of Lauderdale County, Mississippi, and the Meridian Airport Authority. Said member elected by the said six (6) appointed members of said board shall serve as the chairman of said board. 
(b)  Terms of members. The term of office of the two (2) members appointed by the mayor of the city and confirmed by the city council of the city shall be four (4) years from the date of their respective appointments. The term of office of the two (2) members appointed by the Board of Supervisors of Lauderdale County, Mississippi, shall likewise be four (4) years from the date of their respective appointments. The term of office of the two (2) members appointed by the Meridian Airport Authority shall be such term as is prescribed by the Meridian Airport Authority. The term of office of the chairman of said board shall be four (4) years from the date of his or her election by the board as heretofore provided. 
(c)  Powers, duties. The powers and duties of said joint airport zoning board shall be those powers and duties set out and enumerated in sections 61-7-1 through 61-7-29, Mississippi Code Annotated, 1972, as amended from time to time. 
(Code 1962, § 4-1; Ord. No. 4168, §§ 1-3, 9-19-2000) 
Cross reference- City boards and commissions generally, § 2-156 et seq. 
Secs. 4-2-4-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4452, § 1, adopted Feb. 3, 2015, repealed §§ 4-2-4-6, which pertained to airport manager. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 4-7. - City ordinances to apply to airport. 
    All offenses against the city, as declared by the laws and ordinances thereof, except any such ordinances which are inconsistent with or contrary to the airport authorities law or regulations promulgated by the Federal Aviation Administration shall apply to the entire area of Key Field and other property owned by the Meridian Airport Authority, and any person violating any such ordinance on the airport or on other property owned by the Meridian Airport Authority, shall on conviction be punished as if such violation had occurred within the corporate limits. 
(Code 1962, § 4-9; Ord. No. 4452, § 3, 2-3-2015) 
Secs. 4-8, 4-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4452, § 1, adopted Feb. 3, 2015, repealed §§ 4-8 and 4-9, which pertained to rubbish and parking and operating of vehicles for hire at airports. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
Secs. 4-10-4-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4452, § 1, adopted Feb. 3, 2015, repealed Art. II, §§ 4-26-4-31, which pertained to operation of aircraft. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
Chapter 5 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 12; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 14; street food vendors not to sell, keep, use alcoholic beverages, § 14-176(c); offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 16, police, Ch. 18. 
State Law reference- General provisions relating to intoxicants, Miss. Code 1972, Title 67; sale of alcoholic beverages generally, § 67-1-3 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Alcoholic beverages shall include liquor, beer, wine, and all other beverages containing alcohol, and any one (1) or more of such products. 
    Business means any building or premises or place of business owned or operated by any person, firm, partnership, corporation or public or private club wherein any alcoholic beverage is sold or offered for sale at any time; provided, however, the term "business" shall not include any grocery or convenience store which is primarily engaged in the sale of a variety of grocery and convenience items and which sells only packaged beer for consumption off its premises; and the said term also shall not include any restaurant which might, during other portions of the day, serve alcoholic beverages, provided that between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on each day no alcoholic beverage is present in such restaurant. 
    Restaurant means a place which is regularly and in a bona fide manner used and kept open for the serving of meals to guests for compensation, which has suitable seating facilities for guests, and which has suitable kitchen facilities connected therewith for cooking an assortment of foods and meals commonly ordered at various hours of the day; the service of such food as sandwiches and salads only shall not be deemed in compliance with this requirement. No place shall qualify as a restaurant under this chapter unless fifty (50) percent or more of the revenue derived from such place shall be from the preparation, cooking and serving of meals and not from the sale of beverages. 
(Code 1962, § 5-3(a); Ord. No. 3657, § 1, 2-1-83) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 5-2. - Light wine and beer-Privilege tax for retailers. 
    There is hereby imposed on each person engaged in the business of retailing of light wine or beer, a tax of fifteen dollars ($15.00); provided that, any person engaged in such business as a retailer shall be required to pay such tax for each place of business operated by the retailer. 
(Code 1962, § 16-4) 
Cross reference- Taxation generally, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- State tax on dealers in light wine and beer, Miss. Code 1972, § 27-71-303; authority of municipalities to impose tax, § 27-71-345. 
Sec. 5-3. - Same-Privilege tax for wholesalers. 
    There is hereby levied a privilege tax on all persons engaged as wholesalers or distributors of light wines or beer in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00); provided, that this shall only apply where the warehouse or plant of such wholesale distributor is located in the city. 
(Code 1962, § 16-5) 
Cross reference- Taxation generally, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- State tax, Miss. Code 1972, § 27-71-303(b). 
Sec. 5-4. - Sale of alcoholic beverages near churches and schools, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to sell or store intoxicating beverages (including light wines or beer) within four hundred (400) feet of any church, school, kindergarten or funeral home, except within an area zoned commercial, business or industrial or an area bearing like designations, such minimum distance shall be not less than one hundred (100) feet. Such distances shall be measured along a straight line between the nearest points of the building in which such intoxicating beverages are sold or stored and the building housing such church, school, kindergarten or funeral home. 
(b)  This section shall not be retroactive and shall not affect the sale of light wine or beer at any location at which light wine or beer was being sold on October 6, 1959. 
(Code 1962, § 5-1; Ord. No. 3282, 8-23-66) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to prohibit sales of beer or wine near churches or schools, Miss. Code 1972, § 67-3-65. 
Sec. 5-5. - Advertising light wine, beer near churches and schools, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any sign or signs, advertising the sale of light wines or beer within the city to be posted within four hundred (400) feet of any church, school, kindergarten or funeral home located within the city limits except that such signs may be posted within one hundred (100) feet of a church, school, kindergarten or funeral home in any area within the city zoned commercial, business, industrial or an area bearing like designations; such distances shall be measured along a straight line between the nearest points of any such sign and the building housing such church, school, kindergarten or funeral home. 
(Code 1962, § 5-2; Ord. No. 3282, 8-23-66) 
Cross reference- Advertising generally, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 5-6. - Hours of sale restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any business which sells or offers for sale any alcoholic beverage in the city to be or remain open at any time between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on any day. 
(b)  Any person, firm partnership, corporation or public or private club who or which causes or participates in the opening or remaining open of any business which sells or offers for sale any alcoholic beverage in the city or who is present in such business either as owner, employee or customer between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., or who otherwise violates any of the provisions of this section, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the penalty in section 1-9 of the Code of Ordinances by the city. 
(Code 1962, § 5-3; Ord. No. 3657, §§ 1-3, 2-1-83; Ord. No. 4389, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
State Law reference- Authority to establish opening and closing hours, Miss. Code 1972, § 67-3-65. 
Sec. 5-7. - Consumption of alcoholic beverages on public streets and ways. 
    It shall be unlawful within the corporate limits of the city for any person to consume alcoholic beverages (including light wines or beer) on any street, sidewalk, alley, public way, or on other public property; provided, however, that this section does not apply to public sidewalks adjacent to a class A restaurant, as defined by the city's zoning ordinance, possessing a valid license or permit to sell such alcoholic beverages (including light wines or beer), nor does it apply at or during an event sponsored, in whole or in part, by the city and/or Lauderdale County, Mississippi, or at any other event held on any street, sidewalk, alley, public way, or on other public property, if the city, prior thereto, acting through its mayor, who is hereby given the authority to do so, has consented in writing that such other event may be so held, as it is lawful, at any of the events referred to herein, to consume, but not to become intoxicated therefrom, alcoholic beverages (including light wines or beer); and it is also lawful at these events for any person, provided such person has a valid license or permit, to sell at and during the events referred to herein alcoholic beverages (including "light wines or beer"). 
(Code 1962, § 5-5; Ord. No. 3282, 8-23-66; Ord. No. 4080, 7-22-97; Ord. No. 4157, 3-21-2000; Ord. No. 4439, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks generally, Ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Intoxication as an offense, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-29-47. 
Sec. 5-8. - Minors prohibited from establishments serving alcoholic beverages; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to enter knowingly any place of business where alcoholic beverages (including but not limited to light wines and beer) are served for consumption on the premises or to remain at any such place after the character thereof has been discovered; provided, however, that, the provisions of this section shall not apply to any restaurant as that term is defined in this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person who owns, operates or is in charge of any place of business where alcoholic beverages (including but not limited to light wines and beer) are served for consumption on the premises to permit any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to enter or to remain in such place of business; provided, however, that, the provisions of this section shall not apply to any restaurant as that term is defined in this chapter. 
(Code 1962, § 5-6(a),(b); Ord. No. 3468, §§ 1, 2, 8-26-74) 
Sec. 5-8.1. - Persons under the age of eighteen years of age on the premises of certain businesses where alcoholic beverages may be consumed and for related purposes prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed herein unless the context shall otherwise require: 
    Alcoholic beverages shall mean and include all substances which are the subject of and are regulated by Chapters 1, 3 and 5, Title 67, Mississippi Code of 1972. 
    Business shall mean and include any commercial establishment: 
(1)  Which is other than a religious society or ecclesiastical body, a charitable society, a historical or patriotic association or society, a garden or pilgrimage club or association or a fraternal or benevolent organization eligible to have its property exempt from an ad valorem taxation under the provisions of Section 27-31-1, Mississippi Code of 1972; 
(2)  Where alcoholic beverages are permitted to be consumed on the premises and upon which premises alcoholic beverages are consumed; and 
(3)  Which is required to obtain a permit from the City of Meridian in order to lawfully operate within the City of Meridian, but which is not required to obtain a permit from the State of Mississippi under the provisions of Chapters 1, 3 or 5, Title 67, Mississippi Code of 1972, to lawfully operate within the City of Meridian. 
    Minor shall mean and include any person who has not attained the age of eighteen (18) years. 
    Owner shall mean, jointly and singular, any individual, individuals or legal entity, including, but not limited to, sole proprietorship, partnership, association, corporation, joint venture or cooperative, who or which owns a business. 
(b)  Prohibited. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or owners of any business and also the agents, employees and representatives thereof to permit or allow any minor to enter or remain upon the premises of the business during those hours when the business allows the consumption of alcoholic beverages on or within its premises. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for a minor to enter or remain upon the premises of the business during those hours when the business allows the consumption of alcoholic beverages on or within its premises. 
(c)  Penalties. 
(1)  Any owner or agent, employee or representative thereof, who shall violate any provision of this section, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000) or by a term in the city jail not to exceed thirty (30) days or by any combination thereof. In addition to imposing such punishment upon the owner or agent, employee or representative, the permit to operate issued by the City of Meridian to the business may also be suspended or revoked. The partners, officers, directors and shareholders of any legal entity which is the owner of any business may be charged as individuals with a violation of this ordinance and tried as individuals therefor, and, upon conviction thereof, may be punished as provided in this section. Each violation of this ordinance shall be considered a separate violation. 
(2)  Any minor who shall violate any provision of this ordinance shall be subject to Title 43, Chapter 21, Mississippi Code of 1972 and may be punished as provided therein. 
(Ord. No. 3943, §§ 1-3, 10-6-92) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3943, as adopted Oct. 6, 1972, did not specifically amend this Code, hence, inclusion of §§ 1-3 as § 5-8.1 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 5-9. - Sale of alcoholic beverages to persons under the age of twenty-one prohibited; sale of beer and wine restricted; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, furnish, dispose of, give or cause to be sold, furnished, disposed of or given, any alcoholic beverage to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years, except as permitted in section 67-3-54 of the Mississippi Code 1972. As used in this section, the words "alcoholic beverage" mean any alcoholic liquid capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished by a fine not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00) or by imprisonment in the city jail for a term not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1962, § 5-7; Ord. No. 3495, §§ 1-3, 10-13-75) 
Sec. 5-10. - Possession or consumption by persons under twenty-one prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under twenty-one (21) years of age to possess or consume beer or any other alcoholic beverage. 
(b)  Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the penalty described in section 1-9 of the Code of Ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 5-8; Ord. No. 3650, §§ 1, 2, 11-2-82) 
Secs. 5-11-5-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SEXUALLY ORIENTED ACTIVITIES IN ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE ESTABLISHMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4057, §§ 1-8, adopted Aug. 6, 1996, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion of its provisions as a new Ch. 5, Art. II, §§ 5-51-5-58, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 5-51. - Findings of fact. 
(a)  Commercial establishments exist, or may exist, within the city where books, magazines, periodicals, or other printed materials, or photographs, films, motion pictures, prints, video tapes, slides or other visual representations or recordings, or other audio matters, or instruments, novelties, devices or paraphernalia which depict, illustrate, describe or relate to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas are possessed, displayed, exhibited, distributed, and/or sold. 
(b)  Commercial establishments exist, or may exist within the city where dancers, entertainers, performers, or other individuals, who, for commercial gain, model, perform, demonstrate or are presented while displaying or exposing specified anatomical areas, or engaging in straddle dancing or erotic touching with customers. 
(c)  The sexually oriented activities referred to in (a) and (b) above often occur in establishments concurrent with the sale and/or consumption of alcoholic beverages, which tend to further increase criminal activity, disrupt the peace and order of the community, affect the quality of life in the community, result in the moral degradation of the community; and the exploitation of such sexually oriented activities induces persons to purchase and consume alcoholic beverages, and in some cases intolerable amounts thereof. 
(d)  In order to preserve and safeguard the health, safety, property values, community moral standards, and the general welfare of the people, businesses and industries of the city, it is advisable for the city to regulate the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages at establishments where the activities referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) of this section occur. 
(e)  The State of Mississippi has absolute power under the Twenty-First Amendment to prohibit the sale of alcoholic beverages within its borders; and the Mississippi Legislature has delegated to the Mississippi State Tax Commission the authority to promulgate rules and regulations regarding the sale of alcoholic beverages, and the Commission prohibits the sale of alcoholic beverages where the sexually oriented activities referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) above occur; and the city has legislative authority under Section 67-3-65, Mississippi Code of 1972 Annotated and under its inherent police powers to prohibit the sale of light wine and beer in commercial establishments where the sexually oriented activities described in (a) and (b) above occur for the purpose of promoting public health, morals and safety. 
(f)  The state's and city's power to regulate the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages, light wine and beer in commercial establishments under the Twenty-First Amendment and pursuant to their inherent police powers overrides and is unrelated to any activities or communicative value that may attach to the activities referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 4057, § 1, 8-6-96; Ord. No. 4058, § 1, 8-20-96) 
Sec. 5-52. - Territory embraced. 
    The provisions of this article apply to all territory within the legal corporate boundaries of the City of Meridian, Mississippi, a municipal corporation authorized and existing under the laws of the State of Mississippi. 
(Ord. No. 4057, § 2, 8-6-96) 
Sec. 5-53. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions apply: 
    Alcoholic beverage means any alcoholic liquid, including wines of more than four (4) percent of alcohol by weight, capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being, but shall not include wine containing four (4) percent of alcohol by weight, but shall include native wines (regulated under the "Local Option Beverage Control Law", Title 67, Chapter 3, Mississippi Code of 1972 Annotated, as Amended). 
    Beer and light wine means light wine and beer of an alcoholic content of not more than four (4) percent by weight (regulated under Title 67, Chapter 3, Mississippi Code of 1972 Annotated, as Amended). 
    Commercial Establishments means a location and place of business where the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages, light wine or beer may occur. 
    Employee means a person who works or performs, or provides services in connection with a commercial establishment, irrespective of whether said person is paid a salary or wages, or is an independent contractor, provided such person has a substantial or consistent relationship with the business of, or entertainment/services provided by the commercial establishment. Employee includes, but is not limited to, performers, managers and assistant managers, stock persons, tellers, sales representatives, demonstrators and operators. 
    Specified anatomical areas means: 
(1)  Any of the following areas of the human body less than completely or opaquely covered: 
a.  Human genitals or pubic region; 
b.  The entire cleft of the male or female buttocks. Attire which is insufficient to comply with this requirement includes, but is not limited to G-strings, T- backs, and thongs; and 
c.  That portion of the human female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola. This definition shall include the entire lower portion of the human female breast, bust shall not include any portion of the cleavage or the human female breast exhibited by a dress, blouse, shirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing apparel, provided the areola is not exposed; or 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernible turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
    Specified sexual activities means: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; or 
(2)  Acts of anilingus, bestiality, buggery, cunnilingus, coprophagy, coprophilia, fellation, flagellation, masochism, masturbation, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, sadism, sadomasochism, sapphism, sexual intercourse, sodomy, urolagnia or zooerastia; or 
(3)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock, anus or breast; or 
(4)  Excretory functions as part of, or in connection with, any of the activities set forth in (1) through (3) of this definition. 
    Straddle dance, also known as lap dance, table dance or face dance, shall mean any of the following acts: 
(1)  The use by an employee of any part of his or her body to touch the genital or pubic area of a person, excluding another employee, while at the commercial establishment, or touching the genital or pubic area of any employee by a person, including another employee, while at the commercial establishment in exchange for receiving a tip, donation, gratuity or anything of value. It shall be a straddle dance regardless of whether touch occurs while the employee is displaying or exposing any specific anatomical area. It shall also be a straddle dance regardless of whether the touch or touching is direct or through a medium; 
(2)  The straddling of the legs of an employee over any part of the body of a person, other than another employee at the commercial establishment, regardless of whether there is a touch or touching. 
(Ord. No. 4057, § 3, 8-6-96) 
Sec. 5-54. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning or operating a commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages, light wine or beer are offered for sale or consumed on the premises: 
(1)  To suffer or permit on the premises a person or employee to expose to the public view specified anatomical areas or any simulation thereof, or 
(2)  To suffer or permit on the premises a person or employee to engage in any specified sexual activities or any simulation thereof, or 
(3)  To suffer or permit the exposition on the premises of any graphic representation including pictures or projection of film which depict specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities. 
(4)  To suffer or permit a straddle dance to be performed. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any employee of a commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages, light wine or beer is offered for sale or consumed on the premises: 
(1)  To expose to public view specified anatomical areas or any simulation thereof; 
(2)  To engage in any specified sexual activities or any simulation thereof, or 
(3)  To perform a straddle dance. 
(Ord. No. 4057, § 4, 8-6-96) 
Sec. 5-55. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any employee who commits any act or suffers or permits any act prohibited by this article shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment of a term not exceeding ninety (90) days and the cost of prosecution, or by both such fine and imprisonment and the cost of prosecution. Each day any such violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition to the penalties hereinabove provided, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any provision of this article shall be subject to the appropriate civil action, including, but not limited to, the declaration of a public nuisance, injunctive relief for abatement, damages and sanctions, in the court of appropriate jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 4057, § 5, 8-6-96) 
Sec. 5-56. - Severability. 
    It is not the intention of this article to restrict, enlarge or affect in any way existing laws or ordinances of the State of Mississippi or the City of Meridian, or the separate enforcement thereof. No otherwise illegal acts or omissions are, or shall be, excused or made legal by the passage of this article. It is declared to be the legislative intent that if any section, subsection, sentence, clause, or provision of this article is declared void, unconstitutional or invalid for any person, such portion or provision, or the application or enforceability thereof, shall be severable from this article. The remaining portion or provisions of this article, or all applications and the appropriate enforcement thereof, shall not be affected and shall be interpreted, if necessary, so as to give a meaning consistent with the purpose and intent of the enacted ordinance set out in this article. No void, unconstitutional or inlaid portion, or proscribed provision, or application thereof, was an inducement to the enactment of the ordinance codified by this article. 
(Ord. No. 4057, § 6, 8-6-96) 
Sec. 5-57. - Effective date. 
    Because the adoption of this article is necessary for the immediate and temporary preservation of the public peace, health and safety and because the opening of commercial establishments featuring adult entertainment in conjunction with the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages, light wine and beer is a threat to public peace, health, safety and established community moral standards, this article shall be effective immediately. 
(Ord. No. 4057, § 7, 8-6-96) 
Sec. 5-58. - Effect on existing non-conforming commercial establishments. 
    One (1) or more commercial establishments featuring adult entertainment may be in operating in the city on the effective date hereto in a manner that does not conform to the requirements for legal operation when applying this article. For any such non-conforming commercial establishment conducting such business as of the effective date hereof, the effective date of application of the provision of this article to such non-conforming establishment shall be extended by ninety (90) calendar days, after which this article shall be in full force and effect as to such non-conforming commercial establishment. This provision shall not be a defense or an excuse for any act or omission by any person that is or shall be charged with violation of any other laws or ordinances. Further, the extension of time to conform provided by this section shall not apply to any commercial establishment where such beverages are sold or consumed and where, at the time of passage hereof, said establishments acts or omissions of a non-conforming nature were not regularly being performed. 
(Ord. No. 4057, § 8, 8-6-96; Ord. No. 4058, § 2, 8-20-96) 
Sec. 5-59. - Establishment of after hours or B.Y.O.B. clubs. 
    After hours establishment means a commercial establishment open to the general public after the hour of 2:00 a.m. that allows patrons to bring alcoholic beverages onto the premises (BYOB). 
    From and after the effective date of the section it shall be unlawful to operate any after hours establishment within the City of Meridian until a permit shall have been issued by the City of Meridian for the operation of such after hours establishment in accordance with the provisions of this chapter after payment of an application fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus a one hundred dollar ($100.00) annual fee for the renewal of the permit. 
    Application for after hours establishment permit: 
(1)  The owner of any business desiring to operate an after hours establishment, as defined in herein, shall file in person with the City of Meridian a written application, under oath, for a permit. No permit shall be issued until the City has approved the written application, which shall contain questions necessary to the determination of whether the applicant has met all laws of this state and all provisions of this code and other ordinances of the City of Meridian then in effect. The form of such application shall be prescribed by the City of Meridian and approved by the attorney for the City of Meridian.
