    There is hereby adopted as the official plumbing code of the city that certain plumbing code identified and captioned as the "ICC International Plumbing Code, 2012 edition," which code has been presented to and examined by the city council in pamphlet form and is now on file of the city clerk. 
(Code 1962, § 8-17; Ord. No. 3222, § 1, 6-2-64; Ord. No. 3309, § 1, 12-20-67; Ord. No. 3343, § 1, 11-4-69; Ord. No. 3398, § 1, 4-19-72; Ord. No. 3532, § 1, 2-7-78; Ord. No. 3582, § 1, 8-5-80; Ord. No. 3641, § 1, 7-6-82; Ord. No. 3736, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 3927, § 1, 10-15-91; Ord. No. 4020, § 1, 7-18-95; Ord. No. 4094, § 1, 2-17-98; Ord. No. 4206, § 1, 2-5-2002; Ord. No. 4311, § 1, 2-20-2007; Ord. No. 4442, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
Editor's note- At the city's instruction § 7-72 will remain in the Code as part of local building regulations. 
Cross reference- Building code, § 7-16; mechanical code, § 7-31; gas code, § 7-91; electrical code, § 7-111; fire prevention code, § 9-1; housing code, § 13-1. 
Sec. 7-72. - Same-Amendments. 
    The code adopted by this article is amended as follows: 
    Section 1302, Building Sewer, is amended to add a new subsection 1302.6 to read as follows: 
"a.  No person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer, building sewer or appurtenance thereof, or use a power machine for cleaning, rodding, rooting or unclogging a building sewer without first obtaining a written permit from the building official. 
"b.  There shall be two (2) classes of sewer permits: 
(1)  For connecting building sewers to sewer mains; and 
(2)  For maintenance or repair of a building sewer requiring a connection with or opening into or alteration of the sewer line or the use of a power machine for cleaning, rodding, rooting or unclogging a building sewer. 
In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. Permits under (a) above will be issued and charges made as provided under section 7-74 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Meridian, Mississippi. 
"c.  All costs and expenses incident to the installation, connection, maintenance and repair of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation and maintenance of the building sewer. 
"d.  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the building official, to meet all requirements of this article. A permit as set out under paragraph (b) above shall be obtained for connecting new buildings to existing building sewers. 
"e.  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating,placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench, shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) and the Water Pollution Control Federation (WPCF) Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. The building sewer shall be Clay Sewer Pipe, ASTM C-700 with ASTM C-425 Couplings or PVC pipe, ASTM D-3034 (SDR 35) or cast iron soil pipe with preformed neoprene joints, ANSI 112.5.1 or ductile iron pipe, ANSI A21.51, with rubber gasket or mechanical joints, ANSI A21.10 or 11. 
"f.  Connections of building sewer to sewer main shall be made within existing wyes or tees, or in the absence of a wye or tee, with a machine tap and tapping saddle of a design approved by the building official, or by cutting a section from the sewer main, inserting a wye or tee of material similar to the mains, and connecting to sewer main with full circle clamp couplings of a design approved by the building official. All connections in the sewer main and in the building sewer shall be made airtight and watertight. 
"g.  Where an opening is made into a building sewer for maintenance or repair, the opening shall be repaired by cutting a section from the building sewer, inserting a section of sewer pipe of approved material for building sewers, and connecting to existing building sewer with full circle clamp couplings of a design approved by the building official, or by inserting a cleanout connected with full circle clamp couplings as above. All connections in the building sewer shall be made airtight and watertight. 
"h.  No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface run-off or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
"i.  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer or repairs and alterations to building sewers shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. All such connections shall be made airtight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the building official before installation. 
"j.  The applicant for the building sewer connection and maintenance repair permits shall notify the building official when the work is ready for inspection. The connection to the public sewer shall be made under the supervision of the building official or his representative. Work shall be tested for airtightness where practical. 
"k.  All excavations for building sewer installations and maintenance or repair shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to prevent the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city." 
(Code 1962, § 8-21; Ord. No. 3619, § 1, 9-16-81) 
Sec. 7-73. - Date of examinations; reexaminations. 
    The board of adjustments and appeals for the plumbing code shall hold examinations on the second Wednesday of each month, except when there are no applications to be considered. 
(Code 1962, § 8-19; Ord. No. 3224, 6-2-64; Ord. No. 3993, § 3, 10-18-94)

(Code 1962, § 8-20; Ord. No. 3262, § 1, 1-19-66; Ord. No. 3606, § 1, 5-4-81; Ord. No. 3949, § 8, 2-16-93; Ord. No. 4229, § IV, 7-8-2003; Ord. No. 4496, § IV, 2-6-2018, eff. 4-6-2018)

ARTICLE VI. - ELECTRICITY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-111. - Code adopted; interpretation of article. 
    There is hereby adopted as the official electrical code of the City of Meridian that certain code identified and captioned as the "2014 National Electrical Code," which said code having been presented to and examined by the city council in pamphlet form and now on file in the office of the city clerk of the City of Meridian. 
(Ord. No. 3950, § 1, 3-2-93; Ord. No. 4039, § 1, 1-2-96; Ord. No. 4120, § 1, 5-4-99; Ord. No. 4211, § 1, 8-7-2002; Ord. No. 4259, § 1, 12-7-2004; Ord. No. 4294, § I, 10-17-2006; Ord. No. 4332, § 1, 4-15-2008; Ord. No. 4378, § 1, 1-18-2011; Ord. No. 4444, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
Editor's note- Section 1, Ord. No. 3950, adopted Mar. 2, 1993, added new provisions as § 7-111, and § 2 of the ordinance repealed former § 7-111, which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from § 8-33 of the city's 1962 Code as amended by the following:

Sec. 7-112. - Board established; appointment and membership; terms of office; duties and responsibilities; meetings. 
(a)  There is hereby established an electrical examining board, which shall hereinafter be referred to as the "board." The board shall consist of six (6) members, and shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the city council. 
(b)  The building official of the city shall, by virtue of his office, serve as secretary of the board. 
(c)  The members of the board shall be appointed for terms of six (6) years each. The electrical inspector shall be a permanent member of the board. 
(d)  The board shall select one (1) of its members as chairman who shall preside at all meetings, and another member as vice-chairman who shall preside in the absence of the chairman. 
(e)  The board or its agent shall conduct examinations. The board shall receive complaints, conduct hearings, revoke licenses, and make investigations. The board may recommend to the city council from time to time amendments and changes in the City of Meridian Electrical Code of Ordinances. 
(f)  Set meeting time of the electrical examining board to the fourth Tuesday of each month at 1:30 p.m., although special meetings may be called at any time by the chairman. The board shall keep minutes of all its proceedings. 
(Code 1962, § 8-45; Ord. No. 3496, § 3, 10-22-75; Ord. No. 3508, § 1, 8-25-76; Ord. No. 3586, § 1, 9-2-80; Ord. No. 4294, § I, 10-17-2006) 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions generally, § 2-155 et seq. 
Sec. 7-113. - Enforcement by building official; right-of-entry. 
    The building official or his authorized assistant is hereby directed to enforce all of the provisions of this article, and for such purpose he shall have the powers of a police officer. The building official or his authorized assistant may enter any building or premises for the purpose of making inspections or to prevent violation of this article, upon presentation of the proper credentials. 
(Code 1962, § 8-34) 
Sec. 7-114. - Inspection required before concealing wiring. 
    All wiring shall be inspected by the electrical inspector before it is concealed. In case he shall discover any defects, either of material or workmanship therein, such defects shall be promptly remedied. No wiring shall be concealed until it shall have been approved by the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1962, § 8-35) 
Sec. 7-115. - Final inspection, certification. 
    No wiring system shall be energized until after the electrical inspector shall have made the necessary inspections and shall have issued his written certificate of approval. However, if work is done on fixtures or wiring in an existing wiring system at a time when the electrical inspector's office is not open such wiring system may be energized without approval of the electrical inspector upon written certification to the electric utility company by a licensed electrician that the system is ready for electric service, whereupon such licensed electrician shall notify the electrical inspector that the system has been energized and if the city electrical inspector shall thereafter inspect the system and shall disapprove he shall give written notice to the electric utility company to disconnect service. 
(Code 1962, § 8-36; Ord. No. 3554, § 1, 4-3-79; Ord. No. 3679, § 1, 1-18-84; Ord. No. 4294, § I, 10-17-2006) 
Sec. 7-116. - Authority of building official to require correction of errors, prevent violations. 
    The issuance of a permit upon plans and specifications shall not prevent the building official from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in such plans and specifications or from preventing building operations being carried on thereunder when in violation of this article or of any other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 8-38) 
Sec. 7-117. - Notice to stop violations or unsafe work. 
    If any electrical work is done contrary to the provisions of this article, or is done in an unsafe or dangerous manner, the inspector may order the work stopped by verbal or written notice to any person engaged in the doing or causing such work to be done, and such person shall stop work until authorized by the building official or his assistants to proceed with such work. 
(Code 1962, § 8-39; Ord. No. 4294, § I, 10-17-2006) 
Sec. 7-118. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4294, § I, adopted Oct. 17, 2006, omitted § 7-118, which pertained to removing wires from buildings and derived from Code 1962, § 8-41. 
Sec. 7-119. - Dangerous conditions-Notice to repair or remove; abatement by city for noncompliance. 
    Any pole, wire or other electrical construction, though property located, erected or constructed originally, which becomes in such condition as to render it dangerous to persons or property, whether on account of dilapidation, want of repair or any other cause is hereby held to be a nuisance, and the chief of police, fire chief or the electrical inspector may order its owner, or other person responsible therefore, to remove or repair the same as, in the judgment of the building official, or an order given by the mayor on complaint made before him by any other person in cases where the officers above named fail or refuse to act, the same to be done in the manner provided for such cases in article II of chapter 16 of this Code. In the event the owner of the thing complained of, or the person be notified, fails or refuses to do as required, proceedings shall be instituted and prosecuted before the municipal judge as therein provided for the abatement of such nuisances. 
(Code 1962, § 8-42; Ord. No. 4294, § I, 10-17-2006) 
Sec. 7-120. - Same-Abatement without notice. 
    In cases of imminent danger, not admitting of delay, the mayor is authorized to have the building official or some other competent person cut out the current in the locality concerned, or to remove the dangerous pole or wire, or to do whatever else may be necessary to protect persons and property from the immediate and impending danger, without notice to the owner, as authorized in such cases by chapter 17 of this Code. The building official is likewise authorized to act in such cases, without instructions from the mayor when in his judgment immediate action should be taken. 
(Code 1962, § 8-43) 
Sec. 7-121. - Wiring standards. 
    All electrical wiring in all buildings of the city shall be installed in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Encasing wires generally: fire zone number one. All electrical wire hereafter installed in any building located in fire zone one shall be encased in an approved metal raceway. 
(2)  Encasing wires in commercial buildings; wiring generally in other structures. All electrical wires hereafter installed in any commercial building, whether it be in or out of number one fire zone, shall be encased in an approved raceway. All other structures shall be wired in accordance with the adopted issue of the National Electrical Code. 
(3)  Minimum allowed ampacity. A 20-amy circuit shall be the minimum allowed ampacity with the exception of manufacturer's recommendation or testing laboratory listing. 
(Code 1962, § 8-56; Ord. No. 3705, § 1, 12-19-84; Ord. No. 3752, § 1, 8-19-86; Ord. No. 4294, § I, 10-17-2006) 
Sec. 7-122. - Violations, penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, move, remove, demolish, convert, equip, use or occupy or maintain any building or structure or any portion of any building or structure in the city contrary to or in violation of any provisions of this article, or to cause, permit or suffer the same to be done. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of this article is committed, continued or permitted, and upon conviction of any such violation such person shall be punishable as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 8-40) 
Secs. 7-123-7-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 7-136. - License-Required. 
(a)  Master electrician's license. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to engage in or perform in the city any industrial, commercial or residential electrical work as an electrician or electrical contractor without first obtaining from the city a master electrician's license to do so. 
(b)  Residential license. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to engage in or perform in the city any residential electrical work as an electrician or electrical contractor without first obtaining a license to do so. 
(c)  "Residential" defined. For definition purposes, the word "residential" shall mean one-, two- and three-family dwellings. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in any business described above in section (a) to employ, engage, or contract with any subcontractor or any person or entity which provides services which are regulated by the ordinance [this division] of the City of Meridian who has not been duly licensed and currently holds a valid license issued by the city. 
(e)  Any person who shall violate the prohibition of this section shall upon conviction be punished as follows: 
(1)  For a first offense, a monetary fine equal to but not greater than one (1) percent of the total amount (profit and cost) of the contract work being done at the time of said violation, but not less than a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00); 
(2)  For a second offense, a monetary fine equal to but not greater than three (3) percent of the total amount (profit and cost) of the contract work being done at the time of said violation, but not less than a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00); 
(3)  For a third offense, a monetary fine equal to but not greater than five (5) percent of the total amount (profit and cost) of the contract work being done at the time of said violation, but not less than a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00), and any certificate of licensure under this article may be revoked by the electrical examining board upon full hearing and presentation of evidence of three (3) violations within a single twelve-month period. 
(Code 1962, § 8-44; Ord. No. 3496, § 1, 10-22-75; Ord. No. 3752, § 1, 8-19-86; Ord. No. 3949, § 10, 2-16-93; Ord. No. 3993, § 4, 10-18-94; Ord. No. 4294, § II, 10-17-2006) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 7-137. - Same-Application requirements, procedure; licensed electrician to supervise work. 
(a)  Any person desiring to engage in the business of electrician or electrical contractor shall, before doing so, file his application with the inspection department setting forth the facts as provided for on the application which will show his training and qualifications. Such application shall be passed upon by the electrical examining board except a license applied for under reciprocity by one licensed by another state local governmental unit may be issued by the chairman of the board, upon the request of the building official. The applicant shall be subject to such examinations as the electrical examining board shall deem advisable. 
(b)  No person shall engage in the business of installations, repairing or altering of electrical installations or other service governed by the city's electrical code, unless the work performed in the course of such business is performed by the holder of the certificate of licensure or a documented employee of said holder of certificate of licensure. Said documentation shall be an employment card issued by the City of Meridian inspection division. 
(c)  The city shall issue an employment card to each and every employee of a holder of certificate of licensure upon presentation and inspection of documentation verifying employment by the holder of certificate of licensure. Said employee shall maintain and possess said employment card at all times while engaged in the business of electrical installations, repairing or altering of electrical installations or any other service governed by the city's electrical code and shall have such employment card available for inspection at all such times. 
(d)  The holder of a certificate of licensure shall, in writing, inform the city of the termination, resignation or any such change in employment of any person holding an employment card within ten (10) days of such activity and return employment card to the city and return said employment card to the City of Meridian inspection division within said ten (10) days. 
(e)  Any person who shall violate the prohibition of this section shall upon conviction be punished as follows: 
(1)  For a first offense, a monetary fine equal to but not greater than one (1) percent of the total amount (profit and cost) of the contract work being done at the time of said violation, but not less than a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00); 
(2)  For a second offense, a monetary fine equal to but not greater than three (3) percent of the total amount (profit and cost) of the contract work being done at the time of said violation, but not less than a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00); 
(3)  For a third offense, a monetary fine equal to but not greater than five (5) percent of the total amount (profit and cost) of the contract work being done at the time of said violation, but not less than a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00), and any certificate of licensure under this article may be revoked by the electrical examining board upon full hearing and presentation of evidence of three (3) violations within a single twelve-month period. 
(Code 1962, § 8-46; Ord. No. 3496, § 2, 10-22-75; Ord. No. 3803, § 1, 5-3-88; Ord. No. 3949, § 11, 2-16-93; Ord. No. 3993, § 5, 10-18-94) 
Sec. 7-138. - Same-Application submission; fees; license certificates. 
    All applications for an examination or license shall be accompanied by a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the examination and one hundred dollars ($100.00) annually for the master electrician's license. The fee for the residential license shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The application shall be made to the building official on forms provided by him thirty (30) days prior to the date of the examination. License certificates shall be signed and issued by the building official when approved by the examining board. 
(Code 1962, § 8-47; Ord. No. 3496, § 4, 10-22-75; Ord. No. 3586, § 2, 9-2-80; Ord. No. 3634, § 1, 2-16-82; Ord. No. 3752, § 1, 8-19-86; Ord. No. 3949, § 12, 2-16-93) 
Sec. 7-139. - Same-Licensees not subject to examination. 
    All applicants for licenses under this division shall be required to satisfactorily pass an examination as hereinbefore provided, except that all licensed electricians who held a license prior to the effective date of this article may continue in the same classification without examination unless violations are cited as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1962, § 8-47.1; Ord. No. 3496, § 5, 10-22-75) 
Sec. 7-140. - Same-Bond prerequisite to issuance. 
    Before a certificate of licensure shall be delivered under this division, the successful applicant shall post a bond conditioned upon the faithful performance of any and all work authorized by the license in strict accordance with ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 8-47.3; Ord. No. 3496, § 7, 10-22-75) 
Sec. 7-141. - Same-Revocation; hearing; requirements for relicensure; appeal. 
(a)  Any certificate granted under this article, or which may be in force at the time this article is passed, may be revoked by the board, if the holder of the certificate of licensure violates any ordinance or laws relating to electrical installations, or should the holder permit the use of such license to allow a nonlicensed person to directly or indirectly obtain permits for the purpose of installing electrical facilities. Such holder of a certificate of licensure shall be given a full hearing, the board fully satisfying itself as to the violation involved. 
(b)  When a certificate is revoked, a new certificate shall not be granted to the same person for a period of at least thirty (30) days, or until such person shall have corrected any faulty construction or other violation. At its discretion, the board may require that the party involved be required to take an examination, as heretofore provided by this article, prior to reissuing a certificate of licensure. 
(Code 1962, § 8-47.2; Ord. No. 3496, § 6, 10-22-75; Ord. No. 3586, § 3, 9-2-80) 
Sec. 7-142. - Appeals. 
    The electrical board shall, in addition to its other duties, serve as an appeal board to hear the appeal of any person aggrieved by any decision or ruling of the building official, provided that notice of such appeal is given the chairman of the board and the building official within five (5) days after the decision or ruling has been made. In case of an appeal, the secretary shall transmit copies thereof together with any substantiating data to each member of the board. The appeal shall be heard at the next regular or called meeting of the board. An aggrieved party may appear in person or be represented by counsel. Any decision of such board acting as an appeal board shall be final. 
(Code 1962, § 8-47.4; Ord. No. 3496, § 8, 10-22-75; Ord. No. 3586, § 4, 9-2-80) 
Sec. 7-143. - Fines and penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates, neglects, refuses to comply with or resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(b)  In addition to any punishment imposed pursuant to section 1-9 of this Code, any person who shall violate the prohibition of subsection (a) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as follows: 
(1)  For a first offense, a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00); 
(2)  For a second offense, a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) but not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00); and 
(3)  For a third or subsequent offense, a fine of not less than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) but not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1962, § 8-47.5; Ord. No. 3496, § 9, 10-22-75; Ord. No. 3949, § 13, 2-16-93) 
Secs. 7-144-7-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 7-156. - Required. 
(a)  No person shall erect or construct any wiring or electrical installation or add to, enlarge, move, improve, alter, convert, extend or demolish any wiring or electrical installation or cause the same to be done, without first obtaining a permit from the building official or his authorized representative. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate the prohibition of subsection (a) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as follows: 
(1)  For a first offense, a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00); 
(2)  For a second offense, a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) but not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00); and 
(3)  For a third or subsequent offense, a fine of not less than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) but not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1962, § 8-48; Ord. No. 3949, § 14, 2-16-93) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 7-157. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 3752, adopted Aug. 19, 1986, repealed the provisions of former § 7-157, which section pertained to application for electrical permit and derived from Code 1962, § 8-49. 
Sec. 7-158. - Fees. 
(a)  Generally. Electrical permit and inspection fees are established as follows: 
    For issuing each permit a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) plus the following: 
(1)  New construction-Residential, commercial, industrial: $1.00 per designed/permitted amp requirement. 
(2)  Additions/renovations: $1.00 per added designed/permitted amp requirement. 
(3)  Temporary service: $50.00 for first 200 amps, plus $1.00 for each additional amp above 200 amps. 
(4)  Demolition: No charge for electrical. 
(5)  Repeat visits for final inspection: $50.00 for first repeat visit, $100.00 for each subsequent visit. 
(6)  Damage/maintenance fee: $100.00. 
(b)  Failure to obtain permit. If any person commences any electrical work on a building or structure or anything applicable before obtaining the necessary permit from the city, he shall be charged a double fee. 
(c)  Any person who shall violate the prohibition of subsection (b) of this section, upon conviction, shall, in addition to the double fee levied therein, be punished as follows: 
(1)  For a first offense, a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00); 
(2)  For a second offense, a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) but not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00); and 
(3)  For a third or subsequent offense, a fine of not less than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) but not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1962, § 8-53; Ord. No. 3263, § 1, 1-19-66; Ord. No. 3379, § 1, 5-4-71; Ord. No. 3608, § 1, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3949, § 15, 2-16-93; Ord. No. 4229, § II, 7-8-2003; Ord. No. 4496, § II, 2-6-2018, eff. 4-6-2018) 
Sec. 7-159. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 3752, adopted Aug. 19, 1986, repealed the provisions of former § 7-159, which pertained to issuance of permit and derived from Code 1962, § 8-50. 
Sec. 7-160. - Not to authorize violations. 
    The issuance or granting of a permit or approval of plans and/or specifications shall not be deemed or construed to be a permit for or an approval of, any violation of any of the provisions of this Code. No permit presuming to give authority to violate, or fail to comply with, the provisions of this Code, shall be valid except insofar as the work or use which it authorizes is lawful. 
(Code 1962, § 8-52) 
Sec. 7-161. - Exceptions to permit requirements for regular maintenance. 
    Permits required by this division will not be required in the case where regular maintenance personnel are employed for the purpose of repair and maintenance of installations and equipment; provided, however, this section shall not be construed to mean, or relieve any person or persons from complying with any other part of this article, or any part of the National Electrical Code. 
(Code 1962, § 8-54; Ord. No. 4294, § III, 10-17-2006) 
Sec. 7-162. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4294, § III, adopted Oct. 17, 2006, deleted § 7-162, which pertained to exemption for portable appliances and derived from Code 1962, § 8-55. 
Sec. 7-163. - Provisions applicable to electrical signs. 
    On installations as described in section 7-156, a permit will be required for the wiring of electrical signs. However, where signs are manufactured by sign companies authorized to do business in the city, they will be permitted to do their own electrical wiring, in accordance with currently adopted National Electrical Code. 
(Code 1962, § 8-55.1; Ord. No. 3213, § 1, 12-17-63; Ord. No. 4294, § III, 10-17-2006) 
Sec. 7-164. - Expiration. 
    Every electrical permit issued by the inspection division shall expire and become null and void if the electrical work authorized by such permit is not commenced within ninety (90) days from the date of such permit. If the work authorized by the permit is suspended or abandoned for sixty (60) days after the work is commenced, the permit shall expire and become null and void. 
(Code 1962, § 8-51; Ord. No. 3752, § 1, 8-19-86; Ord. No. 4294, § III, 10-17-2006) 
Secs. 7-165-7-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - POLES AND WIRES 

Sec. 7-176. - Permit required; submission of plans. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to set poles or string wires within the city without first submitting plans therefor to the building inspector, and securing permission from such officer to construct in accordance therewith, which permit shall not be granted if the plans are in violation of these rules and regulations. 
(Code 1962, § 8-63) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Authority to grant right to install, maintain poles, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-27-3. 
Sec. 7-177. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4294, § IV, adopted Oct. 17, 2006, deleted § 7-177, which pertained to duty to raise existing wires when new wires run under them new wires run under them and derived from Code 1962, § 8-64. 
Sec. 7-178. - Wires, poles, fixtures not in use to be removed. 
    Loops, wires, poles and other supports no longer in use shall be removed, except when it is positively known they will be used again within sixty (60) days. 
(Code 1962, § 8-65) 
Secs. 7-179-7-195. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4294, § IV, adopted Oct. 17, 2006, deleted §§ 7-179-7-181, which pertained to requirements for installing poles on sidewalks; poles to be in alleys if practicable; poles in certain areas to be painted, marked with owner's names and derived from Code 1962, §§ 8-66-8-68. 
ARTICLE VII. - UNSAFE BUILDINGS 

Sec. 7-196. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4459, § 3, adopted June 2, 2015, repealed § 7-196, which pertained to adoption of Standard Unsafe Building Abatement Code. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 7-197. - Board of adjustments and appeals re unsafe buildings; created, composition. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established a board of adjustments and appeals for the purpose of providing for the final interpretation of the provisions of the code adopted by this article and to perform all the functions prescribed for said board under the code. 
(b)  The board of adjustments and appeals shall be composed of the same persons who now compose the board of adjustments and appeals heretofore created by the city council pursuant to the building code of the city, and the successors in office of such board. Each person hereafter appointed to serve as a member of the board of adjustments and appeals created under the building code shall automatically be and is hereby appointed as a member of the board of adjustments and appeals created herein pursuant to code adopted by this article, and the term of office of each member shall be for the same period of time on both such boards. 
(Code 1962, § 8-77; Ord. No. 3668, §§ 1, 2, 8-17-83) 
Cross reference- City boards and commissions generally, § 2-156 et seq.
