ARTICLE VIII. - ADDRESS DISPLAY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3768, adopted Feb. 17, 1987, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-9 as §§ 7-221-7-229 comprising a new Art. VIII, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 7-221. - Required. 
    The owner or tenant of any dwelling, former dwelling, commercial building, or other structure or activity, whether in use or not, shall display its municipally assigned unique address, indicating a number at or near the point where the location has access for ingress to and egress from any public street, avenue, highway or alley. This address display shall be of such a combination of size and color contrast as to be readily visible from both directions on the public way. 
(Ord. No. 3768, § 1, 2-17-87) 
Sec. 7-222. - Curbside address permitted; substitutes. 
    In a location where curbs are present along the public way abutting a location and vehicular parking for the public or occupants shall not obstruct a view of the curb, the unique address may be placed on the curb at a position thereon so as to be separately identifiable with the location to which it is assigned. The number shall be white on a dark (contrasting) background and measure no more than thirty-six (36) inches in length, and height shall be of such size as to be readily visible from the public way. Where the building or structure is built up to the public way, and curb views are usually obstructed, then a similar display shall be placed upon the building or structure so as to be readily visible from the public way. In lieu of such curbside or building address displays, a freestanding address display observable from both directions, if feasible, of comparable size and contrasting color scheme may be used. 
(Ord. No. 3768, § 2, 2-17-87; Ord. No. 3954, § 1, 5-4-93) 
Sec. 7-223. - Mailbox address display permitted. 
    Where a freestanding mailbox is located on any premises separately assigned an address and such is at or near the public way upon which the private property abuts and is positioned so as to separately identify the building, structure or activity to which the address is officially assigned, the address may be placed on or about the mailbox so as to be visible from both directions. 
(Ord. No. 3768, § 3, 2-17-87) 
Sec. 7-224. - Multi-occupied premises. 
    Where two (2) or more separate dwellings, commercial buildings or other activities or structures occupy a single uniquely addressed parcel of land or building, then at or near the common entranceway to such from the public way and upon or near the separate entrance to each building or activity, a separate number or letter shall be prominently displayed to identify such separate building or activity. 
(Ord. No. 3768, § 4, 2-17-87) 
Sec. 7-225. - Separate building, structure or activity along or upon a common private way. 
    In the event that two (2) or more separate dwelling units, commercial buildings, or other structures or activities are located upon a common private road, then each such separate building, structure or activity shall display thereon or nearby the address pertaining to that separate building, structure or activity so as to be easily identifiable with the same and easily observed from the private way. 
(Ord. No. 3768, § 5, 2-17-87) 
Sec. 7-226. - Multifamily apartment complexes or buildings. 
    As to multifamily apartment complexes or buildings, each building thereof, when more than one (1), including any separate maintenance building serving an apartment complex, shall be identified in a sequential fashion by a prominent letter or number underneath or near which shall also be prominently displayed the inclusive numbers or letters privately assigned the separate apartments or dwelling units contained in such building. Moreover, each separate dwelling unit shall display near the doorway thereto a separate number or letter uniquely identifying such. 
(Ord. No. 3768, § 6, 2-17-87) 
Sec. 7-227. - Building official to assign addresses. 
    Upon an application for a building, structure or other activity or construction permit, the building official shall issue either a permanent or a temporary address to the owner, contractor, developer or other occupant thereof which shall be prominently displayed thereon at or near the place where the activity or proposed construction abuts the public way so as to reasonably comply with the requirements and purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3768, § 7, 2-17-87) 
Sec. 7-228. - Obstruction of address display; maintenance. 
    The owner or occupant of places required to display addresses and numbers or letters of separate dwelling units or business activities within a single structure shall keep the required displays of addresses and numbers or letters unobstructed at all times and shall maintain and clean the same as conditions require so as to allow the same to function as envisioned by this article. 
(Ord. No. 3768, § 8, 2-17-87) 
Sec. 7-229. - Penalties and enforcement. 
    This article shall be enforced by the building official and other officials and employees of the city shall report nonconforming address displays to the official, when such displays have impeded their functions and duties. Any person, owner or occupant of any premises who violates any provision of this article shall suffer a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the first offense and fifty dollars ($50.00) for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. 3768, § 9, 2-17-87) 
Secs. 7-230-7-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - SIGNS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3791, adopted Oct. 20, 1987, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-14 as Art. IX, §§ 7-241-7-254 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Advertising, Ch. 3; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20; obstructing sidewalks with signs, § 20-22; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 23; zoning, App. A; zoning districts, App. A, § 701 et seq. 

Sec. 7-241. - Findings of fact. 
    The city council finds that the sign control regulations set forth herein are a reasonable and proper exercise of its police power, promote the general welfare of the citizens of and visitors to the city, protect the traveling public from dangerous distractions and visual obstructions, protect property values, promote the aesthetics of the city, its scenic beauty and broad vistas, alleviate the congestion of available land and air spaces, and enhance business, residential, tourism and area development in general. The city council further finds that it is reasonable in this exercise of the police power to base these regulations in part on the zoning districts established by the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 1, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 1, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 7-242. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial, when referring to the content of a sign, means a sign related solely to the economic interests of the permittee and his/her audience or such other definition as may be given the word, from time to time, by the courts. 
    Interstate system of highways means that portion of the national system of interstate and defense highways located within this state, as officially designated, or as may hereafter be so designated, by the state highway commission, and approved by the United States Secretary of Commerce, pursuant to the provisions of Title 23, United States Code, "Highways." 
    Lot means a parcel of land occupied or to be occupied by one (1) or more structures and the accessory uses customarily incident thereto, including such open spaces as are required under these or other regulations or ordinances and having its principal frontage upon a public street, approved private street, road or highway. A lot, as used in this article, may consist of one (1) or more platted lots, or tract or tracts. 
    Noncommercial, when referring to the content of a sign, means a sign not related solely to the economic interests of the permittee and his/her audience or such other definition as may be given the word, from time to time, by the courts. 
    Primary system of highways means Highways 19, 45, 39, 145, 11, 80 and 11/80 not including alternate of business routes as determined by the building official. 
    Sign means any words, numerals, figures, devices, designs, trademarks or logos, which are painted on or attached to a frame, pole or brackets or building facade and mounted or painted on or affixed to a building or the ground, by which information is made known to the public outside a building and including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Attention attracting device means any rotating or moving action by mechanical or natural means, or any moving or flashing lights. Exceptions include temporary event attention attracting devices described in section 7-247, Temporary event signs, and electronic message signs described in section 7-249, Qualified exceptions. 
(2)  Detached sign means a portable sign or any sign permanently located on the ground or on a structure located on the ground and not attached to a building. 
(3)  Directly illuminated sign means any sign where the source of illumination of the sign is exposed to the human eye, such as, but not limited to, neon tube, incandescent bulb or fluorescent tube. 
(4)  Indirectly illuminated sign means any sign which is partially or completely illuminated at any time by a light source which is so shielded as not to be visible at eye level. 
(5)  Marquee sign means any sign attached flat against or under the marquee or permanent sidewalk canopy of a building, but not on the upper surface of such structures. 
(6)  Monument sign means a low profile detached sign where the width of the support base is usually as wide or wider than the width of the sign's face, and the sign's face is higher than two (2) feet above the average grade of the ground. 
(7)  Nonconforming sign means any sign that does not comply with the standards and procedures established in this article. 
(8)  Nonconforming sign support means the supporting members of the sign such as the frame, poles, brackets or other structure, by which the sign is mounted on or fixed to a building or the ground, which do not comply with the standards established in this article. 
(9)  Portable sign means a sign whose principal supporting structure is intended, by design and construction to be used by resting upon the ground for support and may be easily moved or relocated for reuse. Portable signs shall include, but are not limited to, signs mounted upon a trailer, bench, wheeled carrier or other nonmotorized mobile structure with or without wheels. 
(10)  Poster panel or billboard means a sign generally known as outdoor advertising, mounted on a semipermanent or permanent structure and depicting information not directly related to the property upon which it is placed. 
(11)  Projecting sign means any sign extending more than one (1) foot from the face of the building to which it is attached. A time and temperature instrument mounted on the face of a building shall be included in this definition. 
(12)  Semiilluminated sign means any sign located on a building face which is uniformly illuminated over its entire area, including the area of the sign, by use of electricity or other artificial light. Semiilluminated signs shall be permitted in any location where illuminated signs are permitted. 
(13)  Snipe sign means any sign of a material, such as, but not limited to, cardboard, paper, pressed wood, plastic or metal which is attached to a fence, window, tree, utility pole or temporary structure, or any sign which is not securely fastened to or painted on a building or firmly anchored to the ground. 
(14)  Temporary event sign means a sign related to temporary events such as any public, charitable, educational or religious event or function, special sale or promotion. A temporary event sign may be a portable sign as defined herein. 
(15)  Time and/or temperature instrument means a sign displaying only time and/or temperature information. 
(16)  Wall sign means any sign attached to and erected parallel to and within one (1) foot of the face or wall of a building, including signs painted on the walls of buildings. 
    Sign alteration means the replacement, enlargement, reduction, or reshaping of a sign or sign support. 
    Sign maintenance means the normal care and minor repair that is necessary to retain a safe, and finished structure, frame, pole, brackets or surface. Changing copy or logo shall be considered maintenance if the information, product or service depicted remains the same and if the sign is to serve the identical use as before the change. 
    Sign refacing means changing or replacing the words, numerals or other surfaces of the sign to serve a different use or create a different visual effect but without altering, moving or replacing the frame, pole, bracket or other structure supporting the sign. 
    Sign support means the supporting members of the sign such as frame poles, brackets or other structures, by which a sign is mounted on or affixed to a building or the ground. 
    Zoning district shall have the meaning ascribed to this phrase by the zoning ordinance of the city and shall, among other things, denote those various separate areas of land described in such ordinance by a combination of capital letters and arabic numerals and further as set out on the official zoning map of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 2, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 2, 11-21-95: Ord. No. 4155, § 2, 3-21-2000) 
Sec. 7-243. - Prohibitions and restrictions. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this article, no sign shall be permitted within the corporate limits of the city, except as follows: 
(1)  Within zoning districts R-1 and R-2. 
a.  One (1) nonilluminated wall sign is permitted per building if not more than one (1) foot square in area and mounted on the building. 
b.  One (1) nonilluminated detached "For Sale" or "For Rent" sign per lot is permitted if not more than eight (8) square feet in area, nor more than six (6) feet in height above the average grade. 
c.  Not more than two (2) nonilluminated, indirectly illuminated or semiilluminated wall signs, nor more than one (1) on a single building facade, for each church, school, or other such public/semipublic facility are permitted. No such sign shall have an overall area exceeding thirty-two (32) square feet. In lieu of one (1) of the wall signs, one (1) detached monument sign shall be permitted. Such monument sign shall be located on the premises and shall not exceed ten (10) feet in height above the average grade, and the sign face shall not exceed fifty (50) square feet in area per face if located ten (10) feet from the street right-of-way. 
(2)  Within zoning district A. Those provisions and restrictions in paragraph (1)A., B., and C. and the provisions of section 7-245, Billboards or poster panels, shall apply. 
(3)  Within zoning district R-3. For any one (1) use of each twenty thousand (20,000) square feet of land or less, there is permitted one (1) nonilluminated detached sign, of not more than twenty (20) square feet in area and not more than six (6) feet high overall. 
(4)  Within zoning district B-1. One (1) illuminated wall sign or detached sign per building of not more than twenty (20) square feet in area, nor more than six (6) feet in height above the average grade is permitted. 
(5)  Within zoning districts B-2, B-3 and B-5. 
a.  All land uses, which are not specifically referenced below, are permitted noncommercial signage of no less than the amount of signage authorized for the other uses within these districts. 
b.  Each business or commercial establishment shall be permitted not more than three (3) indirectly illuminated, semiilluminated, nonilluminated or directly illuminated wall or marquee signs, but only one (1) per facade. The total area of each sign shall not exceed fifteen (15) percent of the total area of the facade upon which it is placed. In lieu of one (1) of the attached wall signs, one (1) projecting sign subject to the limitations above is permitted for each establishment. In the B-5 zoning district, the projecting sign may project over the street right-of-way and must maintain a nine-foot vertical clearance above the sidewalk and be no closer than eighteen (18) inches to the curb. 
c.  Additionally, one (1) detached sign shall be permitted for each building. Such sign shall not exceed thirty (30) feet in height above the average grade and the sign face shall not exceed one hundred fifty (150) square feet in area per face nor more than three hundred (300) square feet on all faces if located ten (10) feet from the street right-of-way. For each additional one-foot setback from the street right-of-way, one (1) additional foot may be added to the height of the sign to a maximum of thirty-five (35) feet. 
d.  In the case of a shopping center designed as one (1) unified entity of one (1) or more buildings, one (1) detached sign identifying the entire center is permitted. All other signs in the center shall consist of wall, projecting or marquee signs as otherwise permitted herein. The detached sign shall not exceed thirty (30) feet in height above the average grade and the sign face shall not exceed one hundred fifty (150) square feet in area per face nor more than three hundred (300) square feet on all faces if located ten (10) feet from the street right-of-way. For each additional one-foot setback from the street right-of-way, one (1) additional foot may be added to the height of the sign to a maximum of thirty-five (35) feet. If not sitting within the landscaped setback, the sign base shall be located within a curbed landscaped area, extending a minimum of three (3) feet on all sides of the sign base. 
e.  The maximum size regulations above-described shall apply to all buildings not having approved private sign standards as set out next below. If such sign standards are utilized, the maximum size of wall and marquee signs shall be ten (10) percent of the area of the facade. Detached signs may not exceed thirty-five (35) feet in height nor have an area more than one hundred fifty (150) square feet per face nor more than three hundred (300) square feet total on all faces. 
f.  In the downtown B-5 areas where there is no front building setback, awnings can contain the name of the business. The business name cannot exceed twenty (20) percent of the total square footage of the awning. The business name can appear once per building facade. This type of signage is in addition to other sign requirements of this section. An under awning sign is also allowed in addition to other sign requirements of this section. The under awning sign must maintain a seven-foot vertical clearance above the sidewalk and cannot extend beyond the width of the awning. 
(6)  Within zoning districts B-4 and I. 
a.  All land uses which are not specifically referenced below, are permitted noncommercial signage of no less than the amount of signage authorized for the other uses within these districts. 
b.  Each business or commercial establishment shall be permitted not more than four (4) indirectly illuminated, semiilluminated, nonilluminated or directly illuminated wall or marquee signs, but only one (1) per facade. The total area of each sign shall not exceed twenty (20) percent of the total area of the facade upon which it is placed. In lieu of one of the attached wall signs, one (1) projecting sign subject to the limitations above is permitted for each establishment. 
c.  Additionally, one (1) detached sign shall be permitted for each building. Such sign shall not exceed thirty (30) feet in height above the average grade and the sign face shall not exceed six hundred (600) square feet in area per face, maximum of two (2) faces, nor more than twelve hundred (1,200) square feet on both faces. Such sign will be located ten (10) feet from the street right-of-way. For each additional one-foot setback from the street right-of-way, one (1) additional foot may be added to the height of the sign to a maximum of forty-five (45) feet. 
d.  In the case of a shopping center designed as one unified entity of one (1) or more buildings, one (1) detached sign per public street frontage is permitted. All other signs in the center shall consist of wall, projecting or marquee signs as otherwise permitted herein. The detached signs shall not exceed twenty (20) feet in height above the average grade and the sign face shall not exceed six hundred (600) square feet in area per face nor more than twelve hundred (1,200) square feet on all faces if located ten (10) feet from the street right-of-way. For each additional one-foot setback from the street right-of-way, one (1) additional foot may be added to the height of the sign to a maximum of forty-five (45) feet. If not sitting within the landscaped setback, the sign base shall be located within a curbed landscaped area, extending a minimum of three (3) feet on all sides of the sign base. 
e.  The maximum size regulations above described shall apply to all buildings not having approved private sign standards as set out next below. If such sign standards are utilized, the maximum size of wall and marquee signs shall be twenty (20) percent of the area of the facade. Detached signs may not exceed forty-five (45) feet in height nor have an area more than three hundred (300) square feet per face nor more than six hundred (600) square feet total on all faces. 
f.  Any detached sign within six hundred sixty (660) feet of the right-of-way of the interstate system of highways may be sixty (60) feet high. Such sign will be located ten (10) feet from the street right-of-way, and for each additional one-foot setback from the street right-of-way one (1) additional foot may be added to the height of the sign to a maximum of eighty-five (85) feet. 
g.  Within zoning districts B-4 and I, a business that has two (2) or more nonconforming detached signs may increase the square footage of the shortest sign. The shortest sign must be located within one hundred (100) feet of the interstate highway right-of-way. The shortest sign may be increased up to fifty-six (56) percent beyond its existing total square footage (all faces) to a maximum of four hundred sixty-six (466) square feet. This increase shall be limited to one (1) occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 3, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 3893, § 1, 10-16-90; Ord. No. 4031, § 1, 10-19-95; Ord. No. 4036, § 3, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 4148, § 1, 3-7-2000; Ord. No. 4187, § I, 7-3-2001; Ord. No. 4191, § 1, 9-18-2001; Admin. Inter. 9-19-2001; Ord. No. 4305, § 1, 1-16-2007) 
Sec. 7-244. - Private sign standards required. 
    The historic preservation commission shall review all signs proposed in designated landmark districts or sites. Sign permits shall not be issued until the ARB has approved the sign and issues a certificate of appropriateness. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 4, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 4, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 4305, § 1, 1-16-2007; Ord. No. 4347, § 1, 4-7-2009) 
Sec. 7-245. - Billboards or poster panels. 
    No billboard or poster panel shall be erected within the corporate limits except in compliance with the following procedures and standards: 
(1)  Written application for a billboard or poster panel permit shall be filed with the building official. 
(2)  The permit shall be issued if the billboard or poster panel meets the following standards: 
a.  Location within six hundred sixty (660) feet of the right-of-way of the interstate system or primary system of highways. 
b.  No larger than six hundred (600) square feet per sign face and no more than two (2) sign faces per billboard or poster panel. 
c.  Located on property zoned B-2, B-3, B-4, I and A. 
d.  A maximum height of forty-five (45) feet measured from the ground upon which the sign base is mounted. 
e.  Not within five hundred (500) feet of an existing billboard or poster panel. 
f.  Proposed poster panel or billboard must meet the minimum setback requirements for the zoning district in which it is to be located. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 5, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 5, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 4290, § 1, 9-5-2006; Ord. No. 4305, § 1, 1-16-2007; Ord. No. 4401, § 1, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 7-246. - Portable signs. 
(a)  Permit; standards. A portable sign shall be allowed by a portable sign permit issued by the office of the building official. Such permit will allow for the placement of one (1) portable sign per lot. A portable sign shall meet the size, height and setback requirements in the zoning district in which it is to be located. Portable signs and all wiring and connections shall meet the National Electrical Code, as adopted from time to time by the city. A portable sign cannot occupy any parking spaces required by the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Anchoring requirements. Anchoring of portable signs shall follow diagrams outlined in Appendix A attached to Ordinance Number 3791. Failure to comply with the above regulations placed on portable sign permits will immediately void the permit and subject the responsible party to penalties as provided herein. 
(c)  Display for sale or lease. Establishments offering portable signs for sale or lease may display such signs outdoors and have readable copy. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 6, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 6, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 4305, § 1, 1-16-2007) 
Editor's note- Appendix A, attached to Ord. No. 3791, is not printed herein; a copy is on file and available for reference, along with Ord. No. 3791, in the offices of the city. 
Sec. 7-247. - Temporary event signs. 
    Temporary event signs shall be allowed in all zoning districts and shall not exceed fifty (50) square feet per sign face. Such signs shall be allowed no more than thirty (30) days prior to the event or function and must be removed within ten (10) days after the event or function. No permit is required for a temporary event sign. Temporary event signs can be utilized for two (2) events per organization or business establishment per calendar year. 
    Temporary event attention attracting devices such as flags, small balloons (two (2) square feet maximum), streamers and pinwheels are permitted. Such devices shall be allowed no more than fourteen (14) days per event and must be removed within forty-eight (48) hours after the event or function. Temporary event attention attracting devices can be utilized for four (4) events per organization or business establishment per calendar year. 
    Attention attracting balloons for temporary events are permitted. Balloons are described as any display of an inflated object, including large inflated characters, blimps, replicas of hot-air balloons, etc., which are anchored to the ground, building or pole. These balloons are allowed in zoning districts B-1, B-2, B-3, B-4, and I. A permit is required for a temporary event balloon. Balloons cannot be flown at a height greater than the distance from the point of anchoring to adjoining property lines, streets or thoroughfares, or power lines. Balloons cannot be flown at heights in excess of one hundred (100) feet. The size of the balloon shall not exceed thirty (30) feet in length or fifteen (15) feet in height. Indirect lighting is permitted. The balloon shall be anchored in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations and the approval of the building official. The applicant must supply a plot plan and description of anchoring devices. Additional signage attached to tethers, part of the tether, or attached to suspended balloons is prohibited. Such devices will be allowed no more than fourteen (14) days per event and shall be removed within forty-eighty (48) hours after the event. These devices can be utilized for four (4) events per organization or business establishment per calendar year. 
    Snipe signs such as yard or garage sale signs are allowed only on private property. Such signs shall be posted no more than forty-eight (48) hours prior to the event and shall be removed within forty-eight (48) hours after the event. 
    Temporary (cloth signs) or banners on city property. Any bona fide not-for-profit organization maybe permitted to hang approved banners on city brackets. Only banners which are seven feet eight inches times three feet, and which comply with all other requirements of Resolution #3900 dated July 7, 1992, are permitted. A permit for such banners shall only be granted after submission in writing, on a form furnished by the community development department, and approved by the banner review committee. 
    Temporary event banners over public right-of-way. Bona fide not-for-profit organizations promoting or sponsoring civic, cultural, educational, scientific, industrial or economic development, tourism or government events may be permitted to hang approved temporary event signs overhead in the public right-of-way which are seventy-five (75) square feet in area or less, and comply with all other requirements of Resolution No. 3905, August 4, 1992. Applications for approval of temporary event signs shall be submitted in writing at least seven (7) days prior to regularly scheduled meetings of the banner review committee on a form furnished by the community development department. The temporary event signs may be in place no longer than thirty (30) days before and ten (10) days after the event with the allowable time to be determined by the banner committee. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 7, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 3848, § 1, 12-19-89; Ord. No. 4036, § 7, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 4305, § 1, 1-16-2007) 
Sec. 7-248. - Additional regulations applicable to all signs wherever located. 
(a)  Permit required; fee. Before a sign is erected a permit must be obtained from the office of the building official and a fee therefor must be paid in an amount or amounts to be periodically set by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Maintenance; appearance. All signs shall be of sound structural quality, not require sign alteration, be maintained in good repair, have a clean and neat appearance, and land adjacent shall be kept free from debris, weeds and trash. 
(c)  Construction; installation. All signs permitted as described in this article, unless otherwise provided, shall be constructed and installed according to the requirements and specifications set forth in the Standard Building Code, as adopted from time to time by the city. 
(d)  Any attention attracting device, as defined in section 7-242, is prohibited from use except for temporary promotions and shall be allowed no more than thirty (30) days prior to the event or function and must be removed ten (10) days after the event or function and can be utilized for two (2) events per calendar year. Such device must comply with the setback and height requirements of the district in which it is located. 
(e)  Snipe signs. Snipe signs are prohibited from use except under the guidelines of section 7-247, Temporary event signs. 
(f)  Location. No part of any sign shall be located less than five (5) feet from a side or rear property line, and no less than ten (10) feet from a street right-of-way line. 
(g)  Label, permit number. No sign except a temporary event sign shall be installed, exhibited, or set in place until a sign permit has been issued for it by the city. All signs shall have permanently affixed thereto a label, clearly visible at all times, indicating the permit number for such sign. 
(h)  Time and/or temperature instruments. Time and/or temperature instruments, as defined in section 7-242, may be permitted provided they are designed in harmony with the building and are architecturally compatible. 
(i)  Canopy signs. In the case of a freestanding canopy (such as a canopy over gasoline pumps), the canopy may have signs on the fascia of the canopy. 
(j)  Sign alteration, refacing; permit required. A sign permit shall be required for sign alteration or sign refacing. A permit is not required to change copy on signs with changeable copy displays. 
(k)  No permit for sign maintenance. A sign permit shall not be required for sign maintenance. 
(l)  Setbacks. No part of any sign shall be located less than five (5) feet from a side or rear property line and no less than ten (10) feet from a street right-of-way line. In instances where a sign setback of ten (10) feet from the public right-of-way is not physically possible, the building official may allow for a smaller sign setback from the right-of-way if, in his judgment, the placement of the sign will in no manner constitute a traffic hazard, create a nuisance or infringe upon the rights of an adjacent property owner. In no instances will a sign be allowed to be placed in the public right-of-way except for those signs allowed in B-5 zoning districts. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 8, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 8, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 4191, § 2, 9-18-2001; Admin. Inter. 9-19-2001; Ord. No. 4305, § 1, 1-16-2007) 
Sec. 7-249. - Qualified exceptions. 
    The following types of signs are exempt from all the provisions of this article, except for illumination, construction and safety regulations and the following separately described standards: 
(1)  Public signs. Signs of noncommercial nature and in the interest of, erected by, or on the order of, a public officer in the performance of his public duty, such as directional signs, regulatory signs, warning signs, and informational signs. 
(2)  Integral. Names of buildings, dates of erection, monumental citations, commemorative tablets and the like when carved into stone, concrete or other similar material or made of bronze, aluminum or other permanent type construction and made an integral part of the structure. 
(3)  Private traffic direction. Signs directing traffic movement onto a premises or within a premises not exceeding four (4) square feet in area for each sign. 
(4)  Political campaign signs. Signs concerning candidates seeking public office, political parties, groups or issues and other data pertinent thereto shall be permitted but shall be confined within private property and shall not encroach into the visibility triangle at street intersections. 
(5)  Identification signs. Signs bearing only property numbers, post box numbers, names of occupants or premises, professional or other identification of premises not having commercial connotations shall comply with the size requirements of the address designation ordinance, being Ordinance Number 3768 [Article VIII of this chapter]. 
(6)  Construction signs. One (1) sign on each roadway frontage not exceeding two hundred (200) square feet in area and bearing project information and names, addresses and telephone numbers of the contractors, architects, developers, planners, financial institutions, or engineers engaged in the construction project and only during the time construction or development is actively underway. Such signs should set back no less than ten (10) feet from any property line. 
(7)  Temporary (cloth signs) or banners. Any establishment may have a banner or temporary cloth sign without obtaining a sign permit. Such temporary cloth signs or banners may remain in place for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days. 
(8)  Historic signs. Signs previously painted on a building designated to be historic by the Meridian Historic Commission may be recreated after approval by the historic preservation commission. 
(9)  Electronic message signs. These signs will be allowed as an exception to the attention attracting device section by the following restrictions: 
a.  Electronic message signs will be allowed in zoning districts B-3, B-4, B-5, I, and P. An electronic message sign will be allowed on private school properties not zoned B-3, B-4, B-5, or I, as determined by the building official on a case by case basis, illuminated concurrent with normal school hours or school events. 
b.  Electronic message signs will be allowed in zoning districts B-3, B-4, B-5, I and P as part of the one (1) detached sign allowed per building as described in sections 7-243(5)c. and (6)c. and shall not exceed one hundred fifty (150) square feet in area in B-3 and B-5 districts and two hundred (200) square feet in area in B-4, I and P districts and will be part of and not in addition to the maximum area allowed for detached signs. On private school properties, the sign shall not exceed one hundred (100) square feet. for all faces, and shall not exceed thirty (30) feet in height above the average grade with set back determined by the building official on a case by case basis. Any deviation from these requirements require the approval of the community development director. 
(10)  Wall murals/paintings (wall art). The following wall art is in addition to wall signage described elsewhere in the sign ordinance. Any property owner desiring to paint, place or erect any painting, mural, public art, or works of art upon an exterior wall of buildings within the city must submit a written request to the community development department's public art review committee before said work is performed. The committee shall inform the applicant of application requirements and shall consider existing signage and the proposed wall art in making their decision. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 9, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 9, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 4042, § 1, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 4145, § 2-15-2000; Ord. No. 4155, § 1, 3-21-2000; Ord. No. 4305, § 1, 1-16-2007; Ord. No. 4347, § 1, 4-7-2009; Ord. No. 4387, § 1, 6-7-11) 
Sec. 7-250. - Removal of obsolete signs. 
    If a building, structure, or premises is vacated for a six-month period of time, the owner of the property shall be responsible for removing any sign or signs located thereon with the exception of advertisements dealing with lease or sale of the premises. The property owner shall also be responsible for removing a sign when the advertised business or activity is no longer conducted in or upon the premises which the sign is located. Additionally, the facade of the building, structure or premises shall be restored to its pre-sign appearance. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 10, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 10, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 4305, § 1, 1-16-2007) 
Sec. 7-251. - Nonconforming signs. 
(a)  Intent. Signs which were legally in existence prior to the adoption of this article which do not conform to the provisions of this article are declared nonconforming signs. It is the intent of this section to recognize that the eventual elimination, as expeditiously and fairly as possible, of nonconforming signs is as much a subject of health, safety, and welfare as is the prohibition of new signs that would violate the provisions of this article. It is also the intent of this section that any elimination of nonconforming signs shall be effected so as to avoid any unreasonable invasion of established property rights. 
(b)  General nonconforming sign provisions. Subject to the exceptions hereinafter set forth, any nonconforming sign may be continued in operation after the effective date of this article, provided that nonconforming signs shall not be: 
(1)  Changed to or replaced with another nonconforming sign. This does not include changing the sign face. 
(2)  Structurally altered so as to extend their useful life. 
(3)  Expanded. 
(4)  Relocated. 
(5)  Reestablished after damage or destruction of more than fifty (50) percent of the value at the time of such damage or destruction. 
(6)  Modified in any way that would increase the degree of nonconformity of such sign. 
Nothing in this article shall prevent the strengthening or restoring to a safe condition of any portion of a sign or structure declared unsafe by proper authority. Such signs may be improved only to the extent that such improvement does not exceed fifty (50) percent of the current market value of the existing structure. 
(c)  Termination of nonconforming signs. 
(1)  Any permanent nonconforming sign or sign structure which is partially destroyed or damaged by fire, accident, or natural cause beyond fifty (50) percent of its current market value shall thereafter be removed or reconstructed in conformance to the regulations of this article. 
(2)  Any permanent nonconforming sign or sign structure which is improved and altered to comply with the provisions of this article shall thereafter be considered as conforming. 
(3)  Snipe signs shall be removed within three (3) months of enactment of this article. 
(4)  Within three (3) months of the enactment of this article, all portable signs shall be removed and a portable sign permit must be obtained at which time the portable sign must conform to the provisions of this article. 
(5)  Any sign determined to be in the public right-of-way shall be removed one (1) month after notification thereof by the building official to the owner of such sign, if known. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 11, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 3893, § 2, 10-16-90; Ord. No. 4036, § 11, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 7-252. - Variances. 
(a)  Intent. Variances will not be allowed by this article except for setbacks. Setback variances will only be allowed to overcome some exceptional condition which clearly poses practical difficulty or particular hardship in such a way as to prevent an owner from displaying his/her sign as intended by this article. Such practical difficulty must be clearly exhibited and must be a result of an external influence; it may not be self-imposed. The building official will make setback variance determinations. 
(b)  Petition for variance: 
(1)  Standing. A petition for variation from the setback provision(s) of this article may be made by any person having a proprietary interest in the sign for which such variance is requested. 
(2)  Filing. A variance request shall be filed in writing with the building official and shall include the following information: 
a.  The names, addresses and telephone number of the petitioner, the owner of the property on which the sign is to be erected or affixed, the owner of the sign, and the person to be erecting or affixing the sign. 
b.  A description of the requested variance. 
c.  Clear justification of the requested variance. 
d.  The location of the building, structure, or lot on which the sign is to be erected or affixed. 
e.  A site plan of the property involved showing accurate placement thereon of the proposed sign. 
f.  A drawing of the plans and specifications of the sign to be erected or affixed and the method of construction and attachment to the building or the ground. Such plans and specifications shall include details of dimension, material, color and weight. 
g.  The written consent of the owner of the building structure or property on which the sign is to be affixed. 
h.  Such other information as the building official may require to determine full compliance with this [article] and other applicable ordinances of the city. 
(3)  Fees. The fee for a sign variance request shall be set by the city council by resolution. 
(c)  Standards for variances. In order for the building official to grant a variance from the setback requirements of this article: 
(1)  Special condition(s) and circumstance(s) must clearly exist which are peculiar to the location on which the sign is proposed. 
(2)  The special conditions or circumstances clearly must not result from the actions of the applicant. 
(3)  The granting of the variance will not confer on the applicant any special privilege denied to others in the same vicinity. 
(4)  Except for the provision for which a variance is requested, the sign or signs shall be in compliance with all other provisions and sections of this article and all other applicable ordinances of the city. 
(5)  The granting of the variance will not cause the proposed sign to conflict with utility and street fixtures or with traffic safety and required visibility at any time. 
(d)  Appeals. Any party aggrieved by an adverse recommendation on a variance may file an appeal of the decision of the building official to the board of zoning appeals. 
(1)  Procedure for appeals. No appeal shall be ruled upon by the board of zoning appeals until the following conditions have been met: 
a.  Written notice of appeal required. A written notice of appeal is required and shall state the decision being appealed and shall be given to the building official within fifteen (15) days from the date of such decision. The building official shall then forward to the board of zoning appeals the decision of the building official with all original documents and exhibits in the case. When an appeal is perfected in this manner, the board of zoning appeals may approve, deny, or delay action on the appeal, or where there is need for additional information may remand the case to the building official for further consideration. 
b.  Reserved. 
(2)  Appeal to the city council. An appeal from the decision of the board of zoning appeals may be appealed to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 12, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 12, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 7-253. - Enforcement. 
(a)  When the building official finds violations of the provisions of this article, the building official shall document the building official's findings, notify in writing the person or persons responsible for such violations and request necessary corrective action within thirty (30) days. The building official shall request removal of nonconforming signs, nonconforming additions, alterations, or structural changes and discontinuance of any illegal work being done. The building official shall take any other action authorized by this article to ensure compliance with or to prevent violation of its provisions. 
(b)  If voluntary compliance, as described above, is not obtained, the building official shall file a sworn complaint in the municipal court seeking the imposition of fines and imprisonment, as provided elsewhere herein, and the abatement of the nuisance created by the offending sign or ground condition. If the court finds the person responsible for the violations guilty, it shall enter a conditional order of abatement authorizing the city to abate the offending conditions if the same shall not have been abated within fifteen (15) days by the person responsible therefor. If such conditions are not abated within that time, the same shall be abated by the city and the costs thereof, plus a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent shall be paid by the person responsible. If the costs and penalty are not promptly paid, the city council, after notice to the responsible party of the date, time and place of a public hearing thereon, shall assess the costs of abatement, plus the twenty-five (25) percent penalty against the land upon which the offending condition or sign is located, if the owner thereof is the person guilty of such violation, otherwise the costs plus penalty shall be collected through a civil suit. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 13, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 13, 11-21-95) 
Sec. 7-254. - Penalty; nuisance. 
    Failure to comply with the regulations established in this article is a misdemeanor and shall subject the violator to a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or six (6) months in jail, or both. Each day during which a violation continues is a separate offense and shall subject the violator to additional penalties and confinement. The maintenance of a sign or ground condition contrary to the provisions of this article constitutes a nuisance and in addition to the other penalties, herein shall subject the person responsible for such condition or sign to an order of abatement. 
(Ord. No. 3791, § 14, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 4036, § 14, 11-21-95) 
Secs. 7-255-7-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - ALARM SYSTEMS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4126, adopted July 6, 1999, repealed former Art. X of this chapter in its entirety. Former Ch. X, §§ 7-261-7-266, 7-271-7-273 pertained to alarm systems and derived from Ord. No. 3912, §§ 1-9, adopted July 6, 1991. Sections 1-9 of Ord. No. 4126 enacted similar new provisions which have been included herein as Art. X at the editor's discretion. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 9-21 et seq.; police, Ch. 18. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY. 

Sec. 7-261. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish regulations and controls relating to the use and installation of fire, burglary and robbery alarm systems within the city, in order to ensure efficient utilization of the city's public safety resources, to eliminate false alarms, and to improve response to genuine emergencies. 
(Ord. No. 4126, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 7-262. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, certain words and phrases shall have the meanings and definitions ascribed to them in this section, unless a different meaning or definition is apparent from the context in which the word or phrase is used. 
    Act of God. An unforeseeable or inevitable occurrence, such as a tornado or lightning, occasioned exclusively by nature, and without human agency or interference. 
    Alarm. Shall have the same meaning as "alarm system", defined below. 
    Alarm business. The undertaking for profit by any person, partnership, corporation, firm, business or other entity of, selling, maintaining, servicing, inspecting, repairing, leasing, monitoring, altering, replacing, moving or installing any alarm or alarm system on or in any building, structure, place or facility, including, but not limited to, alarm businesses as defined herein who have their domicile with the State of Mississippi or outside the State of Mississippi, and who provide any alarm business services within the City of Meridian; provided, however, that the term "alarm business" shall not include any person, partnership, corporation, firm, business or other entity engaged in the manufacture or sale of an alarm system from a fixed location, who does not visit the location where the alarm system is to be installed and does not participate in the installation or design or monitoring of the installation at a specific location. 
    Alarm business privilege license. Upon proper application, the approval granted by the city to operate as an alarm business. 
    Alarm system. Any mechanical, electrical, or electronic device, which is designed or used for the detection of fire and/or any unauthorized entry into a building, structure or facility, or for alerting others of fire and/or the commission of an unlawful act within a building, structure or facility, or both, and which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message to a monitoring system which will result in a request for assistance from the fire department and/or police department. Devices that are not designed or used to register alarms that are audible, visible or perceptible outside of the protected building, structure or facility, are not included within the definition, nor are auxiliary devices installed by any telephone company to protect telephone company systems that might be damaged or disrupted by the use of an alarm system. For the purposes of this article, the term "alarm system" or "alarm" refers to each alarm system or alarm serving a single business or residence. 
    Audible alarm. Any mechanical, electrical or electronic device that is designed or used for the detection of fire and/or unauthorized entry into a building, structure or facility, or for alerting others of fire and/or the commission of an unlawful act within a building, structure or facility, or both, and which, when activated, emits a sound from a device(s), such as a bell or siren, which is installed in the interior, on the exterior, or both, of a building, structure or facility. 
    Central dispatch. The E-911 commission. 
    City. The City of Meridian, Mississippi. 
    City council. The elected city council of the City of Meridian, Mississippi. 
    False alarm. Any activation of an alarm system that is reasonably designed or intended to require a response by the fire department and/or police department, except alarms resulting from any one of the following causes: 
(1)  Criminal activity or unauthorized entry; 
(2)  High winds, causing structural damage; 
(3)  Flooding of the protected premises; 
(4)  An earthquake, causing structural damage; 
(5)  Lightning, causing physical damage to the protected premises; 
(6)  Fire, causing physical damage to the protected premises; 
(7)  Unforeseen power failure; or 
(8)  Maintenance of alarm devices and/or systems, provided central dispatch is notified beforehand, by the alarm user and its designated monitoring service. 
    Fire department. The City of Meridian Fire Department. 
    Grace false alarms. False alarms which are forgiven and are not subject to a service fee for fire department and/or police department response. 
    Malfunction. Activation of an alarm system, not due to fault or negligence on the part of the lessee, owner or user of the alarm system(s). 
    Person. Includes any natural person (masculine or feminine), corporation, association, firm, business, individual, and every other entity, both singular and plural. 
    Police department. The City of Meridian Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 4126, § 1, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 7-263. - Duties of license holders. 
    Every license holder shall comply with all provisions of this article applicable to license holders. 
(Ord. No. 4126, § 6, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 7-264. - False alarms. 
(a)  Service fee. Any owner, lessee, or user, having an alarm or alarm system on any premises, shall after six (6) grace false alarms or malfunctions per alarm system per calendar year, be required to pay a service fee for each fire department, police department, and/or other city service response, due to a malfunction or false alarm in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per response, beginning with the seventh false alarm or malfunction per calendar year. 
(b)  Reports. The fire chief, for fire alarms, and the police chief, for all other alarms, shall within thirty (30) days of each false alarm, give notice in writing to the licensee of the false alarm, stating the number of grace false alarms to date and the number of remaining grace false alarms before action will be taken to require a report, or further action. After the sixth grace false alarm, form an alarm user within a calendar year, the fire chief or police chief shall notify the user of the fact and require that the alarm user report to the appropriate chief within fifteen (15) days of the notice, describing the user's efforts to discover and eliminate the cause of the false alarms. The report may be extended by the chief giving notice, for a reasonable time, not to exceed forty-five (45) days. Failure to file the required reports as provided herein, is a violation of this article. 
(c)  Findings. If the fire chief, for fire alarms, or the police chief, for all other alarms, determines that the report is unsatisfactory or that the alarm user has failed to show that he or she has taken or will take reasonable action to eliminate false alarms, or if after making reports, the appropriate chief determines that the report is inadequate or does not make sufficient provision for rectifying problems with the alarm, then the user shall be deemed in violation of this article and shall be subject to suspension or revocation of licensure. 
(Ord. No. 4126, § 7, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 4248, § 1, 6-1-2004) 
Sec. 7-265. - Special provisions, exceptions, severability, and confidentiality. 
(a)  Direct dialing systems. No person shall send, cause to be sold, use or cause to be used, any telephone device or attachment that automatically selects, directly or indirectly, a public primary telephone trunk of central dispatch and produces any prerecorded message to report any fire, burglary, robbery, or other emergency, however, private alarm businesses and private alarm monitoring services may allow the use of auto-dialers, programmed to dial automatically, to the private alarm company or monitoring service. 
(b)  Exceptions. This article is not intended to, and shall not repeal, amend, or modify sections 9-1, 9-29, and 9-30 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Meridian. None of the provisions of this article shall apply to the following: 
(1)  Alarm or alarm system installed in a motor vehicle; 
(2)  Government agencies (federal, state, county, or municipal) equipped with an alarm system; 
(3)  Licensed agents involved in periodic maintenance and testing of permitted alarms and alarm systems, with prior clearance from the police chief. 
(c)  Severability. If any part or parts of this article shall be held by any court or administrative agency to be void or invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this article. 
(d)  Confidentiality. Information furnished, provided, and secured, pursuant to the application and criminal history investigation required under the terms of this article, shall be confidential and not subject to public inspection, except pursuant to a waiver of confidentiality executed by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 4126, § 8, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 7-266. - Violation, penalty, and enforcement. 
(a)  Violation. It shall be a violation of this article, for any person or other legal entity, to fail to obtain the required permit or license, to suffer, allow, or permit false alarms, to willfully submit false alarms, or otherwise to violate or refuse to comply with the terms of this article. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person who violates the terms of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 4126, § 9, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 7-267-7-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 14. 

Sec. 7-271. - License required. 
(a)  Alarm business. No person shall engage in, carry on, or conduct business within the city, without first applying in writing for and receiving an alarm business privilege license, therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article. The application shall be signed by the applicant himself or herself, if an individual; by a general partner, if a partnership; by an authorized representative, if a group or association; by the chief executive officer, if a corporation; or if a foreign corporation, by a resident local manager or local officer of such corporation. The application shall contain such information as the city may require. 
(b)  Bond required. Each applicant for an alarm business privilege license shall furnish to the city clerk, at the time of each application and renewal, a good and sufficient penal bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), conditioned the applicant shall comply with all provisions of this article and other ordinances related to alarm businesses and that the bond shall remain in full force and effect. No alarm business may do, carry out or offer alarm business services within the city at any time without having first furnished the required bond. 
(c)  Fees. Annual fees for original alarm business privilege licenses shall be as follows: Alarm business-Fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(d)  Period. All alarm business privilege licenses shall be issued for a period of one (1) year, and shall expire on the one year anniversary date. Alarm business privilege licenses not renewed with ten (10) days of expiration, shall incur a late charge of ten dollars ($10.00) per thirty (30) day period of delinquency, or part thereof. 
(e)  Fees cumulative. The fees imposed by this article shall be in addition to any and all fees or taxes imposed or required by state or local statutes. 
(Ord. No. 4126, § 3, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 7-272. - Specific licensing requirements; alarm business licensure. 
    All alarm businesses who wish to conduct such business in the City of Meridian shall first make application for an alarm business privilege license, on a form provided by the city. Approval of the application shall be subject to the following: a criminal history investigation; fingerprinting; and photographs. The police department shall conduct an investigation and no alarm business privilege license shall be issued by the city without approval by the fire chief, police chief, and city clerk. An alarm business privilege license shall be denied if: 
(1)  The applicant, his or her agent or employee, has made any false, fraudulent, misleading statement of fact or material fact, in the application of the alarm business privilege license or in any report or record required to be filed with any city agency or department; or 
(2)  The applicant has violated or failed or refused to comply with any of the provisions of this article; or 
(3)  The applicant had a similar privilege license revoked or denied within the past year, unless the applicant can show a material change in circumstances since the date of revocation or denial; or 
(4)  The applicant has been convicted of any felony, within the past ten (10) years. 
(Ord. No. 4126, § 4, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 7-273. - Denials, suspensions, and revocation. 
(a)  Licensure denials. Privilege licensure shall be denied, only for the reasons set forth in section 7-272. 
(b)  Suspensions and revocations. Any privilege license granted under the terms of this article may be suspended or revoked by the fire chief, police chief, or the city clerk for violation of any provision of this article. Any permit or privilege license so suspended or revoked, shall be surrendered to the city by the applicant, immediately upon receipt of notice of the action. The fire chief, police chief, or city clerk, shall give notice of suspension or revocation to the applicant, at the address shown on the application. No part of any permit or licensure fee or connection fee shall be refunded upon suspension or revocation. 
(c)  Appeals. Any person or other entity whose application for a permit or privilege license has been denied, suspended, or revoked, may appeal such decision within thirty (30) days of the date of notice of denial, suspension or revocation, to the city council. No formal hearing shall be allowed, although the city council may, in its discretion, allow the calling of witnesses, not to exceed three (3), in support of or in opposition to the appeal. The decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 4126, § 5, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 7-274-7-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - INTERNATIONAL RESIDENTIAL CODE[8]

Chapter 8 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Election of mayor and council members. 
    Beginning with those elected at the regular municipal election in the year 1985, and in all municipal elections thereafter, the city council shall be composed of five (5) members, one (1) of whom shall be a resident of each of the five (5) wards and shall be voted on and elected only by the qualified electors residing within the ward in which that council member resides, and the mayor shall be elected by the qualified electors of the city at large. 
(Code 1962, § 10-01; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 9-4-62; Ord. No. 3519, § 1, 2-25-77; Ord. No. 3549, § 2, 2-21-79) 
State Law reference- Election of mayor and council under mayor-council form of government, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-8-7. 
Sec. 8-2. - Election commissioners-Appointment, term, general duties. 
(a)  The mayor, subject to the approval of the city council, shall appoint five (5) election commissioners, one (1) of whom shall be designated to have printed and distributed the "official ballots", and who shall perform all duties with respect to municipal elections prescribed by law to be performed by the county election officials where not otherwise provided and such other duties as provided by the municipal charter and this chapter. 
(b)  Such election commissioners shall be appointed at the first regular meeting in October, as follows: Two (2) commissioners shall be appointed in October, 1994; two (2) commissioners shall be appointed in October, 1995; and one (1) commissioner shall be appointed in October, 1996. The commissioners as so appointed shall each serve for four (4) years from the date of their respective appointments or until their successors are appointed. 
(Code 1962, § 10-1; Ord. No. 3988, § 1, 9-6-94) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 23-15-221. 
Sec. 8-3. - Same-Compensation. 
    The election commissioners shall each be paid, by warrant on the general fund, seventy dollars ($70.00) per day for every day actually employed in the performance of their respective duties, not to exceed twenty-five (25) days for any one (1) election, after the accounts for such services have been examined, approved and allowed as provided in section 2-142 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 10-2; Ord. No. 4180, § 1, 2-20-2001) 
Sec. 8-4. - Same-Meetings; organization; procedures. 
    The election commissioners shall meet at the city clerk's office at 10:00 a.m., on the first Tuesday after their election, unless an earlier date and another hour be by them mutually agreed upon, for the purpose of organizing, at which meeting they may transact any business requiring attention, and may adjourn from time to time as business may require. Their methods of procedure and their performance of the duties they are authorized to perform, shall be the same, as near as may be, as provided for county election commissioners by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1962, § 10-3) 
Sec. 8-5. - Same-Printing, distribution of ballots. 
    The election commissioner appointed to have printed and distributed the official ballots to be used in elections, shall perform his duties in connection therewith, as near as may be, in the manner required by the state laws of the county commissioner appointed for similar purpose; and to each of the election managers who may be designated by proper authorities to receive and distribute the ballots at the several voting places, he shall deliver the requisite number of official ballots and cards of instruction for the voting place to which such election manager has been assigned. 
(Code 1962, § 10-4) 
Sec. 8-6. - Same-Duty to hear appeals concerning registrations. 
    The commissioners of elections shall meet whenever business may require and sit as a board to hear and determine appeals from the decision of the city registrars, or from the decision of the city clerk as registrar, as the case may be, allowing or refusing the application of any elector to be registered on the city registration book. 
(Code 1962, § 10-5) 
State Law reference- Provisions for appeal from registrars to county election commissioners, Miss. Code 1972, § 23-5-55; provisions applicable to municipal election commissioners, § 21-11-13. 
Sec. 8-7. - Same-Duty to review, revise registration and poll books. 
    The commissioners of elections shall review and revise the city registration books and poll books prior to every city election. 
(Code 1962, § 10-6) 
State Law reference- Requirement that county election commissioners review and revise registration books, Miss. Code 1972, §§ 23-5-79, 23-5-81; such provisions applicable to municipal commissioners, § 21-11-13. 
Sec. 8-8. - Election managers and clerks-Appointment, qualifications. 
    The election managers and clerks shall be appointed by the election commissioners from the qualified electors of the city prior to every election. They shall be discreet persons of good standing, not members of the city government, and shall be, as equally as possible, selected from opposing political parties. If any person appointed shall fail to attend and serve, the managers present, if any, may designate one (1) to fill his place; and if the election commissioners fail to make the appointments, or, in case of the failure of all those appointed to attend and serve, any three (3) qualified electors present when the polls should open may act as managers. Any person appointed to be manager or act as manager or appointed as clerk shall be a resident of the precinct in which the polling place is located. 
(Code 1962, § 10-7) 
State Law reference- Appointment of election managers and clerks, Miss. Code 1972, §§ 23-5-99, 23-5-103. 
Sec. 8-9. - Same-Oath. 
    Before entering upon the discharge of their duties, the managers and clerks shall be sworn by the city clerk or by some other officer authorized to administer oaths, faithfully to perform their duties at the election according to law, and not to attempt to guide, aid, direct or influence any voter in the exercise of his right to vote, except as expressly allowed by law. 
(Code 1962, § 10-8) 
Sec. 8-10. - Same-Compensation. 
    Election managers and clerks shall each be paid not to exceed seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per day and an additional ten dollars ($10.00) for the manager or person who shall carry the ballots, boxes, poll books and other necessities and an additional ten dollars ($10.00) for returning same, by check drawn on the general fund, for every day actually employed in the performance of their respective duties, not to exceed ten (10) days for any one (1) election. Managers attending the required training sessions shall be compensated at a rate not less than the federal hourly minimum wage nor more than ten dollars ($10.00) per hour, but for not more than two (2) hours of attendance. Such compensation shall only be paid after the accounts for such services shall have been examined, approved and allowed by the city council, as other accounts are approved and allowed as provided in section 2-142 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 10-9; Ord. No. 4180, § 2, 2-20-2001) 
State Law reference- Compensation of municipal managers and clerks to be same as county managers and clerks, Miss. Code 1972, § 23-5-184; compensation of county managers and clerks, § 23-5-183. 
Sec. 8-11. - Same-General duties. 
    The managers and clerks shall hold the election at the voting places for which they are respectively appointed. The managers shall take care that the election is conducted fairly and agreeably to law; they shall be the judges of the qualifications of electors, and shall discharge all other duties required by law, the municipal charter and this Code, of inspectors or managers of elections. The clerks shall keep a record of the names of the electors voting, shall keep count in the usual way, by tally sheets, of all the votes cast and announced by the managers for each and all of the candidates, and perform such other duties as are usually required of clerks of election. 
(Code 1962, § 10-10) 
State Law reference- General duties of election managers and clerks, Miss. Code 1972, §§ 23-5-101, 23-5-103; duty of managers to distribute ballots, § 23-5-131. 
Sec. 8-12. - Same-Duty to distribute ballots, instructions. 
(a)  At the time of appointing managers and clerks, the election commissioners shall designate one (1) of the managers at each voting place to receive and distribute the official ballots, to each of which managers so designated shall be delivered by the proper election commissioner the requisite number of official ballots and cards of instruction as provided by Mississippi Code 1972, section 23-5-121 for the voting place to which he has been assigned. 
(b)  The managers designated in accordance with this section shall remain at the polls at a convenient place for the distribution of the ballots to the voters at the voting places to which they have been respectively assigned; and, when requested by an elector entitled to vote, shall hand him an official ballot, but not until the managers shall have adjudged him entitled to vote, and shall discharge all the duties with respect to the distribution and care of official ballots, and the disposition of the cards of instruction, that are required by Mississippi Code 1972, section 23-5-131. 
(Code 1962, § 10-11) 
Sec. 8-13. - Voting wards established. 
    The City of Meridian is hereby re-apportioned and divided into five (5) wards, with each such ward being set out on the map attached hereto and marked as Exhibit A. The perimeter metes and bounds description of the five (5) wards, as re-apportioned, are declared to be as follows: 
Ward 1 
    Begin at the intersection of the centerline of King Road with the North line of Section 26, Township 7 North, Range 15 East; thence Southeasterly along the centerline of said King Road to its intersection with the centerline of 40th Street; thence East along the centerline of said 40th Street to its intersection with the centerline of Grandview Avenue; thence Southeasterly along the centerline of Grandview Avenue to its intersection with the centerline of 34th Street; thence East along the centerline of said 34th Street to its intersection with the centerline of 10th Avenue; thence North along the centerline of said 10th Avenue to its intersection with the centerline of North Hills Street; thence East along the centerline of said North Hills Street to its intersection with the centerlines of Newell Road and Lindley Road; thence Eastward along the centerline of Lindley Road to a point of intersection with the East line of the City of Meridian, said point being 1,320 feet West of the East line of Section 28, T7N, R16E; thence North, along the city limits, for a distance of 785 feet, more or less, to the North line of the Southeast 1/4 of the Southeast 1/4 of Section 28, T7N, R16E; thence East along said North line of the Southeast 1/4 of the Southeast 1/4 to the East line of said Section 28; thence North along the East line of said Section 28 to the North line of said Section 28; thence West along the North line of said Section 28 to the Southeast corner of the Southwest 1/4 of Southeast 1/4 of Section 21, T7N, R16E; thence North along the East line of the West 1/2 of the Southeast 1/4 of said Section 21 and continuing North along the East line of the West 1/2 of the Northeast 1/4 of said Section 21 to the Southwest corner of the Northeast 1/4 of Northeast 1/4 of said Section 21; thence West along the South line of the Northwest 1/4 of the Northeast 1/4 of said Section 21 to the Southwest corner of the Northwest 1/4 of the Northeast 1/4 of said Section 21; thence North along the West line of said Northwest 1/4 of the Northeast 1/4 of said Section 21 to the South right-of-way line of Country Club Road (also known as Dr. Pepper Road); thence East along the South right-of-way line of said Country Club Road to a point of intersection with the West right-of-way line of Lizelia Road; thence North along the West right-of-way line of Lizelia Road to a point on the South line of Section 15, T7N, R16E; thence East along the South line of said Section 15 to the Southeast corner of said Section 15, T7N, R16E; thence North along the East line of said Section 15 and continuing North along the East line of Section 10 and Section 3, T7N, R16E to its intersection with the North right-of-way line of Briarwood Road; thence West along the North right-of-way line of said Briarwood Road to its intersection with the Northwesterly extension of the South right-of-way line of Harvey Cut-Off Road; thence Southeasterly along the extended South right-of-way line of said Harvey Cut-Off Road to its intersection with the West line of Section 9, T7N, R16E; thence South along the West line of said Section 9 and continue South along the West line of Section 16, T7N, R16E to the Northeast corner of Southeast 1/4 of Southeast 1/4 of Section 17, T7N, R16E; thence West along the North line of said Southeast 1/4 of Southeast 1/4 to the Northwest corner thereof; thence South 330.27 feet along the West line of said Southeast 1/4 of Southeast 1/4 to a point; thence West to a point 330.27 feet South of the Northwest corner of Southwest 1/4 of Southeast 1/4 of said Section 17; thence North 330.27 feet to the Northwest corner of said Southwest 1/4 of Southeast 1/4 of said Section 17; thence West along the North line of the Southeast 1/4 of Southwest 1/4 of said Section 17 to its intersection with the Northerly line of Lot 5, Harrington Subdivision, as recorded in Map Book 10, Page 1 of the records of the Chancery Clerk of Lauderdale County, Mississippi; thence Northwesterly along the extended Northerly line of said Lot 5 to its intersection with the West right-of-way line of Poplar Springs Drive (Old Highway 39); thence Southwesterly along the West right-of-way line of Poplar Springs Drive to its intersection with the extended South right-of-way line of Old Country Club Road West; thence Southeasterly along the South right-of-way line of Old Country Club Road West to its intersection with the West line of Southwest 1/4 of Southeast 1/4 of Section 17, T7N, R16E; thence South along the West line of said Southwest 1/4 of Southeast 1/4 of said Section 17 and the West line of Northwest 1/4 of Northeast 1/4 of Section 20, T7N, R16E to the Southwest corner of said Northwest 1/4 of Northeast 1/4 of said Section 20; thence West along the North line of the South 1/2 of the Northwest 1/4 of said Section 20 to the West line of said Section 20; thence South along the West line of Section 20 to the Northeast corner of Northeast 1/4 of Southeast 1/4 of Section 19, T7N, R16E, thence South 0 degrees 14 minutes 49 seconds East 606.44 feet along the East line of said Northeast 1/4 of Southeast 1/4 to a point; thence in a Southwesterly direction along a curve having a delta of 44 degrees 36 minutes 21 seconds left, a radius of 124.07 feet, and an arc length of 96.59 feet; thence South 48 degrees 13 minutes 39 seconds West 94.04 feet; thence in a Southwesterly direction along a curve having a delta of 50 degrees 54 minutes 31 seconds right, a radius of 64.0 feet, and an arc length of 56.87 feet; thence North 80 degrees 51 minutes 50 seconds West 239.25 feet to the Eastern right-of-way of Poplar Springs Drive; thence South 6 degrees 53 minutes 50 seconds West along said Eastern right-of-way for a distance of 86.07 feet; thence South 80 degrees 51 minutes 50 seconds East 282.18 feet; thence South 86 degrees 34 minutes 15 seconds East 179.19 feet to point in the West line of Section 20, T7N, R16E; thence South along the West line of said Section 20 to its intersection with the North line of Section 30, T7N, R16E; thence West along the North line of said Section 30 and the North line of Section 25, T7N, R15E and the North line of Section 26, T7N, R15E to its intersection with the centerline of King Road and the point of beginning.

thence Northerly along the East right-of-way line of U.S. Highway 45 to its intersection with the North line of the South 1/2 of Section 34, T7N, R16E; thence West along the North line of said South 1/2 of said Section 34 and continue West along the North line of the South 1/2 of Section 33, T7N, R16E to its intersection with the Northwesterly right-of-way line of Old Marion Drive (formerly Old U.S. Highway 45); Sec. 8-14. - Polling places established. 
    Beginning with the regular municipal election in the year 2013, and in all municipal elections thereafter, each ward as hereinabove described shall be subdivided into voting precincts and each voting precinct shall be serviced, for voting purposes, by a designated polling place. Each such voting precinct and designated polling place shall be as described below and set forth on Exhibit B:
