No. 4066, § 2, 12-3-96; Ord. No. 4180, § 3, 2-20-2001; Ord. No. 4225, § 2, 4-15-2003; Ord. No. 4264, 3-1-2005; Ord. No. 4310, 2-6-2007; Ord. No. 4410, § 2, 7-17-2012; Ord. No. 4457, 5-5-2015; Ord. No. 4458, 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 8-15. - Elections to be held at polling places; clerks, managers for each polling place required. 
    All elections in the city shall be held at polling places hereinabove established and designated, and clerks and managers for holding all elections in the city shall be appointed for each of said polling places as provided by law until otherwise ordained. 
(Code 1962, § 10-14; Ord. No. 3177, § 4, 9-4-62; Ord. No. 3549, § 4, 2-21-79; Ord. No. 4066, § 3, 12-3-96) 
State Law reference- For appointment of managers, see Miss Code 1972, § 23-5-99; appointment of clerks, § 23-5-103. 
Sec. 8-16. - Preparation of ballots for mayor, councilmen. 
    The election commissioners and the executive committees holding elections and party primaries for the nomination and election of mayor and members of the city council shall cause ballots to be prepared so as to provide for the election of a mayor by the voters of the entire city, and one (1) council member from each of the five (5) wards created and established by this chapter. 
(Code 1962, § 10-15; Ord. No. 3177, §§ 5, 6, 9-4-62; Ord. No. 3549, § 5, 2-21-79) 
Sec. 8-17. - Opening, closing hours for polls. 
    The polls shall be opened at 7:00 a.m. and kept open until 7:00 p.m. as the city charter provides. 
(Code 1962, § 10-16) 
Sec. 8-18. - Arrangement of voting places. 
    The election commissioners shall make provisions at each of the voting places for the voters to approach the polls from one (1) direction, line, door, or passage, and, after having their ballots deposited, to depart in another direction as nearly opposite as convenient, as is required to be done by Mississippi Code 1972, section 23-5-109. 
(Code 1962, § 10-17) 
Sec. 8-19. - Duty to furnish ballot boxes, stationery, forms, custody of ballot boxes. 
(a)  Prior to every election the election commissioners shall procure from the city clerk a sufficient number of ballot boxes, which, secured by good and substantial locks, they shall distribute to the several voting places before the time for opening the polls. They shall also furnish to the managers and clerks at each voting place a sufficient quantity of stationery for use in holding the election, including blank forms to be used in making returns of the election. 
(b)  The ballot boxes used in elections shall be in the care and custody of the managers of the election, and shall be dealt with by the managers in all particulars as provided with respect to ballot boxes in county elections by Mississippi Code 1972, section 23-5-111, except that after each election the ballot boxes shall be delivered, with the keys thereof, to the city clerk for preservation, who shall keep them for future use, and when called for shall deliver them to the election commissioners. 
(Code 1962, § 10-18) 
Sec. 8-20. - Duty to furnish booths, equipment. 
    The city clerk, prior to every election, shall provide at each voting place a sufficient number of voting compartments or booths, shelves, and tables, also pen, ink, and blotting paper for each booth, for the use of voters, and perform all other duties with respect thereto as are required of the supervisors by Mississippi Code 1972, section 23-5-117. 
(Code 1962, § 10-19) 
Sec. 8-21. - Police to keep peace, prevent interference with elections. 
    The chief of police shall assign a sufficient number of policemen to each voting place, to be present during the election to keep the peace and to protect the voting place, to prevent interference with the election, improper intrusion and loitering about the voting place, and to perform such other duties as, in elections for state and county officers, are required of bailiffs by Mississippi Code 1972, sections 23-5-105 and 23-5-109. 
(Code 1962, § 10-20) 
Sec. 8-22. - Loitering about polls prohibited. 
    Every person entitled to vote shall have free and unobstructed access to the polls for the purpose of voting when others are not voting. The room in which the election is held, or a space of at least thirty (30) feet in every direction from the polls, shall be kept open and clear of all persons except the election officers and two (2) challengers. 
(Code 1962, § 10-21) 
Sec. 8-23. - Counting ballots, certification of results at each voting place. 
    The manager and clerks, after closing the polls, shall proceed immediately, in a public manner, to count the ballots cast at the several voting places over which they respectively have charge, and shall make a certificate of the result thereof, stating the number of votes cast at such voting place, the number of votes received by each candidate, and the names of the persons receiving the highest number of votes at such place for the respective offices. 
(Code 1962, § 10-22) 
Sec. 8-24. - Consolidation of results, certificate of totals; canvass by commissioners. 
(a)  The managers and clerks of the several voting places, after completing the count as required by the preceding section, shall meet in some convenient room in the city hall building, on the day following the election, at 10:00 a.m. and consolidate the votes cast for each candidate at the several voting places as shown by the certificates and returns of the election of officers for the several places as above provided, and shall make a certificate of the result of such consolidated votes. The certificate shall state the total number of votes cast at all the voting places, the total number received by each candidate, and the names of the persons receiving the highest number of votes for the respective offices after such consolidation. Such certificate shall be signed by all the managers and clerks of each and all the voting places. 
(b)  When the result of the election shall have been ascertained by the managers, they, or one (1) of their number, or some fit person designated by them, shall, by noon of the second day after the election, deliver to the commissioners of election, at the city hall a statement of the whole number of votes given for each person, and for what office; and the election commissioners shall canvass the returns, ascertain and declare the result. 
(c)  The election commissioners shall then file the, certificate of such election returns with the city clerk whereupon the city council shall by proper resolution, based on the election returns, forward the result to the secretary of state. 
(Code 1962, § 10-23) 
Secs. 8-25-8-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 8-36. - Persons entitled to register, vote. 
    The qualification of electors and their right to register and vote, shall be as provided by the constitution and laws of the state regulating the rights of persons to register and vote in municipal elections. 
(Code 1962, § 10-30) 
State Law reference- Qualifications of electors, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-11-1; registration generally, § 21-11-3. 
Sec. 8-37. - Illegal registration, registering under false name prohibited. 
    Any person who shall procure his registration as a qualified elector of the city when he knows that he is not entitled to be registered, or under a false name, shall, on conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 10-33) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 23-5-43. 
Sec. 8-38. - Appeals from denial of right to register or contesting registration of others. 
(a)  From denial of registration. Any person denied the right to register as a voter may appeal from the decision of the registrars, or from the decision of the city clerk, as the case may be, to the election commissioners, by filing with such registrars, or with the city clerk, on the same day of such denial, or within five (5) days thereafter, a written application for an appeal. 
(b)  Contesting registration. Any elector may likewise appeal to the election commissioners from the decision of the registrars, or of the city clerk, allowing any other person to be registered as a voter; but, before the appeal can be had, the party appealing shall give notice in writing to the person whose registration is appealed from, stating the grounds of the appeal, which notice shall be served by the chief of police or by any policeman as other process is required to be served, but no fee shall be demanded for the service by the officer serving same. 
(c)  Procedure. Whenever any such appeal as that provided for in this section is taken, the registrars, or the city clerk, as the case may be, shall immediately notify the election commissioners, who shall, as soon as practicable thereafter, meet in official session in some convenient room in the city hall for the purpose of hearing and acting upon the appeal, after having given to the party appealing, and to the person whose registration is appealed from, written notice of the time and place of such meeting at least one (1) day before the time of the meeting. 
(Code 1962, § 10-34) 
State Law reference- Provisions governing appeals from registrars, Miss. Code 1972, § 23-5-55 et seq. 
Sec. 8-39. - Form of registration books. 
    The registration books in which shall be registered the qualified electors of the city shall be, as near as may be, like the county registration books, the form of which is prescribed by Mississippi Code 1972, section 23-5-25, except that the first column shall be for numbers of the registration, and the book shall show precincts instead of districts of electors' residence. 
(Code 1962, § 10-35) 
Sec. 8-40. - Poll books-Required; form. 
    In addition to the general registration book in which all electors shall be registered, there shall be a poll book for each precinct of the city, to be kept by the city clerk as registrar, which shall have printed at or across the tops of the pages the following or similar words to designate the precinct and the purposes for which the book is to be used: "Registered Voters in Precinct _______, City of Meridian, Miss., With Election Commissioners' Revisions." The pages shall be ruled in columns, appropriately headed, one (1) column for each of the following purposes: Number of registration; date of registration; names of electors; age; after which there shall follow a number of columns, one (1) for each election, under the general heading, "Dates of Elections," with the following words of instruction added: "When elector votes, same to be indicated by election managers in proper column;" also a number of columns, one (1) for each election, under the general heading, "Revision by Election Commissioners," with the following words of instruction added: "If voter disqualified for any reason, election commissioners must note same in proper column below; that is, in column representing the year in which the election is to be held for which the revision is made." 
(Code 1962, § 10-36) 
State Law reference- Form of poll books under state law, Miss. Code 1972, § 23-5-73. 
Sec. 8-41. - Same-Form, contents of entries. 
    The name of each elector on the registration book, immediately after being registered there, shall be entered by the city clerk, in its alphabetical order, on the poll book of the proper precinct, together with the date on which each was registered, the number of each registration and the age of each elector, as the same appear on the registration book. 
(Code 1962, § 10-37) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 23-5-73. 
Sec. 8-42. - Same-Review, revision by commission. 
    Prior to every municipal election, general or special, the poll books shall be reviewed and revised by the election commissioners. The commissioners shall note thereon, in the proper column, such facts as they may find necessary to be noted with respect to the qualifications of any elector at the time of the revision. 
(Code 1962, § 10-38) 
State Law reference- Revision of poll books, Miss. Code 1972, §§ 23-5-79, 23-5-81. 
Sec. 8-43. - Same-Possession, use at elections; managers to be judges of qualifications. 
    At each municipal election the poll books shall be in the possession of the election managers, who, when any elector offers to vote, shall inquire into and satisfy themselves as to any facts found noted on the poll book by the election commissioners with respect to the qualifications of such elector. The election managers shall be the final judges of the qualifications of electors offering to vote as provided in section 8-11 of this chapter. The managers shall cause one (1) of the clerks to write in the proper column in the poll book the word "voted" opposite the name of each elector as he votes. 
(Code 1962, § 10-39) 
Sec. 8-44. - Custody, restricted use of registration and poll books. 
    The registration book and poll books shall be public records of the office of the city clerk and he shall carefully preserve them as such. He shall not take the registration book from the city hall for any purpose whatever, or permit the same to be done by any other person, except in obedience to process or orders of a court, nor shall the poll books be taken from such building except in obedience to such order, or except by the election commissioners when necessary to be done for the purpose of revision, or by managers and clerks of municipal elections for the purpose of holding any regular or special municipal election. The poll books shall not be furnished to managers and clerks of any primary election of any political party to be used by them in the conducting of such party primary, but copies of the entries on the poll books or registration book may be made by such managers or by any other person. 
(Code 1962, § 10-40) 
Sec. 8-45. - Procedure for new registration of electors. 
(a)  Whenever, in the opinion of the city council a new registration of the qualified electors of the city is necessary, the city council shall, by ordinance, order that a new registration be made on a certain date to be fixed and therein named, and that after six (6) months from the date the new registration begins such registration in effect at the time of the passage of the ordinance shall be null and void and of no effect. 
(b)  The mayor shall appoint two (2) registrars, who shall be residents and qualified electors of the city, one (1) from each political party whose duty it shall be, within ten (10) days of their appointment, to give ten (10) days' notice in some newspaper of general circulation in the city of the time and place of making such registration. 
(c)  Such registrars shall proceed to make a registration of the qualified electors of the city in every respect as the city clerk as registrar is hereinbefore required and directed to do. Such registrars shall continue the registration for thirty (30) days, commencing each day at 8:00 a.m. and closing at 5:00 p.m. 
(d)  Before entering upon the performance of their duties such registrars shall take and subscribe the oath of office prescribed by section 268 of the constitution of the state, to be administered by the city clerk or by any other officer authorized to administer oaths. 
(Code 1962, § 10-41) 
Sec. 8-46. - City clerk to continue new registration. 
    After such registrars shall have continued the new registration for the thirty (30) days as provided by the preceding section, the registration book shall be deposited with the city clerk, who shall thereafter be the registrar of the city, and shall continue the registration begun by such registrar, registering on such book, in his office at the city hall, any qualified elector who may apply for registration and who shall not have been registered by such registrars. 
(Code 1962, § 10-42) 
Chapter 9 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; alarm systems, § 7-261 et seq.; flood damage prevention and control, Ch. 10; housing, Ch. 13; planning, Ch. 17; subdivision regulations, Ch. 21; zoning regulations, App. A. 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for extinguishment and prevention of fires and authority to regulate certain activities and structures constituting fire hazards, see Miss. Code 1972, § 21-19-21; authority to establish and maintain fire department, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-25-3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Fire code. 
    There is hereby adopted as the official fire code of the City of Meridian that certain code identified and captioned as the "2012 International Fire Code," which said code having been presented to and examined by the city council in pamphlet form and now on file in the office of the city clerk of the City of Meridian. 
(Ord. No. 4384, §§ 1, 2, 4-5-2011; Ord. No. 4445, §§ 1, 2, 8-5-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4384, § 2, adopted April 5, 2011, repealed the former § 9-1, and enacted a new § 9-1 as set out herein. The former § 9-1 pertained to the adoption of the fire prevention and life safety codes and derived from the Code of 1962, § 11-27; Ord. No. 3253, adopted October 5, 1965; Ord. No. 3368, adopted October 6, 1970; Ord. No. 3585, adopted August 5, 1980; Ord. No. 3644, adopted July 6, 1982; Ord. No. 3741, adopted April 15, 1986; Ord. No. 3855, adopted March 6, 1990; Ord. No. 3948, adopted February 2, 1993; Ord. No. 4018, adopted July 5, 1995; Ord. No. 4092, adopted December 16, 1997 and Ord. No. 4176, adopted December 19, 2000. 
Cross reference- Building code, § 7-16 et seq.; mechanical code, § 7-31; plumbing code, § 7-71; gas code, § 7-91; electrical code, § 7-111; unsafe buildings abatement code, § 7-196; housing code, § 13-1. 
Sec. 9-2. - Responsibility for enforcement of fire prevention code. 
    The responsibility for enforcing the code adopted by this chapter shall be vested in the fire chief, the fire marshal and any fire inspectors designated in writing by the fire chief. These officials shall be and each of them are hereby granted authority to issue citations returnable to the city court or to the proper authority for violations of any of the provisions of the Standard Fire Prevention Code and the sections of the Code of Ordinances concerning fire zones and fire lanes and such citations shall have the same full force and effect as if issued by the police department of the city or any of its officers. 
(Code 1962, § 11-22; Ord. No. 3855, § 4, 2-6-90; Ord. No. 3919, § 1, 8-20-91) 
Sec. 9-3. - Parking propane, butane vehicles in fire district 1. 
    No truck or other motor vehicle used for the bulk transportation of liquefied compressed gases, commonly known as butane and propane, shall ever be parked in the number 1 fire district of the city, except in case of an emergency. 
(Code 1962, § 11-23) 
Sec. 9-4. - Location of propane, butane storage. 
    All bulk plants for storage of such gases shall be located outside the number 1 fire district of the city and storage tanks shall not be located closer than two hundred (200) feet to any building; provided, however, this section shall not apply to storage facilities existing on December 16, 1959 in the number 1 fire district, nor additional facilities that may be constructed on property already owned for such purpose and on which such bulk plants were located on December 16, 1959 within the number 1 fire district of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 11-24) 
State Law reference- For authority to regulate storage of flammable materials, see Miss. Code 1972, § 21-19-21. 
Sec. 9-5. - Bulk delivery of propane, butane in fire district 1. 
    No truck or motor vehicle used for transportation of such gases in bulk shall be used to deliver any such gases in the number 1 fire district of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 11-25) 
Sec. 9-6. - Fire lanes and fire zones. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section the following terms shall have those meanings respectively ascribed to them in this subsection; those terms or phrases not defined herein shall be accorded their usual and customary meanings. 
    Fire lane. That portion of any paved or improved surface designed and/or used for motor vehicular traffic which is officially designated as a required route of access for firefighting equipment. 
    Fire zone. That portion of any paved or improved surface immediately adjacent to any building or to any sidewalk and/or curb separating such building from an area designed and/or used for motor vehicular traffic which is officially designated as a required means of access to such building for firefighting personnel and equipment. 
(b)  Fire lanes; signs. All driving lanes or lanes of travel for motor vehicular traffic located upon any off-street parking area, drive, or alleyway maintained by the owner or management of any place of public assembly, hospital, apartment, or commercial building; or any complex of such buildings, shall constitute officially designated fire lanes required for the access of firefighting equipment, and appropriate signs giving notice thereof shall be erected and maintained at the entrance or entranceways to any such area. 
(c)  Fire zones; location and dimensions; signs. All fire zones, whether located upon publicly or privately owned property, shall be marked upon the surface thereof with forty-five-degree lines of reflectorized yellow paint each four (4) inches in width and no more than four (4) feet apart. All such fire zones shall be further marked by signs conforming to the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices permanently erected or installed every sixty (60) feet or such lesser distance as may be deemed necessary by the fire marshal. 
(d)  Authority of fire marshal to designate other fire zones and fire lanes. In addition to those fire lanes defined herein, the fire marshal shall have the authority to designate the location of such other fire lanes as shall be reasonably necessary and the authority to designate the location and dimensions of all fire zones, whether the same be upon publicly or privately owned property. The fire marshal shall require all such fire lanes and fire zones to be appropriately marked and signed. 
(e)  Penalties. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park, place, or stop any motor vehicle or trailer, whether attended or unattended, within a fire lane or fire zone, or to cause an obstruction of any kind or nature whatsoever to be placed or to remain for any period of time within any fire lane or fire zone marked and/or signed in accordance with this section. 
(2)  Any person who shall violate any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by the imposition of a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) or by imprisonment for a period of time not to exceed ninety (90) days or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(3)  Any unattended motor vehicle or trailer found parked or placed in violation of any of the provisions hereof may be impounded and reasonable towing and storage charge assessed against the owner thereof. 
(Ord. No. 3918, § 5, 8-20-91) 
Editor's note- Section 7 of Ord. No. 3918, adopted Aug. 20, 1991, provided for inclusion of §§ 1-5 of the ordinance as §§ 9-6-9-10. For purposes of classification the editor has included the provisions as § 9-6. 
Secs. 9-7-9-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2; additional compensation for firemen authorized, § 2-58; police, Ch. 18; following of fire apparatus or parking near fires prohibited, § 23-10; driving vehicles over unprotected fire hoses prohibited, § 23-11; permit required to use fire hydrants, § 25-15. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-21. - Existing department continued. 
    The fire department of the city as now constituted is hereby continued until changed by ordinance or resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 11-1) 
Sec. 9-22. - Composition. 
    The fire department of the city shall be composed of a chief and such number of assistants, officers, firemen, clerks and other employees as shall be determined from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 11-2) 
Sec. 9-23. - General duties of personnel. 
    In addition to the duties required by this article, by the laws of this state or as fixed from time to time by ordinance or resolution of the city council, the chief of the fire department and all personnel of such department shall take all proper steps to prevent, extinguish and suppress all fires within the corporate limits of the city and to aid in the rescue of persons and to prevent damage or injury to persons and property. 
(Code 1962, § 11-3) 
Sec. 9-24. - Number, location of fire stations. 
    The number of stations to be maintained, and the location of each shall be designated by the city council from time to time by ordinance. 
(Code 1962, § 11-10) 
Sec. 9-25. - Authority to cut dangerous, obstructing wires. 
    The chief of the fire department, or assistant chief, when in command of a fire, may cut or have cut any telegraph, telephone or electric light wires whenever the same is necessary to protect one (1) or more firemen or other persons from danger, or when such wires are obstructions to the firemen in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1962, § 11-11) 
Sec. 9-26. - Authority to destroy buildings, walls, fences. 
    The chief of the fire department, or the assistant chief, when in command of any fire, shall have authority to pull down or remove, or cause to be pulled down or removed, any building or fence or wall when, in his judgment, it is necessary to suppress the conflagration or prevent the spreading of the fire. 
(Code 1962, § 11-12) 
Sec. 9-27. - Damaging apparatus, hindering department prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage any fire engine belonging to the city, or any of the apparatus thereto belonging, or to place any obstruction in the way so as to hinder in any manner the free access to any engine, or hook and ladder carriage or hose carriage, or other apparatus, at any time, or to damage or remove any of the fire hooks or ladders from their proper places of deposit, except at the alarm of fire for the purpose of extinguishing the fire, or by the order of the proper officer for the purpose of washing, cleansing, repairing or other necessary purpose. 
(Code 1962, § 11-13) 
Sec. 9-28. - Interfering with apparatus prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere in any manner with any fire engine, hook and ladder truck, hose, carriage, or other fire apparatus while on its way to or from a fire, or while at a fire, or upon any other occasion. 
(Code 1962, § 11-14) 
Sec. 9-29. - Interfering with, damaging fire alarms prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except for the purpose of turning on an alarm of fire, to interfere with the fire alarm telegraph in any manner whatever, or to damage any box, wire or other property connected therewith. 
(Code 1962, § 11-15) 
Sec. 9-30. - False alarms prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully, maliciously or mischievously to create a false alarm of fire by turning on a false alarm or by any other method whatsoever. 
(Code 1962, § 11-16) 
Secs. 9-31-9-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE CHIEF 

Sec. 9-41. - Supervision of department, personnel. 
    The chief of the fire department, subject to the general supervision of the mayor, shall have direction and control of the fire department, and may prepare and promulgate, from time to time, such reasonable rules and regulations, as he may deem advisable, for the government of the department and employees composing the same, not in conflict with the city charter or with the laws and regulations passed by the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 11-4) 
Sec. 9-42. - Duty to direct operations at fires; obedience by personnel. 
    The chief, or the assistant chiefs under the direction of the chief, shall attend all fires and alarms, and shall have sole direction of the operations of the department at fires. They shall locate the engines and other apparatus as they arrive at fires, and shall assign to them and to the several employees such positions and service as their judgment dictates. All officers and employees must obey their orders strictly. 
(Code 1962, § 11-5) 
Sec. 9-43. - Records, reports required. 
    The chief of the fire department shall keep an accurate account of all fires and of all alarms, and shall keep an account of the origin or supposed origin of all fires, the amount of loss incurred and amount of insurance on the destroyed or damaged property in each case, and shall, at the first meeting in January of each year, make full report thereof for the year just closed, to the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 11-6) 
Sec. 9-44. - Duty to inventory department property. 
    The fire chief shall, prior to the first day of January of each year, furnish to the mayor an inventory of all the property belonging to the city used by or in charge of the fire department. 
(Code 1962, § 11-7) 
Sec. 9-45. - Duty to report condition of department property. 
    The chief of the fire department shall report to the mayor, on the first Monday of January of each year, and at such other times as he may deem advisable or necessary, the condition of the apparatus, hose, buildings, and any other property of the department, together with any information or suggestion which might be beneficial to the city or the fire department. 
(Code 1962, § 11-8) 
Sec. 9-46. - Assistant to perform duties during absence, inability. 
    In the event of the absence of the chief of the fire department, or his inability to serve from any cause, an assistant chief shall assume the responsibilities of the chief and discharge the duties of his office. 
(Code 1962, § 11-9) 
Secs. 9-47-9-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPEN BURNING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4435, adopted May 6, 2014, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III, §§ 9-61-9-65, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 4093, §§ 1-6, 2-3-98. 

Sec. 9-61. - Designation. 
    This article may be cited as the "Open Burning Ordinance of the City of Meridian." 
(Ord. No. 4435, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 9-62. - Open burning. 
    It shall be unlawful to cause the production of emission of dense smoke or to openly burn debris, rubbish, domestic or commercial waste, or any other material within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 4435, § 2, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 9-63. - Violation; penalty. 
    Anyone violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine and/or imprisonment as described in section 1-9 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Meridian, Mississippi. 
(Ord. No. 4435, § 3, 5-6-2014) 
Secs. 9-64-9-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIRE DISTRICTS[4] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. 3772, adopted Mar. 24, 1987, did not specifically amend this Code, hence, inclusion of §§ 1-3 as §§ 9-71-9-73, comprising a new Art. IV, was at the discretion of the editor.
