    This article shall not apply to any machine operated for gambling purposes, to any machine kept at a regular place of business of distributors or manufacturers for sale or lease without being operated, or to any pool table operated in a place of business commonly known as a pool hall or billiard parlor is taxable under the state's sales tax law. 
(Code 1962, § 16-65; Ord. No. 3357, § 6, 6-30-70) 
Secs. 14-130-14-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - DEALERS IN USED PRECIOUS METALS, ETC 

Sec. 14-146. - Permit-Required. 
    Every person acquiring, purchasing or otherwise dealing in antique, used or scrap jewelry, gems, flatware, silverware, silver, gold or other precious metals in whatever form, or used tape recorders, bicycles, radios, televisions, stereos, cameras, guns and tools, for the purpose of resale, pawn, barter or exchange either in original form or in the case of jewelry and precious metals in a remounted, melted or reformed state, shall be required to obtain a permit from the chief of police prior to engaging in such business, which permit shall be valid for not more than one (1) year. 
(Code 1962, § 16-71; Ord. No. 3599, § 1, 3-18-81; Ord. 3622, § 1, 9-16-81) 
Sec. 14-147. - Same-Application. 
    To obtain a permit, applicants shall supply to the chief of police the following information: 
(1)  Name, social security number, and date of birth of applicant, and if a corporation, firm, partnership or other entity, the names, social security numbers and dates of birth of all officers and directors (and/or members of the firm or partnership) each of whom shall be designated as to their office; 
(2)  Address of applicant, and, in addition, if a corporation, firm, partnership or other entity, the address of all officers and directors, firm members or partners; names of employees, social security numbers and dates of birth and their addresses; 
(3)  Criminal convictions, other than traffic offenses of applicant, officers, directors, firm members or partners and employees; 
(4)  Street address of place from which business is to be conducted, and the location where items described in section 14-146 above shall be kept during the time period set forth in section 14-149 hereof; 
(5)  A recent photograph of applicant, officers, directors, firm members, partners and employees; 
(6)  The days of the week and hours of the day during which business will be conducted. 
A willful providing of false information shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 16-72; Ord. No. 3599, § 2, 3-18-81; Ord. No. 3622, § 2, 9-16-81) 
Sec. 14-148. - Same-Revocation; grounds therefor. 
    Upon conviction of a violation of any provision of this article or upon the failure to comply with its terms, the chief of police shall revoke any permit issued pursuant to the provisions hereof. 
(Code 1962, § 16-79; Ord. No. 3599, § 9, 3-18-81; Ord. No. 3622, § 9, 9-16-81) 
Sec. 14-149. - Five-day holding period. 
    It shall be unlawful for any such person engaging in the activity described in section 14-146 above, for a period of five (5) days from the date of such purchase or other acquisition to sell, exchange, pawn, barter, or remove from the place in which such business is conducted, or in case the place of business is located in a motel or hotel, the room or rooms in which the business is conducted, or such other place as may be approved by the chief of police, or to change the form of any of the items described in section 14-146 above by remounting, melting, cutting up, dismantling or otherwise to change the form of any of such items, or to change the serial number or other identifying nomenclature on any of such items of personalty. 
(Code 1962, § 16-73; Ord. No. 3599, § 3, 3-18-81; Ord. No. 3622, § 3, 9-16-81) 
Sec. 14-150. - Items to be kept separately. 
    During the five-day period set forth and provided for in section 14-149, all items described in section 14-146 hereof shall be kept physically separated according to the date of purchase or other acquisition and shall not be commingled with any other personalty. 
(Code 1962, § 16-74; Ord. No. 3599, § 4, 3-18-81; Ord. No. 3622, § 4, 9-16-81) 
Sec. 14-151. - Transaction log required. 
    Every person dealing in the items described in section 14-146 above shall maintain a log in duplicate and shall enter on such log a clear and accurate description of any items described in section 14-146 which are purchased or otherwise acquired and the date and amount of money or other thing of value paid for said items and the name, race, sex, driver's license (state and number), residence and address of the seller. The seller and the purchaser shall each sign the log acknowledging the accuracy of the description of such items sold and the consideration paid for such items. For each day the person described in section 14-146 shall purchase or otherwise acquire any of the items described in section 14-146, such person shall deliver to the chief of police in a manner designated by him a copy of the log concerning that day's business, such copy of such log to be delivered by noon of the day following. The original log shall be carefully preserved without alteration and kept at the place of business and shall at all times be open and available for inspection by the chief of police or his designee. Failure to log each purchase or other acquisition of any item described in section 14-146 shall constitute a separate violation of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 16-75; Ord. No. 3599, § 5, 3-18-81; Ord. No. 3622, § 5, 9-16-81) 
Sec. 14-152. - Failure to comply constitutes an offense. 
    Each day a person engaging in the activities defined in section 14-146 shall fail to obtain a permit from the chief of police or maintain a log as required, or shall fail to deliver to the chief of police a copy of the log for which provision is herein made or other violation of this article continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1962, § 16-76; Ord. No. 3599, § 6, 3-18-81; Ord. No. 3622, § 6, 9-16-81) 
Sec. 14-153. - Presumption that items were acquired for resale. 
    In any criminal proceeding hereunder the holder of a permit issued pursuant to the terms of this article shall be presumed to have acquired, purchased or otherwise come into the possession of the items described in section 14-146 hereof for purposes of resale. 
(Code 1962, § 16-78; Ord. No. 3599, § 8, 3-18-81; Ord. No. 3622, § 8, 9-16-81) 
Sec. 14-154. - Provisions inapplicable re repossession of security. 
    This article shall not apply to the repossession of any item described in section 14-146 hereof pursuant to a lawful security agreement. 
(Code 1962, § 16-80; Ord. No. 3599, § 10, 3-18-81; Ord. No. 3622, § 10, 9-16-81) 
Sec. 14-155. - Penalties. 
    Every person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall, on conviction thereof, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-9 of this Code, for each offense. 
(Code 1962, § 16-77; Ord. No. 3599, § 7, 3-18-81; Ord. No. 3622, § 7, 9-16-81) 
Secs. 14-156-14-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - STREET FOOD VENDORS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3771, adopted Mar. 24, 1987, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-7 as Art. IX, §§ 14-171-14-177, was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Peddlers, ambulatory vendors selling food or beverages, § 11-3; permits for sales of food, etc.; in or adjacent to public parks, § 11-4. 

Sec. 14-171. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Approved public location is any portion of a public way designated by the street food vendor advisory board for occupancy by a street food vendor. 
    Food means any organic substance or nonalcoholic beverage to be hand-delivered from a pushcart, capable of being consumed by humans, including, but not limited to, any bread, meat, sauce, garnish or vegetable. "Food" shall not include any fresh vegetable or meat or other farm produce from the garden or land of the person offering the same for sale, nor shall it include such things as honey, molasses, preserves, jellies, juices or milk or other products sold in nonindividual servings. "Food" shall not mean any plate lunch, cake, pies, breads, roasts, casseroles or other dishes of multiple-serving size traditionally designed for consumption by more than one (1) average person. 
    Public way is any public street, avenue alley, highway, stream, creek and the banks thereof, park, parking lot of a public building and other public lands within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Pushcart means a mobile nonmotorized cart, wagon or other similarly constructed object, upon which is attached and located equipment and facilities for storage, refrigeration or heating of any food to be hand-delivered to customers for off-premises consumption. 
    Street food vendor means any person, firm or corporation that sells food from a pushcart at an approved public location within the city. 
    Street food vendor advisory board means the board composed of the following officials of the city: the director of the department of parks, recreation and cultural affairs, the building official and the main street manager. 
(Ord. No. 3771, § 1, 3-24-87) 
Sec. 14-172. - Street food vendor advisory board. 
(a)  Created. There is hereby created a "street food vendor advisory board" (hereafter "advisory board") to be composed of the director of the department of parks, recreation and cultural affairs, the building official and the main street manager of the city. 
(b)  Designations of approved locations. The advisory board is hereby delegated the responsibility to designate places as approved public locations within the public way for operation of-pushcarts by street food vendors and shall hold a public hearing annually to receive public comments before making upon such designations. In making such designations the advisory board shall consider the traffic flow, proximity to tourist attractions and shoppers, presence of other food establishments within seventy-five (75) feet of any proposed location, types of food to be sold, hours of operation and other such factors as may bear upon the public convenience and necessity for such an operation. Temporary approved public locations may be designated during such events as public festivals, fairs, sporting events and other similar activities of short duration. 
(c)  Approval, disapproval of licenses. The advisory board shall have final approval or disapproval of licenses to operate and shall annually assign to licensed owners approved public locations for a twelve-month period or less. 
(d)  Permits for motorized road vendor vehicles. The advisory board shall also consider and approve applications for permits for the operation of motorized food vendor vehicles in the public parks and, in that regard, shall apply all the provisions this article which are not uniquely applicable to pushcarts. The director of the department of parks, recreation and cultural affairs shall designate the location for the sale of food from such vehicles and the days and hours of operation of such, after due regard for the policy reflected in section 11-4 of this Code, which limits food sales in the parks, otherwise these motorized food vendors are excepted from the limitations of such section. 
(e)  Annual report. The advisory board shall annually make a report of its actions to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3771, § 3, 3-24-87; Ord. No. 3812, § 1, 9-6-88) 
Cross reference- Food and food handlers, Ch. 11; permit for sale of food, etc., in or adjacent to parks, from street food vendor advisory board, § 11-4. 
Sec. 14-173. - License-Required; fee. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who desires to offer for sale and to sell any food, as defined herein, from a pushcart at a location within the public way or from a motorized food vendor vehicle in the public parks within the corporate limits of the city shall first obtain a license from the city and pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) annually for each such pushcart or fees of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) annually and five dollars ($5.00) for each day's operation for each motorized food vendor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 3771, § 2, 3-24-87; Ord. No. 3812, § 2, 9-6-88) 
Sec. 14-174. - Same-Application; contents and procedure. 
(a)  Before the advisory board shall grant a license to a street food vendor, the person, firm or corporation desiring to conduct such business shall first file a sworn application with the tax office, which application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, age and business and home addresses of the owner and proposed operators for the past five (5) years; 
(2)  List of any misdemeanor or felony convictions of the owner and proposed operators for the past five (5) years; 
(3)  Statement of the financial condition of the owner, indicating any civil judgments rendered against such person and any bankruptcy proceedings against or by such person. Three (3) local credit references shall also be provided; 
(4)  Descriptions of the types of food proposed to be sold, hours of operation, address of off-site location where such pushcart, food and equipment shall be prepared, cleaned or maintained and address of the approved public location desired; 
(5)  Size and descriptions of the pushcart and equipment; and 
(6)  Other such information as the advisory board shall, from time to time, deem appropriate to include on such application. 
(b)  The tax office shall cause the application to be investigated and forward its finding and the application to the advisory board. The advisory board shall review the application; interview the owner; determine the location where the vendor may operate; and either issue or deny the license. The license shall be conditioned upon the submission within thirty (30) days to the tax office of the following: 
(1)  A certificate of insurance for public liability for property and personal injury, in an amount to be designated by the advisory board, from some reputable company authorized to do business in the state, naming the city as coinsured; 
(2)  A copy of the health certificate or certificates from the state board of health shall be filed with the tax office certifying that the pushcart, the owner and operators and the off-site maintenance and food preparation location, if any, meet all health regulations; and 
(3)  If heating facilities are to be utilized on the pushcart, the owner shall submit a copy of a certificate of inspection from the fire department indicating approval of such pushcart. 
(Ord. No. 3771, § 4, 3-24-87) 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 9-21 et seq.; health and sanitation, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 14-175. - Same-Revocation. 
    The tax office shall revoke a license to operate for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Nonuser of the location for a period of thirty (30) days by a licensed owner between April 1 and October 31 of any year; 
(2)  Failure to maintain health and fire inspection certificates; 
(3)  Conviction of any felony or misdemeanor of the operator or owner involving moral turpitude; 
(4)  Conviction by the municipal court for breach of any of the rules, regulations and restrictions herein set forth. 
(Ord. No. 3771, § 6, 3-24-87) 
Sec. 14-176. - Requirements for operation. 
(a)  Cleanliness; litter; trash containers; breakable food containers. The area surrounding the approved public location shall be policed and kept clean daily for a distance of fifty (50) feet from all spillage or leakage of food or other substances and any and all litter, whether generated by the operation or the public at large. A clean, plastic-linered metal trash container clearly marked for litter shall be kept and maintained upon the approved location and emptied daily or more frequently as conditions warrant. No breakable containers of any kind shall be sold or used as containers for food. 
(b)  Distribution of handbills or menus; noise; music. The operator shall not distribute handbills or menus from the location and there shall be no loud and offensive noises or music emitted from the location, unless approved by the advisory board as compatible with the occasion or location. 
(c)  Off-premises delivery of food; supply deliveries; sales to persons in motor vehicles; alcoholic beverages; nonprescription drugs. No deliveries of food off-premises shall be made and the public way shall not be blocked or obstructed for purposes of supply deliveries. Sales to persons sitting in motor vehicles shall not be made. No nonprescription drugs or alcoholic beverages shall be sold, kept or used or used on the premises by any person. 
(Ord. No. 3771, § 5, 3-24-87) 
Cross reference- Distributing of advertising matter, etc., § 3-2; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 5; garbage, trash and refuse, § 12-16 et seq.; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20; obstructing streets or sidewalks generally, § 20-21. 
Sec. 14-177. - Penalties; appeals. 
    Any owner or operator who violates any provision of this article may be assessed a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first offense and a mandatory fine of at least fifty dollars ($50.00) for any subsequent offense, upon a proper complaint filed in and proceedings held before the municipal court. Appeals from any license revocation by the tax office or adjudications and assessments of fines by the municipal court may be had to the appropriate state court. 
(Ord. No. 3771, § 7, 3-24-87) 
Chapter 15 - MOBILE HOMES AND TRAILERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 17; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9; flood damage prevention and control, Ch. 10; housing, Ch. 13; planning, Ch. 17; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20; subdivision regulations, Ch. 21; water and sewers, Ch. 25; zoning regulations, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Powers and duties of building official. 
    The building official of the city is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all provisions of this chapter, and for such purpose, he shall have the powers of a police officer. His duties shall include inspecting applications and the premises regarding the issuance of permits for the location of trailer and mobile home units by any person, partnership or corporation within the city limits. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-1; Ord. No. 3376, § 1, 4-6-71) 
Sec. 15-2. - Application for permit to locate mobile home or trailer within city. 
    Any person, partnership or corporation desiring to locate a trailer or mobile home within the city limits of the city shall make application for same to the planning and inspection department of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-2; Ord. No. 3376, § 2, 4-6-71) 
Sec. 15-3. - Fee to accompany application. 
    Any person making such application shall pay unto the city such a fee of five dollars ($5.00) to accompany such application. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-3; Ord. No. 3376, § 3, 4-6-71) 
Sec. 15-4. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who violates or refuses to comply with, or who resists enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter may be arrested and brought before a court of competent jurisdiction and, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-5; Ord. No. 3376, § 5, 4-6-71) 
Secs. 15-5-15-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION, INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Placement of manufactured homes in floodways, § 10-57(4); standards for manufactured homes in flood hazard areas, § 10-59. 

Sec. 15-21. - Applicability of article. 
    All mobile homes and travel trailers placed, used and/or occupied in the city, shall be governed by the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-16; Ord. No. 3473, § 1, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-22. - Definitions. 
    Wherever used in this article the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
    Accessory structure. Any structural addition to the mobile home which includes awnings, cabanas, carports, porches and similar appurtenant structures. 
    Agent. Any person authorized by the licensee of a mobile home or trailer park to operate or maintain such park under the provisions of this article. 
    Alley. A way which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property. 
    Building. A roofed structure erected for permanent use. 
    Building official. The building official in charge of the building department of the city and his authorized agents. 
    Density. The number of mobile homes or travel trailer stands per gross acre. 
    Driveway. A minor private drive used by vehicles and pedestrians on a mobile home lot or for common access to a small group of lots or common facilities. 
    Fees. Charges made by the city for administrative expense. 
    Hardship cases. Humanitarian circumstances whereby the owner of an individual lot of record or a member of his or her immediate family may require temporary housing. 
    License. A written document issued by the city tax assessor allowing a person to operate and maintain a mobile home development under the provisions of this article. 
    Lot area. The total area reserved for exclusive use of the occupants of a mobile home. 
    Lot line. A line bounding the lot as shown on the accepted plot plan. 
    Lot of record. A lot which is part of a subdivision recorded in the office of the chancery clerk of the county, or a lot or parcel described by metes and bounds, the description of which has been so recorded. 
    Mobile home or mobile home unit. A movable or portable dwelling designed without a permanent foundation for year round living. It includes single units but also may consist of one (1) or more units that can be telescoped when towed and expanded later for additional capacity, or of two (2) or more units, separately towable but designed to be jointed into one (1) integral unit. 
    Mobile home lot. A parcel of land for the placement of one (1) mobile home and the exclusive use of its occupants. 
    Mobile home park. Any tract of land developed or used for the purpose of accommodating more than one (1) mobile home occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes, whether or not a charge is made for such accommodations. 
    Mobile home stand. That part of an individual mobile home lot which has been reserved for the placement of the mobile home. 
    Occupied area. That area of an individual mobile home lot which has been covered by a mobile home and its accessory structures. 
    Operator. A person who manages a mobile home or travel trailer park for another or who operates such a park that he leases from an owner. 
    Park management. The person who owns or has charge, care or control of the mobile home development. 
    Permanent building. A building, except a mobile home accessory structure. 
    Permit. A written permit or certification issued by the building official permitting the construction, alteration and extension of a mobile home or travel trailer park under the provisions of this article and regulations issued hereunder. 
    Plat. Any map, plan or chart of a city, town, section or subdivision, indicating the location and boundaries of individual properties. 
    Plot. A parcel of land consisting of one (1) or more lots or portions thereof which is described by reference to a recorded plat or metes and bounds. 
    Private street. A private way which affords principal means of access to abutting individual mobile home lots and auxiliary buildings. 
    Public street. A public way which affords principal means of access to abutting properties. 
    Public systems (water and sewerage). Systems which are owned and operated by the city and which are adequately controlled by the city. 
    Service building. A building housing toilet, lavatory and other facilities as may be required by this article and is used by the public. 
    Setbacks. The areas on the same lot with a mobile home between the lot line and the front, rear or side of a mobile home stand. This includes areas which must remain clear of all structures such as enclosed patios, expandable rooms, garage or other additions. 
    Sewer connection. A connection consisting of all pipes, fittings and appurtenances from the drain outlet of the mobile home to the inlet of the corresponding sewer riser pipe of the sewerage system serving the mobile home development. 
    Sewer riser pipe. That portion of a sewer lateral which extends vertically to the ground elevation and terminates at a mobile home or travel trailer stand. 
    Special exception. A special exception is a use that would not be appropriate generally or without restriction throughout the zoning district but which, if controlled as to number, area, location or relation to the neighborhood, would promote the public health, safety, welfare, morals, order, comfort, convenience, appearance, prosperity or general welfare. 
    Tiedowns. Structural means used to secure mobile homes to the mobile home lot. 
    Travel traveler. A vehicular, portable structure built on a chassis, designed to be used as a temporary dwelling and to be towed behind a motor vehicle. 
    Travel trailer park. Any premises on which one (1) or more pickup coaches or travel trailers are parked or situated and used for the purpose of supplying to the public a parking space for one (1) or more such coaches or trailers. 
    Zoning ordinance. The comprehensive zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-17; Ord. No. 3473, § 2, 9-3-74) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-23. - Enforcement authorization; right of appeal. 
(a)  The building official is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce the provisions of this article. Upon presentation of proper credentials, he or the authorized members of his staff may enter upon the premises of any mobile home or travel trailer park, or any building or structure thereon, located in the city, during reasonable hours, to perform any duty imposed upon him by this article. 
(b)  Any owner of a mobile home or travel trailer park shall, if aggrieved by a decision of the building official, have the right to appeal to the zoning board of appeals created under the comprehensive zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-18; Ord. No. 3473, § 3, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-24. - Prohibited parking. 
    Except as may be otherwise authorized herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to permanently park or temporarily or otherwise occupy any mobile home on any street, alley, highway or other public place, or on any parking lot or on any residential, commercial or industrial property not specifically zoned for the occupancy of such mobile homes. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any travel trailer on any street, alley, highway or on any municipal property for more than one (1) hour. It shall also be unlawful for any mobile home dealer or any other person to deliver any mobile home to any property not specifically zoned for the occupancy of mobile homes, or to place or set up any mobile home on any property not specifically zoned for the occupancy of mobile homes. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-19; Ord. No. 3473, § 3, 9-3-74; Ord. No. 3535, § 1, 2-21-78) 
Sec. 15-25. - Use restriction. 
    No person shall use or occupy a mobile home or travel trailer as a place of business on any lot or tract of ground within the corporate limits of the city, except as an office; provided, any such unit so used is connected to the public water and sewerage system and to all other utilities, as required herein, and conforms to all city codes and ordinances as required; except that, upon approval of the building official, all other requirements contained herein may be waived. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-20; Ord. No. 3473, § 3, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-26. - Location restrictions. 
    No person shall use or occupy any mobile home unit permanently for living or sleeping purposes on the same lot or parcel of land with a residence building, whether the latter be occupied or unoccupied, nor a vacant tract of land or lot which is not a part of an approved mobile home or travel trailer park within the city. It shall be unlawful to connect or extend any public utilities to any mobile home unless such unit is located in an approved mobile home or travel trailer park. The zoning board of appeals, in cases of hardship, may grant a special exception to this section upon an application signed by the owner of the property and by the owners and tenants of all adjacent property. For special exceptions a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be assessed for the first six (6) months, and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) renewal fee for each six (6) months thereafter. Also, as a special exception to this section, the owner of any residence building condemned and demolished under the provisions of the housing code of the city and situated in either a C-1 district or a C-2 district under the official zoning ordinance of the city may replace such residence at any time within one (1) year after its demolition with a mobile home for the occupancy only of the owner and the owner's family. In no case shall a mobile home placed under a special exception be rented to anyone or be used for any purpose other than the purpose authorized by the zoning board of appeals. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-21; Ord. No. 3473, § 3, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-27. - Self-contained unit restrictions. 
    No person shall use or occupy permanently any mobile home or travel trailer unit equipped with self-contained plumbing fixtures unless such fixtures are connected to the city sewer disposal system or approved by the state board of health. Such complete self-contained portable system and connections to the city disposal system shall comply with all city and state plumbing requirements. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-22; Ord. No. 3473, § 3, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-28. - Park licenses; applications. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate and maintain a mobile home or travel trailer park in the city without first securing a privilege license from the city tax collector and renewing such license annually. Such license shall be displayed at all times in the office of the pertinent park. 
(b)  Application for such license shall be filed with the tax collector. Such application shall be by a written letter of request or on a form furnished by the city and shall be signed by the owner. Before issuing any such license the tax collector shall submit the application to the building official for endorsement indicating compliance with the applicable requirements of this article or the indication in writing of conditions under which such license may be approved. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-23; Ord. No. 3473, § 4, 9-3-74) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 15-29. - New park licenses; building permits required for alterations. 
(a)  Building permits in accordance with the provisions of the city's building code shall be obtained before beginning construction of any new park or alteration or addition thereto. An application for said privilege license shall be initiated at the time of securing such permits. Upon satisfactory completion of construction and final inspections thereof, the building official shall endorse such application without additional charge and upon payment of the prescribed fee, the tax assessor shall issue the license. Annually thereafter, the license may be renewed upon compliance with the conditions stipulated hereinabove. 
(b)  A building permit shall be obtained before beginning construction of any alteration or addition, including foundation and tie-down work, on all mobile home units located on individual sites and in all existing parks. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-24; Ord. No. 3473, § 4, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-30. - Inspection required; fees. 
(a)  Applications for initial licensing of existing parks and thereafter the annual renewal of such license for all parks shall be conditioned on an inspection of the premises by the building official, or his designated representative, to permit endorsement of such application as required in section 15-28(b) above. 
(b)  All applications for initial licenses and all renewals therefor shall be accompanied by an inspection fee calculated on the basis of a minimum of ten dollars ($10.00) or one dollar ($1.00) for each lot or space together with any other structures and improvements located thereon, whichever is greater. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-25; Ord. No. 3473, § 4, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-31. - Park planning. 
(a)  All mobile home and travel trailer parks as they exist, including an approved park plan on the effective date of this article shall not be affected by any of the construction standards contained herein; however, any additions or expansions of existing parks and any new parks shall be subject to the full provisions of this article including approval of the planning commission as to location and general layout. 
(b)  All of the provisions of this article shall apply to all mobile home and travel trailer parks situated beyond the corporate limits of the city when such parks utilize city water and/or sewerage. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-26; Ord. No. 3473, § 5, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-32. - Nonresidential uses forbidden. 
    No part of any park shall be used for nonresidential purposes except such uses as are required for the servicing and well being of the park residents and for the management and maintenance of the park. Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed as prohibiting the sale of a mobile home located on a mobile home stand and connected to the pertinent utilities. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-27; Ord. No. 3473, § 5, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-33. - Environmental requirements. 
    The site shall not be exposed to objectionable smoke, dust, noise, odors or other adverse influences, and no portion subject to predictable sudden flooding or erosion and shall not be used for any purpose which would expose persons or property to hazards. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-28; Ord. No. 3473, § 5, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-34. - Applications for zoning. 
    For planning commission review, two (2) copies of the site plan drawn to scale shall be submitted not less than five (5) days prior to the meeting at which it is to be considered for zoning. Such site plan shall clearly set forth the proposed plan of development showing the general park layout and the extent of all physical improvements and facilities to be provided, including the following: 
(1)  The boundaries of the property as indicated by an accurate survey; 
(2)  When full construction of a park is planned for development by stages, indicate the stages or units in which the park will be developed. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-29; Ord. No. 3473, § 5, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-35. - Minimum standards for improvements, park areas, density, recreation areas. 
(a)  In reviewing site plans for new mobile home or trailer parks or the expansion of or addition to existing parks, the planning commission shall consider the following minimum standards for improvement and development, which upon approval of zoning shall be presented in every pertinent detail with the application for a building permit as required in section 15-29(a). 
(b)  Any proposed new park shall not have less than eight (8) mobile home or travel trailer lots which conform to the requirements of this article. 
(c)  The maximum density of mobile homes shall be regulated by separation requirements, occupied lot area ratios and recreation area requirements as set forth in this article. Density may vary considerably in accommodating different sizes of mobile home units with its accessory structures used in the locality and in the type of layout proposed. 
(d)  No mobile home shall be located closer than fifteen (15) feet from any other mobile home or permanent building within the mobile home development. 
(e)  Mobile home stands shall not occupy an area in excess of one-third of the respective lot area. The accumulated occupied area of the mobile home and its accessory structures on a mobile home lot shall not exceed eighty (80) percent of the respective lot area. 
(f)  Not less than eight (8) percent of the gross site area shall be devoted to recreational facilities generally provided in a central location. Recreation area may include facilities such as indoor recreation area, swimming pools and similar uses. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-30; Ord. No. 3473, § 6, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-36. - Streets. 
(a)  General. All mobile home developments shall be provided with safe and convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets or roads to each mobile home lot. Such access shall be provided by streets and driveways paved with concrete or asphalt. 
(b)  Entrance streets. Entrance to mobile home developments shall have direct connections to a public street and shall be designed to allow free movement of traffic on such adjacent public streets. Such entrances from the property line to the public street shall be paved according to city specifications. 
(c)  Circulation. The street system shall provide convenient circulation by means of minor streets and properly located collector streets. Dead-end streets shall be limited in length to five hundred fifty (550) feet and the closed end shall be provided with an adequate vehicular turnaround (one hundred (100) feet diameter cul-de-sac). 
(d)  Pavement widths. Pavements should be a minimum of thirteen (13) feet per moving lane with ten (10) feet extra width per side for parallel parking if provided. 
(e)  Street grades. Grades of all streets shall be sufficient to ensure adequate surface drainage but should not be more than twelve (12) percent. 
(f)  Intersections. Street intersections should generally be at right angles. Off-sets at intersections and intersections of more than two (2) streets at one (1) point should be avoided. 
(g)  Street lights. Lighting shall be designed to produce a minimum of two-tenths (0.2) of a footcandle throughout the street system. Potentially hazardous locations such as major street intersections and steps or stepped ramps shall be individually illuminated with a minimum of six-tenths (0.6) footcandle. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-31; Ord. No. 3473, § 6, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-37. - Mobile home lot limits. 
    The limits of each mobile home lot shall be marked on the ground by suitable means. Location of lot limits on the ground shall be the same as shown on approved plans. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-32; Ord. No. 3473, § 6, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-38. - Setback and open space. 
(a)  There shall be a minimum of fifteen (15) feet of space in all directions between a mobile unit and any permanent building. For the purpose of this section, covered patios, carports or individual storage buildings shall not be considered as permanent buildings, provided that no such patio roof, carport or storage building shall be located closer than five (5) feet to any mobile unit lot line. 
(b)  Mobile units shall be located at least fifteen (15) feet from any side or rear property line of the park boundary and at least twenty (20) feet from any front property line; provided, however, that at any intersection of public streets bounding a park, no mobile unit or permanent structure of any kind shall be located within a triangle formed by a diagonal line connecting points on the two (2) street property lines measured twenty-five (25) feet along the property lines of each of the streets from the street corner intersection. 
(c)  Mobile units shall be set at least fifteen (15) feet from any park, interior street or guest parking areas. 
(d)  Individual mobile home lots may have open, unenclosed or roofed patios or carports of metal, fiberglass or other combustible material, provided such structures follow the setback and spacing requirements established herein. 
(e)  Mobile units together with accessory structures such as storage buildings and roofed-over patios or carports shall not cover more than eighty (80) percent of a mobile unit lot. 
(f)  Paved driveways shall be provided on lots for convenient access to mobile homes. The minimum width shall be ten (10) feet for solid driveways and two (2) feet six (6) inches each for strip driveways. 
(g)  Parking spaces. The design criteria for automobile parking shall be based upon one (1) parking space for each mobile home lot. Parking may be in tandem. 
(h)  Outdoor living area. Each mobile home lot shall be provided with an outdoor living and service area. Such area shall be improved as necessary to assure reasonable privacy and comfort. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-33; Ord. No. 3473, § 6, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-39. - Foundations and tie-downs-Required. 
(a)  Every mobile home located within the city shall be equipped with adequate foundations and tie-downs intended to secure such units against movement, settling and overturning for the protection of life and property. 
(b)  All mobile homes moving into a park shall comply with the requirements of this section within forty-five (45) days after arrival. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the mobile home park owner or operator to notify their tenants of the foundation and tie-down requirements of this article. Where the tenant refuses to comply with such requirements, it shall be the responsibility of the owner or operator to notify the building official. The building official shall take whatever enforcement procedures he deems necessary to enforce compliance by the tenant. 
(d)  The building official shall furnish a copy of this article to each owner or operator of a mobile home park. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-34; Ord. No. 3473, § 6, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-40. - Same-Requirements. 
(a)  Generally. Every mobile home stand shall be improved to provide adequate supports for the placement and tie-down of all mobile units. 
(b)  Footings or foundations. When concrete slabs, runners or strips are provided as required below, piers or blocking may be placed thereon, provided: 
(1)  a.  Such strips or runners are a minimum of four (4) inches in thickness and reinforced with not less than ten (10) gauge wire mesh. 
b.  Such slabs, runners or strips may be a minimum of six (6) inches compacted gravel with a one-inch minimum asphalt surface. In such event, foundation footings and tie-down anchorage requirements shall apply, as below. 
(2)  Strips or runners shall be not less than thirty (30) inches wide. 
(3)  Slabs, strips or runners shall be not less than the length of the mobile unit to be placed thereon. 
(4)  Eyebolts for tie-down equipment may be set in the concrete slabs, strips or runners as required below. 
(c)  Footing dimensions. When individual or spot footings are used for piers or blocking, such footings shall be a minimum sixteen (16) inches by sixteen (16) inches by four (4) inches concrete block spaced as required below. 
(1)  All piers or blocking shall provide a maximum spacing of ten (10) feet, center to center, measured along the frame rail of the unit installed thereon. 
(2)  All such piers or blocking shall be not less than eight (8) inches by eight (8) inches by sixteen (16) inches solid or hollow load bearing concrete units. Where hollow units are used, all voids shall be placed in a vertical position. 
(3)  Shims, if required, shall be placed between the beam frame and the pier to provide a level and rigid unit installation. 
(d)  Storage. No space beneath any mobile home shall be used for any storage other than the unit wheels, tires and garden tools unless the storage area of such unit is surfaced with concrete or asphalt. 
(e)  Skirting. Skirting shall be installed around the entire perimeter of such mobile unit with adequate access provided for inspections. 
(f)  Minimum tie-downs. 
(1)  General. Since the city is located within the inland area of the established storm or windload region, either the frame or "over the roof" or both methods of tie-down anchorage may be used. At least one (1) of these methods shall be a mandatory requirement to be installed as provided herein-below. 
(2)  Number of tie-downs required. All mobile home stands shall be provided with tie-downs as follows: 
Length of frame Number of Ties Up to 30 feet ..... 2 per side 30 feet to 50 feet ..... 3 per side 50 feet to 70 feet ..... 4 per side Over 70 feet ..... 5 per side  
(3)  Ground anchor. All ground anchors shall be as follows: 
a.  Types. Anchors shall be bolted in concrete, screw auger or anchor driven or any other type manufactured and approved for use. 
b.  Size. All anchors shall be galvanized, high tensile steel not less than five-eighths of an inch in diameter, with a drop forged closed eye or any other approved method of anchorage. All anchors shall be not less than four (4) feet in length, installed to full depth, according to manufacturer's recommendation, with only the eye protruding above grade for connecting the tie-down system. 
c.  Connections to the mobile home I beam frame shall be a five-eighths-inch or larger drop forged closed eye bolted through a hole drilled through the frame or by any other approved and adequate wrap-around, hood or clamp method. 
d.  Not less than five-eighths-inch drop forged turnbuckles with closed eyes and screw pins shall be attached to the frame above and ground anchor below and securely tightened in place. Steel straps or cables may be used in lieu of turnbuckles if they are of equal or greater strength and are securely tightened in place with a tensioning tool and clamped. 
(g)  Homes located in areas of special flood hazard. Mobile homes located in areas of special flood hazard shall be governed by the requirements of section 10-59. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-35; Ord. No. 3473, § 6, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-41. - Water, sewerage and gas. 
    Every mobile home and travel trailer park shall contain a water, sewerage and, if applicable, gas piping system consisting of piping, equipment and appurtenances which shall be installed and maintained in accordance with the requirements of the city's plumbing and gas codes. Any mobile home unit equipped for the use of LPG gas may continue the use of such system. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-36; Ord. No. 3473, § 7, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-42. - Electrical systems. 
(a)  General. Every mobile home and travel trailer park shall contain a wiring system consisting of wiring, fixtures, equipment and appurtenances which shall be installed and maintained in accordance with the National Electrical Code adopted by the city. At least twenty-five (25) percent of the parking spaces shall have service entrance equipment capable of handling a minimum of two hundred (200) amperes at 120/240 volts single phase. The remaining seventy-five (75) percent of the spaces shall have service entrance equipment capable of handling a minimum of one hundred (100) amperes at 120/240 volts single phase. 
(b)  Power distribution lines. Main power lines and all service wiring may be installed underground or overhead. Mobile home park owners may choose either method as offered by the local electric utility. 
(c)  Installation requirements. Electrical systems installed in every mobile home and travel trailer park shall be in accordance with the National Electrical Code. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-37; Ord. No. 3473, § 8, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-43. - Fire protection. 
(a)  The water supply system of mobile home and travel trailer parks shall permit the operation of a minimum of two (2), two and one-half-inch hose stems. 
(b)  Barbecue pits, fireplaces and wood burning stoves shall be so located, constructed, maintained and used as to minimize fire hazards and smoke nuisance both on the property on which used and on neighboring property. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-38(e), (h); Ord. No. 3473, § 9, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-44. - Refuse handling. 
(a)  The storage, collection and disposal of refuse in mobile home and travel trailer parks shall be conducted in a manner to create no health hazards, rodent harborage, insect breeding areas, fire hazard or water or air pollution. 
(b)  It shall be the joint responsibility of each occupant and the management to ensure that all refuse containing garbage is stored in an approved container as specified by article II of chapter 12 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(c)  Where central collection facilities are established for the collection of refuse, garbage or trash, pending removal by the hauler, such facilities shall be in accordance with the specifications of the city. 
(d)  Any private or contract hauler collecting and disposing of such trash and garbage shall submit evidence that all disposals will be made at a site or facility approved by the county health department. 
(e)  Every transient or travel trailer park shall provide its own garbage and trash container which shall be in accordance with paragraph (c) of this section. 
(f)  Any mobile home park desiring garbage and trash disposal service by the city shall submit a letter of agreement for approval by the city engineer. Such agreement shall hold the public works department harmless for any and all damage that may occur to the private streets in said park and to any automobile or other property located therein. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-39; Ord. No. 3473, § 10, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-45. - Insect and rodent control; debris control; maintenance of storage areas; exterior openings; control of weeds and brush. 
(a)  Grounds, buildings and structures shall be maintained free of insect and rodent harborage and infestation. Extermination methods and other measures to control insects and rodents shall conform with the requirements of the state board of health. 
(b)  Parks shall be maintained free of accumulations of debris and stagnant water which may provide rodent harborage or breeding places for flies, mosquitoes and other pests. 
(c)  Storage areas shall be so maintained as to prevent rodent harborage; lumber, pipe and other building material shall be stored at least one (1) foot above ground. 
(d)  Where the potential for insect and rodent infestation exists, all exterior openings in or beneath any structure shall be appropriately screened with wire mesh or other suitable materials. 
(e)  The growth of brush, weeds and grass shall be controlled to prevent harborage of ticks, chiggers and other noxious insects. Parks shall be so maintained as to prevent the growth of ragweed, poison ivy, poison oak, poison sumac and other noxious weeds considered detrimental to health. Open areas shall be maintained free of heavy undergrowth of any description. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-40; Ord. No. 3473, § 11, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-46. - Compliance with article; notification of residents; management supervision; register of occupants; contagious diseases. 
(a)  The person to whom a license for a mobile home park is issued shall operate the park in compliance with this article and shall provide adequate supervision to maintain the park, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(b)  The park management shall notify park occupants of all applicable provisions of this article and inform them of their duties and responsibilities under this article. 
(c)  The park management shall supervise the placement of each mobile home on its mobile home stand which includes securing its stability and installing all utility connections. 
(d)  The park management shall maintain a register containing the names of all park occupants identified by lot number or street address. Such register shall be available to any authorized person inspecting the park. 
(e)  The park management shall notify the health department immediately of any suspected communicable or contagious disease within the park. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-41; Ord. No. 3473, § 12, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-47. - Responsibilities of occupants; placement of home; pets; porches and storage; disposition of trash. 
(a)  The park occupant shall comply with all applicable requirements of this article and shall maintain his mobile home lot, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(b)  The park occupant shall be responsible for proper placement of his mobile home on its mobile home stand and proper installation of all utility connections in accordance with the instructions of the park management. 
(c)  Pets, if permitted in the park, shall be subject to the Code of Ordinances of the city. 
(d)  Porches, awnings and other additions shall be installed only if permitted and approved by the park management. When installed, they shall be maintained in good repair. The space immediately underneath a mobile home shall be used for storage only if permitted by the park management. If permitted, the following conditions shall be satisfied: 
(1)  The storage area shall be provided with a base of impervious material. 
(2)  Stored items shall be located so as not to interfere with the underneath inspection of the mobile home. 
(e)  The park occupant shall store and dispose of all his rubbish and garbage in a clean, sanitary and safe manner. The garbage container shall be rodent-proof, insect-proof and watertight. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-42; Ord. No. 3473, § 12, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-48. - Zoning board of appeals; duties; special exceptions; guidelines for granting special exceptions. 
    The duties of the zoning board of appeals shall be to hear and decide only such special exceptions as the board is specifically authorized to pass on by the terms of this article; to decide such questions as are involved in determining whether special exceptions should be granted; and to grant special exceptions with such conditions and safeguards as are appropriate under this article, or to deny special exceptions when not in harmony with the purpose and intent of this article. A special exception shall not be granted by the zoning board of appeals unless and until: 
(1)  A written application for a special exception is submitted indicating the section of this article under which the special exception is sought and stating the grounds on which it is requested. 
(2)  The zoning board of appeals shall make a finding that it is empowered under the section of this article described in the application to grant the special exception, and that the granting of the special exception will not adversely affect the public interest. 
(3)  Before any special exception shall issue, the zoning board of appeals shall make written findings certifying compliance with the specific rules governing individual special exceptions and that satisfactory provision and arrangement has been made concerning the following, where applicable: 
a.  Ingress and egress to property and proposed structures thereon with particular reference to automotive and pedestrian safety and convenience, traffic flow and control, and access in case of fire or catastrophe; 
b.  Off-street parking and loading areas where required, with particular attention to the items in a. above and the economic, noise, glare, or odor effects of the special exception on adjoining properties and properties generally in the district; 
c.  Refuse and service areas, with particular reference to the items in a. and b. above; 
d.  Utilities, with reference to locations, availability, and compatibility; 
e.  Screening and buffering with reference to type, dimensions and character; 
f.  Signs, if any, and proposed exterior lighting with reference to glare, traffic safety, economic effect and compatibility and harmony with properties in the district; 
g.  Required yards and other open space; 
h.  General compatibility with adjacent properties and other property in the district. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-43; Ord. No. 3473, § 13, 9-3-74) 
Cross reference- City boards and commissions generally, § 2-156 et seq. 
Sec. 15-49. - Appeals to city council. 
    Any person may appeal from a ruling of the zoning board of appeals. Such appeal shall be made within thirty (30) days of the date of such ruling, to the city council. The appellant shall file with the zoning board of appeals a notice of appeal, specifying the grounds thereof. The chairman of the zoning board of appeals shall forthwith transmit to the city council all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. The final disposition of any such appeal shall be in the form of a decision expressed in a resolution, either reversing, modifying or affirming, wholly or partially, the zoning board of appeals decision or determination. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-45; Ord. No. 3473, § 15, 9-3-74) 
Sec. 15-50. - Penalties. 
    Any person who willfully violates any provision of this article shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-44; Ord. No. 3473, § 14, 9-3-74) 
Chapter 16 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- General penalty for code violations, § 1-9; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 5; sexually oriented activities in alcoholic beverage establishments, § 5-51 et seq.; police, Ch. 18; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 23. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - State misdemeanors declared offenses against city. 
    All offenses under the penal laws of the state which are misdemeanors are hereby declared to be offenses against the city when such offenses are committed within the corporate limits of the city and upon conviction thereof the same punishment shall be imposed by the city as is provided by the laws of the state, with regard to such offenses against the state, except that such punishment shall not be in excess of that provided by section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 17-46) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit acts constituting misdemeanors under state law, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-19-15; misdemeanors under state penal laws as criminal offenses against municipalities, § 21-13-19. 
Sec. 16-2. - Abandoned iceboxes, other airtight containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or within any unoccupied or abandoned building, dwelling or other structure under his or its control, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or other container which has an airtight door or lid, snap lock or other locking device which may not be released from the inside, without first removing such door or lid, snap lock or other locking device from such icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(Code 1962, § 17-01; Ord. No. 3198, 3-19-63) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-5-9. 
Sec. 16-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4503, adopted Nov. 6, 2018, repealed § 16-3, which pertained to begging and derived from the 1962 Code; and Ord. No. 3674, adopted Nov. 16, 1983. 
Sec. 16-4. - Cemeteries-Permission required to establish, expand. 
    No burying ground or cemetery in addition to those already established and in use and no addition to any burying ground or cemetery already in use shall hereafter be opened and used within the corporate limits of the city without the special permission of the mayor and the city council first being given. Such permission shall be given by ordinance designating and describing the plat of ground permitted to be added, opened and used. 
(Code 1962, § 17-2) 
Sec. 16-5. - Same-Defacing; violating graves. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, break down, mutilate or deface any tomb, grave or sepulchral monument, to injure or disturb any tree, shrubbery or flowers or to violate in any way a grave or lot in any cemetery or burial ground. 
(Code 1962, § 17-3) 
Sec. 16-6. - Same-Permit required to open graves or remove body from city. 
    No tomb, grave or vault in the city containing any dead body shall be opened without written permission from the county health officer. No human body or remains thereof within the city shall be disinterred, disentombed or removed from the limits of the city without such written permission. 
(Code 1962, § 17-4) 
State Law reference- Opening graves prohibited in certain instances, Miss. Code 1972, §§ 97-29-19, 97-29-23. 
Sec. 16-7. - Damaging plants, grass in parks or around city hall. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take away, break, destroy or otherwise mutilate any flower, tree, plant or shrub or to walk on or trespass upon the grass growing in the city parks or area surrounding the city hall. 
(Code 1962, § 17-7) 
State Law reference- Injuring shade or ornamental trees prohibited, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-17-83. 
Sec. 16-8. - Damaging, defacing public or private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, disfigure or injure or cause to be destroyed, disfigured or injured any public property of the city or any real or personal property of any other person. 
(Code 1962, § 17-8) 
Sec. 16-9. - Defacing public improvements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to write or print with chalk or any other substance or to paint or paste any letters or pictures for any purposes whatever upon any sidewalk, street improvement or upon any public building or public improvement within the city. 
(Code 1962, § 17-9) 
State Law reference- Damaging, defacing public buildings prohibited, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-17-39. 
Sec. 16-10. - Disorderly conduct-In public buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, including officers and employees of the city government, to engage in any loud and boisterous laughing, talking or carousals of any kind in or about any public building. 
(Code 1962, § 17-10) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to prohibit and suppress disorderly practices, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-19-19. 
Sec. 16-11. - Same-At public meetings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person at any public meeting of any description held within the city to behave in a disorderly manner in or about such meeting or in such a manner as calculated to disturb the peace and quietness of the neighborhood in which such meeting is being held. 
(Code 1962, § 17-11) 
Sec. 16-12. - Same-Disorderly gatherings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any persons to collect together in any house or other place within the city limit and engage in disorderly conduct to the disturbance of the neighborhood. The permitting of such a gathering by the owner, lessee or proprietor of any house or premises shall be unlawful. 
(Code 1962, § 17-12) 
Sec. 16-13. - Same-Disturbing persons on streets, sidewalks, public ways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to abuse, provoke or disturb by word or act any person in, walking upon or along any street, road, public way or sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1962, § 17-13) 
Sec. 16-14. - Same-Fighting, quarreling, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any fighting or other disorderly conduct in any street, house or other place within the city. 
(Code 1962, § 17-14) 
Sec. 16-15. - Same-Throwing stones, other missiles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person on any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city to throw any brick, stone or missile of any kind, either in sport or otherwise, whether or not such object be thrown at another person. However, it shall not be unlawful on public property that is intended for sport or recreation to throw objects such as a baseball, softball, football, basketball, Frisbee, or other object designed and intended for sport or other recreational use, whether or not such object be thrown at another person. Furthermore, it shall not be unlawful to throw by hand, beads, strings of beads, coins, candy, and like objects traditionally dispensed in Mardi Gras related events, whether or not thrown at another person when said activity is conducted as part of a municipally approved parade or public event provided the sponsor or sponsors of said parade or other public event have prior thereto obtained liability insurance for said parade or other public event naming the City of Meridian, Mississippi, an insured party in an amount not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00), or such other amount as may be set by Section 11-46-15(1) Code of 1972 as amended. 
(Code 1962, § 17-15; Ord. No. 4262, § 1, 2-1-2005) 
Sec. 16-16. - Disturbing worship. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any congregation lawfully assembled for religious worship or to disquiet and annoy by talking, laughing or any other improper or rude behavior any person forming part of such congregation so assembled for religious worship. 
(Code 1962, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-35-17. 
Sec. 16-17. - Fireworks prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter, exchange, give away or distribute, or use or explode within the city any skyrockets, firecrackers, torpedoes, Roman candles, or other explosives commonly known as fireworks, but nothing herein shall prohibit the sale of such commodities by regular wholesalers to dealers outside the city, nor shall this section prohibit licensed displays as provided for in chapter 20 of the Standard Fire Prevention Code. 
(b)  Any person who violates the terms and provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and punishable as provided in section 1-9 of this Code, and each separate sale shall be and constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1962, § 17-16.1; Ord. No. 3276, §§ 1, 2, 6-7-66) 
Sec. 16-18. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4392, adopted August 16, 2011, repealed § 16-18, which pertained to fortunetelling prohibited and derived from the Code of 1962, § 17-17. 
Sec. 16-19. - Gambling-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city: 
(1)  To play at any game or amusement for money or other valuable thing. 
(2)  To operate or play with money or other valuable thing any gaming or gambling machine or device by whatever name known or called. 
(3)  To pay, deposit or hazard any money or other valuable thing for the purpose of winning or attempting to win any prize or premium by whatever name known or called, offered by any person or by any gaming or gambling machine or device. 
(4)  To wager, bet or hazard any money or other valuable thing on any game of chance or whatever name called or however played or operated or upon the results of any election, or any other event or contingency. 
(Code 1962, § 17-18) 
State Law reference- Cane racks, slot machines, etc., prohibited, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-33-7; wagering prohibited, § 97-33-1. 
Sec. 16-20. - Same-Keeping devices. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, possess, exhibit or be concerned directly or indirectly in any faro bank, banks of gaming of any kind or any gaming table of any kind or description by whatever name called. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, to keep, possess, exhibit or be concerned directly or indirectly in any device, whether mechanically or electrically operated, which, by chance, provide inning and total scores in fictitious baseball games. 
(c)  Any person convicted under the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1962, § 17-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-33-9. 
Sec. 16-21. - Same-Lotteries, raffles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person publicly or privately to put up a lottery to be drawn for or any prize to be raffled or played for. The selling or exposing for sale of any lottery ticket or any chance in any raffle is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1962, § 17-20) 
State Law reference- Lotteries, Miss. Code 1972, §§ 97-33-31-97-33-49. 
Sec. 16-22. - Same-Prohibited in hotels, boardinghouses, taverns. 
    It shall be unlawful for the keeper of any boardinghouse, hotel or tavern knowingly to permit any gaming prohibited by the preceding section of this chapter in any such boardinghouse, hotel or tavern. 
(Code 1962, § 17-21) 
State Law reference- Hotel keepers, etc., permitting gambling, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-33-15. 
Sec. 16-23. - Same-Slot machines. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any slot machine to be operated or played on any premises under his control, which slot machine or other device may be played or operated for any sort of prize or premium, or which may be operated or played for any ticket or check entitling any person to any prize or premium or to any right to further operate or play such machine or device, or which may be played or operated on any uncertainty or chance as to what shall be received for the money placed therein; provided, that the operation of slot machines as dummy salesmen shall not be unlawful where no prizes or premiums are offered or played for and where the amount and kind of the purchase is definitely and certainly known by the intending purchaser in advance of depositing his money. 
(b)  Every person owning or having an interest in any slot machine, prohibited by this section, who shall knowingly permit the same to be operated or played at any place in the corporate limits of the city shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1962, § 17-22) 
Sec. 16-24. - Impersonating city officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person falsely to assume to be or to represent himself to be an officer of the city. The attempting without legal authority to exercise the power and authority of an officer of the city is prohibited. 
(Code 1962, § 17-23) 
Sec. 16-25. - Public indecency. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully perform any of the following acts in a place where a person should reasonably expect to be in view of the public: 
(1)  An actual or simulated act of sexual intercourse or masturbation; 
(2)  Exposure of the genitals; 
(3)  A lewd appearance in a state of partial or complete nudity; 
(4)  A lewd caress of indecent fondling of the body of another person; 
(5)  A lewd caress of indecent fondling of the sexual organs of any person, including oneself; 
(6)  Urination or defecation; or 
(7)  Appears wearing pants or skirts more than three inches below the top of the hips (crest of the ilium) exposing the skin or undergarments. 
(Code 1962, § 17-25; Ord. No. 4386, § 1, 4-19-2011) 
Sec. 16-26. - Intoxication. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be drunk or in a state of intoxication in any public place within the corporate limits or to be intoxicated in any private place to the disturbance of any other person. 
(Code 1962, § 17-27) 
State Law reference- Public drunkenness prohibited, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-29-47. 
Sec. 16-27. - Minors-Frequenting gambling houses, houses of ill-fame, poolrooms, tenpin alleys. 
    It shall be unlawful for any minor to visit knowingly any gambling house or room, house of ill-fame, public billiard hall or poolroom or to remain at any such place after the character thereof has been discovered; provided that, the provisions of this section shall not apply to any minor employed with the consent of his parent or guardian to work in such billiard hall or poolroom, which is kept in accordance with the law. The owner or keeper of any such place mentioned in this section shall not permit minors to frequent such establishments except in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1962, § 17-31) 
State Law reference- Gambling with minors prohibited, Miss. Code 1972, §§ 97-33-21 and 97-33-23; enticing children for prostitution prohibited, § 97-5-5; minors prohibited from entering pool halls, § 97-5-11. 
Sec. 16-28. - Same-Selling tobacco to. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter, deliver or give away any cigar, cigarette, smoking tobacco or snuff to any child under the age of eighteen (18) years unless previously authorized in writing by the parent or guardian of such child. Any person convicted under the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 17-32) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-5-25. 
Sec. 16-28.1. - Use of tobacco products by minors and students. 
(a)  Use by minors prohibited. No person under eighteen (18) years of age shall use any tobacco product within the corporate limits of the City of Meridian. 
(b)  Use by students prohibited. No student, regardless of his or her age, of any high school, middle school, or elementary school, public or private, shall use any tobacco product on any educational property or at an educational activity within the corporate limits of the City of Meridian. 
(c)  Definitions. 
    Educational activity. A school sanctioned event attended by students within the City of Meridian for academic, athletic, performance, or social purposes, to include transportation to and from, regardless whether such activity is held on educational property. 
    Educational property. Any public or private elementary, middle, or high school building or bus, public or private school campus, grounds, recreational area, athletic field, or property owned, used, or operated by a school board, board of trustees, or directors for the administration of any public or private educational institution. 
    Tobacco product. Any tobacco cigarette, cigar, pipe tobacco, smokeless tobacco or any other form of tobacco which may be used for smoking, chewing, inhaling, or ingesting by any other means. 
    Use. The smoking of tobacco products, the possession of a lighted cigarette, cigar, or other tobacco product, the chewing, oral consumption, spitting, inhaling or other ingestion of any tobacco product or the possession of any container of tobacco spittle. 
(d)  The penalty for violation of this section shall be a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), or community service not to exceed twenty (20) hours. A repeat violation of this section shall be mandatory participation, by the violator, in a tobacco use cessation program in addition to a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), or community service not to exceed twenty (20) hours. 
(Ord. No. 4111, §§ 101-104, 9-15-98) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4111, §§ 101-104, adopted Sept. 15, 1998, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of its provisions as § 16-28.1 herein was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 16-29. - Noises-Loud, unnecessary prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise or any noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 17-33) 
State Law reference- For authority of municipalities to regulate noises, see Miss. Code 1972, § 21-19-15; noises disturbing family prohibited, § 97-35-39; mufflers required on motor vehicles, § 63-7-55. 
Sec. 16-30. - Same-Prohibited acts enumerated. 
    The following acts among others are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in violation of the preceding section, but such enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive, namely: 
(1)  Horns, signaling devices, etc. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle on any street or public place of the city, except as a danger warning, the creation of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound by means of any such signaling device and the sounding of such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. The use of any signaling device except one (1) operated by hand or electricity, the use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust and the use of any signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up. 
(2)  Radios, phonographs, etc. 
a.  The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person who is in the room, vehicle or chamber in which such machine or device is operated and who is a voluntary listener thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of fifty (50) feet from the building, structure or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
b.  1.  In addition to the prohibition set forth in paragraph (a) hereinabove, it shall be specifically unlawful for any person to operate, and/or amplify the sound produced by a radio, tape player, CD player, "boom box" or other mechanical and/or electrical soundmaking device, including, but not limited to those within motor vehicles, so that the sound is plainly audible to a person of normal hearing sensitivity at a distance of fifty (50) feet from the radio, tape player, CD player or other device. 
2.  The prohibition of this paragraph b. shall not apply to any law enforcement, fire or emergency service motor vehicle equipped with any communications device necessary in the performance of its duties or emergency procedures or to noises made by places of worship using bells, amplifiers, chimes or carillons or to use of public address systems in any ball park or stadium while an athletic contest is in progress therein. 
3.  The City of Meridian may grant permits for activity of a temporary duration during which the prohibitions of this paragraph b. may be suspended. 
4.  In addition to or in lieu of any other penalty imposed for a violation of this Section 16-30, any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the prohibitions of this paragraph b. shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for a first offense, two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a second offense and five hundred ($500.00) for a third or subsequent offense. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(3)  Loudspeakers, amplifiers, etc. The use of calliopes, mechanical loudspeakers or amplifiers of any kind for any purpose upon the streets of the city. 
(4)  Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing on the public streets, particularly between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, dwelling, hotel or other type of residence or of any persons in the vicinity. 
(5)  Animals, birds. etc. The keeping of any animal or bird which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. 
(6)  Steam whistles. The blowing of any train whistle or steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger or upon request of proper city authorities. 
(7)  Exhausts. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motorboat or motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom.
