(8)  Defect in vehicle or load. The use of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise. 
(9)  Loading, unloading, opening boxes. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers. 
(10)  Construction or repairing of buildings. The erection (including excavating), demolition, alteration or repair of any building other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on weekdays is prohibited except with a permit from the building official. If the building official should determine that the public health and safety will not be impaired by the erection, demolition, excavating, alteration or repair of any building between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., and if he shall further determine that loss or inconvenience would result to any party in interest, he may grant permission for such work to be done between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. upon application being made at the time the permit for the work is awarded or during the progress of the work. 
(11)  Schools, courts, churches, hospitals. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the same are in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital; provided that conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, hospital or court street. 
(12)  Hawkers, peddlers, etc. The shouting or crying of peddlers, hawkers, and vendors which disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
(13)  Noises to attract attention. The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise to any performance, show or sale. 
(14)  Transportation of metal rails, etc. The transportation of rails, pillars or columns of iron, steel or other material over and along streets and other public places upon carts, drays, cars, trucks or in any other manner so loaded as to cause loud noises or as to disturb the peace and the quiet of such streets or other public places. 
(15)  Pile drivers, hammers, etc. The operation between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist or other appliance, the use of which is attended by loud or unusual noise. 
(16)  Blowers. The operation of any noise-creating blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient to deaden such noise. 
(Code 1962, § 17-34; Ord. No. 3588, § 1, 9-2-80; Ord. No. 3947, § 2, 1-5-93; Ord. No. 4428, § 1, 12-3-2013) 
Sec. 16-31. - Same-Exceptions. 
    The provisions of sections 16-29 and 16-30 shall not be construed to prohibit music being made upon the streets or sidewalks by brass bands, nor to prohibit religious organizations from beating drums in their religious worship. 
(Code 1962, § 17-35) 
Sec. 16-32. - Masks or disguises, trick or treat visitations and Halloween curfew. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person over twelve (12) years of age to appear in or upon any of the streets, highways, alleys, public parks or other places of the city in any mask or disguise whereby the identity of such person is concealed, without permission of the mayor or chief of police. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to appear on the streets, highways, public homes, private homes or public places in the city to make trick or treat visitations; except, that this section shall not apply to children twelve (12) years of age and under on Halloween night. 
(c)  A special curfew hour of 8:00 p.m. on Halloween evening is hereby established for the trick or treat visitations permitted by subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1962, § 17-35; Ord. No. 3203, 6-18-63; Ord. No. 4414, § 1, 11-6-2012) 
Sec. 16-33. - Prostitution. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in prostitution or to aid or abet prostitution or to procure or solicit for the purpose of prostitution, or to reside in, enter or remain in any place, structure or building, or to enter or remain in any vehicle or conveyance for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution, or to keep or set up a house of ill-fame, brothel or bawdy house, or to receive any person for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution into any vehicle, conveyance, place, structure or building, or to permit any person for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution in any vehicle, conveyance, place, structure or building or to direct, take or transport, or to offer to agree to take or transport, or aid or assist in transporting, any person to any vehicle, conveyance, place, structure or building or to any other person with knowledge or reasonable cause to know that the purpose of such directing, taking or transporting is prostitution, lewdness or assignation, or to lease or rent or contract to lease or rent any vehicle, conveyance, place, structure or building or part thereof, knowing or with good reason to know that it is intended to be used for any of the purposes herein provided, or to aid, abet or participate in the doing of any of the acts prohibited by this section. 
(Code 1962, § 17-36) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-29-49. 
Sec. 16-34. - Resisting, hindering officers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, resist or oppose the chief of police, any police officer or any other officer of the city while engaged in the lawful discharge of their respective duties. 
(Code 1962, § 17-37) 
State Law reference- Resisting service of process prohibited, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-9-75. 
Sec. 16-35. - Schools, homes for dependent children; disturbing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do or perform any act calculated to disturb the conduct of any educational institution or home for dependent children or to attempt in any manner to interfere with the government thereof. 
(Code 1962, § 17-38) 
Sec. 16-36. - Schools, sales near. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or offer for sale, any food, food products or any article of merchandise on any portion of any street or sidewalk which lies adjacent to any school building or school grounds within the city. 
(Code 1962, § 17-39) 
Sec. 16-37. - Sleeping in city hall, school buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy or permit to be occupied any office, room, hall or other portion of the city hall building or of any school building belonging to the city or the grounds of any such buildings as a lodging or sleeping room. 
(Code 1962, § 17-40) 
Sec. 16-38. - Slingshots, blow guns, bows; discharging prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or discharge gravel, marbles, shot, arrows or any other substance out of a rubber sling, gravel shooter, slingshot, blow gun, blow pellet gun, "BB" gun or other similar device or implement, by whatever name known. 
(Code 1962, § 17-41) 
Sec. 16-39. - Toy weapons, air guns; discharging. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to use, shoot or discharge any toy pistol, air gun, parlor rifle or similar weapon. It is expressly provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the discharging of any toy cap pistols, or other devices, in which paper caps manufactured in accordance with United States Interstate Commerce Commission regulations for packing or shipping of toy paper caps are used or exploded, and the discharge of such toy cap pistols is hereby declared to be permissible. 
(Code 1962, § 17-50) 
State Law reference- Sale of toy pistols or ammunition therefor prohibited, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-37-33; shooting air guns at another prohibited, § 97-3-7. 
Sec. 16-40. - Unlawful assemblies; authority to disperse; power to command assistance. 
(a)  If any person or persons, whether armed or not, are unlawfully, riotously or tumultuously assembled within the city, or if any assembly of persons shall be so assembled as shall tend to create a disturbance of incite a riot or disorderly conduct within the city, any police officer or other duly authorized officer of the city shall command the persons so assembled immediately and peaceably to disperse. Any person so commanded who does not thereupon immediately and peaceably disperse in accordance with such command shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  If any person commanded to disperse by an officer in accordance with paragraph (a) of this section does not thereupon immediately and peaceably disperse the officer may command the assistance of any and all persons in seizing, arresting and securing such person in custody. Any person failing to obey such command to render assistance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1962, § 17-51) 
Sec. 16-41. - Weapons-Carrying concealed; forfeiture of weapon; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person except authorized officials to carry concealed in whole or in part any bowie knife, dirk knife, butcher knife, switchblade knife, metallic knuckles, blackjack, slingshot, pistol, revolver, or any rifle with a barrel of less than sixteen (16) inches in length, or any shotgun with a barrel of less than eighteen (18) inches in length, machine gun or any fully automatic firearm or deadly weapon, or any muffler or silencer for any firearm, whether or not it is accompanied by a firearm. Upon the conviction of any person for the violation of the provisions of this section the weapon shown in each case to have been carried or concealed in whole or in part shall be forfeited to the city and the chief of police shall forthwith publicly destroy such weapon; provided that, the provisions of this section shall not apply to a person lawfully engaged in the selling and delivering of ice as a paid employee of an ice company during working hours but shall apply to such employee if the ice pick is carried concealed on his person after working hours, nor shall this section apply to any person keeping an ice pick in his home or business premises for the purpose of using ice on his premises. The burden of providing either of the abovementioned defenses shall be on the accused. 
(Code 1962, § 17-54; Ord. No. 3220, 5-19-64) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, §§ 97-37-1-97-37-9. 
Sec. 16-41.1. - Open possession of weapons banned. 
(a)  The City of Meridian hereby bans the open possession of weapons of any kind including but not limited to firearms, handguns, pistols, rifles, shotguns, stun guns, knives and any other item of any kind or nature that could or may be used as a weapon on municipal property as designated in subsection (b) of this section. Nothing herein shall be deemed to prohibit sworn law enforcement officers from carrying their officially issued weapons on and in said municipal properties. 
(b)  The City of Meridian hereby designates those facilities and offices located in City Hall, Meridian Law Enforcement Center, Meridian fire stations, other municipal offices, and city parks and playgrounds, expressly excepting public roads, streets and sidewalks, as municipal property solely for purposes of this section and as a "sensitive place" where the activities, duties and responsibilities of the municipality are carried out. 
(Ord. No. 4418, §§ 1, 2, 7-23-2013) 
Sec. 16-42. - Same-Discharging firearms prohibited; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge firearms of any description anywhere within the corporate limits of the city, except in self-defense, in the enforcement of the laws when imperatively necessary, in the performance of military duty under military regulations and except under the regulations prescribed in the following paragraphs. Firearms may be discharged within the corporate limits of the city whenever such activity is conducted by an organized shooting or gun club or other organized body of citizens; provided that, before such activity shall be permitted, a written permit shall be issued by the chief of police designating to what person or organized body such permit is issued, the place where such shooting is to be done and prescribing such regulations and restrictions as may be consistent with public safety. 
(Code 1962, § 17-55) 
Sec. 16-43. - Same-Selling, giving to minors or intoxicated persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give or lend to any minor or intoxicated person, knowing such person is to be a minor or in a state of intoxication, any deadly weapon or other weapon the carrying of which concealed is prohibited, or pistol cartridge as provided in section 16-41 of this chapter. 
(Code 1962, § 17-56; Ord. No. 3221, 5-19-64) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-37-13. 
Sec. 16-44. - Weights and measures-State standards adopted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to sell any goods, wares or merchandise by weight or measure unless the weight or measure by which the same shall be sold, shall be in accordance with the standard of weights and measures prescribed by the laws of this state. 
(Code 1962, § 17-57) 
State Law reference- Standards of weights and measures established, Miss. Code 1972, § 75-27-101. 
Sec. 16-45. - Same-Packages to be marked; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any packages containing goods, wares and merchandise put up by them, unless such packages shall have plainly marked and indicated thereon the net weight or net measure, as the case may be, of the goods, wares or merchandise contained therein; but nothing in this section contained shall relate to the sale of goods, wares or merchandise sold or offered for sale in the original packages put up by the manufacturer. 
(Code 1962, § 17-58) 
Sec. 16-46. - Same-Defective machines no defense. 
    In every prosecution for a violation of sections 16-44 or 16-45 it shall be a defense that any machine or contrivance was used to cut or measure the goods, wares or merchandise sold or offered for sale, and that such machine or contrivance was so constructed as that it did not accurately or correctly cut or measure the correct quantity of goods so sold or offered for sale; but in all such cases the actual weight or measure according to the lawful standard of weights and measures shall govern. 
(Code 1962, § 17-59) 
Sec. 16-47. - Racing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage with another in racing or running without reasonable excuse, on or along any sidewalk or street or in any other public place, anywhere in the city. 
(Code 1962, § 17-60) 
Sec. 16-48. - Loitering for purposes of illegally using, possessing, transferring or selling controlled substances-Prohibited generally. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to loiter in a public place in a manner and under circumstances intentionally manifesting the purpose of illegally using, possessing, transferring or selling any controlled substance as defined in section 41-29-139 of Mississippi Code Annotated of 1972, as now enacted or hereinafter amended. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such a purpose is manifested are: 
(1)  The person is a known illegal user, possessor or seller of controlled substances, or the person is at a location frequented by persons who illegally use, possess, transfer or sell controlled substances; and 
(2)  The person repeatedly beckons to, stops, attempts to stop or engages in conversation with passersby, whether such passersby are on foot or in a motor vehicle, for the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to illegally possess, transfer or buy any controlled substances; or 
(3)  The person repeatedly passes to or receives from passersby, whether such passersby are on foot or in a motor vehicle, money, objects or written material for the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to illegally possess, transfer or buy any controlled substance. 
(b)  In order for there to be a violation of subsection A, the loitering person's affirmative language and conduct under the totality of the circumstances must be such as to demonstrate by its express or implied content a specific effort to induce, entice, solicit or procure another to illegally use, possess, transfer or buy a controlled substance. No arrest shall be made for mere loitering nor without probable cause that the loitering person is engaged in acts for the purpose of illegally using, buying, selling or possessing controlled substances. 
(c)  For the purpose of this section: 
(1)  A known illegal user, possessor or seller of controlled substances is a person who, within eighteen (18) months previous to the date of arrest for violation of this section, has within the knowledge of or information known to the arresting officer, been convicted of or has been the subject of a nonadjudication of guilt involving the illegal manufacturing, using, possessing, selling, purchasing or delivering of any controlled substance. 
(2)  Public place is an area generally visible to public view and includes streets, sidewalks, bridges, alleys, plazas, parks, driveways, parking lots, automobiles whether moving or not, and buildings open to the general public including those which serve food or drink, or provide entertainment, and the doorways and entrances to buildings or dwellings and the grounds enclosing them. 
(3)  Loitering shall mean remaining idle in essentially one location and shall include the concept of spending time idly, being dilatory, lingering, staying, sauntering, delaying, standing around and shall also include the colloquial expression "hanging around." 
(Ord. No. 3877, § 1, 8-7-90) 
Sec. 16-49. - Same-Violation. 
    Any person violating section 16-48 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished, upon conviction of a first offense, by a mandatory fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and may be confined for ninety (90) days in the city jail. Upon conviction of a subsequent offense within one (1) year of a prior conviction, a person may be ordered to pay a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and shall receive a mandatory sentence to the city jail for thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 3877, § 2, 8-7-90) 
Sec. 16-50. - Prohibit the use of outdoor grills within the interior or within fifteen feet of dwellings of more than two units. 
(a)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to kindle, ignite, start, use, or operate any outdoor grill (1) inside the interior of within any garage or car-port of any apartment complex or dwelling with more than two (2) units; (2) upon any balcony, porch, entry, or exit of any apartment complex or dwelling of more than two (2) units; or (3) within a distance of fifteen (15) feet of the exterior of any apartment complex or dwelling with more than two (2) units. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person who violates the terms and provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor whose penalty for violation of this section shall be a fine not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), and each separate occurrence shall be and constitute a separate offense. 
    A law enforcement officer or the fire marshal or his designee may issue a citation for committing the above prohibited acts. The citation shall contain the name and address of the offender; describe the offense charged; give the numerical designation of the applicable statue or ordinance; state the name of the law enforcement officer who issued the citation; and order the offender to appear before the municipal court at a time and place certain. The citation shall inform the offender that, in lieu of appearing at the time and place stated, the offender may, within that stated time, appear personally at the office of the clerk of the court and upon signing a plea of guilty and a waiver of trail pay a stated fine and stated costs, if any. The citation shall inform the offender that, in lieu of appearing at the time and place stated, he may, within the stated time, sign the guilty plea and waiver agreeing to pay the total amount of the fine and costs to the violations bureau. The citation shall inform the offender that he may be arrested if he fails to appear at either the clerk's office or for municipal court. 
    A law enforcement officer or fire marshal or his designee who issues a citation shall complete and sign the citation form, serve a copy of the completed form upon the offenders and, without unnecessary delay, swear to and file the original with the court. 
(Ord. No. 4318, § 1, 5-1-2007) 
Sec. 16-51. - Novelty lighters-Prohibit retail sale or distribution. 
(a)  Prohibitions, inapplicability. The retail sale, offer of retail sale, gift or distribution of any novelty lighter within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Meridian is prohibited. This prohibition is inapplicable to (1) novelty lighters which are only being actively transported through the city; or (2) novelty lighters located in a warehouse closed to the public for purposes of retail sales. 
(b)  Definition. 
    Novelty lighter means a lighter that has entertaining audio or visual effects, or that depicts (logos, decals, art work, etc.) or resembles in physical form or function articles commonly recognized as appealing to or intended for use by children ten (10) years of age or younger. This includes, but is not limited to, lighters that depict or resemble cartoon characters, toys, guns, watches, musical instruments, vehicles, toy animals, food or beverages, or that play musical notes or have flashing lights or other entertaining features. A novelty lighter may operate by any fuel, including butane or liquid fuel. 
(c)  Exceptions. The term "novelty lighter" excludes: (1) any lighter manufactured prior to 1980; and (2) any lighter which lacks fuel or a device necessary to produce combustion or a flame. 
(d)  Enforcement. The provisions of this section of the Code shall be enforced by the fire marshal, any police officer, any code enforcement officer, and any other City of Meridian official authorized to enforce any provision of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Meridian. 
(e)  Violation-penalty. Any person who violates the terms and provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor whose penalty for violation of this section shall be a fine not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), and each separate occurrence shall be and constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 4337, 8-19-2008) 
Secs. 16-52-16-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to prohibit, remove and abate nuisances, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-19-1; nuisances generally and actions to enjoin, §§ 95-3-1-95-3-27. 

Sec. 16-61. - Conditions constituting. 
    Any house, structure, building, yard, lot, place or any matter or thing, anywhere within the corporate limits of the city of the kind or character herein below described, is hereby declared to be a nuisance: 
(1)  Any matter or thing calculated to endanger the life or health of the citizens of the city, or of any neighborhood in which same may be, or calculated to produce or aggravate sickness or disease, or which is in such unsanitary condition as to be offensive to the sight or smell of persons residing or being in the neighborhood; 
(2)  Any house, structure, excavation, or other matter or thing, liable to cause material hurt to any person; or 
(3)  Calculated to endanger the safety of property; or 
(4)  Anything that annoys or disturbs to an unreasonable degree the comfort of any of the citizens; 
(5)  Anything, the existence or maintenance of which is prohibited by law; 
(6)  Any other matter or thing, or condition thereof, which by law may be designated or held as a nuisance. 
(Code 1962, § 17-67) 
Sec. 16-62. - Causing, permitting prohibited. 
    Any person who shall do any act, or create, cause or permit within the city on land or premises owned by him or under his control, or in any street, avenue, alley or sidewalk, anything which is a nuisance, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and in addition to any penalty prescribed upon condition thereof, the nuisance may be ordered abated by the mayor or the municipal judge at the expense of the defendant as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1962, § 17-68) 
Sec. 16-63. - Notice to abate-Required; time allowed. 
    Before any matter or thing shall be abated as a nuisance which itself is not prohibited by law, but which is considered a nuisance on account of its condition, or on account of the manner in which it is conducted, carried on, pursued or maintained, the person responsible therefor, and also the owner of the thing considered a nuisance, and the owner of the property on which the same may be, or the agent of such owner, if the owner himself be absent from the city, shall be, by an authorized officer, notified in writing of such nuisance, and required to abate the same in such manner as may be by the notice specified, and a reasonable time under the circumstances in each case, to be specified in the notice, shall be given such person or owner to abate, in the manner required, the nuisance complained of. The time allowed shall in no case be less than twenty-four (24) hours, unless the nuisance be of such a character as to demand a shorter time, and unless, further, it be such as demands and warrants immediate abatement without investigation by a court, as hereinafter provided for by this chapter. 
(Code 1962, § 17-69) 
Sec. 16-64. - Same-Form; officers authorized to issue. 
    The notice required by the preceding section may, in all cases, be in a form similar to that specifically provided by section 16-74 of this chapter, for the removal of nuisances occasioned by unclean and filthy premises, and may be given: 
(1)  By the chief of police or any police officer, the county health officer or an agent of the county health department, in all cases of nuisances considered as dangerous and detrimental to the health of the city, or of the neighborhood in which same may be, or offensive on account of unsanitary conditions; 
(2)  By the chief of police, any police officer or by the building official, in all cases where the thing considered to be a nuisance is a building awning, wall or other similar structure, or a part of a building or other such structure, the existence or condition of which is regarded as rendering it, by reason of dilapidation, defective construction, or other similar cause, unsafe and dangerous to life or liable to work material hurt to any person, or to any person's property; 
(3)  By the chief of police, any police officer, the building official, in all cases where the thing considered as being a nuisance is a telegraph, telephone, electric light or electric street railway pole or wire, or other electrical construction, the existence, condition or construction of which is regarded as rendering it unsafe and dangerous to life or liable to do material injury to person or property; 
(4)  By the chief of police or any police officer, the chief of the fire department or any member of the fire department, in all cases where the matter or thing complained of is sparks from engines or elsewhere, rubbish, trash or refuse, oil, gunpowder, or any other inflammable material or substance, considered a nuisance, in dangerous proximity to buildings, and by reason of its character or situation, endangering the safety of property; 
(5)  By the chief of police or any police officer in any and all other cases requiring a notice. 
(Code 1962, § 17-70) 
Sec. 16-65. - Failure to abate-Arrest, determination of nuisances. 
    If, after the expiration of the time allowed by the notice provided for by section 16-63, the alleged nuisance is not abated, removed, or satisfactorily remedied, complaint may be made on oath before the municipal judge by the officer who may have issued the notice, or by any other person, against the person notified and refusing, charging the existence and continuance of a nuisance, and alleging the nature and location thereof, and the person charged shall be arrested and held to answer accordingly; whereupon, the question as to whether or not the thing or conditions complained of is a nuisance as alleged shall be inquired into, tried and determined by the municipal judge, as other cases are tried. 
(Code 1962, § 17-71) 
Sec. 16-66. - Same-Trial procedure; penalty; order of abatement. 
    On the trail under the provisions of the preceding section, the municipal judge, after seeing that the defendant, or each of them, if there are more than one (1), has had the proper notice, shall hear such evidence as may be offered, and if necessary shall inspect the alleged nuisance, and shall render such judgment as the evidence warrants. If the charge be sustained, the municipal judge may, on conviction, impose upon the offender such penalty, in his discretion, as may be authorized, and, after such conviction, in addition thereto, may adjudge and condemn as a nuisance the thing complained of, and may order the abatement of the nuisance, specifying how it shall be done, whether the nuisance be removed or be remedied in a manner to be prescribed, and enter judgment accordingly. 
(Code 1962, § 17-72) 
Sec. 16-67. - Abatement by police chief authorized. 
    If the judgment of abatement be not complied with by the defendant as required within such time as may be granted, the chief of police shall proceed to abate the nuisance in the manner provided for in sections 16-76 to 16-79 of this chapter for the abatement of nuisances occasioned by unclean and filthy premises, and shall render account of the expense or cost thereof to the city council, to be recovered as provided for in such cases. The chief of police may, if necessary, employ any person who is specially qualified and competent to do or direct the particular work required; provided that, the work be such as requires the services and direction of one (1) specially qualified. 
(Code 1962, § 17-73) 
Cross reference- Police generally, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 16-68. - Complaint and investigation of nuisances. 
    Any person may make complaint of the existence of a nuisance to any officer authorized to require its abatement under the provisions of section 16-64 of this chapter. It shall be the duty of such officer to investigate the nuisance complained of and to notify the owner and require its abatement in the manner prescribed by this chapter, if, in the opinion of such officer, the thing complained of, or the conduct thereof, is a nuisance which should be abated, and if, further, it is a nuisance requiring a previous notice to abate. If such officer, for any cause, should decline or delay action, the person complaining may make complaint to the mayor against the offender, alleging the existence and continuance of the nuisance, whereupon the mayor may, by notice, require the abatement of the nuisance in the manner hereinbefore provided, and if not abated, like proceedings may be had as if the notice had been issued by an officer specially authorized. 
(Code 1962, § 17-74) 
Sec. 16-69. - Summary abatement authorized. 
    Whenever a nuisance is of such a character as to require immediate abatement, not permitting of the notice and investigation hereinbefore provided for, imminently dangerous to life, health, person or property, it shall be the duty of the chief of police or any other officer specially authorized, to remove or abate same without further investigation and delay. 
(Code 1962, § 17-75) 
Sec. 16-70. - Notice not required when act prohibited by law. 
    The notice required by the preceding sections of this article to be served before the institution of proceedings before the municipal judge, is not necessary in cases where the matter or thing or business pursuit complained of is in itself an offense constituting a nuisance, the maintenance or permission or doing or carrying on of which is prohibited by law, and for which a penalty is specifically prescribed. In any such case tried before the municipal judge, if the charge be sustained, the municipal judge may, on conviction, impose upon the offender such penalty, in his discretion, as may be authorized. After such conviction, the municipal judge may, in addition thereto, adjudge and condemn as a nuisance the thing complained of, or the room, building or other place where the prohibited business or acts are carried on or pursued, and may order the abatement of same in such lawful manner as he may prescribe, and enter judgment accordingly, notwithstanding the defendant may not have had previous notice to discontinue or abate same, and the chief of police shall proceed to execute the order of abatement as provided for in other cases. 
(Code 1962, § 17-76) 
Sec. 16-71. - Each day's continuation declared separate offense. 
    Each day's continuance of a nuisance, under any provision of this article, after the same has been adjudged as such, shall constitute a separate and distinct offense, and the offender shall be subject to arrest, trial and punishment therefor accordingly; and such further orders for abatement of the nuisance may be made, on any such subsequent trial, as in the judgment of the municipal judge may seem necessary and proper. 
(Code 1962, § 17-77) 
Sec. 16-72. - Unsanitary conditions constituting nuisances-Specified. 
    Any premises or grounds anywhere within the corporate limits of the city, occupied or unoccupied, especially any privy or vault, or any lot or stable where animals are kept, being, by reason of any kind of filth or stagnant water accumulating thereon, or from any other cause, in any unsanitary condition to such extent as is calculated to endanger the life or health of the citizens of the city, or of the neighborhood in which the same may be, or calculated to produce or aggravate sickness or disease, or to such extent as to be offensive to the sight or smell of persons residing or being in the neighborhood, are hereby declared to be nuisances, subject to being dealt with as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1962, § 17-78) 
Sec. 16-73. - Same-Refusal to abate after notice. 
    The owner of any premises in a condition as specified in the preceding section, and likewise the occupant or lessee thereof, who, being responsible as hereinbefore provided, shall fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of this chapter requiring owners, occupants and lessees of occupied and unoccupied premises and grounds to keep them in proper sanitary condition, on being required and notified in writing to do so by order of the county health department, by the county health officer, the chief of police or any policeman, or by such other officer as may at the time be, by ordinance, authorized, within twenty-four (24) hours after service of such notice, or within such longer time as may be designated by the notice, shall be subject to arrest and trial before the municipal judge on a charge of committing or maintaining a nuisance. 
(Code 1962, § 17-79) 
Sec. 16-74. - Same-Form of notice to abate. 
    The notice required by the preceding section may be in the following or a similar form, care being taken to designate the premises with reasonable and sufficient certainty: 
Meridian, Miss., _______ 
To _______ 
    You are hereby required and notified to abate a nuisance on your premises, No. _______, _______ street, (or avenue, as the case may be), occupied by _______ in this city, caused by _____ _____
This you will do at your own expense. If the said nuisance is not abated within _______ hours (or days, if a number of days be given) from the service of this notice, I will proceed as the law directs. 
Respectively, 
_____ 
(Code 1962, § 17-80) 
Sec. 16-75. - Same-Determination of existence of nuisance; penalty; order to police chief to abate. 
    The question of the existence of the alleged nuisance shall be tried and determined by the municipal judge, if the notice be not complied with as provided by section 16-66 of this chapter. On the trial, the municipal judge, after seeing to it that the defendant has received the required notice, shall carefully inquire, through the testimony of witnesses as in other cases, or by a personal inspection of the premises, as to the conditions which are alleged and charged as being a nuisance. If on such trial the defendant be adjudged guilty, a fine in such sum as may be authorized, in the municipal judge's discretion, shall be imposed. On such conviction, the municipal judge further may order that the nuisance be abated and direct that the chief of police execute the order of abatement, and judgment shall be entered accordingly. 
(Code 1962, § 17-81) 
Sec. 16-76. - Same-Duty of police chief to abate. 
    After judgment ordering the abatement of a nuisance as above provided, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to have the premises cleaned by the removal therefrom of the filthy, offensive or unsanitary substance or matter or thing, or to have them drained and freed of the stagnant water, as the order and circumstances in the case require, and to have the premises disinfected, all to such extent as may be necessary to comply with the judgment and order of the court. 
(Code 1962, § 17-82) 
Sec. 16-77. - Same-Use of city equipment and employees, private contractors to abate; lien for costs. 
    For the purpose of abating any nuisance, as required by the preceding section, the chief of police may, under the direction of the mayor, use or direct the use of such vehicles and equipment belonging to the city, together with sufficient laborers employed by the city, as may be necessary to accomplish such abatement. If for any reason it is necessary, the chief of police may employ any competent person, not connected with the city, as a private contractor to do the whole or part of work ordered. The cost or expense of doing such work, whether done by the city or by any other person as above provided, shall be borne by the city and made a charge against the owner and occupant and a lien against the property, as authorized by the charter of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 17-83) 
Sec. 16-78. - Same-Failure of owner to pay abatement costs; report to tax collector, assessor, city council; payment by city. 
    If the owner or occupant of the premises cleaned as provided by the preceding section, shall not immediately pay to the chief of police the cost incurred in doing same, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to report such costs in writing, itemized, to the tax collector, and also to the city council as their next regular meeting thereafter. Such account or bill of costs, or such part thereof as may be reasonable and just, shall be approved by the city council, and if the report of the chief of police and the bill show that the work was done by any other person than the employees of the city, payment of the same shall be ordered. 
(Code 1962, § 17-84) 
Sec. 16-79. - Same-Collection of costs from owner, occupant. 
    The cost shall be assessed, with twenty-five (25) percent damages, and the tax collector shall collect the same with the next accruing city taxes, unless the city council elect to recover same of the owner or occupant of the property by suit in a court of competent jurisdiction, in which event it shall be so ordered by the city council, and the assessor and the collector of taxes shall be given such instructions as to their further duties with respect to such assessment and collection as may be deemed necessary. 
(Code 1962, § 17-85) 
Secs. 16-80-16-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - IMPRISONMENT OF OFFENDERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to maintain jails, Miss. Code 1972, § 47-1-39; authority to imprison and work persons convicted of violating municipal ordinances, § 47-1-41. 

Sec. 16-96. - Place of confinement. 
    Any person convicted in the municipal court and sentenced to a term of imprisonment shall be committed to the city jail. The city jail is the prison of the city, in which shall be imprisoned all persons required by law to be imprisoned by the city authorities. 
(Code 1962, § 17-92) 
Sec. 16-97. - Imprisonment until fine, costs paid. 
    Any person convicted in the municipal court and sentenced to pay a fine and costs only shall be committed to the city jail until the fine and costs imposed are paid in money, or by labor at the rate of pay as prescribed by section 16-98. 
(Code 1962, § 17-93) 
Sec. 16-98. - Payment of fine, costs by labor. 
    In any case where the penalty imposed is both a fine and imprisonment, and if the fines and costs are not paid in money, the person so sentenced shall be required to pay the same by labor at the rate of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day before beginning the service of his term of imprisonment in the city jail. 
(Code 1962, § 17-94; Ord. No. 3470, § 1, 9-3-74) 
State Law reference- Authority to require prisoners to work on streets, see Miss. Code 1972, § 47-1-39; credit to be given per Miss. Code 1972, § 47-1-47, Miss. Code 1972, § 47-1-41. 
Sec. 16-99. - Prisoners to be jailed when not working. 
    Prisoners ordered to work on the streets in payment of fines and costs imposed against them, shall be lodged in the city jail at night, and on Sundays, and when not engaged in work, except that no prisoner shall be imprisoned beyond the maximum imprisonment prescribed by law, if such prisoner is found to be indigent. 
(Code 1962, § 17-95) 
Sec. 16-100. - Supervision, duties of jailor. 
    The jailor, under the supervision of the chief of police, shall be keeper of the city jail, and it shall be his duty to have it kept in proper repair and in good sanitary condition. He shall have charge of all prisoners while they are confined in the jail, and shall comply with all the laws governing and regulating the keeping of prisoners. 
(Code 1962, § 17-96) 
Sec. 16-101. - Separation of sexes, juveniles. 
    In confining prisoners in the city jail, separate cells shall be used for persons of different sexes. No person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be confined in a cell with other prisoners, but a separate and suitable room shall be provided for the detention of such minor prisoners. 
(Code 1962, § 17-97) 
State Law reference- Separation of sexes in municipal jails, Miss. Code 1972, § 47-1-39. 
Sec. 16-102. - Communicating with prisoners. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to speak or to hold any communication with any prisoner while at work on the streets, except by permission and in the presence of the officer in charge; any person violating this section, after having been admonished by the officer having the prisoners in charge, to desist and abstain from such communication, shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 17-98) 
Sec. 16-103. - Medical care. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police upon the claim of any prisoner of a need for medical attention to arrange for an examination by a reputable physician, the cost of which shall be borne by the city upon the certification of the chief. 
(Code 1962, § 17-99) 
Sec. 16-104. - Escape-Penalty. 
    If any person confined in the city jail upon any conviction for a criminal offense shall break such jail and escape therefrom, or shall escape from custody before confinement therein, he shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 17-100) 
Sec. 16-105. - Same-No credit for time at large. 
    If any prisoner, confined in the city jail for a criminal offense, shall escape therefrom, he may be pursued, retaken, and imprisoned again, notwithstanding the term for which he was sentenced to be imprisoned may have expired at the time he shall be retaken, and shall remain so imprisoned until he shall have served as a prisoner the entire length of time which he would have been required to so serve had he not escaped, and until tried for such escape, or until discharged, on a failure to prosecute therefor. 
(Code 1962, § 17-101) 
Sec. 16-106. - Same-Aiding escape from officers. 
    Every person in the city who shall aid or assist any prisoner in escaping or attempting to escape from the custody of any policeman or other officer or person who shall have the lawful charge of such prisoner upon any criminal charge, shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 17-102) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-9-33. 
Sec. 16-107. - Same-Aiding escape from jail. 
    Every person who shall, by any means whatever, aid or assist any prisoner lawfully detained in the city jail or other place of confinement in the city, in an attempt to escape therefrom, whether such escape be effective or not or who shall forcibly rescue any prisoner held in legal custody in the city upon any criminal charge, shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 17-103) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 97-9-31. 
Secs. 16-108-16-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INTERCEPTION OF POLICE RADIO SIGNALS 

Sec. 16-121. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    High frequency police radio receiving set shall mean any radio receiving set capable of receiving any message sent out by any police radio station. 
    Person shall include the singular and the plural and shall also mean and include any person, firm, corporation, association, club, copartnership, society or any other organization. 
(Code 1962, § 17-115; Ord. No. 3227, 8-4-67) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 16-122. - High frequency police radio sets prohibited; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to equip or operate inside the city any motor vehicle with a high frequency police radio receiving set, unless such motor vehicle is being used by the federal, state, city or county government, a peace officer, or a permit for the use of the same shall be granted as hereinafter prescribed. 
(Code 1962, § 17-116; Ord. No. 3227, 8-4-67) 
Sec. 16-123. - Permits-Application. 
    Any person desiring a permit from the city council to operate a high frequency police radio receiving set in a motor vehicle inside the city shall file an application with the city council in writing, stating the name of the applicant, the license number, engine number, model and make of the motor vehicle in which it is desired to install such set and shall furnish a photograph of applicant and his fingerprints. The application shall also state the reason why it is desired to install said set. If the city council finds that the application shows a need for the set, that the set will be used for a lawful purpose, and that the public interest will be served by a granting of the application he shall issue a permit for installation and use of the set upon payment by the applicant of a fee of five dollars ($5.00) per year. An application must be filed and a new permit must be secured for each year a high frequency police radio receiving set is used. 
(Code 1962, § 17-117; Ord. No. 3227, 8-4-67) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 16-124. - Same-Not transferable. 
    Any permit issued under the provision of section 16-123 heretofore shall not be transferable to any other person and any high frequency police radio receiving set authorized to be installed and used by any such permit shall not be placed in any other motor vehicle than the one (1) described in the application for such permit without first obtaining from the city council for the removal of such set to the other motor vehicle. No fee shall be charged for such removal permit. In case of a change in license number of any motor vehicle in which a high frequency police radio receiving set has been permitted under this article, the owner of such vehicle shall notify the police chief of such change within five (5) days after the change is made. 
(Code 1962, § 17-118; Ord. No. 3227, 8-4-67) 
Sec. 16-125. - Police radio calls. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle, other than city officers and police and fire department officers in the line of duty, to follow up and answer such radio police calls, or in any way interfere with police officers answering radio police calls. 
(Code 1962, § 17-119; Ord. No. 3227, 8-4-67) 
Sec. 16-126. - Installation of radios. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install any high frequency police radio receiving set in any motor vehicle unless the owner and operator of said motor vehicle is within the exceptions set forth in section 16-122. 
(Code 1962, § 17-120; Ord. No. 3227, 8-4-67) 
Secs. 16-127-16-140. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - CURFEW FOR MINORS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4046, § 9, adopted March 19, 1996, repealed provisions formerly set out as Ch. 16, Art. VI, §§ 16-151-16-160 of the Code, which pertained to the nocturnal curfew for minors and derived from Ord. No. 3972, §§ 1-10, adopted June 7, 1994; Ord. No. 3995, §§ 1-10, adopted Nov. 1, 1994; Res. No. 4187, adopted Nov. 15, 1994; and Ord. No. 4016, §§ 1-10, adopted June 20, 1995. Ord. No. 4046, §§ 1-11, enacted new curfew provisions which have been included herein as Ch. 16, Art. VI, §§ 16-151-16-161, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 16-151. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the curfew ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 1, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 16-152. - Purpose and findings. 
    The city council has determined that large numbers of juveniles congregate in the city causing general disturbances to residents, and contributing to an excessive number of incidents of drug and alcohol related crimes, thefts, assaults and homicides including a high percentage of crimes committed by and against juveniles; and 
    The city council finds and determines that special and extenuating circumstances exist within this city that call for special regulation of minors within the city in order to protect them from each other and from other persons on the street during the certain herein specified hours, and to aid in crime prevention, to promote parental supervision and authority over minors and to decrease juvenile crime rates; and 
    In accordance with the prevailing community standards, this article serves to regulate the conduct of juveniles on streets during those certain herein specified hours, to be effectively and consistently enforced for the protection of the juveniles in Meridian from each other and from other persons on the streets during those certain herein specified hours, for the enforcement of parental control of, authority over and responsibility for their children, for the protection of the public from mischief by juveniles, for the reduction in the incidents of juvenile criminal activity, for the furtherance of family responsibility and for the public good, safety and welfare; and 
    After careful review and evaluation of this article, the council finds that there is justification for the purposes and findings herein to enact this article. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 2, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 16-153. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular and words in the singular number include the plural. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Adult is a person eighteen (18) years or older or any person who is legally emancipated. 
    City is the City of Meridian, Mississippi with administrative offices at City Hall, P.O. Box 1430, Meridian Mississippi 39302-1430. 
    Compulsory school age child means a child who has attained or will attain the age of six (6) years on or before September 1 of the calendar year and who has not attained the age of seventeen (17) years on or before September 1 of the calendar year. 
    Minor or juvenile is any unemancipated person under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
    Parent is any person or persons having legal custody of a minor (i) as a natural or adoptive parent; (ii) as a legal guardian; or (iii) as a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of a court. 
    Police Department shall refer to the police department headquarters located at 2415 6th Street, Meridian, Mississippi, or any officially designated precinct of said Department. 
    Remain means to stay behind, to tarry and to stay unnecessarily upon the streets, including the congregating of groups (or of interacting minors) totaling four (4) or more persons in which any minor involved would not be using the streets for ordinary or serious purposes such as mere passage or going home. The numerous exemptions expressly defined in section 16-154 demonstrates that this article is not a mere prohibitory or presence type curfew ordinance. 
    Street is a way or place, of whatsoever nature, open to the use of the public as a matter or right for purposes of vehicular travel or in the case of time, whether central standard time or central daylight savings time, generally observed at that hour by the public in the city, prima facie the time when observed in the city administrative office and police department. 
    Year of age continues from one birthday, such as the seventeenth, to (but not including the day of) the next, making it clear that seventeen (17) or less years of age is herein treated as equivalent to the phrase "under eighteen (18) years of age", unless specifically defined differently herein. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 3, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 16-154. - Restrictions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any minor under eighteen (18) years of age to retain in or upon any public street, highway, park, vacant lot or other public place within the city between those hours beginning at 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. next following, Sundays through Thursdays, and between those hours beginning at 12:00 a.m. (midnight) on Fridays to 6:00 a.m. next following, and beginning at 12:00 a.m. (midnight) on Saturdays to 6:00 a.m. next following. 
(b)  It shall also be unlawful for any compulsory school age child to remain in or upon any public street, highway, park, vacant lot or other place within the city during the following period: 
(1)  8:45 a.m. until 2:45 p.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday, and from 8:45 a.m. until 1:30 p.m. on Wednesday, during the school term in which [a] compulsory school age child is to be enrolled in a public or private legitimate non-public school, as required by the Mississippi Compulsory School Attendance Law (Section 37-13-19). 
(2)  Notwithstanding subsection (b)(1) above, beginning with the last stated day of the school term, the hours of curfew for subsection (a) above will be from 12:00 a.m. (midnight) to 6:00 a.m. next following on Sundays through Saturdays and shall so remain until the beginning of the next regular school term at which time the hours of curfew set forth in subsection (a) above shall again be applicable. 
(3)  Not withstanding subsection (b)(1) above, beginning with the last stated day of the school term, the hours of curfew stated therein will be suspended until the beginning of the next regular school term, at which time these stated hours shall again be applicable. 
(c)  It shall further be unlawful for a parent or a minor to knowingly permit or by inefficient control to allow such minor to be or remain upon any city street under circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise beyond the scope of this article. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge which a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a minor in that parent's legal custody. It is intended to continue to keep neglectful or careless parents up to a reasonable community standard of parental responsibility through an objective test. It shall, a fortiori, be no defense, that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts of such minor child. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 4, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 16-155. - Exceptions. 
    The following shall constitute the valid exceptions to the operation of the curfew. 
(1)  At any time, if a minor is accompanied by his or her parent; or, 
(2)  When a minor is accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent of such minor to take said parent's place in accompanying said minor for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area; or, 
(3)  If the minor is legally employed, for the period from forty-five minutes before to forty-five minutes after work, while going directly between his or her home and place of employment. This exception shall also apply if the minor is in a public place during curfew hours in the course of his or her employment. To come within this exception, the minor must be carrying a written statement of employment issued by employer, pursuant to the authorization of the chief of police, to expire within ninety (90) days; or, 
(4)  If a minor is on the property of or the sidewalk directly adjacent to the place where such minor resides, or the place immediately adjacent thereto, if the owner of the adjacent property does not communicate an objection to the minor and the police officer; or, 
(5)  When returning home by a direct route from (and within thirty (30) minutes of the termination of) a school activity or an activity of a religious or other voluntary association, or a place of public entertainment. This exception shall not apply beyond 1:30 a.m. If the event is not commercial in nature or does not have a fixed, publicly known time at which it will or does end, the sponsoring organization must register the event with the chief of police (or his assigned representative) at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance, informing the police department of the time such event is scheduled to begin, the place at which it shall be held, the time at which it shall end and the name of the sponsoring organization and the name, address and telephone number of a person whom the police department may contact with regards to the event; or 
(6)  In the case of reasonable necessity, but only after such minor's parent has communicated to the police department personnel the facts establishing such reasonable necessity relating to specified streets at a designated time for a described purpose including place of origin and destination. A copy of such communication, or the police record thereof, duly certified by the chief of police to be correct, an appropriate notation of the time it was received and of the names and addresses of such parent and minor shall constitute evidence of qualification under this exception; or, 
(7)  When exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly. Such minor shall provide bona fide evidence of such exercise and provide notice to city officials by first delivering to the Police Department a written communication, signed by such minor, with their home address and telephone number, addressed to the mayor of the city specifying when, where and in what manner said minor will be on the streets at night (during hours when the curfew ordinance [is] to still otherwise be applicable to said minor) in the exercise of a First Amendment right specified in such communication. Said notice must be received a minimum of 24 hours prior to the intended exercise of First Amendment rights and shall be subject to the same requirements and restrictions as the current policy and procedure applicable to parade permits; or 
(8)  When a minor is, with parental consent, in a motor vehicle engaged in bona fide interstate travel through the city, particularly on Interstates 59 and 20 and all access roads to these interstate systems. This also exempts all interstate travel beginning or ending in the City of Meridian; and 
(9)  Any exception set forth in the text of the Mississippi Compulsory School Attendance Law, Section 37-13-91. 
    Each of the foregoing exceptions, and their several limitations, such as provisions for notification, are severable, as hereinafter provided, but here re-emphasized. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 5, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 16-156. - Violations. 
(a)  A police officer of the city who has probable cause to believe that a minor is in violation of this article shall transport the minor to the police department. 
    When a minor is taken to the police department, the minor's parents shall be immediately contacted. If after this contact there is still probable cause to believe that the minor was violating this article, the minor shall be held until the parent comes to take the minor home. When the parent arrives, he or she shall be given a copy of this article. If no parent has arrived within two (2) hours, the minor shall be turned over to custody of the local juvenile authorities until a parent can take custody of him or her, and the chief of police shall, by certified mail, send to the minor's parent written notice of said violation and a copy of this article. Said notice shall be sent to the minor's parent at his or her last known address and evidence of its mailing as specified shall constitute sufficient notice of the minor's violation. 
(b)  (1)  If, after the warning notice as set forth in subsection 16-156(a) herein is delivered to the parent, there is a second violation of this article by the minor, the parent of the minor will be held to have violated subsection 16-154(b) in connection with the second violation by the minor, and this shall be treated as a first offense by the parent. For such first parental offense, a parent shall be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00). For each subsequent offense, the fine shall be increased by a doubling factor, fifty dollars ($50.00) for second, one hundred dollars ($100.00) for third, two hundred dollars ($200.00) for fourth offense, etc. 
(2)  In addition to the fine set forth in subsection (b)(1), each minor shall be sentenced to perform community service work for each third and additional violation. The court, in its discretion, may require each parent to perform community service work, with due regard given for age and health considerations, for each third and subsequent violation. 
(c)  Any minor who shall violate any of the provisions of this article more than one (1) time shall be dealt with according to the youth court law of the State of Mississippi and in accordance with the directives of the youth court of Lauderdale County, Mississippi, or other court as shall have jurisdiction of said minor. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 6, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 16-157. - Construction and Severability. 
    Severability is intended through and within the provisions of this article. If any provision, including inter alia, any exception, part, phrase, or term of, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, the application of other persons or circumstances shall not be affected thereby and the validity of this article in any and all other respects shall not be affected thereby. The council does not intend a result that is absurd, impossible to execute or unreasonable. It is intended that this article be held inapplicable in such cases, if any, where its application would be unconstitutional. A constitutional construction is intended and shall be given. The council does not intend to violate the Constitution of the State of Mississippi or the Constitution of the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 7, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 16-158. - Continuing evaluation. 
    The city council will continue its evaluation and updating of this article through methods including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Within one (1) month after the implementation of this article and each and every month thereafter, the chief of police or his duly appointed representative shall provide the city council with a complete report concerning the effect of this article on crimes committed by and against minors, and of the number of warnings issued and arrests of minors and parents hereunder, and such other information and statistical or otherwise, as council may request. 
(2)  After receipt of the police chief's report, the clerk of the council shall place this matter on the city council agenda for discussion, review and continuing its evaluation. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 8, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 16-159. - Effective date. 
    In the interest of the immediate or temporary preservation of public peace, health or safety or for other good cause, this article shall be effective from and after passage, if passed by a unanimous vote, and thirty (30) days after passage if passed by a majority vote. 
    As of the effective date hereof, the ordinance known as the "Amended Nocturnal Curfew Ordinance" and the ordinance known as the "Daytime Curfew Ordinance", each previously ordained by the city council shall stand repealed. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 9, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 16-160. - Notice. 
    The city clerk shall provide notice of this article and of the curfew regulations established by it by having copies of the article posted in, or about such public or quasi-public places as may be determined by the mayor, city council and police department in order that the public may be constantly informed of the existence of the article and its amendments and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 10, 3-19-96) 
Sec. 16-161. - Article cumulative. 
    This article shall be cumulative and in addition to any other laws in force. 
(Ord. No. 4046, § 11, 3-19-96) 
Secs. 16-162-16-170. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VIII. - BONITA LAKES WATERSHED FIRE PREVENTION ACT OF 2005[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4266, adopted Apr. 5, 2005 did not specify manner of codification, hence these provision were included as Art. VIII, §§ 16-182-16-184 by the editor. 

Sec. 16-182. - Findings and intent. 
    The Meridian City Council does hereby find as follows: 
    Smoking on any trail within the Bonita Lakes Watershed presents a significant and unacceptable fire hazard; and 
    Many visitors to the Bonita Lakes Watershed patron this location for the purpose of pursuing health related activities such as walking, jogging and hiking; and 
    Smoking, even in outdoor locations, is inconsistent with health related physical fitness activities; and 
    In order to facilitate the safety, health and enjoyment of individuals at Bonita Lakes, a smoke free environment should be maintained on all trails located on the Bonita Lakes Watershed; and 
    The litter associated with smoking is inconsistent with the natural beauty and attractiveness of the Bonita Lakes Watershed; and 
    The Meridian City Council finds and declares that the purposes of this article are (1) to protect the public health, safety and welfare by prohibiting smoking and the related fire hazard on all trails at Bonita Lakes Watershed on property owned by the City of Meridian; (2) to guarantee the right of nonsmokers to breathe smokefree air; and (3) to assist in maintaining litter free conditions at Bonita Lakes. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in all areas whether open or enclosed which are located on any portion of any trail located at the Bonita Lakes Watershed and owned by the City of Meridian, and that a "trail" is defined for purposes of this provision as an improved or unimproved path designed for the movement of pedestrian traffic, including jogging paths, equestrian traffic, or off-road vehicles, but shall not include golf-cart paths at the municipal golf course. 
(Ord. No. 4266, 4-5-2005) 
Sec. 16-183. - Enforcement. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the mayor of the city or an authorized designee. 
(b)  Notice of the provisions of this article shall be posted at the main entrance to the Bonita Lakes Watershed located adjacent to Highway 19 South. 
(c)  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an infraction, punishable by a fine not exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) for each separate occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 4266, 4-5-2005) 
Sec. 16-184. - Other applicable laws. 
    This article shall not be interpreted or construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise restricted by other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 4266, 4-5-2005) 
Chapter 17 - PLANNING[1]

ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Provisions relating to planning commissions, Miss. Code 1972, § 17-1-3 et seq. 

Sec. 17-16. - Created; membership, terms. 
    There is hereby created a city planning commission which shall consist of nine (9) members to be appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval of the city council, after the initial terms expire, appointments shall be made for a term of five (5) years. 
(Code 1962, § 2-99; Ord. No. 3637, § 1, 4-6-82) 
Sec. 17-17. - Compensation. 
    The members of the city planning commission shall serve without compensation of any kind. 
(Code 1962, § 2-100) 
Sec. 17-18. - Duties. 
    The duties of the city planning commission shall be to consider, within the limits of time which each of the members can contribute, such matters pertaining to city planning as are submitted to it in writing or originated by the commission, and to recommend to the city council such action as may be agreed upon by such commission. 
(Code 1962, § 2-101) 
Sec. 17-19. - Additional personnel. 
    The mayor shall upon the request of the city planning commission make available to the city planning commission such engineering, secretarial, and other services of the city as in his judgement may be available from existing city personnel. 
(Code 1962, § 2-102) 
Secs. 17-20-17-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4288, § 1, adopted Feb. 5, 2006, repealed the former Art. III, §§ 17-30-17-55, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter. For complete derivation see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions generally, § 2-155 et seq.; flood damage prevention and control, Ch. 10; variance procedures relative to historic structures § 10-29. 
State Law reference- Historic preservation districts and landmarks, Miss. Code 1972, § 39-13-1 et seq. 

Sec. 17-30. - Short title. 
    This article shall be cited as the Meridian Historic Preservation Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-31. - Historic preservation-Purpose. 
    The purposes and objectives of this article include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Safeguarding the local heritage by preserving the cultural, social, economic, political and architectural elements of the local history; 
(2)  Stabilizing or improving property values in the preservation district by district-wide upgrading of structures and environments, thus elevating the tax base; 
(3)  Fostering civic beauty by improving the buildings and environmental quality, through preservation and restoration of historic properties; 
(4)  Strengthening the local economy through preservation work and possible tourist interest and travel in the restored district; 
(5)  Promoting the use and preservation of historic districts for the education, welfare and pleasure of the residents; 
(6)  Establishing a program of public, semi-public and private historic preservation activities, to foster coordinated efforts by all sections of the community; 
(7)  Developing a financial plan using private, public and nonprofit funds to implement the program; 
(8)  Integrating the historic buildings and sites with the modern environment, realizing that a dynamic community is the result of a variety of visual effects, each complementing and reinforcing the other. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-32. - Historic preservation-Authority. 
(a)  Regulations. In addition to any power or authority of the city to regulate by planning or zoning laws and regulations or by local laws and regulations, the governing body of the city is hereby empowered to provide by regulations, special conditions or restrictions for the protection, enhancement, preservation and use of historic properties. Such regulations, special conditions and restrictions may include appropriate and reasonable control of the use or appearance of adjacent or associated private property within the public view, or both. 
(b)  Easements. The city may acquire, by purchase or donation, historic preservation easements in any area within their respective jurisdictions wherever and to the extent that the governing body of the city determines that the acquisition will be in the public interest. 
(c)  Exemption from other codes. In order to promote the preservation and restoration of historic properties within its jurisdiction, the city may exempt a historic property from the application of such standards contained in the life-safety or building codes, or both, if the commission and the building official determine that strict compliance would prevent or seriously hinder the preservation of said historic property and that this exemption will not significantly reduce public safety. 
(d)  Definitions. For the purpose of this article the definition of words and phrases shall be that established by MS Law Section 39-13-2 as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-33. - Meridian Historic Preservation Commission-Created. 
(a)  The City of Meridian does hereby establish a historic preservation commission, hereinafter referred to as "the Meridian Historic Preservation Commission", or "the Commission" or as "the MHPC" or as "the Meridian HPC", pursuant to Section 39-13-5 of the Mississippi Code of 1972 as amended, to preserve, promote and develop the historical resources of the city. 
(b)  The commission shall consist of seven (7) residents of the city who shall be appointed as for boards and commissions generally with due regard to proper representation in such fields as history, architecture, urban planning, archaeology, real estate, marketing and law. 
(c)  All members of the commission shall serve at the will and pleasure of the governing authority appointing them and shall serve staggered terms not to exceed six (6) years, and shall be eligible for reappointment. The commission shall employ such qualified staff and counsel as it deems necessary. 
(d)  The commission shall be and hereby is empowered to promulgate and publish other regulations as it deems necessary and appropriate for the conduct of its business. 
(e)  All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public and regular minutes recording the "yeas" and "nays" of all votes taken and all exhibits shall be kept and preserved; provided, however, that upon a vote of a majority of the members present, the commission may go into closed session, but only if necessary and for the purpose of maintaining confidentially during a discussion concerning property values. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-34. - Same-Authorization. 
    The commission established by the city shall, upon the approval of the city be authorized to: 
(1)  Advise the city as to the designation of historical preservation districts and the designation of historic landmarks and landmark sites; 
(2)  Recommend ordinances or amendments thereto, and otherwise provide the information for the purposes of historic preservation to the city; 
(3)  Conduct a survey of local historic properties, complying with all applicable standards and criteria of the statewide survey undertaken by the state's department of archives and history; 
(4)  Acquire fee and lessor interests in historic properties, including adjacent or associated lands, by purchase, bequest or donation; 
(5)  Preserve, restore, maintain and operate historic properties under the ownership or control of the city; 
(6)  Lease, sell and otherwise transfer or dispose of historic properties subject to rights of public access and other covenants, and in a manner that will preserve the property; 
(7)  Contract with the state or the federal government or any agency of either, or with any other organization; 
(8)  Cooperate with the federal, state and local governments in the pursuance of the objectives of historic preservation; 
(9)  Participate in the conduct of land use, urban renewal and other planning processes undertaken for historic preservation; 
(10)  Promote and conduct an educational and interpretive program on historic properties within its jurisdiction; 
(11)  Enter, solely in performance of its official duties and only at reasonable times, upon private lands for examination or survey thereof. However, no member, employee or agent of the commission may enter any private building or structure without the express consent of the owner or occupant thereof; 
(12)  Incorporate as a nonprofit corporation. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-35. - Same-Appropriations and acquisitions. 
    The city is authorized under state law to make appropriations to the commission necessary for the expenses of the operation of the commission, and may make available additional amounts necessary for the acquisition, restoration, preservation, operation and management of historic properties. The city may apply to participate in the certified local government program of the National Park Service, which is administered in Mississippi by the department of archives and history and may on behalf of the commission apply for funding from the department of archives and history to supplement funds available from the city itself. The city council shall not acquire by eminent domain any historic preservation properties unless such properties are needed for governmental purposes other than historic preservation. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Secs. 17-36-17-39. - Reserved. 
Sec. 17-40. - Historic districts, landmarks and landmark sites-Designation. 
    The city may establish by ordinance one (1) or more historic districts and/or sites within the area of its jurisdiction. No historic district, districts or sites shall be designated until the following requirements are met: 
(1)  An investigation of the historical, architectural, archaeological and cultural significance of the buildings, structures, features, sites and surroundings of the proposed districts, landmarks or historic sites shall be made; 
(2)  A public hearing will be had, after notice, specifying the boundaries of any proposed historic preservation district historic landmarks and landmark sites. Such notice shall be published once a week for at least three (3) consecutive weeks in at least one (1) newspaper published in the city.
