The first publication of such resolution shall be made not less than twenty-one (21) days prior to the date fixed in such resolution for the public hearing, and the last publication shall be made not more than seven (7) days prior to such date; 
(3)  No historic preservation district or landmark shall be designated until the state's department of archives and history has been notified by certified letter from the city and invited to make recommendations regarding the proposed district boundaries. When a proposed historic district, or landmark or landmark site boundary deviates from formal legal descriptions, there must be written justification for such a deviation in any local designating ordinance. 
(4)  Within sixty (60) calendar days after the public hearing held in connection herewith, the city council shall consider the proposal and either designate the proposed area as a historic preservation district, or deny designation of the proposed area as a historic preservation district; 
(5)  Appeals from such determination by the city council shall be as otherwise required by law as for appeals from zoning decisions by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-41. - Same-Nomination. 
(a)  A potential historic district or landmark or landmark site may be proposed for designation by either a majority of the members of the commission, or an owner of a potential landmark or landmark site, or an organization which has as one of its central purposes the promotion of historic preservation objectives. If in private ownership, a landmark site must include significant surviving landscape features to qualify for designation unless its primary significance is archeological, and new construction after review and approval, shall be built to fit into such landscape features rather than replace them or shall be designed to avoid insofar as possible an archeological resource rather than replace it. If in public ownership, the commission shall discourage new construction on a site of great significance to the entire community unless the new construction can be located on a portion of the site which will permit a continuing understanding of its historical character and will avoid damage to surviving landscape features or an archeological resource. 
(b)  Once a nomination has been filed with the commission to designate one (1) or more local properties, a decision on whether to proceed with the designation must be made within six (6) months. A majority of the commission's members must vote in favor of any proposed designation in order for the file supporting the designation to be sent forward to the city council for its consideration. 
(c)  No file purporting to justify a proposed designation may be forwarded to the city council unless the commission's recommendation includes a map that clearly delineates boundaries for the proposed designation, a verbal description and justification of the proposed boundaries and a written statement of significance for the historic district or landmark or landmark site proposed for designation. 
(d)  The commission must notify, as quickly as reasonably possible, other municipal agencies and any appropriate county or state agencies of the designation of a historic district, landmark or landmark site. The commission must maintain in its official files an updated list and map of local designations and provide copies of such a map to other governmental agencies within one (1) week of the preparation of a new version of the map. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-42. - Historic districts and landmarks established. 
    The following historic preservation district, landmarks and landmark sites is hereby established and adopted: 
(1)  Meridian Downtown Historic District. Beginning at the intersection of the north ROW line of the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad with the centerline of 18th Avenue; and then, southwest along the north line of the IC&G Railroad to its intersection with the centerline of 26th Avenue; and then northwest along the centerline of 26th Avenue to its intersections with the centerline of 6th Street; and then northeast along the centerline of 6th Street to its intersection with the centerline of 19th Avenue; and then southeast along the centerline of 19th Avenue to the centerline of 5th Street; and then northeast along the centerline of 5th Street to the centerline of 18th Avenue; and the southeast along the centerline of 18th Avenue to the point of beginning described above. 
(2)  The historic landmarks and landmark sites as these are listed on the National Register of Historic Places and as same may be amended from time to time, and the Jerry and Selena Burton House at 1417 29th Avenue being also Tax Parcel #083073349900301400. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006; Ord. No. 4438, § 1, 6-3-2014) 
Sec. 17-43. - Residential districts recognized. 
    Although six (6) local residential neighborhood historic districts have been listed on the National Register of Historic Places, these districts have not been adopted locally as being included in the area subject to this article. However, this shall not preclude such districts, landmarks and landmark sites from receiving the benefit of federal, state, and local tax abatements, exemptions, credits, grants, endowments or other such incentives for their preservation. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Secs. 17-44-17-49. - Reserved. 
Sec. 17-50. - Certificates of appropriateness [COA]-Approval required. 
(a)  The commission or the city council acting upon the advice of the commission, may approve an application and issue a certificate of appropriateness [COA] if it finds that a proposed construction, alteration, demolition, subdivision or relocation is: consistent with the design review guidelines established by the commission; would be compatible with the character of a historic district or landmark or landmark site; and does not compromise the historic and architectural integrity of the historic district landmark or landmark site. 
(b)  The city council may require that a property owner post a bond to guarantee satisfactory completion of a relocation project. 
(c)  A partial demolition shall be considered an alteration. 
(d)  Applications for a COA shall be denied only upon determination by the commission that the proposed changes would: 
(1)  Result in such disharmony of scale and/or style between the proposed project and its immediate surroundings and the historic preservation district as a whole as to undermine the architectural integrity and character of the historic preservation district, and inhibit the accomplishment of the purposes of this article; or, 
(2)  Result in such a change in the architectural design or character of an existing building or improvement as to undermine the architectural design or character of such existing building or improvement, and inhibit the accomplishment of the purposes of this article; or, 
(3)  Result in the loss or irreparable harm to an existing building or improvement of architectural or historical significance. 
(4)  In making its evaluation, the commission shall seek to accomplish the purposes of this article and, in particular, to preserve and protect the architectural and historical integrity and character of the historic preservation district or historic site. 
(e)  The commission shall promulgate and publish such regulations and standards as necessary to inform the public of and to clarify and make certain the criteria by which applications for certificates of appropriateness shall be evaluated. 
(f)  The commission shall not consider interior arrangement, design, or use nor shall it make any requirements affecting such, except as necessary for the attainment of the purposes of this article. 
(g)  In cases in which the commission shall disapprove an application for a COA, the written denial thereof shall include specific reasons for such denial and recommendations allowing qualification. 
(h)  The commission may approve such application in any case where either the owner, or the district would suffer extreme hardship, unless the COA was issued forthwith. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-51. - Same-Applicability. 
(a)  Except as otherwise allowed under this section, after designation as a historic district, landmark or landmark site, no exterior portion of any building or other structure (including walls, fences, light fixtures, steps and pavement, or other appurtenance features), nor above-ground utility structure, nor any type of outdoor advertising sign shall be erected, altered, restored, moved or demolished until an application for a COA as to exterior features and proposed changes thereto has been submitted to and approved by the commission. A COA shall be required whether or not a building permit is required. The city does herein require such a certificate to be issued by the commission prior to the issuance of any building permit or other approval. 
(b)  No change in the use of any structure or property within a designated historic district, landmark or landmark site shall be permitted until after an application for a COA has been submitted to and approved by the commission. The city does herein require such a certificate to be issued by the commission prior to the approval of any change of zoning classification within the historic district or of the historic landmark or landmark site. 
(c)  When small portions of a building or a structure are to be restored, such minor restoration work may be allowed without approval of a COA at the discretion of the building official upon a finding that such restoration will maintain the original historical integrity of the building or structure. 
(d)  Interior changes shall not require a COA unless the MHPC secretary finds such changes to be incongruous with the historical, architectural, archaeological or cultural aspects of the historic district, landmark or landmark site. 
(e)  The ordinary maintenance or repair of any structure which does not involve a change in design, material, color or outer appearance thereof, and minor restoration work which maintains the original historical integrity of the structure and any change which the building official or similar official shall certify is required because of an unsafe or dangerous condition may be allowed without benefit of a COA if approved by the MHPC secretary. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-52. - Same-Criteria for issuance. 
    The commission shall adhere to and seek compatibility of structures in the historic district, landmark or landmark site in terms of size, texture, scale, and site plan, and in so doing; the following guidelines shall be considered in passing upon applications for a COA: 
(1)  For new construction: 
a.  All new construction shall be visually compatible with the buildings and environment with which they are related; 
b.  The design, scale, gross volume, arrangement, site plan, texture, material and exterior architectural features of new construction shall be in harmony with its surroundings, and shall not impair the "tout ensemble" of the neighborhood; 
c.  No single architectural style shall be imposed and diversity is encouraged; 
d.  Quality and excellence in design should be major determinants with the primary goal being the creation of future contributing resources. 
(2)  For exterior alterations including signage: 
a.  All exterior alterations to a building shall be compatible with the building itself and other buildings with which it is related, as described in subsection (1)b above, and in applying these standards the original design of the building may be considered; 
b.  Exterior alterations shall not affect the architectural character or historic quality of the building. 
(3)  For demolition: In considering an application for demolition within a historic district, landmark or landmark site the following shall be considered: 
a.  The historic or architectural significance of the building; 
b.  The importance of the building to the "tout ensemble" of the district; 
c.  The special character and aesthetic interests that the building adds to the district; 
d.  The difficulty or impossibility of reproducing such a building because of its design, texture, material or detail; 
e.  The future utilization of the site. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-53. - Same-Procedure for issuance. 
(a)  Prior to issuance or denial of a COA, the commission shall take such action as may be reasonably required to inform the owners of any property likely to be materially affected by the application, and shall give the applicant and such owners an opportunity to be heard. 
(b)  Anyone desiring to take action within a historic preservation district, landmark or landmark site for which a building or other permit from the city is either required, or not otherwise required, shall apply for a COA directly to the commission by making an application containing: 
(1)  A description of the subject property and its location within the historic preservation district; 
(2)  A description of the action sought to be taken; 
(3)  Explanation of how the action is to be accomplished; 
(4)  Other information and exhibits as may be required; 
(5)  And a review fee per the latest adopted fee schedule. 
(c)  Whether a building permit is otherwise required or not, after a COA has been issued, the city's community development department shall have the authority to inspect the work in progress to ensure compliance with the plans, specifications and other conditions upon which the COA was issued. 
(d)  Any person may appeal from a ruling of the commission. Such appeal shall be made within thirty (30) days of the date of such ruling, to the city council. The appellant shall file with the commission a notice of appeal, specifying the grounds thereof. The chairman of the commission shall forthwith transmit to the governing authority all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. The final disposition of any such appeal shall be in the form of a decision expressed in a resolution, with reversing, modifying, or affirming, wholly, or partially, the commission's decision or determination. Any person aggrieved at the findings of the city council shall have the right of appeal in the manner provided by law as for zoning decisions. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Secs. 17-54-17-58. - Reserved. 
Sec. 17-59. - Certificates of appropriateness-Demolition. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this article for the owner of any building or other structure within the established and adopted historic districts, landmarks and landmark sites to undertake or to contract for the demolition of any such building or structure without first having obtained a COA for such demolition. 
(b)  A historic property designated by ordinance as herein provided may be demolished only after one hundred eighty (180) days' written notice of the owner's proposed action has been given to the commission. During this period, the commission may negotiate with the owner and with any other parties in an effort to find a means of preserving the property. The commission may enter into negotiations with the owner for the acquisition by gift, purchase, exchange or otherwise of the property or any interest therein. 
(c)  The commission may reduce the waiting period required by this section in any case where it has found reasonable cause for such reduction and said cause is made into record. If a property in a historic district or a historic landmark or landmark site is demolished without review and approval by the commission, the governing authority may require that the owner rebuild on the site using as much of the original building material as possible, but in general following the same form. Unauthorized demolition of a portion of a structure shall not serve as justification for a demolition permit whenever it can be shown that restoration or rehabilitation would still be feasible. 
(d)  Whenever a structure or structures is demolished without review and approval by the commission, the governing authority may require that no permit shall be issued for any structure or structures proposed for the same parcel which would require a footprint larger than the footprint of the demolished structure or structures. 
(5)  If a historic landmark or landmark site of statewide or national significance is demolished without review and approval by the commission, the governing authority may require that no permit for any construction on the parcel from which the landmark or landmark site has been removed may be issued for a period of up to twenty-four (24) months. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-60. - Demolition by neglect. 
(a)  "Demolition by neglect" is defined as improper maintenance or lack of maintenance of any property in a historic district, or any historic landmark or landmark site, which results in substantial deterioration of such a property and threatens its continued stability and preservation. 
(b)  If the commission determines that a historic property is being "demolished by neglect," they shall notify the record owner or owners of the building of this finding, stating the reasons therefore, and shall give the record owner thirty (30) days from the date of the notice in which to commence work rectifying the specifics provided by the commission. 
(c)  If the work to rectify has not commenced by the thirtieth day, the commission shall again notify the record owner or owners to appear at the next meeting of the commission. If, after reviewing the facts of the case, the commission determines that the historic property is being "demolished by neglect" and that insufficient efforts are being made to preserve the resource, then it shall, through the appropriate officer or agency of the city, bring charges against the owner or owners for the violation of this article. 
(d)  In addition to the powers specified in MS Law Section 21-19-11(1) for cleaning private property, the city, with concurrence by the Mississippi Department of Archives and History, may make repairs necessary to correct demolition by neglect and the cost of such repairs shall become a lien against the property in accordance with MS Law Section 21-19-11(3). 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-61. - Tax exemptions. 
    Upon favorable recommendation of the commission, the city council may grant exemption from increases in ad valorem property tax resulting from improvements made in historic districts, landmarks and landmark sites pursuant to city Ordinance No. 4246 as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Sec. 17-62. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that a violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 4288, Exh. A, 2-5-2006) 
Secs. 17-63-17-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TREE PROTECTION[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Moving or trimming trees and shrubs in city rights-of-way, avenues, etc., § 20-30. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-71. - Intent and purpose. 
    The intent of this article is to aid in the stabilization of soil by the prevention of erosion and sedimentation; to reduce stormwater runoff and the costs associated therewith and replenish ground water supplies; to aid in the removal of carbon dioxide and generation of oxygen in the atmosphere; to provide a buffer and screen against noise pollution; to provide protection against severe weather; to aid in the control of drainage restoration of denuded soil subsequent to construction or grading; to provide a haven for birds which in turn assist in the control of insects; to protect and increase property values; conserve and enhance the physical environment and aesthetics; generally to protect and enhance the quality of life and the general welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 1, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 1, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-72. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person is any public or private individual, group, firm, corporation, partnership, association, society or combination of human beings whether legal or natural. 
    Removal is the actual removal or causing the effective removal through damaging, poisoning or other direct or indirect actions resulting in the death of a tree. 
    Shrub is any woody plant that remains low and produces shoots or trunks from the base. 
    Tree is any tree or shrub pruned "tree form" in a public place. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 2, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-73. - Tree species to be planted. 
    The city shall develop and submit to the commission a list of the kinds and species of trees suitable and desirable for planting and the areas and conditions under which such trees should be planted. The commission shall review and approve said list, which as approved shall be known as the "Master Tree List." 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 7, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 7, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-74. - Administration and enforcement. 
    The community development department is hereby authorized to administer and enforce this article. The enforcement officer under this article shall be the city's landscape architect or urban forester. The enforcement officer shall have the authority to regulate all work performed under any permit issued under this article. It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, prevent, delay or interfere with the enforcement officer while engaged in the lawful execution or enforcement of this article. This shall not be construed as an attempt to prohibit the pursuit of any legal or equitable remedy in a court of competent jurisdiction for the protection of personal or property rights by any person within the city. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 8, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 8, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-75. - Trees in public places. 
    The city shall have exclusive jurisdiction over all trees, shrubs and grassy areas planted or growing in public right-of-ways, city parks and city-owned property. The city shall have the authority to plant, prune, spray, treat, preserve and remove trees, shrubs, and grassy areas in the above-described locations to ensure the safety and beauty of such public places. 
    The city may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree, shrub or part thereof which is found to be injurious to public utilities or private or public improvements, or is severely infected with any injurious fungus, disease or pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of same is in accordance with this article. 
    No such activities that involve the removal or pruning of a tree shall be undertaken by the city until review and consideration by the community development department. 
    No [person] shall intentionally or accidentally injure or damage any city tree. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 9, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 9, 11-17-92; Ord. No. 4219, § 1, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 17-76. - Permit required for the preservation, removal or planting of trees on public property. 
(a)  No person shall prune, spray, treat, preserve, remove or plant any tree in any public place without first obtaining a permit. 
(b)  Any person desiring a permit to prune, spray, treat, preserve or remove a tree in any public place shall submit a written application to the community development department setting forth: 
(1)  The number and kind of trees to be pruned, sprayed, treated, preserved or removed. 
(2)  The kind of treatment to be administered. 
(3)  The kind and condition of the nearest trees upon adjoining property. 
(4)  Such other information as the community development shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether a permit should be issued. 
(c)  Any person desiring a permit to plant any tree in any public place shall submit a written application to the community development department setting forth: 
(1)  A diagram of the area showing pavement, streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, with a definite indicated scale. 
(2)  The number, location and variety of trees to be planted. 
(3)  The number, location and variety of trees already existing in the area. 
(4)  The method of planting, including the supplying of suitable soil. 
(5)  Information concerning the on-going maintenance for the proposed tree. 
(6)  Such other information as the community development department shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether a permit should be issued. 
(d)  The community development department shall issue a permit under this section when it is determined that the desired action is necessary, the proposed methods satisfactory, and the plantings conform with the master street tree list, current comprehensive city tree plan as approved by the city council. Before and during all work authorized by the permit, the holder shall prominently keep the same on conspicuous display at the worksite. 
(e)  Public utilities having the right to construct and maintain power or transmission lines on public areas pursuant to valid certificates of public convenience and necessity from the public service commission are authorized to properly, and of necessity only, trim such trees, without further permit, as is necessary for the safe and proper operation and maintenance of such lines and consistent with the preservation and protection of our urban forest. Public utilities shall communicate and cooperate with appropriate city staff to facilitate proper maintenance of urban trees as well as power and transmission lines. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 10, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 10, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-77. - Distance from street corners and fire hydrants. 
    Trees and shrubbery may be planted near a street corner if approved by the community development department. No tree or shrub shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet and five (5) feet, respectively, from any fire hydrants. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 11, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 11, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-78. - Utilities. 
    No trees other than those species listed as small trees in the "master tree list" may be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of any overhead utility wire. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 12, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 12, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-79. - Interference with tree commission. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay, or interfere with the city tree commission or the city, or any of their agents, while engaging in and about the planting, maintenance or removal of any trees or shrubs authorized by this article. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 13, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 13, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-80. - Review by city council. 
    The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts, and decisions of the city tree commission. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city tree commission to the city council which shall make the final decision. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 14, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 14, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-81. - Emergencies. 
    In case of emergencies involving, but not limited to, hurricanes, windstorms, floods, freezes or other natural disasters, the requirements of this article may be suspended by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 15, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 15, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-82. - Penalties. 
    The city's landscape architect or urban forester shall evaluate each damaged tree and determine whether repair or replacement is required. Tree repair shall be the monetary value associated with all damage to a tree and may include wound treatment, bracing, pruning, and improving compacted soil (construction site damage). Tree replacement shall be the monetary value for replacement of a tree, which may be a one (1) for one (1) exchange or several smaller trees for one (1) larger tree and shall also include costs for tree, stump, and debris removal. 
    The Guide for Plant Appraisal, most current edition, shall determine monetary value for tree repair and tree replacement. 
    If removal is necessary for any tree planted in any public place without a permit, violator shall be responsible for all removal costs. 
    Noncompliance of penalties determined, after having been duly notified, shall constitute a misdemeanor, and any person convicted in city court of such a misdemeanor shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), per offense, and in addition shall pay all penalties, costs and expenses as determined by the court. Each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 16, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 16, 11-17-92; Ord. No. 4219, § 2, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 17-83. - Pruning or removal of trees and/or stumps on private property. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to require a permit for the pruning or removal of trees and/or stumps on private property. 
(b)  Permit required. A tree or stump removal permit is required of anyone removing or pruning trees or for stump removal on private property within the city's incorporated area. The required permit of any person, partnership or corporation receiving compensation for such tree removal or pruning or for stump removal may be issued effective for one (1) year from its issuance date. The city's building inspection division will, when it is proper so to do, issue the permit required herein. There is no charge for the permit. Any person partnership or corporation receiving compensation for such tree removal, pruning or stump removal shall obtain a general contractor's bond and must comply with section 12-57 of the city's Code of Ordinances. A property owner removing or pruning trees or removing stump must also comply with said section 12-57, the same as contractors of businesses must comply with. 
(c)  Enforcement. Any person, partnership or corporation violating or failing to comply with the requirements of this section shall be issued a written warning of noncompliance and a written demand for necessary corrective action within ten (10) days. If voluntary compliance is not obtained, the building official shall file a sworn complaint in the municipal court. Failure to comply with the regulations set forth in this section is a misdemeanor and shall subject the violator to a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day. Each day during which a violation continues is a separate offense and shall subject the offender to additional fines. 
(Ord. No. 4143, §§ 1-3, 1-4-2000) 
Secs. 17-84-17-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TREE COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and authorities, § 2-155 et seq. 

Sec. 17-91. - Creation and establishment. 
    There is hereby created and established a city tree commission which shall consist of seven (7) members, citizens and residents of Meridian, and at least one (1) Keep America Beautiful Commission member who shall be appointed by the mayor subject to approval by city council. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 3, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 3, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-92. - Term of office; compensation. 
(a)  The terms of the commissioners shall be three (3) years. On the first commission, two (2) members shall be appointed for (1) one year, three (3) members shall be appointed for two (2) years and two (2) members shall be appointed for three (3) years. Thereafter, appointments shall be made for three (3) years with persons to serve until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(b)  In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any members, a successor shall be appointed in like manner as above for the unexpired portion of the term. Members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 4, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 4, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 17-93. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the city to develop and present to the commission a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal, and disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. The commission shall review and approve such plan and such plan shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan for the city. The commission, when requested by the mayor or city council, shall consider, investigate, make finding, report and recommend upon any matter or issue within the scope of its work. The tree commission will not be responsible for city-owned forest lands that are managed by the Mississippi Forestry Commission at the time this article is adopted. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 5, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 5, 11-17-92; Ord. No. 4219, § 3, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 17-94. - Operation. 
    The commission shall annually elect its own officers, make its own rules and regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of its members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 3890, § 6, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3946, § 6, 11-17-92) 
Chapter 18 - POLICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- General penalty, § 1-9; additional compensation for policemen authorized, § 2-58; presence of police required during sessions of municipal court, § 2-185; alarm systems, § 7-261 et seq.; abatement of nuisances by police chief authorized, § 16-67; duty of police chief to abate nuisances, § 16-76; powers and duties of chief of police relative to traffic, § 23-2. 
State Law reference- For authority to appoint, regulate, support police force, see Miss. Code 1972, § 21-21-3; authority to conduct police stations, § 21-37-1; authority to pay policemen for overtime, § 21-9-63; authority to pay expenses of policemen attending training schools, § 21-21-7; medical care for injured policemen, § 21-21-9. 

Sec. 18-1. - Composition of department. 
    The police department shall be composed of a chief of police and such officers, assistants and employees as may from time to time be designated by the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 18-1) 
Sec. 18-2. - General duties of chief; supervision by mayor. 
    The chief of police shall, under the general direction and control of the mayor, be the head of the city's police department including all divisions of such department. He shall make all assignments to duty of the personnel of the police department and be responsible directly to the mayor for the proper and efficient operation of the police department. He shall, with the approval of the mayor, make such rules and regulations relating to the internal administration of the police department and its personnel as he deems necessary provided such regulations are not violative of any law or ordinance of this city. 
(Code 1962, § 18-2) 
Sec. 18-3. - Duties of records and court clerk. 
    The records and court clerk shall be the official clerk of the municipal court and shall keep and maintain such records in such court as are now and hereafter required by law or ordinance and shall, in addition, perform such other duties as may be assigned. He shall devote his full time to the discharge of his duties. 
(code 1962, § 18-3) 
State Law reference- Duties of municipal court clerk generally, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-23-11. 
Sec. 18-4. - Police officers declared governmental officers; general duties. 
    Police officers of the city are hereby declared to be governmental officers of the city, and the sole duties of all police officers shall be the enforcement of all criminal laws and ordinances of the city within its corporate limits. 
(Code 1962, § 18-4) 
Sec. 18-5. - Police officers to devote full time to duties. 
    Each member of the police force, including the chief of police, shall devote his or her whole time and attention to the business of the police department, and, although certain hours may be allotted to the members of the force for the ordinary performance of duty, each shall be deemed always subject to being recalled to duty, and must at all times be prepared to act immediately, on notice that his or her services are required. 
(Code 1962, § 18-5; Ord. No. 3913, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 18-6. - Impersonating police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, not being a police officer, to act as such, or to assume to act as such, or to wear the uniform or badge of a police officer, or in any manner whatever to represent himself as a police officer. Any person offending against the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1962, § 18-6) 
Sec. 18-7. - Inspections required; record of absences, time on duty. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police, or a sergeant of the police department under his direction to inspect the men when going on and off duty, and to make and keep an accurate return of the presence or absence of each member, together with the time each member has served. 
(Code 1962, § 18-7) 
Sec. 18-8. - Records to be kept by chief. 
    The chief of police shall keep in the police station the following well-bound record books, to be supplied by the city: 
(1)  Record of beats; daily reports. A record showing the beat to which each policeman is assigned, or the work in which he is engaged; and a summary of the daily reports and doings of the officers and other members of the force; 
(2)  Arrest docket. An arrest docket, on which shall be entered the following with respect to each arrest. The date of arrest; the true name of every person arrested; offense for which arrested; name of police officer or other officer making the arrest; disposition made of person arrested, whether released on bond or lodged in city jail, and if released on bond, amount of same and name of sureties; any other material facts connected with arrests which the chief may order recorded. 
(3)  Record of property and money taken from prisoners. A register on which shall be entered the following with respect to all money and other property taken from prisoners, or otherwise coming into possession of the chief of police or any member of the police department: The date of taking the property; the name of the person from whom taken or received; amount and description of the money or other property; the name of the officer taking the same; name of owner, whether it is the property of the prisoner or other person from whom taken, or whether it is stolen property, and if the owner is unknown, the fact to be so entered; and any other items which may be material. 
(Code 1962, § 18-8) 
Sec. 18-9. - Reports by chief to mayor. 
    The chief of police shall, in writing, report to the mayor each month his official acts and doings; the condition of the police department; the number of times each policeman has been absent each month, with the cause of such absence; the condition of the police station and city jail; the number of arrests made and the causes of arrests; the number of violations of ordinances reported, with any remark on the conduct of the police officer calling for remark; and he shall also report all violations of duty by the police department, and on failure to discharge this last named duty he himself may be held to be guilty of a neglect of duty, and may be tried the same as if his neglect appears to be wilful. 
(Code 1962, § 18-9) 
Sec. 18-10. - Chief to prevent political activity by police officer. 
    The chief of police shall see to it that no police officer participates in any political activity otherwise than to cast his vote at elections. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to report to the mayor any violation of this section. 
(Code 1962, § 18-10) 
Sec. 18-11. - Chief to preserve law and order, protect health. 
    The chief of police shall endeavor at all times, day or night, to preserve the public peace, prevent the commission of crimes, and arrest offenders; he shall protect the rights of persons and property; he shall pay strict regard to matters concerning the public health; he shall report all nuisances in streets, alleys and other places; he shall provide proper police force and protection at fires; he shall protect strangers and travelers at railway stations and other public places in the city; he shall enforce obedience to all laws and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 18-11) 
Sec. 18-12. - Disposition of property belonging to prisoners. 
    The chief of police shall take charge of all money and property taken from prisoners, or otherwise coming into the possession of any member of the police department, and an entry of same shall be made on the book required to be kept for that purpose. If it is the prisoner's property, or that of some other known person, the chief of police shall deliver it at the proper time to the prisoner or other person entitled to same, and note on the book the fact of such delivery. If it is stolen property or not the property of the prisoner, and the owner is unknown, it shall be proceeded with as provided by the following section. 
(Code 1962, § 18-13) 
Sec. 18-13. - Receipts to be deposited with city clerk. 
    The court clerk shall collect and deposit with the city clerk all fines and costs imposed in the municipal court and all forfeitures adjudged in that court, together with all collections made by him from every other source. 
(Code 1962, § 18-14) 
Sec. 18-14. - Molesting, interfering with police dogs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously torture, torment, beat, kick, strike, mutilate, injure, disable, or kill any dog used by the police department of the city in the performance of the functions or duties of such department, or to interfere with or meddle with any such dog while being used by such department or any officer or member thereof in the performance of any of the duties or functions of such department or of such officer or member. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1962, § 18-15) 
Sec. 18-15. - Police jurisdiction extended to all city property. 
    The police jurisdiction of the city is hereby declared to extend to all property owned by the city, whether within or outside of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 18-16) 
Sec. 18-16. - Special police-Appointment. 
    The mayor, with the approval of the city council, may appoint for a specified time as many special policemen from among employees of the city as may be deemed advisable for service in connection with any civil disturbance or any other emergency designated by the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 18-18; Ord. No. 3201, 5-21-63) 
Sec. 18-17. - Same-Powers, privileges. 
    During the term of service of special policemen appointed pursuant to section 18-16, they shall possess all of the powers and privileges and perform all of the duties of patrolmen in the standing police force of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 18-19; Ord. No. 3201, 5-21-63) 
Sec. 18-18. - Same-Identifying emblem. 
    Special policemen appointed pursuant to section 18-16 shall wear such identifying emblem as may be prescribed by the mayor and it shall be unlawful for any such special policemen to attempt to carry out any law, order or rule or regulation promulgated when he is not wearing such identifying emblem. 
(Code 1962, § 18-20; Ord. No. 3201, 5-21-63) 
Chapter 19 - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Planning, Ch. 17; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 23. 

Sec. 19-1. - Obstructing street crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company to obstruct any street or avenue in the city where the same is intersected by a railroad track by dropping or stopping any car or train of cars or any locomotive on the tracks on such street or avenue, and permitting the same to remain for longer than five (5) minutes. Any conductor, or any other person in charge of or operating any car, or train of cars, or locomotive, so unlawfully obstructing as aforesaid any street or avenue in the city, or assisting in, or knowingly permitting the obstruction of any street or avenue in the city by any car, train of cars or locomotive, as aforesaid, shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 19-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to regulate street crossings, see Miss. Code 1972, § 21-37-9. 
Sec. 19-2. - Duty to clear crossings for fire apparatus. 
    Upon the sounding of the fire alarm, or upon the sight of the fire apparatus of the city going to or coming from a supposed or actual fire, it shall be the duty of all persons in charge of railway trains at the street crossings of the city to clear such crossings and keep the same cleared until the fire apparatus has passed, or has gone in another direction. 
(Code 1962, § 19-2) 
Sec. 19-3. - Moving detached cars over crossings prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any employee of any railroad company to move or cause any car to move over any street or grade crossing in the city while detached from a locomotive. 
(Code 1962, § 19-3) 
Sec. 19-4. - Obstructing tracks, injuring railroad property prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the free use of any railroad by standing on or by placing any obstacle on or against the tracks of such railroad, or to injure in any way the property of any railroad company within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 19-4) 
Sec. 19-5. - Duty to install lights along tracks, at crossings. 
    All railroad companies whose trains run within the corporate limits of the city are hereby required and ordered to establish, or cause to be established, suitable lights in the yards along the line of such roads, and especially at the public crossings within the city. 
(Code 1962, § 19-5) 
Sec. 19-6. - Jumping on moving trains prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than railroad employees to climb or jump upon any car or engine, while such car or engine is in motion. 
(Code 1962, § 19-6) 
Sec. 19-7. - Backing into, along passenger depot. 
    It shall be unlawful to back a train of cars, or part of a train, or an engine into or along a passenger depot at a greater rate of speed than three (3) miles an hour, and every such train, part of a train, or engine backing into or along a passenger depot, and within fifty (50) feet thereof, shall for at least three hundred (300) feet before it reaches or comes opposite to such depot, be preceded by a servant of the railroad company on foot, not exceeding forty (40) nor under twenty (20) feet in advance, to give warning. 
(Code 1962, § 19-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 77-9-229. 
Sec. 19-8. - Speed limit in city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company to run any engine or train of cars within the corporate limits of the city at a greater rate of speed than thirty (30) miles per hour; provided, however, that, this section shall not apply where the state railroad commission has prescribed a speed of greater than thirty (30) miles per hour as provided in Mississippi Code 1972, section 77-9-237. 
(Code 1962, § 19-8) 
Sec. 19-9. - Railroads to construct, repair crossings; approval by building official. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every railroad company, whose tracks are laid within the corporate limits of the city to lay pavement of hard and durable material, level with the tops of the rails, on each side of all rails, entirely between the rails of each separate main track and side track. Such pavement shall be so shaped or arranged as to offer no obstruction to wheeled vehicles of any kind. 
(b)  It shall be the further duty of each railroad company to maintain all street crossings in good repair. 
(c)  The building official shall approve the construction and maintenance work on all street crossings before such crossings shall be opened for public travel. 
(Code 1962, § 19-9) 
Sec. 19-10. - Flying switches prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company or other person to switch a railroad car in the manner commonly known as a "flying," "running," "walking," or "kicking" switch, within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 19-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 77-9-243. 
Sec. 19-11. - Loitering at depots prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in or about any railroad depot in the city at any time; provided, however, that, this section shall not apply to any persons being at such depots for the purpose of boarding trains, meeting passengers or on business which requires their presence at such depots. 
(Code 1962, § 19-11) 
Sec. 19-12. - Automatic signals required. 
    The railroad company or companies owning or operating any railroad tracks crossing the following streets or highways in the city shall construct and maintain automatic bell and light signals at each side of such crossings operating twenty-four (24) hours each day, as follows, to-wit: 
(1)  Eighth Avenue-Southern Railroad. Automatic signals protecting all Southern tracks over Eighth Avenue crossing. These signals will operate independently of adjacent Gulf, Mobile and Ohio protection. 
(2)  Eleventh Avenue-Southern Railroad. Automatic signals protecting all tracks except industrial track now serving Lyle Concrete Block Company, Pure Oil Company Bulk Plant and Hulett Furniture Company warehouse. These signals to interconnect with similar installation on adjacent Gulf, Mobile and Ohio tracks. The industrial track serving the above industries will be protected by the train crew, when necessary to occupy this crossing. 
(3)  Seventeenth Avenue-Southern Railroad. Automatic signals on each side of Southern tracks to protect all Southern tracks on the Northwesterly side of Gulf, Mobile and Ohio tracks. Such signals shall interconnect the Southern Flashing lights signals with similar installation to protect Gulf, Mobile and Ohio tracks. The Southern track parallel to and on the Southeasterly side of the Gulf, Mobile and Ohio tracks will be protected by crew of train using this crossing. 
(4)  Twenty-seventh Avenue-Joint Southern Railroad-Illinois Central Railroad. Joining automatic signals protecting Southern main track, Illinois Central main track, and Illinois Central secondary main track. The two Illinois Central northerly tracks serving Illinois Central freight house will be protected by train crew of train using this crossing. 
(5)  Thirty-first Avenue-Joint Southern Railroad-Illinois Central Railroad. Joint automatic signals protecting all Southern and Illinois Central tracks. 
(6)  Thirty-third Avenue-Joint Southern Railroad-Illinois Central Railroad. Joint automatic signals protecting all Southern and Illinois Central tracks over this crossing. 
(7)  Forty-ninth Avenue-Joint Southern Railroad-Illinois Central Railroad. Joint automatic crossing signals protecting all Southern and Illinois Central tracks. 
(8)  Eighth Avenue-Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad. Grade crossing automatic signals. Crossing signal system to be independent of the adjacent Southern crossing signal system. 
(9)  Eleventh Avenue-Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad. Grade crossing automatic signal system. This crossing signal to be operated in conjunction with the crossing signal system of the Southern Railroad. 
(10)  Seventeenth Avenue-Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad. Grade automatic signals. The crossing signal system to be operated in conjunction with the crossing signal system of the Southern Railroad. 
(11)  Thirty-first Avenue-Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad. Grade crossing automatic signals protecting Gulf, Mobile and Ohio tracks. 
(Code 1962, § 19-12) 
Sec. 19-13. - Gulf, Mobile and Ohio to protect crossing over yards. 
    The Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad Company shall at the 27th Avenue crossing, where such avenue crosses the railroad yard of the said railroad, maintain a floodlighting system over its tracks and a flashing overhanging beacon light on the northwesterly approach and the southeasterly approach to such tracks; such flashing beacon to be operated twenty-four (24) hours per day and such crossing of such railroad company are to be illuminated at night. 
(Code 1962, § 19-13) 
Sec. 19-14. - Flagman required when backing over crossings. 
    All railroad cars when being backed over any street crossing in the city, shall have a competent flagman on the rear end thereof who shall keep a lookout in the direction such cars are moving and signal the engineer if any person or vehicle on the crossing be or appear to be in danger of injury by reason of the movement of such cars. 
(Code 1962, § 19-14) 
Sec. 19-15. - Obedience to flagmen or signals required; flagmen to report violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any pedestrian or the driver of any vehicle, to disregard the warning signal of danger given by any flagmen or automatic signal at any railroad crossing, or to attempt to cross the railroad track after being so warned until after the flagmen or automatic signal shall have given a signal of safety. All flagmen shall promptly report all violations of this section to the police department, giving license number of the vehicle driven by any party violating this section, or otherwise identifying such violator's car. 
(Code 1962, § 19-15) 
Chapter 20 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Interest and sinking fund for street improvement bonds, § 2-138; consumption of alcoholic beverages on public streets and ways prohibited. § 5-7; riding and driving animals on sidewalks prohibited, § 6-6; standing of mules and horses in streets, § 6-7; allowing livestock on streets and sidewalks prohibited, § 6-9; street food vendors, § 14-171 et seq.; signs, § 7-241 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to close or vacate streets, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-37-7; authority to exercise full jurisdiction over streets, sidewalks, § 21-37-3; power of imminent domain for street purposes, § 21-37-47; authority to provide for street lighting, § 21-37-11. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Method of naming streets. 
    The general plan of designating the streets north and south and of the avenues both East and west shall be by numbers. The streets north of the designated point, being a common section corner of Sections 16, 17, 20, and 21 of Township 6 North, Range 16 East, Lauderdale County, Mississippi and also being the Southwest corner of the Bonita Lakes Mall plat as recorded in Map Book 11 on page 13 in the office of the Chancery Clerk of Lauderdale County, Mississippi, shall be numbered therefrom northward in regular and consecutive order to the northern limits of the city; while the streets south of said point shall be numbered therefrom southward in regular and consecutive order to the southern limits of the city and shall include the designation "South", for example, "2 nd Street South". 
    The avenues west of said point shall be numbered therefrom westward in regular and consecutive order to the western boundary of the city; while the avenues east of said point shall be numbered therefrom eastward in regular and consecutive order to the eastern boundary of the city and shall include the designation "East", for example, "2 nd Avenue East". 
    All existing street or avenue designations prior to the date of the ordinance shall remain. 
(Code 1962, § 20-1; Ord. No. 4358, § 1, 10-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-2. - Official map adopted. 
    That certain map on file in the office of the city engineer, styled the official grid map of the City of Meridian, Mississippi, dated December 18, 1962, is hereby adopted as the official map of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 20-1.1; Ord. No. 3188, § 1, 12-18-62) 
Sec. 20-3. - Director of public works to clean, maintain paved streets. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of public works to direct and superintend the cleaning, preserving and protecting of the streets and avenues of the city that are paved. 
(Code 1962, § 20-2) 
Sec. 20-4. - Duty of owners, occupants to clean sidewalks. 
    It shall be the duty of all occupants of improved property and all owners of vacant property adjacent to which the sidewalks have been paved to keep such pavements clean and to do such sweeping and scraping as may be necessary to remove clay, dirt and trash therefrom and to render the same passable and sightly. 
(Code 1962, § 20-3) 
Sec. 20-5. - Changes in streets, sidewalks-Petition by property owner. 
    When the owner of any real estate abutting on a street, alley or sidewalk or any other persons shall apply to the city council to open or widen such street, avenue, alley or sidewalk, or to change the existing grade thereof by excavating or by filling the same, such application shall be presented in the form of a written petition addressed to the city council, designating with particularity the street, avenue, alley or sidewalk, or portion thereof, and the alterations and work which the petitioners desire and request to have done. Such petitions shall be signed with ink by the owners of the real estate abutting that portion of the street, avenue, alley or sidewalk, the opening, widening, excavation or filling of which is petitioned for, and similarly signed by the owners of any other property that may be affected thereby, who may be of those petitioning. Each person signing such petition shall agree to make no claim against the city for any damages that may be done to his property by reason of the doing of the work petitioned for. 
(Code 1962, § 20-4) 
Sec. 20-6. - Same-Recording, filing petitions. 
    All petitions for changing street and sidewalk conditions, as provided for in section 20-5, must be entered in full by the city clerk on the minute book of the city council, and the original placed on file and carefully preserved. 
(Code 1962, § 20-5) 
Sec. 20-7. - Requirements for opening of streets dedicated but not presently opened or improved. 
(a)  The expense of physically opening and improving any street, avenue, alley or other public thoroughfare in the city which, prior to March 7, 1972, was dedicated for use as such street, avenue, alley or public thoroughfare and not physically opened or improved shall be borne by the adjoining property owner or owners requesting that such street, avenue, alley or public thoroughfare be physically opened. 
(b)  Whenever any such dedicated but physically unopened or unimproved street, avenue, alley or public thoroughfare is opened or improved, the property owner or owners requesting that such street, avenue, alley or public thoroughfare be opened or improved shall, before such street, avenue, alley or public thoroughfare shall be accepted as a public street of the city, make such improvements to such dedicated street, which shall at the time of such request be in force and effect respecting the streets of any new subdivision of the city, including grubbing, grading, paving, construction of curbs and gutters, culverts and bridges, water mains and sanitary and storm sewer mains as required by the subdivision ordinances in effect at that time. 
(c)  After the making of such improvements in such dedicated public street, avenue, alley or public thoroughfare as required herein and the acceptance of such street by the city, all of such improvements within the right-of-way of such street, avenue, alley or public thoroughfare shall become the property of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 20-5.1; Ord. No. 3396, §§ 1-3, 3-7-72) 
Sec. 20-8. - Permit to excavate, perform work on, place building material or structure on streets, sidewalks; indemnification of city-Required. 
(a)  Every person desiring to make excavation in any street, alley or avenue in the city, or to perform work upon any such sidewalk, curb, gutter or paving therein, or to pile any building material or erect any structure therein shall before so doing obtain from the director of public works a permit so to do. Every person obtaining such permit shall by the acceptance thereof become bound and obligated to the city to save it harmless on account of all injury to persons or property or any injury to any pavement, curb, sidewalk or gutter occasioned by any such excavation or work in the streets, alleys and avenues, the piling of building material or erecting of structures therein. 
(b)  Before such a permit is granted therefor, such person shall deposit with the city clerk a sum of money as, in the judgment of the director of public works, shall be sufficient to cover the costs of replacing permanent pavement or improvement, the surplus, if any, to be returned when the work is completed. 
(c)  Every such permit issued by the director of public works shall be executed in duplicate and shall be signed by the director of public works and also by the person obtaining the same. Immediately upon the execution of the permit and the bond, as required in the following section, the director of public works shall deliver the duplicate permit to the applicant. 
(Code 1962, § 20-6) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 20-9. - Same-Bond prerequisite to issuance. 
(a)  Every person obtaining a permit, as provided for in section 20-8, shall at the time of receiving the same make, execute and deliver to the director of public works a good and sufficient bond, payable to the city with a surety company doing business in the state as surety thereon, in such amount as the director of public works may require, not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). Such bond shall be conditioned to save the city harmless on account of all injury or damages which it may suffer by reason of injury to persons or property, or injuries to any pavement, sidewalk, curb or gutter occasioned by the making of any excavation, the doing of any work or the piling of any building material or the erecting of any structure in the streets, alleys or avenues, as provided in the preceding section. 
(b)  Any regular contractor or public utility using the streets, or any part thereof, may execute a like bond, general in its terms, to cover any and all work that may be done by such contractor or public utility in the streets for such sum as may be fixed by the city council, not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). Such bond when executed and delivered shall be in lieu of the bond hereinabove required in each case. 
(Code 1962, § 20-7) 
Sec. 20-10. - Filling excavations; lighting barricading required. 
    Any person making an excavation in any street, alley or sidewalk or under the pavement thereof pursuant to a permit issued as provided in section 20-8 of this chapter, shall thoroughly ram all fills with heavy rammers and shall replace any paving or curbing torn up so as to leave such street, alley or sidewalk in the same condition it was prior to such excavation. Any such excavation that is left overnight in an unfinished condition shall be made safe by placing danger lights in the manner prescribed in section 20-11 and, if necessary, by barricading, as may be directed by the director of public works. 
(Code 1962, § 20-8) 
Sec. 20-11. - Danger lights on excavations, unfinished fill, other obstructions. 
    Any excavation, unfinished fill or any obstruction of any kind whatever placed in any street, alley or sidewalk and permitted to remain overnight shall be marked on each side by a lamp or lantern with good and sufficient light therein and in such manner as to plainly show the place and extent of such excavation, unfinished fill or obstruction. Such lamps or lanterns shall be erected and lighted not later than sunset each evening and kept burning continuously until sunrise next morning. 
(Code 1962, § 20-9) 
Sec. 20-12. - Barricades across unsafe bridges, streets. 
    In case any bridge or any part of a street shall at any time become unsafe or dangerous for use as a public street, the same shall be closed to public travel by the erection of a substantial barricade, on which red lights shall be placed at night, until such bridge or street shall have been rendered safe for public travel. It shall be unlawful for any person to use or attempt to use any such bridge or street until such barricade shall have been removed by order of the director of public works. 
(Code 1962, § 20-10) 
Sec. 20-13. - Dropping materials, debris from buildings under construction. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the construction, alteration, repair or removal of any building or other structure anywhere in the city, to cast, to drop or permit to be cast or dropped from any elevation of such building or other structure any building material, rubbish or debris of such structure upon any street or sidewalk; provided, that it shall be lawful to lower and remove from such structure any timber, material, debris or other similar substance, by the use of machinery, buckets, baskets or such other safe appliances as by the building inspector may be deemed best adapted to insure against injury to persons or property or annoyance to the public. 
(Code 1962, § 20-11) 
State Law reference- Authority to require barriers or other safeguards when building construction creates hazardous condition, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-19-27. 
Sec. 20-14. - Wrecker or automobile towing services to remove debris from streets. 
(a)  All persons engaged in the business of offering wrecker service or automobile towing service within the city are hereby required to clean and remove from the streets of the city all broken glass and other debris resulting from automotive collisions served by wrecker or automobile towing businesses. 
(b)  The removal of all such debris shall be done by such wrecker service or automobile towing service at the time that such towing service is performed. 
(c)  Any person violating any provision of this section may upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 20-11.1; Ord. No. 3375, §§ 1-3, 4-6-71) 
Sec. 20-15. - Discharging waste water into streets, sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any slop, wash or waste water of any kind to flow from his yard or lot over the surface of a sidewalk, street, avenue, alley whether the same be paved or unpaved, or over a gutter, ditch or drain, whether the water be clean or foul. 
(Code 1962, § 20-12) 
Sec. 20-16. - Conducting roof and other clean water to gutters. 
    All water from the roof gutters of houses and all clean water from other sources on premises that is permitted to enter the street gutters, except surface waters, shall be carried from such houses or premises through drain pipes entirely beneath such pavements to the outer edge of the curbing and discharged into the gutters beyond the curbing; provided that, in cases where the above requirement is impracticable, the director of public works, may, if in his judgment necessary, grant a special permit for house-gutter water and other clean water to be allowed to flow over the surface of a sidewalk pavement. 
(Code 1962, § 20-13) 
Sec. 20-17. - Damage to streets, sidewalks by abutting owner or occupant prohibited. 
    In all cases where a sidewalk or street improvement, curbing or gutter is disturbed or damaged by the wilful acts of the owner or agent of the property adjacent thereto, or by such owner or agent permitting to be disturbed or damaged by the unlawful acts of another, or by the gross or wilful neglect on the part of such owner or agent, for such acts, or gross and wilful neglect, such owner or agent shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1962, § 20-14) 
Sec. 20-18. - Driving across sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle across a paved sidewalk, except at a point where the pavement is provided with a driveway, unless it is absolutely necessary and unavoidable, in which event there shall first be laid over the pavement a complete covering of planks or other suitable material of sufficient thickness and width and strength to make the pavement secure against injury liable to result from the weight of the vehicle, and over which covering the vehicle must be driven. Such covering shall be removed immediately after the vehicle has crossed it. 
(Code 1962, § 20-15) 
Sec. 20-19. - Dragging articles over streets, sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drag or move over or along any street or sidewalk in the city that is paved or improved with brick, chert or any other kind of paving material, any article the weight or character of which is liable to displace or loosen the paving material or otherwise damage the pavement or improvement; provided, however, that, such article may be dragged or moved over or along such streets and sidewalks if such article is supported and conveyed on wheels or rollers of sufficient width to do no damage to the pavement or improvement. 
(Code 1962, § 20-16) 
Sec. 20-20. - Trees, shrubs obstructing intersections or view of traffic signs. 
(a)  The planting of shrubbery or trees on the right-of-way of any street or avenue within the city at any point which is within fifty (50) feet of the intersection of any street or avenue of the city with any other street or avenue of the city is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  Any person or corporation violating any provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 20-17) 
Sec. 20-21. - Obstructing streets or sidewalks-Prohibited acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place goods, wares, merchandise, fruits, vegetables, boxes, barrels, containers, dispensers, signs, basketball goals or any obstruction of any kind in or upon any street, avenue, alley or sidewalk within the city. 
(b)  It shall likewise be unlawful for any person in charge of or occupying any property to permit goods, wares, merchandise, boxes, barrels, containers, dispensers, signs, basketball goals or other obstructions to remain on the street, alley, avenue or sidewalk adjoining the property or building in his charge or control, whether the same was placed thereon by such person or not. This shall include the exposing of goods or other property for sale, display, advertisement, or for other purposes, in such a manner as to rest upon or project over the sidewalks of the city, or to be suspended between the awning post or upon wires, ropes or frameworks suspended between the awning posts, the allowance of the act of basketball or in any manner to obstruct the free use of such sidewalks and passage thereon by the public. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct vehicular traffic in any city street or pedestrian traffic on any sidewalk, participate in the act of basketball or any activity that obstructs the free use of any street, avenue, public place, or sidewalk within the city. 
Penalties. Any person guilty of committing any of the above acts shall face a penalty of: 
a.  A find not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense; 
b.  A fine not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a second offense; and 
c.  A fine not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for any subsequent offense. 
(Code 1962, § 20-18; Ord. No. 3202, 6-18-63; Ord. No. 4244, §§ 1, 2, 4-20-04; Ord. No. 4503, 11-6-18) 
Cross reference- Obstruction of public ways by street food vendors, § 14-176(c). 
Sec. 20-22. - Obstructing sidewalks with signs, advertisements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or cause to be placed in, or on the area between the sidewalk and curb of the streets of the city, any obstruction, sign or advertisement of any kind. 
(Code 1962, § 20-19) 
Cross reference- Advertising, Ch. 3; signs, § 7-241 et seq. 
Sec. 20-23. - Stands for sale of merchandise prohibited on streets, sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or operate any box or stand for the keeping or sale of merchandise in or upon any street or sidewalk of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 20-20) 
Sec. 20-24. - Foreign material, debris, dirt, etc., falling from load, or wheels or body of trucks, tractors, etc. 
(a)  No person shall drive or move any truck, tractor, recreational vehicle, other motorized vehicles of trailer or equipment within the corporate limits unless such motorized vehicles or trailer or equipment is so constructed or loaded and operated as to prevent and avoid any load, contents, litter, debris, dirt, rocks, limbs, mud, man-made materials, trash, vegetation or other materials foreign to the improved roadways, from being blown, or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. No person shall drive or move any vehicles, trailer or equipment within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other place, any mud, dirt, debris, litter or foreign matter, if he or she removes such within a reasonable time shall not be deemed in violation of this section. "Reasonable time" is defined as before the conclusion of that days' activities or more often if directed by the public works director or his designee. 
(b)  Any person violating subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each such violation. 
(Ord. No. 3911, §§ 1, 2, 8-6-91) 
Sec. 20-25. - Obstructing streets, sidewalks with commercial activities or exhibitions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or permit to be obstructed any street, avenue, alley or sidewalk by selling, advertising, showing or disposing or offering for sale, or offering to show, advertise or dispose of any goods, wares or merchandise or by giving or taking part in any kind of entertainment or exhibition in a street, avenue, alley or sidewalk for any of the above purposes whereby persons are induced to collect together so as to obstruct free passage on and along such street, avenue or sidewalk. 
(Code 1962, § 20-22) 
Sec. 20-26. - Skating, playing on streets, sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to skate on roller skates, or to ride any velocipede, tricycle, "scooter" or "pedo-car," or to loiter or engage in any play or game, on any paved street of the city, or on any sidewalk in the downtown section, or adjacent to any church in the city. It shall also be unlawful for any parent or guardian to knowingly allow or permit his minor child or ward, under the age of twelve (12) years, to violate any of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1962, § 20-23) 
Sec. 20-27. - Wires crossing streets in fire limits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place any telephone wire, wires for the purposes of conducting electricity, guy wire or any wire for the purpose whatsoever, across any street, avenue or sidewalk in the fire limits in the city; provided, that such wires may be placed across such streets, avenues, and sidewalks at right angles therewith at an intersection. 
(Code 1962, § 20-24) 
Sec. 20-28. - Gates, doors opening across sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any gates or doors, except self-closing screen doors, to structures bordering on sidewalks, to be erected or constructed so as to open outward, onto, or across any sidewalk. All such gates, and doors are declared to be nuisances, constituting obstructions to sidewalks, and any person so erecting, or causing to be so erected, any gate or door, except self-closing screen doors, after this Code goes into effect, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1962, § 20-25) 
Sec. 20-29. - Post-office letter boxes authorized on sidewalks, lampposts; defacing. 
    The post-office department of the United States government is hereby granted permission to erect, under the supervision and direction of the director of public works, posts on the sidewalks of the city and to attach and fasten post-office letter boxes thereto, or to attach and fasten such boxes to any lampposts with the consent of the person owning such lampposts. It shall be unlawful for any person to deface or in any way injure any post-office letter box attached to any such post or erected in any hotel or elsewhere in the city. 
(Code 1962, § 20-26) 
Sec. 20-30. - Trees and shrubs within street right-of-way. 
    The city may move or trim, or cause to be moved or trimmed, any tree or shrub within the right-of-way of any street, avenue, or public way within the city, when the mayor has determined that it is in the best interest of the health, welfare and safety of the public. 
(Code 1962, § 20-27; Ord. No. 3204, 8-7-63) 
Cross reference- Tree protection, § 17-71 et seq. 
Sec. 20-31. - Closing and vacating streets and alleys-Generally. 
    The public streets, avenues and alleys of the city and portions thereof may be closed and vacated or quit-claim deeds granted from time to time, by the city council on petition of all of the abutting landowners of the street, avenue or alley or portion thereof. A hearing on the petition shall be held before the Meridian Planning Commission, serving as an advisory committee of citizens. After such hearing, the planning commission shall make its recommendation to the city council, which recommendation may be accepted or rejected by the council, or may be accepted in part and rejected in part, or may be sent back to the planning commission for further consideration and/or hearing. The recommendation of the planning commission shall be considered by the city council at its next regularly scheduled council meeting in the time and manner prescribed by the city's agenda ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 3891, 10-2-90) 
Sec. 20-32. - Same-Contents of petition. 
    No petition for closing or vacating a street, avenue or alley or for a quitclaim deed to same will be considered unless it is under oath, signed by all abutting or affected land owners and contains the following: 
(1)  The name and address of each adjoining land owner. 
(2)  A certification from an attorney stating that everyone signing the petition is a bona fide abutting property owner and that they constitute all of the abutting or affected land owners to the street or alley described in the petition. 
(3)  A map or plat showing the street or alley proposed for closing or to be conveyed by quitclaim deed and the affected surrounding properties. 
(4)  A legal description of the street, avenue or alley proposed for closing or to be included in the quitclaim deed. 
(5)  A written certification from all public utilities including but not limited to electric, gas, telephone and television cable companies certifying that there are no utilities in, on or under the subject property; that they do not have any easements thereto; and that they have no objection to the closing and vacating of such street or the conveyance thereof. 
(6)  A statement whereby all of the persons signing the petition waive their right to any compensation for the closing and vacating of the street, avenue or alley. 
(Ord. No. 3891, 10-2-90) 
Sec. 20-33. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3974, adopted July 5, 1994, deleted § 20-33 in its entirety. Former § 20-33 pertained to compensation for closing and vacating streets and alleys, and derived from Ord. No. 3891, adopted October 2, 1990. 
Sec. 20-34. - Same-Costs.
