    All administrative costs and fees incurred by the city in connection with a petition to close and vacate a street or alley or for a quitclaim deed shall be paid by the abutting landowners, including, but not limited to, all publication costs, recording fees and appraisal fees. The landowners shall deposit a sum sufficient to cover the above administrative costs upon filing of their petition. The amount of the fee shall be determined by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3891, 10-2-90) 
Sec. 20-35. - Reservation of easements. 
    The city council, in its discretion, may reserve a utility easement over and across the street or alley being closed and vacated or a portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 3891, 10-2-90) 
Secs. 20-36-20-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 

Sec. 20-46. - Conformity to specifications of director of public works. 
    All construction or repair work hereafter done in, upon or under any street, avenue or sidewalk in the city shall be done in accordance with plans and specifications to be furnished by the director of public works and not otherwise. 
(Code 1962, § 20-32) 
Sec. 20-47. - Order by city council required; exceptions. 
    No sidewalk or street shall be paved or repaired and such improvement paid for out of public money unless the same is ordered to be done by the city council or in such manner as may in special cases be prescribed by the charter. 
(Code 1962, § 20-33) 
Sec. 20-48. - Ordinance requiring abutting owner to improve sidewalks, gutters. 
    Whenever it is deemed advisable by the city council that any sidewalk or gutter be paved or curbed or that any such improvement already done be repaired or renewed, it shall be the duty of the city council to pass an ordinance compelling the same to be done by the owner of the real estate adjacent to the sidewalk on and along which such improvement is required. Such ordinance shall designate the sidewalk gutter to be improved and what improvement is required, whether paving or curbing, or both, or whether such improvement already done is to be renewed or only repaired, specifying, in case of pavement, the width the required strip of pavement shall be, the material with which and the manner in which the required improvement is to be done, if to be done otherwise than required by section 20-49. 
(Code 1962, § 20-34) 
Sec. 20-49. - General specifications for sidewalk paving. 
    All sidewalk pavements, unless otherwise specially directed by ordinance, shall be constructed of concrete, so that the surface of the finished pavement shall conform to the established grade and otherwise in accordance with the city's specifications for the construction of sidewalk pavements. 
(Code 1962, § 20-35) 
Sec. 20-50. - Grades-Establishment, adoption. 
    Whenever it is determined by the city council that a sidewalk, street or gutter shall be paved, the director of public works or such other competent person as may be authorized to do so shall establish a grade for the sidewalk or street to be paved, unless such a grade has previously been established, and to report such grade with a profile of same to the city council for approval and adoption. After a grade is decided upon it shall be adopted by ordinance and by such ordinance declared to be the established grade for such sidewalk or street, reference being made therein to the profiles which indicate same. 
(Code 1962, § 20-36) 
Sec. 20-51. - Same-Profiles to be endorsed and filed. 
    Each profile provided for by section 20-50 shall have words endorsed thereon, indicating clearly and accurately the sidewalk or street the grade of which it represents and the title and date of approval of the ordinance by which such grade was adopted. Such profiles shall be kept on file in the office of the director of public works and by him carefully preserved. A copy of each profile shall be deposited with the city clerk to be preserved by him in his office. 
(Code 1962, § 20-37) 
Sec. 20-52. - Distance from sidewalk pavement to property line. 
    Except in certain cases where conditions may render same impracticable, or undesirable for sufficient reasons, and where otherwise ordered by ordinance, the following regulations shall prevail and govern in the construction of sidewalk pavements: Whenever the strip of pavement is ordered to be five (5) feet wide, the inner edge thereof shall be laid a distance of one (1) foot from the property line. 
(Code 1962, § 20-38) 
Sec. 20-53. - Construction of driveways across sidewalks. 
    At all points on sidewalks where it is necessary for vehicles to cross the sidewalk on entering the adjacent premises, driveways shall be constructed according to the city's specifications for the construction of driveways, and shall extend from the curb or gutter line across the sidewalk to the property line, in cases where there may be a curb or gutter permanently constructed of brick, stone or other similar material. Otherwise, the driveway may extend from the property line only to the outer edge of the strip of sidewalk pavement. 
(Code 1962, § 20-39) 
Sec. 20-54. - Drainage construction in connection with construction of driveways. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct a driveway from their property to any city street without providing for the proper drainage of such city street and ditches adjacent thereto. 
(b)  Where driveways cross open ditches in the streets, avenues, and parkways, culverts shall be installed. Said culverts shall be of such size and shall be constructed of such material as determined by the department of public works, depending on the conditions existing. In no instance shall the size of opening be less than that obtained by a fifteen-inch diameter pipe. The length of culvert shall be determined by the following method: For ditch depth of two (2) feet or less the culvert shall extend not less than five (5) feet beyond both edges of the driveway where it crosses the ditch. For each additional foot depth of ditch add two (2) feet to the above figure, except that no culvert shall be less than twenty (20) feet long and except that where headwalls are constructed at the ends of the culvert the length shall be as determined by the department of public works. 
(c)  Any person, firm or corporation found guilty of violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 20-40; Ord. No. 3168, §§ 1-3, 4-18-62) 
Secs. 20-55-20-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PIPES AND MAINS 

Sec. 20-66. - Application of article. 
    All sewer, water and gas pipes laid in the streets and avenues of the city, shall be laid in accordance with the provisions of this article, and according to such further regulations as may be prescribed by other ordinances of the city council. All persons owning or laying such pipes, are hereby required to observe and comply with same. 
(Code 1962, § 20-45) 
Sec. 20-67. - Location of sewer mains, laterals. 
    All sewer mains and laterals of the city's sewerage system laid in and along the streets and avenues, shall be laid along the center of the streets and avenues, except when otherwise ordered by the director of public works. 
(Code 1962, § 20-46) 
Sec. 20-68. - Location of water mains. 
    All water mains laid in and along any street, shall be laid on the north side of the center of the street, and all water mains laid in and along any avenue, shall be laid on the west side of the center of the avenue, except when otherwise ordered by the director of public works. 
(Code 1962, § 20-47) 
Sec. 20-69. - Location of gas mains. 
    All gas mains laid in and along any street, shall be laid on the south side of the center of the street; all gas mains laid in and along any avenue, shall be laid on the east side of the center of the avenue, except when otherwise ordered by the director of public works. 
(Code 1962, § 20-48) 
Sec. 20-70. - Depth of water, gas mains. 
    All water and gas mains shall be laid not less than three (3) feet in depth below the established grade of the street or avenue in and along which the same are laid. 
(Code 1962, § 20-49) 
Sec. 20-71. - Water, gas pipes parallel to sewers. 
    No water or gas pipe shall be laid parallel with a line of sewer within five (5) feet of such sewer line, unless by written permit from the director of public works. 
(Code 1962, § 20-50) 
Sec. 20-72. - Location of surface conditions. 
    It shall be the duty of all gas companies, or any and all plumbers, or other persons, in making surface pipe connections on the side of any main, to conduct the same to the inside of the curbstone of not less than three (3) feet below the established grade. 
(Code 1962, § 20-51) 
Sec. 20-73. - Excavations along, near sewers. 
    It shall be the duty of all gas companies, other utilities, or individuals, to notify the director of public works before making an excavation across or near a line of sewer. All such excavations must be made in a manner to meet the approval of the director of public works. 
(Code 1962, § 20-52) 
Sec. 20-74. - Method of laying drain pipes. 
    Whenever it is necessary to place any drain pipe under any permanent pavement of stone, brick, or other material, the drain pipe shall be driven through the earth under the pavement without disturbing the surface of the pavement whenever the same be practicable, and if it is not practicable to drive the pipe, then in such case the necessary excavation shall be bored with a posthole auger, or with a similar tool, and not dug, and if this method is impracticable, then the necessary excavation may be dug, without in either case disturbing the pavement; and in no case shall a permit be given to tear up a pavement, except in cases where neither of the foregoing methods is practicable, the same to be decided in each and every case by the director of public works authorized to grant the permit. 
(Code 1962, § 20-53) 
Secs. 20-75-20-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MAJOR STREET PLAN[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3901, adopted Jan. 8, 1991, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-6 as Art. IV was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 17; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 23. 

Sec. 20-91. - General purposes and intent. 
    The general purposes and intent of the city in adoption of this official major street plan are as follows: 
(1)  To provide a convenient and adequate major street network to meet the needs of residential, commercial, and industrial traffic within the city, and to facilitate flow of traffic through and around the city; 
(2)  To reduce the use of minor streets for through traffic, thus contributing to the safety and comfort of dwellers along such minor streets; 
(3)  To give assurance and guidance as to intent concerning location of major streets in order that developers, residents, and commercial and industrial interests may be informed thereby; 
(4)  To provide a basis for city programs for right-of-way acquisition, and for design and construction appropriate to such streets; and 
(5)  To guide planning and control of land use along such streets in order to minimize potential marginal interference with free traffic flow, and to protect the uses along such streets from potential damaging effects of concentrated traffic flow. 
(Ord. No. 3901, § 1, 1-8-91) 
Sec. 20-92. - Existing and proposed streets designated as arterial or collector streets. 
    The following existing or proposed streets, or portions of existing or proposed streets, are hereby declared to comprise the major street plan for the city, and designated as arterial or collector streets as follows: 
(1)  Arterial streets. Arterial streets are hereby defined as a class of streets that carry relatively large volumes of through traffic from local and collector streets and conduct it to and from the various traffic focal points in the city. Arterials interconnect the principal traffic generators within the city as well as important rural routes. A secondary function of arterials is to provide access to abutting properties. The length of a typical trip on the system should exceed one (1) mile, and arterials generally should be spaced about one (1) mile apart. Major arterials are designed for the traffic volumes they carry, while minor arterials are underdesigned for the traffic volumes they carry and require improvement. The major streets designated as major and minor arterials are listed below: 
State Hwy 19, (within city limits), major arterial. 
Old U. S. Hwy. 80, (within city limits), major arterial. 
U. S. Hwy. 11, (within city limits), major arterial. 
State Hwy. 39, (within city limits), major arterial. 
U. S. Hwy. 45, (within city limits), major arterial. 
State Hwy 493, (within city limits), major arterial. 
22nd Avenue, (from 14th Street to N. Frontage Road), major arterial. 
8th Street, (from Hwy 11 S. to 21st Avenue), major arterial. 
31st/29th Street, (from North Frontage Road to 8th Street), major arterial. 
29th Avenue, (from 8th Street to North Hills Street), minor arterial. 
23rd Avenue, (from 14th Street to Front Street), major arterial. 
23rd Avenue, (from 14th Street to 43rd Street), minor arterial. 
North Hills Street, (from Hwy 19 to 35th Avenue and from 18th Avenue to Newell Road), minor arterial. 
North Hills Street, (from 35th Avenue to 18th Avenue), major arterial. 
Newell Road, (from Hwy 39 North to U. S. Hwy 45), minor arterial. 
State Boulevard, (from 39th Avenue and 15th Street to North Hills Street), major arterial.

24th Avenue, (from 7th Street to Poplar Springs Drive), major arterial. 
49th Avenue, (from state maintenance to city limits), minor arterial. 
10th Avenue, (from Front Street to North Hills Street), minor arterial which requires widening. 
14th Street, (from 26th Avenue to Front Street), major arterial. 
6th Street, (from 18th Avenue to 5th Street), minor arterial. 
Front Street, (from 26th Avenue to beginning of state maintenance), minor arterial. 
(2)  Collector streets. Collector streets are hereby defined as that class of streets which connects traffic between local streets and the arterial system and provides access to abutting property. These streets also provide for through-traffic movements within a local area, such as a subdivision. Collector streets should be spaced at approximately half-mile intervals. Collector Streets are designated below: 
Kings Road, (from 38th Street to city limits). 
40th Street, (from Hwy 19 North to Grandview Avenue).

(Ord. No. 3901, § 1, 1-8-91; Ord. No. 3909, § 1, 5-21-91) 
Sec. 20-93. - Effect of designation as arterial or collector streets. 
    The streets so designated, and no other, shall be developed and maintained as arterial or collector streets, and shall be used as through streets for movement of concentrated flows of traffic. 
(1)  Width of right-of-way. Arterial streets shall have a minimum right-of-way width of eighty (80) feet; minor arterials and collector streets a minimum right-of-way of sixty (60) feet. 
(2)  Traffic flow. Except where traffic signals control flow, traffic shall have right-of-way in the following order, and stop signs shall be erected accordingly: Traffic flow on arterial streets shall have right-of-way over traffic flow on collector and minor streets and traffic flow on collector streets shall have right-of-way over traffic flow on minor streets. Where streets of the same designation intersect, right-of-way shall be as determined through regulations adopted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 3901, § 3, 1-8-91) 
Sec. 20-94. - Setbacks and curb cuts. 
    In order to preserve free traffic flow on arterial and collector streets, to minimize frictions caused by land uses bordering such streets and to protect inhabitants of residences bordering such streets from hazards, noise, glare, and fumes arising from concentrated flow of traffic: 
(1)  No portion of any residential structure shall be erected closer than sixty-five (65) feet to the centerline of any street designated as an arterial street, nor closer than fifty-five (55) feet to the centerline of a street designated as a collector street. 
(2)  No curb cut shall be made in connection with any commercial or industrial structure or use unless plans, showing the relation of the curb cut to the structures and parking area, if any, on the lot and to structures, parking areas, and curb cuts on adjacent lots, shall have been first approved by the department of community development before being approved by the public works director. 
(Ord. No. 3901, § 4, 1-8-91; Ord. No. 3923, 9-16-91) 
Sec. 20-95. - Phasing of street plans. 
    Improvements to existing streets or the construction of new streets shall be done in phases or stages not to exceed five (5) years. Street improvements or new construction shall start within the five-year phase for which the project is designated. Right-of-way for new streets or street improvements must be obtained by the city either by donation or through right-of-way purchase. The city will construct or improve streets according to the city's needs and the availability of funds. If city funds are not available, the city may construct the streets and then assess the abutting property owners the cost of the improvements. However, if right-of-way has been donated to the city with the condition that the street must be constructed, the city must begin construction within five (5) years for that particular phase according to the plan. If a developer chooses to build one (1) or more of the planned new streets shown on the map, then the work must be done to city standards. 
(Ord. No. 3901, § 5, 1-8-91) 
Sec. 20-96. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person violating any section of this ordinance or regulations developed pursuant whereto shall, upon conviction, be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days, or both, and each day's continued violation shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3901, § 6, 1-8-91) 
Chapter 21 - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Statements of policy. 
(a)  The subdivision of land is an important part of the community development process because the welfare of the entire community is affected in many important respects by the subdivision and subsequent development of its lands. 
(b)  The advantages afforded by the regulation of land development accrue to the citizens of the community, to the home owner and/or other occupants of premises, to the landowner, to the developer, and to the investor. 
(c)  The regulation of the subdivision of property is intended to, and should be administered in a manner that will implement the comprehensive plan; harmoniously relate development of various tracts of land with overall community needs; establish minimum criteria and standards to which improvements shall be installed and/or constructed; and provide a means for the orderly recordation of the subdivided parcels as well as the location and salient features of improvements thereto. 
(d)  The regulations and standards for the subdivision of lands as provided herein are proposed as a means of assuring the development of the city to standards commensurate with the wishes of its citizens based on the reasonable long term cost for the development. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-2. - Statement of intent. 
    The intent of this chapter is to accomplish the following: 
(1)  To protect and provide for the public health, safety, and general welfare of the community. 
(2)  To guide and encourage the future growth and development of the city in accordance with the comprehensive plan. 
(3)  To provide residential subdivisions which offer building lots affordable to all of the citizens of Meridian. 
(4)  To encourage the development of residential subdivisions for all of its citizens thereby building a future tax base for the city. 
(5)  To encourage new residential construction on existing lots throughout the city, thereby putting underutilized lots which already have utilities back into production. 
(6)  To provide for adequate light, air, and privacy; to secure safety from fire, flood, and other danger; and to prevent overcrowding of land and undue congestion of population. 
(7)  To protect the character and the social and economic stability of all parts of the city and to encourage the orderly and beneficial development of all parts of Meridian. 
(8)  To guide public and private policy and action in order to provide adequate and efficient transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks, playgrounds, recreation, and other public requirements and facilities. 
(9)  To provide the most beneficial relationship between the uses of land and buildings and the circulation of traffic throughout the municipality, having particular regard to the avoidance of congestion in the streets and highways, and the pedestrian traffic movement appropriate to the various uses of land and buildings and to provide for the proper location and width of streets and building lines. 
(10)  To establish reasonable standards of design and procedures for subdivision, in order to further the orderly layout, and use of land; and to ensure proper legal description and monumenting of subdivided land. 
(11)  To ensure that proper facilities are available and will have a sufficient capacity to serve the proposed subdivision. 
(12)  To prevent the pollution of air, streams, and ponds, to assure the adequacy of drainage facilities; to safeguard the water table; and to encourage the wise use and management of natural resources throughout the city in order to preserve the integrity, stability, and beauty of the community and value of the land. 
(13)  To preserve the natural beauty and topography of Meridian and to ensure appropriate development with a regard to these natural features. 
(14)  To provide for open spaces through the most efficient design and layout of the land, including the use of average density in preserving the density of land as established in the Zoning Ordinance of Meridian. 
(15)  To protect and conserve the value of land throughout the city and the value of buildings and improvements upon the land, and to minimize the conflicts among the uses of land and buildings. 
(16)  To provide a more convenient means of describing property than by metes and bounds descriptions. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-3. - Interpretation. 
    Interpretations, standards and detailed requirements for items not specifically covered by this regulation shall be maintained in the office of the department of community development or in the department of public works. For the purpose of these regulations certain terms and words are to be used and interpreted as defined hereinafter. Words used in the present tense shall include the future tense; words in the singular number include the plural and words in the plural number include the singular, the word "person" includes a firm or corporation, as well as an individual, and the word "lot" includes the words "plot" and "parcel", except where the natural construction of the writing indicates otherwise. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not permissive; the word "may" is permissive. Map means the Official Zoning Map of Meridian, Mississippi. Any term not defined within this Code shall be construed to be used in this Code as defined by the latest edition of Webster's Unabridged Dictionary. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-4. - Conflict with other public provisions. 
    The regulations are not intended to interfere with, abrogate, or annul any other ordinance, rule, or regulation, statute, or any other provision at law. Where any provision of these regulations impose restrictions different from those imposed by any other ordinance, rule, or regulation or, other provision of law, whichever provision of law is more restrictive or impose higher standards, shall control. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-5. - Conditions. 
    Regulations of the subdivision of land and the attachment of reasonable conditions to land subdivision is an exercise of valid police power delegated by the state to this municipality. The developer/subdivider has the duty of compliance with reasonable conditions laid down by the planning commission and the governing body for design, dedication, improvement, and restrictive use of land so as to conform to the physical and economical development of the municipality and to the safety and general welfare of the future lot owners in the subdivision and the community at large. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-6. - Procedure for resubdivision. 
    For any change in a map of an approved or recorded subdivision plat, if such changes affect any street layout shown on such map, or area reserved thereon for public use, or any lot line, or if it affects any map or plan legally reached prior to the adoption of any regulations controlling subdivision, such parcel shall be approved by the planning commission by the same procedure, rules, and regulations as for subdivisions. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-7. - Definitions. 
    Alley means a minor way, dedicated for public use, which is primarily for vehicular access to the sides or rear of lots. 
    Arterial means a street which has the primary purpose of carrying through traffic and the secondary purpose of providing access to abutting property. It is considered to be a major street. Meridian's arterial streets are listed in the comprehensive plan. 
    Block means a unit of land bounded by streets or by a combination of streets and public land, railroad right-of-way, waterways, or any other barrier to the continuity to development; a block may also include a group of lots surrounding a single cul-de-sac or as otherwise determined by the department of community development. 
    Capital improvements program means a proposed schedule of all future projects listed in order of construction priority together with cost estimates and the anticipated means of financing each project. 
    Collector means a street having the primary purpose of intercepting traffic from intersecting local streets and handling this movement to the nearest arterial street. A secondary function is service to abutting land use. It is considered to be a major street. 
    Comprehensive plan means the duly adopted comprehensive plan for the city including subsequent amendments. 
    Cul-de-sac means a street having one (1) end open to traffic and being permanently terminated by vehicular turnaround. 
    Dead end street means a street with a single common ingress and egress. See also stub street. 
    Drainage means the removal of surface water or groundwater from land by drains, grading, or other means. 
    Drainage structure means culvert, bridge, curb and gutter, inlet, or an improved open ditch. 
    Easement means a permanent or temporary grant of right-of-way by a property owner. 
    Highway means a thoroughfare controlled and maintained by the Mississippi State Highway Department. 
    Improvements means any drainage structure, roadway, parkway, sidewalk, tree, lawn, off-street parking area, lot improvement, or other facility for which the local government will assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation, or which will affect an improvement for which local government responsibility is established. All such improvements shall be properly bonded. 
    Infrastructure improvements means water improvements and sewer improvements such as water lines, sewer lines and any other improvements designated by the city council in any contract or other form of agreement with a developer to provide infrastructure improvements relative to single-family residential developments inside the corporate boundaries of the city. 
    Local residential street means a street designed to provide vehicular access to abutting property and to discourage through traffic. Cul-de-sacs and loop streets are both examples of local streets. 
    Lot means a tract, parcel or portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land intended as a unit for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer or for building development. 
    Lot split means the division of an existing lot into two (2) lots that meet current zoning requirements. 
    Major subdivision means all subdivisions not classified as minor subdivisions, including but not limited to subdivisions of five (5) or more lots, or any size subdivision requiring any new street or extension of the local governmental facilities, or the creation of any public improvements. 
    Marginal access street means a service street that runs parallel to a higher-order street which, for purposes of safety, provides access to abutting properties and separation from through traffic. May be designed as a residential access street or subcollector as anticipated daily traffic dictates. 
    Minor subdivision means any subdivision containing not more than four (4) lots fronting on an existing street, not involving any new street or road, or planned development or the extension of municipal facilities, or the creation of any public improvements, and not adversely affecting the remainder of the parcel of adjoining property, and not in conflict with any provision or portion of the City's Comprehensive Plan, Official Map, Zoning Ordinance, Water and Sewer Ordinance, or these regulations. 
    Final plat means a drawing of a permanent nature showing the precise location and dimension of such features as streets, lots, easements, and other elements pertinent to transfer of ownership and prepared for permanent record. 
    Preliminary plat means a drawing showing the proposed general patterns of streets, lots, and land uses within a tract to be subdivided. 
    Resubdivision means a change in a map of an approved or recorded subdivision plat if such change affects any street layout on such map or area reserved thereon for public use, or any lot line; or if it affects any map or plan legally recorded prior to the adoption of any regulations controlling subdivisions. 
    Right-of-way means a strip of land acquired by reservation, dedication, forced dedication, prescription, or condemnation and intended to be occupied or occupied by a road, crosswalk, railroad, electric transmission lines, oil or gas pipeline, water line, sanitary storm sewer and other similar uses. 
    Rule exception means the allowing of a subdivision to deviate from one or more specific standards and requirements of these rules and regulations. 
    Sketch plat or sketch plan means a rough plan of a proposed subdivision or other development. It is a sketch preparatory to the preparation of the preliminary plat (or subdivision plat in the case of minor subdivisions) to enable the subdivider to save time and expense in reaching general agreement with the city as to the form of the plat and the objectives of these regulations. 
    Stream means a body of water flowing on the earth. 
    Public street means a right-of-way which affords principal means of vehicular access to property abutting thereon, which right-of-way has been dedicated to the public for such use. This includes the land between the street lines (right-of-way) lines, whether improved (paved) or unimproved. 
    Stub street means a temporary dead-end street that extends to the boundary of the subdivision to provide future connection of streets to abutting unsubdivided tracts, or connect with stub streets in existing subdivisions. May be permitted when development is phased over a period of time, but only if the street in its entirety has been approved in the preliminary plat. 
    Subcollector street means a frontage street which provides access to abutting properties and which may also conduct traffic from residential access streets that intersect it, but it is designed to discourage through traffic from outside the development. Subcollectors collect traffic only from residential access streets. 
    Subdivider means a person, firm, or corporation undertaking the subdividing of land. 
    Subdivision means any land, vacant or improved, which is divided or proposed to be divided into three (3) or more lots, parcels, sites, units, plots, or interests of less than five (5) acres for the purpose of offer, sale, lease, or development, either on the installment plan or upon any and all other plans, terms and conditions, including resubdivision. Subdivision includes the division or development of residential and nonresidential zoned land, whether by deed, metes and bounds description, devise, intestacy, lease, map, plat, or other recorded instrument. The exceptions are lot splits and cemeteries. 
    Utility means to include but not limited to: all pipes, wires, connections, conductors, switches, line transformers, and insulators which may supply natural gas, electricity, sewerage or water, or which may be used for communications transmission. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4247, § 1, 6-1-2004) 
Secs. 21-8-21-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS, FILING REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 21-21. - General procedure. 
    Whenever any subdivision of land is proposed, before any contract is made for the sale of any part thereof, and before any permit for the erection of a structure in such proposed subdivision shall be granted, the subdividing owner, or his authorized agent, shall apply for and secure approval of such proposed subdivision in accordance with the following procedure, which includes basically two (2) steps for a minor subdivision and three (3) steps for a major subdivision: 
(1)  Minor subdivision: 
a.  Sketch plat. 
b.  Final subdivision plat. 
(2)  Major subdivision: 
a.  Sketch plat. 
b.  Preliminary plat. 
c.  Final subdivision plat. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-22. - Plat required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to layout for the purpose of selling a tract or parcel of land in the city into three (3) or more building sites without first having the same surveyed and platted as hereinafter set forth by a registered land surveyor in the State of Mississippi and a plat thereof filed for record as provided by law with said surveyor's signature and seal thereon. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-23. - Preapplication procedure. 
    Prior to filing an application for approval of a preliminary plat, the subdivider shall submit a sketch plat of the proposed subdivision layout to the community development department. The sketch plat shall indicate location of the subdivision, street alignment, existing improvements and lot sizes. The sketch plat is to be used by the subdivider and the community development department to anticipate possible problems with the proposed subdivision. The community development department shall inform the subdivider whether plans and data as submitted meet with the policies and objectives of these regulations. The sketch plat shall contain items (1) through (5) and item (9) of the preliminary plat contents. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-24. - Preliminary plat-Preparation; conformance required. 
    A preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision shall be prepared by the subdivider or his agent and submitted to the Planning Commission for its consideration and approval. Before approval, the Commission shall satisfy itself that the proposed street pattern and land use will conform to the Comprehensive Plan, zoning title, and other local standards. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-25. - Same-Submission; plat; scale; contents. 
    Five (5) prints of the preliminary plat shall be provided to the planning division at least twenty-one (21) calendar days before the meeting date at which approval is asked. The preliminary plat shall be drawn to a minimum scale of one (1) inch to two hundred (200) feet and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The proposed name of the subdivision and the names of the adjacent subdivision. 
(2)  The boundary lines of the tract with dimensions. 
(3)  The general location, width, and alignment of existing and proposed streets, sidewalks, and any highways and alleys. 
(4)  The general pattern and sizes of proposed lots and tracts. 
(5)  The proposed use of land, whether for single family, multi family, commercial, industrial, parks, schools, etc. 
(6)  Topography of the area contained in the plat shown by two or five foot contour intervals. 
(7)  All platted or existing streets and property lines or land adjacent for a distance of not less than four hundred (400) feet. 
(8)  Approximate gradients of proposed streets within the plat. 
(9)  The names of the subdivider, the firms responsible for the preparation of the plat, north arrow, scale, date of preparation and any revision, space for endorsement by the city engineer and the planning commission. 
(10)  Location, size, and invert elevation of sanitary and storm sewers; location and size of water mains; location of gas lines; fire hydrants; electric and telephone equipment and street lights; if water mains and sewer are not on or adjacent to the tract, indicate the direction and distance to, and size of nearest ones, showing invert elevations of sewers. 
(11)  Description on the preliminary plat of any existing street or roads which abut, touch, or extend through the subdivision. The description shall include types and widths of existing surfaces; right-of-way widths; and width, load carrying capacity, and waterway adequacy of any bridges or culverts. The preliminary plat shall also include a statement as to how the surface of any such road or street will be improved as part of the subdivision development process in order to comply with section 21-47. 
(12)  General location of the limits of the area of special flood hazard as defined in chapter 10, section 10-5. This area shall be certified by a registered civil engineer. 
(13)  All technical design work shall be accomplished by a registered professional engineer engaged in the practice of civil engineering in the State of Mississippi or someone under his direct supervision. 
(14)  A phasing plan indicating location, size and order of construction phases. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 3964, 12-21-93) 
Sec. 21-26. - Same-Consideration. 
    The planning commission shall consider the proposed preliminary plat in an official meeting. The commission may, at its discretion, invite comments from interested parties concerning the preliminary plat. If the commission determines that the proposed preliminary plat conforms to the regulations and all zoning requirements applicable to the property, it shall approve the same. If the commission determines that the proposed preliminary plat does not conform to the requirements of the subdivision regulations or any applicable zoning requirements, it shall notify the applicant of such fact. If the planning commission determines the proposed plat is not sensitive to the natural topography and does not take other natural features into account, it shall withhold approval until a revised plat, is submitted which the planning commission finds acceptable. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-27. - Same-Approval not to constitute acceptance of a subdivision. 
    Approval of the preliminary plat does not constitute acceptance of the subdivision but authorizes preparation of the final plat. Only rough grading may take place in the subdivision prior to approval and endorsement of the final plat and the submittal to and approval of street construction plans by public works. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-28. - Same-Approval under PUD ordinance. 
    An approved preliminary plan filed under the planned unit development ordinance shall serve as the preliminary plat. The subdivider may file a final plat for any or all portions of the approved plan. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-29. - Final plat-Preparation; conformance. 
    After the preliminary plat has been approved, a final plat shall be prepared and submitted to the department of community development to be placed on the city council agenda for final approval. The final plat may encompass all or a portion of area encompassed by the preliminary plat. If in the opinion of the city engineer the submitted final plat does not substantially conform to the preliminary plat, the department of community development may advise the developer that he must resubmit a new preliminary plat for review and approval by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-30. - Same-Approval and acceptance of dedication. 
    The final plat shall be submitted to the city council for approval. The city council shall approve or disapprove the dedication of land for public purposes within a reasonable period of time following the date of submission of the plat. If the city council defers approval or disapprove such dedication, it shall advise the applicant and the planning commission of the reason thereof. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-31. - Same-Submission; scale; contents. 
    Twelve (12) prints of the final plat shall be submitted to the planning division at least twenty-one (21) working days prior to the date of the meeting at which approval is asked. The plat shall be drawn to a minimum scale of one (1) inch to one hundred (100) feet and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name of the subdivision and adjacent subdivisions; the names of streets which shall conform to the existing pattern; and a system of lot and block numbers in an orderly sequence. 
(2)  A boundary survey of third order surveying accuracy (minimum closure error, one in five thousand (5,000) with bearings and distances referenced to section or fractional section corners or other base lines shown on the plat and readily reproducible. 
(3)  Calculation sheets containing the following data: the length and radii of all curbed street and lot lines and the bearings and length of all straight street lot lines and the area in square feet of each lot. Bearings and distances referenced to sectional or fractional section lines or other base lines shown on the plat and readily reproducible on the ground. Street centerline bearing and distance with centerline curve data (deflection angle, radii, degree of curvature, chord distance and bearing and length of curve). 
(4)  The dimensions in feet and decimals of feet along front and side street and the location and dimension of all necessary easements be shown on the plat. 
(5)  Certification of dedication of all public streets, highways, and other right-of-ways or parcels for public park or other public use, signed by the owners and all other parties who have a mortgage or lien interest in the property; certification that all prior easement rights to any person, utility or corporation have been absolved on the parcels to be dedicated to public use. The person, utility, or corporation have been absolved on the parcels to be dedicated to public use. The person, utility, or corporation shall retain whatever rights they would have as if located in a public street. Recording data for all prior easements shall be included. Those prior easements shall be included and not subordinated. 
(6)  Certification by a registered land surveyor of the State of Mississippi to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him or someone under his direct supervision. 
(7)  North arrow, scale, and date. 
(8)  Space for endorsement by the city clerk and treasurer. 
(9)  Space for the endorsement by the Chancery Clerk. 
(10)  All endorsement spaces shall be shown on the plat in the order given above to minimize confusion in the sequence of signing the plat. 
(11)  Commercial subdivisions are not required to show lot and block numbers on the final plat. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4240, § 1, 4-20-2004; Ord. No. 4431, § 1 (Att. A), 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 21-32. - Certificate of title. 
    The owner shall have prepared and submitted to community development a proof of the title of land embraced in such subdivision before the plat may be approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-33. - Protective covenants. 
    The owner shall have prepared and submitted to community development for approval, prior to the consideration by the city council, the protective covenants, inform for recording, that embrace the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-34. - Regulations governing lot splits. 
    A previously platted lot may be divided as a lot split by either metes and bounds description or by replat. If such a lot is to be divided by metes and bounds description, however, it may be so divided only one (1) time and be only one (1) new dividing lot line and shall not be divided again without replatting, and such lot split need not comply with procedures set out in chapter 26 inclusive. A lot to be divided more than one (1) time or involving more than one (1) new dividing lot shall be considered a replat and shall be subject to all procedures set out in this chapter. In event of such lot split, the remaining or unused portion of such lot shall meet all zoning setbacks and subdivision requirements for a full size lot, except when it is owned and maintained by an adjoining owner as part of a single lot or home site. 
    In either case, the lots, so produced by a lot split shall conform to all minimum standards of these regulations and the zoning ordinance and other applicable codes of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Secs. 21-35-21-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL PLANNING STANDARDS 

Sec. 21-41. - Protection from flooding. 
    Subdivision proposals shall be designed to assure that all such proposals are consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; that all public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical, and water systems are located, elevated, and constructed to minimize or to eliminate flood damage; that adequate drainage is provided so as to reduce exposure to flood hazards. Subdivisions shall be designed in accordance with standards established in chapter 10 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Meridian. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-42. - Street arrangement. 
    Provision will be made for the extension of any existing dead-end streets (as distinguished from a cul-de-sac) whenever possible. Off-center street intersections should have an offset of a minimum of one hundred and twenty-five (125) feet (center line offset). Streets with reverse curves must conform to the existing topography as nearly as possible in order that drainage problems may be reduced. Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles and no street shall intersect any other street at less than seventy-five (75) degrees unless approved by the department of community development. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-43. - Relation to adjoining streets. 
    The system of streets designed for the subdivision must connect with any street already platted to the boundary from an abutting subdivision. At intervals of no more than one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) feet, all street rights-of-way must be continued to the boundaries of the tract subdivided. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-44. - Large allotments. 
    In case a tract is subdivided into larger parcels than normal building lots, such parcels shall be arranged to permit the opening of future streets and logical resubdivision. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-45. - Dead-end streets, stub streets, and cul-de-sacs. 
(a)  Dead-end streets will not be approved unless such dead-end streets are provided to connect with future streets on adjacent properties. 
(b)  Alignment of streets in new divisions of land shall conform to and provide for the continuation of the principal adjacent pre-existing streets or their proper projection where adjoining property has not been developed. 
(c)  The streets shall be at least as wide as the pre-existing streets to which they relate and shall be situated in such a way as to accommodate rational future access and street patterns. 
(d)  All streets shall be properly integrated and coordinated with existing streets, and the proposed system of streets within and contiguous to the subdivision, and dedicated rights-of-way as established in the comprehensive plan. 
(e)  Such proposed street rights-of-way shall be extended to the boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided, unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions, or unless in the opinion of community development such extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision with the existing layout or the most advantageous future development of adjacent tracts. 
(f)  The necessary rights-of-way for stub streets to provide adequate access to adjacent property or utility easements to provide utility service shall be dedicated at the time a subdivision is recorded. When the adjacent property is developed, the developer of such property shall connect and construct all stub streets and extend utility service to connect with the adjacent subdivision to public works standards. 
(g)  Stub roads in multi-staged subdivisions: In any subdivision recorded or built in sections, all stub streets or utilities in a section designed to serve property in the subdivision but to be developed in a later section shall be constructed at the time other streets or utilities in that section are constructed. 
(h)  Temporary turnarounds and reversion of excess ROW to abutting lots: A temporary T or L shaped turnaround shall be provided on all temporary dead-end (stub) streets, with the notation on the subdivision plat that land outside the normal street ROW shall revert to abutters whenever the street is continued. Public works may limit the length of temporary dead-end streets in accordance with the design standards of these (subdivision) regulations. 
(i)  Developer of future tract constructs streets in existing subdivision stub streets: Where appropriate, stub streets shall be reserved for future street usage in conjunction with the development of adjacent tracts. Stub streets reserved for future street usage will not be required to be improved unless lots are platted that front on such stub streets. Otherwise, these areas shall be reserved for street improvements to be provided by the developer of the adjacent tract. In situations where completion of improvements are not required, the stub street shall be graded and laid-out in anticipation of future improvements. 
    Whenever there exists a dedicated or platted area reserved for future street usage adjacent to the boundary of a tract being developed, such street shall be extended into the proposed development provided this use is not adverse to the manmade or natural features of the site. 
(j)  Drainage, barricades and traffic control on stub streets: 
(1)  Proper provision shall be made for adequate storm drainage at the ends of dead end streets. 
(2)  Appropriate barricades and other traffic controls shall be installed by the developer at dead ends, in accordance with city codes. 
(k)  No landlocked parcels: A tract shall be subdivided so that no remnants or land-locked spaces without access to the vehicular/pedestrian circulation system, will ultimately remain. 
(l)  Minimum length of stub streets to require a turnaround: Dead end streets having a length greater than two hundred (200) feet shall be provided with a temporary turnaround of either a circular or back-and-turn design. 
(m)  Cul-de-sacs may be permitted where a vehicular connection to other streets is not essential. Such cul-de-sacs shall provide access to all lots and a turnaround shall be provided at the closed end. The turnarounds on cul-de-sacs up to six hundred sixty (660) feet long shall have an outside paved street radius of at least forty (40) feet and a street property line radius of at least fifty (50) feet provided parking on the street is prohibited. Cul-de-sacs over six hundred sixty (660) feet long shall have an outside paved street radius of at least fifty (50) feet and a street property line (right-of-way) radius of sixty (60) feet. On-street parking is allowed in cul-de-sacs with an outside paved street radius of at least fifty (50) feet. Cul-de-sacs over six hundred sixty (660) feet long shall provide stub streets at appropriate intervals to be determined by public works. The maximum length of a cul-de-sac is one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) feet. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-46. - Pedestrian walkways. 
    In blocks where substantial pedestrian traffic may occur such as adjacent to schools, community development may require pedestrian walkways through blocks. Such walkway rights-of-way shall be ten (10) to fifteen (15) feet in width, and contain a concrete walk at least five (5) feet wide the entire length. Such walkways shall be dedicated to the public in the same manner as streets. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-47. - Street standards. 
(a)  For the purpose of facilitating the movement of traffic, streets are classified in the comprehensive plan as arterials, collectors, and minor residential streets. A copy of this plan shall be on file in the office of community development and reference shall be made to this plan before any preliminary subdivision plat is approved. 
(b)  Standards for streets shall be as follows: 
(1)  Arterial: 
a.  Minimum right-of-way width, eighty (80) feet. 
b.  Maximum gradient, ten (10) percent. 
c.  Minimum sight distance of vertical curves, six hundred (600) feet. 
d.  Minimum street width to be forty-four (44) feet (face to face of curb). 
(2)  Residential collector and business or industrial: 
a.  Minimum right-of-way width, sixty (60) feet. 
b.  Maximum gradient, twelve (12) percent. 
c.  Minimum sight distance of vertical curves, four hundred (400) feet. 
d.  Minimum street width to be thirty-three (33) feet (face to face of curb). 
(3)  Local residential: 
a.  Minimum right-of-way width, fifty (50) feet. 
b.  Maximum gradient, twelve (12) percent. 
c.  Minimum sight distance of vertical curves, one hundred fifty (150) feet. 
d.  Minimum street width to be twenty-six (26) feet (face to face of curb) for streets with curb and gutter. 
e.  Minimum paved street width to be twenty-two (22) feet for streets with open ditches with five (5) foot shoulders on each side of street. Open ditch drainage is not permitted in R-1A zoning districts, except where lot sizes are of at least two (2) acres each. 
(4)  Alleys: 
a.  Minimum right-of-way width, twenty (20) feet. 
b.  Maximum gradient, twelve (12) percent. 
c.  Minimum sight distance of vertical curve, one hundred fifty (150) feet. 
d.  Street width to be paved full width, twenty (20) feet. 
    The minimum gradient on a street shall be one (1) percent except that in an unusual case public works may permit a minimum of one-half (.5) percent. Curb radius at intersections shall be a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet. 
    The above standards may be modified at the discretion of public works. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-48. - Horizontal curve alignment. 
    A tangent of at least one hundred (100) feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets. Where connecting street lines deflect from each other at any one point by more than five (5) degrees, they shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to ensure sufficient sight distance for minor and collector streets or of such other radii as public works shall determine. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-49. - Proposed subdivision abutting or bounded by present or future major street. 
    When a proposed subdivision abuts a thoroughfare, or is bounded by a line that will in the future lie in a thoroughfare, as shown in the comprehensive plan, then the owner of that subdivision shall dedicate, without charge, any land within such subdivision that is necessary to provide conformity with the above standards. By accepting such dedication of right-of-way, the city certifies that the proposed thoroughfare shall be constructed within five (5) years after acceptance of the completed subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-50. - Lot arrangement and sizes generally. 
    The lot size, width, depth, shape, orientation and the minimum building setback lines shall comply with the requirements set forth in the zoning ordinance of the city. Depth and width of properties reserved or laid-out for commercial and industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide for the off-street service and parking facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated. Lots fronting on arterial streets must provide enough space for a turnaround so that vehicles will not have to back out onto these streets. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-51. - Subdivision entrance and other decorative structures. 
    Where one (1) or more entrance or street structures or ornaments such as monuments, pillars, fences, walls, statuary or other decorative features are to be installed in a permanent fashion, the location, size and design shall be included with the street plans submitted to public works for approval. This submission shall also include a copy of the bylaws or other documentation of the association which will have a permanent responsibility for maintenance. Such by-laws, or other documentation shall contain language which will, in the opinion of public works assure proper maintenance of such structures by such association. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Secs. 21-52-21-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 21-61. - Generally; installation of improvements. 
    The subdivider of land within the city shall be required to install or otherwise provide for improvements within the subdivision as required for development. If, however, public works, in anticipation of development outside the boundaries of a proposed subdivision, finds that the water, sewer and/or transportation needs of said development will be best served by the use of such improvements through all or any portion of said subdivision, the subdivider shall be required to construct such improvements in said subdivision of adequate size to service said outside development. In such cases the city will pay the difference in actual cost of materials (specifically excluding the costs of rights-of-way and easements) between that approved for the developer and that required by the city. The amount of the difference shall be determined by the city council, prior to the planning commission's acceptance of the preliminary plat of said subdivision. 
    Improvements shall not be installed prior to proper endorsement by the city council. The proper installation of such improvements, other than those by a private utility company, shall be assured by provision of an improvement guarantee as required by this article. All improvements installed by the developer shall comply with public works specifications and standards. The subdivider shall provide laboratory testing as specified by public works throughout construction. 
    In a new residential subdivision the city may provide water and sewer improvements (water lines, sewer lines and fire hydrants) on public property, but not lift stations, force mains, water meters, meter boxes, water and sewer taps. The extent, timing and provisions for those water and sewer improvements will be under the supervision of public works, and must be first approved by public works. The design of all such improvements, including those that the city may provide, will be the responsibility of the developer, but are subject to approval by the public works. The city may issue water and sewer revenue bonds, if required, to provide such water and sewer improvements. The value of the improvements provided by the city on public property will be made available to the developer based upon approval of the developer's construction plan, in an amount not to exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the total value of eligible water and sewer infrastructure per subdivision; however, where the new improvement (house) sells for one hundred twenty-five thousand dollars ($125,000.00) or less, the value percent increases to thirty (30) percent. This incentive applies only to a developer who selects Option 1 in section 21-69, improvement guarantees. To the extent that the law will permit the city so to do, property taxes on subdivided property will not be increased until after the improvement (house) has been completed and community development has issued a certificate of occupancy for such house. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4189, § 1, 9-4-2001; Admin. Inter. 9-11-2001; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-62. - Design and improvement standards. 
    The following improvements in sections 21-62, 21-63, 21-64, 21-66 and 21-67, shall be required of the subdivider. Sections 21-67 and 21-68 shall be required of the subdivider and/or the utility company as applicable. All utilities shall be installed according to the specifications and minimum standards of the controlling utility company or public agency except as otherwise provided by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-63. - Monuments. 
    Concrete markers shall be placed at all block corners. Monuments shall be a 5/8 x 2' iron pin set in concrete to identify points of intersection. An iron pin marker shall be placed at all lot corners and points of curvature and points of tangency. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-64. - Streets. 
(a)  All streets in the subdivision other than those providing access to adjourning undeveloped properties shall be paved. Only rough grading may take place within a street right-of-way until construction plans have been approved by public works. All street construction shall conform to specifications and standards of the city and compliance therewith shall be confirmed by public works prior to release of improvement guaranty by the city council. Streets may be built with either curb and gutter or open ditches. If curb and gutter are constructed, then the curbs must be constructed of concrete and inlets and storm drains installed as approved by public works. All subdivisions will contain side walks built to city specifications. 
(b)  Private streets: Private streets are allowed only in limited situations: in planned unit developments or in large lot developments having at least two (2) acre lots, or in other special situations, subject to the approval of public works and city council. They must be shown on plats as "private streets". Water meters will be placed at the public right-of-way. Sewer connections will also be made at the public right-of-way. Private streets cannot be through streets and they cannot serve as stub streets or half streets for future land divisions on abutting tracts. However, private streets must be built to a level of service sufficient for access by emergency and service vehicles at all times. Private streets must provide unrestricted access to all lots and uses served. Turnarounds at the ends of private streets must also be provided. Finally, the developer must provide public works with a copy of an agreement indicating how the street will be maintained and who is responsible for the maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006; Ord. No. 4434, § 1 (Att. A), 4-15-2014) 
Sec. 21-65. - Storm drainage. 
    The subdivider shall install culverts, storm sewers, stabilized ditches and other improvements to adequately handle stormwater. All improvements shall comply with public works minimum standards and shall be approved by public works prior to construction. 
(1)  The horizontal and vertical alignment of streets shall be compatible with the storm water runoff system and drainage design. 
(2)  Street grades shall be coordinated with lot drainage as proposed in the grading plan. 
(3)  The hydraulic capacity of the curb and gutter shall be determined by accepted engineering practices taking into consideration roughness, street cross-slope, and street gradient, and allowable spread of water over the travel lane. 
(4)  The hydraulic capacity of curb inlets shall be determined by accepted engineering procedure taking into consideration inlet geometry and characteristics of the gutter flow. Curb inlets shall be spaced so as to limit the spread of water to not more than one (1) quarter of the street width during a design storm of five-year return period and fifteen (15) minute duration. Inlets shall also be located at all low points in the gutter grade, to prevent gutter flow from crossing traffic lanes of an intersecting street, or at points of special concern as designated by public works. All cross drain culverts shall be of reinforced concrete unless otherwise approved by public works. Other culvert materials approved by the state highway department may be used for all other applications except cross drains. 
(5)  Site drainage system to tie to community drainage system. 
(6)  Tracts and lots to reduce on-site excess runoff: Lots shall be developed to maximize the amount of natural drainage which is percolated into the soil and to minimize direct overland runoff into adjoining street and water courses. Stormwater runoff from roofs and other impervious surfaces should be diverted into swales or terraces on the lot when possible to slow down water flow and increase absorption. 
(7)  On-site retention basin may be required. 
(8)  Shoreline and stream bank protection: A buffer yard of fifteen (15) feet is required between the top of a stream bank and any structure, other than boat landings, docks, bridges, and pumping or water treatment facilities. The above width of the buffer yard may be modified at the discretion of public works. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-66. - Erosion control. 
    Erosion control means the subdivider shall provide erosion control on all disturbed areas within the subdivision as required by public works. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-67. - Underground utilities excluding water and sewage. 
    All utilities as defined herein shall be installed either overhead or underground, at the option of the subdivider, developer or owner before issuance of a certificate of occupancy. This option is granted for all zoning districts except R-1A, which requires underground utilities. 
(1)  Installation: The provider of the utility in any subdivision shall furnish a letter confirming all installations as required by this section have been completed and conform with industry standards. This confirmation shall be submitted to the building code official prior to requesting a certificate of occupancy. The utility company will be franchised by the city. The installation and cost of the service will be agreed upon by the utility company and the subdivider, developer or owner. 
(2)  Easements and rights-of-way: It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider to provide them in such a manner that the utility company can have access to terminals, transformers, etc. for normal maintenance. 
(3)  Street lighting: Lighting for all new subdivisions shall be provided at approximately one hundred fifty-foot intervals, either on alternate or the same side of the street. Such lighting shall be installed by the franchised utility company. 
(4)  Exceptions: Permanent exception; the provisions of this section shall not apply to any of the following uses: 
a.  All electrical power lines rated at or above the "feeder" line class. For the purpose thereof, a "feeder" line is defined as that portion of an electrical circuit which provides power from a power substation and which has a rated capacity of three thousand (3,000) KVA or more. 
b.  All television cable lines rated at or above "trunk" line class. For purpose hereof, a "trunk" line is defined as that portion of a telecable system's line that is .750 inches in diameter. 
c.  Existing poles, overhead wires, and associated overhead structures, when part of a continuous line, or services to individual properties from such existing overhead lines that are within a subdivision approved and recorded prior to the adoption of this chapter. 
d.  Existing poles, overhead wires, and associated overhead structures, when part of a continuous line, or services to individual properties adjacent to but not within the areas being subdivided. 
e.  Nothing in this chapter will prevent the replacement of poles, overhead wires, and associated overhead structures on these lines when necessary for the purpose of maintaining the line or upgrading the capacity thereof or, in the case of single-phase lines, the addition of the necessary facilities for three-phasing of the line. 
f.  Radio and television antennas. 
g.  Structures on corner lots; in streets and alleys, and on easements adjacent thereto; and in cases where electrical and communication lines cross a street or other district boundary from an area where overhead lines are not prohibited may be connected to said overhead lines and are hereby exempt from the provision of this chapter. 
h.  Overhead lines attached to the exterior surface of a building by means of a bracket or other fixture and extending from one (1) location on the building to another location on the same building, or to an adjacent building without crossing a property line. 
i.  Poles used exclusively for street or area lighting or for traffic control facilities. 
j.  Service terminals, transformers, regulators, meters, or other on and above ground appurtenances normally used with and as part of an underground distribution system. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 3989, § 1, 9-6-94) 
Sec. 21-68. - Sanitary sewers and other utilities. 
(a)  The subdivider shall be responsible for the proper installation of sanitary sewers, sewer laterals, fresh water supply, water taps and connection to the city sewerage treatment and water supply facilities, including fire plugs and valves. Installation of the sewer laterals and water taps shall be extended to the property line and permanently marked to properly service each lot. 
(b)  The city will waive the sewer and water tap fees on all accepted subdivision development for a period of five (5) years after the acceptance of the subdivision by the city, provided the only expense incurred by the city is the setting of the water meter. 
(c)  No subdivision shall be approved and no construction therein permitted until a said subdivision has access to a sewer main tied to the Meridian sewerage treatment facility. Sewer and water lines shall meet the following standards: 
Sewer lines: Minimum diameter: Eight (8) inches 
Minimum velocity: Two (2) feet per second Man holes: Maximum spacing: Four hundred (400) feet Fire hydrants: Maximum spacing: Five hundred (500) feet Water lines: Minimum size: Eight (8) inches  
(d)  The above standards may be modified at the discretion of public works. Letters of approval from the bureau of pollution control board and the Mississippi State Board of Health shall be submitted prior to approval to proceed with the construction of the improvements. 
(e)  Sanitary sewer. Large lot subdivisions (lots of two (2) acres and more) are not required to connect to city sewer system if they have eight (8) lots or less and meet health department approval. 
(f)  Street lights in subdivisions shall be placed to industry standards by the utility company franchised by the city. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-69. - Improvement guarantees. 
    Prior to public works review and approval of construction plans and specifications, the subdivider must select either of the following two (2) options: 
    Option 1. All improvements shall be completed and dedicated to the city within one (1) year of construction plan approval. All improvements will be guaranteed by the subdivider for a period of one (1) year from the date of acceptance against failure due to faulty workmanship or materials. See "maintenance guarantee" below. 
    Option 2. A "performance guaranty" shall be posted by the subdivider guaranteeing to the city that all improvements will be installed and completed in accordance with the approved plan and applicable subdivision requirements within one (1) year of construction plan approval. Plans and specifications for improvements must be approved by public works prior to submittal and approval of a final plat. The subdivider may then sell lots and secure building permits for structures on individual lots. However, no "occupancy permits" will be issued until all subdivision improvements have been substantially completed and same is approved in writing by public works. 
    Upon fulfilling either of the above options, the city council will approve the "final plat" and same will be property executed and recorded in the Lauderdale County Land Records. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006; Ord. No. 4314, § 1, 3-20-2007) 
Sec. 21-70. - Timetable for construction. 
    As part of construction plan approval, the subdivider will establish a plan of construction including a timetable for completion of all improvements which shall not exceed one (1) year for any development phase. This plan and timetable shall be part of the final plan approval by public works. In the event of a hardship beyond the subdivider's control, an extension of the construction timetable may be allowed by public works. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-71. - The guarantees. 
    The guaranty may be in either of the forms outlined below: 
(1)  A "maintenance guarantee" will be furnished to the city clerk by the subdivider at the completion of all work. The amount of the guaranty will be ten (10) percent of the cost of all improvements and it will guarantee against maintenance cost occurring during the twelve (12) months following construction caused by failure of the improvements due to faulty workmanship or materials. 
(2)  A "performance guaranty" will be required of subdividers who wish to sell lots or secure building permits prior to the completion of all improvements. The amount of the guaranty will be one hundred ten (110) percent of the estimate of the cost of the improvements to be made as approved by public works. During the construction period as work is satisfactorily completed, the amount of the guarantee will be reduced appropriately but not below one hundred ten (110) percent of the estimated cost of completing the remaining improvements. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-72. - Method of guaranty. 
    The method of guarantee provided by the subdivider and submitted to the city clerk will be in any one (1) or more of the following manners: 
(1)  A performance bond issued by a surety company licensed to do business in the State of Mississippi. 
(2)  A letter of credit from a Federally Insured Bank or Savings and Loan Association doing business in the State of Mississippi. 
(3)  An asset escrow account established with the city. Into such escrow account would be deposited cash, cash equivalent securities. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Secs. 21-73-21-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 21-81. - Rule exception. 
    The standards and procedures required in this title shall be interpreted and applied literally in the case of all subdivision plats submitted after the date of the adoption of these regulations. In case, however, of hardship caused by size, location, configuration of land, topography or other factors which affect a specific tract or subdivision or portion thereof, the subdivider may request a rule exception from one or more of the requirements contained herein. A rule exception may be requested at the time of filing the preliminary or final plat. A rule exception may be approved by the planning commission and the city council provided that such action will not violate the public interest, unnecessarily burden the city, or will annul the intent and purpose of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 21-82. - Filing fee. 
    The following fee shall be paid at the time and place of application by all persons or corporations submitting preliminary plats for approval by the planning commission. The fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) plus: 
(1)  Four dollars ($4.00) per lot for ten (10) or less lots. 
(2)  Three dollars ($3.00) per lot for eleven (11) to fifty (50) lots. 
(3)  Two dollars ($2.00) per lot for fifty-one (51) to one hundred fifty (150) lots. 
(4)  One dollar ($1.00) per lot for one hundred fifty one (151) lots or more. 
    Minimum total fee shall be fifty-four dollars ($54.00). This fee shall be paid at the time the preliminary plat is submitted to community development and shall apply to approval of the preliminary plat and final plat provided the final plat includes the same area to be subdivided as the preliminary plat. If the final plat is submitted in segments or phases, then the above fee schedule shall apply to all submittals except the first. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Sec. 21-83. - Submittal of recorded plat. 
    After the final plat has been approved by the city council, the subdivider, within ten (10) working days, shall be responsible for having the plat recorded at the Lauderdale County Courthouse and must supply the city with copies of the recorded plat as follows: 
(1)  To public works-Three (3) paper copies, one (1) reproducible copy, one (1) copy mounted on linen and one (1) digital copy of both the plat and "as built" plans of associated public improvements; 
(2)  To community development-Two (2) paper copies. 
(3)  To city clerk-One (1) paper copy. 
    Failure to provide the appropriate number, type and distribution of copies within the above time limit shall render the city council's approval null and void. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 4301, 12-19-2006) 
Secs. 21-84-21-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 21-91. - Penalty for violations; actions. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation who shall knowingly and wilfully violate the terms, conditions, or provisions of this chapter for violation of which no other criminal penalty is prescribed, shall be sentenced to pay a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00), and in case of continuing violations without reasonable effort on the part of the defendant to correct same, each day after shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 7-7-92) 
Chapter 22 - TAXATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2; privilege tax for retailers of light wine and beer, § 5-2; privilege tax for wholesalers of light wine and beer, § 5-3; local privilege tax law adopted, § 14-1. 

Sec. 22-1. - Definition.
