(e)  At nighttime, the car being towed shall display lamps as required by state law. Not more than one (1) motor vehicle shall be towed at a time. 
(Code 1962, § 23-64) 
State Law reference- General regulation of trailers and towed vehicles, Miss. Code 1972, § 63-5-25; lighting required, § 63-7-11. 
Sec. 23-83. - Towing more than one trailer prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to attach more than one (1) trailer to any motor vehicle being operated over and along the streets of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 23-65) 
Sec. 23-84. - Sitting in lap of driver prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to have in his lap any other person, adult or minor, nor shall the driver of such vehicle be seated in the lap of any person while the vehicle is in motion. 
(Code 1962, § 23-66) 
Sec. 23-85. - Regulation of travel through 26th Avenue underpass. 
    All persons traveling through the underpass on 26th Avenue shall observe the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in such underpass or in the entrances thereto. 
(2)  Upon the approach of any emergency vehicle, all other vehicles shall clear the underpass and remain clear thereof until the emergency vehicle or vehicles have passed through. 
(3)  All vehicles shall use the west passageway in traveling south and the east passageway in traveling north through such underpass. 
(4)  No vehicle shall stop in such underpass. 
(5)  No vehicle shall turn around in such underpass or the entrances thereto, and the same rules and regulations with respect to turning on the streets and avenues shall apply as to such underpass. 
(6)  No vehicle shall undertake to pass another vehicle in such underpass. 
(7)  No vehicle shall stop in any such manner as to in any way block the entrances to such underpass. 
(8)  No vehicle shall travel at a greater rate of speed than fifteen (15) miles an hour passing through such underpass. 
(9)  No pedestrian shall walk in such underpass upon the driveways thereof, except in crossing the driveway at the north entrance to reach the stairway on the east side of the entrance to such underpass, or in going from the stairway to the sidewalk on the west side thereof, and shall cross at the point at right angles to the sidewalk. 
(10)  It shall be unlawful for any person to walk upon or be upon the revetment walls at the entrances or approaches to such underpass. 
(Code 1962, § 23-67) 
Sec. 23-86. - Emergency vehicles-Duties on approach of. 
(a)  Upon the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle, when the driver is giving audible signal by siren, exhaust whistle or bell, the driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right-of-way and shall immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to, the right-hand edge or curb of the street clear of any intersection and shall stop and remain in such position until the authorized emergency vehicle has passed, except when otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  This section shall not operate to relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the highway. 
(Code 1962, § 23-68) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 63-3-809. 
Sec. 23-87. - Same-To have right-of-way. 
    United States mail vehicles, ambulances and vehicles of the police and fire departments shall have the right-of-way on any street. All vehicles pertaining to the fire department shall have prior right-of-way over all other vehicles or cars upon the streets of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person in charge or control of any buggy, wagon, carriage, automobile engine or train, or any other vehicle propelled by whatsoever motive power, to carelessly, wantonly, wilfully, or maliciously delay any fire apparatus of the city going to or returning from any supposed or actual fire. 
(Code 1962, § 23-69) 
Sec. 23-88. - Vehicles to stop for restive horses. 
    Every person running, operating or driving a motor vehicle shall, at the request or upon signal by putting up the hand, from any person driving or riding a restive horse, cause such motor vehicle to stop and remain standing, and on request shall cause the engine or motor of such vehicle to stop and remain standing, and on request shall cause the engine or motor of such vehicle to cease running so long as may be reasonably necessary to allow such horse to pass in safety. 
(Code 1962, § 23-70) 
Secs. 23-89-23-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to regulate parking of vehicles, Miss. Code 1972, § 63-3-211(a)(1). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-106. - General parking requirements. 
    Except on one-way streets, vehicles shall in all cases be parked on the right-hand side of the street in the direction of traffic. Where parking spaces are marked on the street, they shall be parked only within such parking spaces. Where vehicles are parked at an angle to the curb, they shall be left with a front wheel against the curb; and where they are parked parallel with the curb, the right front and rear wheels shall be left within fifteen (15) inches of the curb; provided that, all vehicles longer than nineteen (19) feet over all, shall always be parked parallel to the curb anywhere in the city. 
(Code 1962, § 23-77) 
State Law reference- Requirement that vehicles be parked on right-hand side of roadway, Miss. Code 1972, § 63-3-907. 
Sec. 23-107. - Manner of parking on unpaved, unmarked streets; time in absence of markings, signs. 
    On all unpaved streets, and on all paved streets where there are no parking spaces marked and where there are no signs displayed which prohibit parking, vehicles shall be parked parallel with and as near to the right-hand curb as practicable. Where there are no parking signs displayed limiting the time for parking on such streets, vehicles may be parked for any length of time except as otherwise limited or prohibited by this article. 
(Code 1962, § 23-78) 
Sec. 23-108. - Prohibited in certain places. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk; 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(3)  Within an intersection; 
(4)  Within ten (10) feet of a fire hydrant; 
(5)  On a crosswalk; 
(6)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
(7)  Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign, or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway; 
(8)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless the traffic authority indicates a different length by signs or markings; 
(9)  Within fifteen feet (15) of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
(10)  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of the entrance when properly signposted; 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(13)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a street or within a street tunnel; 
(14)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping; 
(15)  In the subway; 
(16)  In the driveway leading into filling stations or private premises; 
(17)  In front of the entrance of any hotel or theater; provided that taxi stations may be established and maintained in front of hotels when authorized by the city manager; 
(18)  Within any space reserved as a motorbus stop. 
(b)  No person shall move a vehicle owned by any person into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
(Code 1962, § 23-79; Ord. No. 4139, 11-16-99; Ord. No. 4156, 3-21-99; Ord. No. 4178, §§ 1-4, 1-9-2001) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 63-3-901. 
Sec. 23-109. - Manner of parking to load, unload. 
    When being loaded or unloaded, trucks and drays may be backed up to the curb, but shall be so placed as to cause the least practicable interference with traffic on the streets. Horses or mules attached to vehicles backed up to the curb when loading and unloading shall be turned at right angles to the vehicle to which attached in the direction in which the traffic on that side of the street is moving. Every truck or dray shall be promptly loaded and unloaded and shall not be permitted to stand or remain stationed at any place on the street in the down town section of the city, except while being loaded or unloaded, unless the same shall be parked in the manner required for other vehicles. 
(Code 1962, § 23-80) 
Sec. 23-110. - Designation of loading zones. 
    The director of public works is hereby authorized to determine and designate the location of curb loading zones and shall have such zones properly marked as such but in no event shall there be more than one (1) such loading zone on each side of each block unless the block is in excess of three hundred (300) feet in length. 
(Code 1962, § 23-81; Ord. No. 4021, § 4, 7-18-95) 
Sec. 23-111. - Parking in loading zones. 
    No person shall stop or park any vehicle in any space in the city marked as a curb loading zone for any purpose other than for the expeditious unloading, delivery or pick-up and loading of material or merchandise during the hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect, which hours are hereby fixed from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. except upon Sunday and national holidays; provided, that in no case shall a vehicle be stopped or parked in any such zone for a period in excess of thirty (30) minutes in the business district of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 23-82) 
Sec. 23-112. - Loading, unloading trailers in certain areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any vehicle equipped with a trailer or semi-trailer to load or unload between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon and between the hours of 2:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m. within the following area in the city: All that portion of the city lying north of 4th Street bounded on the west by 26th Avenue, on the east by 20th Avenue and on the north by 9th Street. Also all that portion of 2nd Street between 21st Avenue and 23rd Avenue; provided, that this shall not apply where such loading and unloading may be done in any alley or in any off-street area. 
(Code 1962, § 23-83) 
Sec. 23-113. - Parking under unusual conditions. 
    In case of crowds, congested traffic or any other unusual conditions on the street, vehicles shall be parked as may be directed by any traffic officer personally directing the traffic on such street. 
(Code 1962, § 23-85) 
Sec. 23-114. - Buses to stop near curb; designation, compliance with bus stops; parking long vehicles at angle prohibited. 
    Every motorbus shall stop to receive and discharge passengers on the near side of the street, parallel with and as near to the right-hand curb as practicable. No motorbus or any other vehicle more than eighteen (18) feet long, shall ever be parked at any angle to the curb. Motorbus stops may be established in the down town section by an order of the mayor. Where such bus stops are so established, motorbuses shall stop only at such stops. 
(Code 1962, § 23-86) 
Sec. 23-115. - Duties when leaving vehicle unattended. 
    No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended on any street in the city without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition and removing the key, or when standing upon any perceptible grade without effectively setting the brake thereon and turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the street. 
(Code 1962, § 23-87) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code 1972, § 63-3-909. 
Sec. 23-116. - Repairing vehicles in streets. 
    It shall be unlawful to park, station or leave any vehicle in any street in front of any garage, blacksmith shop, or other shop for the purpose of being repaired; nor shall any person work on or repair any vehicle while in the street except temporary repairs in case of emergency. 
(Code 1962, § 23-88) 
Sec. 23-117. - Leaving vehicles for sale on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any dealer or other person to station or park any motor vehicle, or other vehicle, kept or offered for sale, on any of the streets or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 23-89) 
Sec. 23-118. - Operating filling station on street, sidewalks, servicing vehicles on sidewalks prohibited. 
    No person shall be permitted to operate any automobile filling station or service station either wholly or partly on any street or sidewalk in the city; nor shall any person stop or park any motor either wholly or partly on any sidewalk or near any filling or service station while being served or for the purpose of being served by any such filling or service station, or for the purpose of changing tires or having any repairs whatever done; nor shall any such filling station or service station serve any car so stopped on the sidewalk. 
(Code 1962, § 23-90) 
Sec. 23-119. - Moving parked vehicles without permission prohibited. 
    Except as provided in section 23-120 of this chapter it shall be unlawful for any person to take, use or drive any vehicle parked or stationed at any point in the city without first having obtained the consent of the owner or persons so parking or stationing the same. 
(Code 1962, § 23-91) 
Sec. 23-120. - Impounding unlawfully parked vehicles authorized; redemption, fee. 
    Every vehicle which may be improperly or unlawfully stationed, parked or left in any street of the city, may be removed and impounded by any traffic or police officer of the city, who shall promptly report the same to police headquarters for record. Such impounded vehicle shall be delivered to the owner or other person entitled to possession thereof on the payment of an impounding fee of ten dollars ($10.00), which shall be accounted for by the police department. 
(Code 1962, § 23-92) 
State Law reference- Authority of police to remove illegally stopped vehicles, Miss. Code 1972, § 63-3-905. 
Sec. 23-121. - Parking, stopping, standing prohibited on portions of certain streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator or driver of any motor vehicle to park or cause such motor vehicle to remain stopped or standing on portions of streets and avenues within the corporate limits of the city as established from time to time and marked with signs giving notice of such prohibitions. 
(Code 1962, § 23-93) 
Sec. 23-122. - Parking of trucks prohibited in certain residential zones. 
(a)  Whenever used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Trailer shall mean every vehicle without motive power designed for use in connection with a truck tractor. 
    Truck shall mean any motor vehicle designed for the transportation of property and capable of carrying a load weighing in excess of two thousand two hundred (2,200) pounds. 
    Truck tractor shall mean a motor vehicle designed primarily for drawing trailers and other vehicles, and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the trailer or other vehicle and load so drawn. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any truck, truck tractor or trailer on any street in any A-0, A-1, A-2 or A-3 residential district, as shown on the official zoning map of the city; provided, however, any such vehicle may be parked on such street when necessary to pick up or deliver heavy merchandise or materials at the location it is parked, but only for so long as may be required to make such pickup or delivery. 
(c)  In any prosecution for violation of this section, proof that such vehicle was parked on any such street shall be prima facie evidence that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked at the same location. 
(Code 1962, § 23-94; Ord. No. 3537, §§ 1-3, 4-19-78; Ord. No. 3896, 11-6-90) 
Sec. 23-123. - Handicapped parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park in any parking area reserved for the handicapped any motor vehicle which does not have one (1) of the following: 
(1)  On the vehicle license plate the special decal authorized for handicapped persons by Mississippi Code 1972, section 27-19-56; or 
(2)  On the vehicle dashboard the parking certificate bearing the international wheelchair logo authorized by such statute. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park in any parking area reserved for the handicapped any motor vehicle bearing such special decal and/or parking certificate which is not then driven or occupied by the handicapped person to whom such special decal or parking certificate was issued. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each such violation. 
(Code 1962, § 23-95; Ord. No. 3665, §§ 1-3, 7-5-83) 
Secs. 23-124-23-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING ZONES AND SPACES 

Sec. 23-136. - Definition. 
    Whenever the word "operator" is used in this division it shall be construed to mean and include every individual who shall operate a vehicle as the owner thereof, or as the agent, employee or permittee of the owner. 
(Code 1962, § 23-100) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 23-137. - Authority of director of public works to designate zones, spaces. 
    The director of public works shall have authority to designate parking zones and parking spaces within the city and to limit, regulate and determine the maximum length of time a vehicle may be parked in any such parking space. 
(Code 1962, § 23-101; Ord. No. 4021, § 3, 7-18-95) 
Sec. 23-138. - Ticketing, report of overtime parking; owner prima facie responsible. 
    Whenever any person has parked a vehicle in violation of this chapter or in violation of any other restriction on parking established by this Code or by the chief of police under the authority of section 23-2 or any other provision of this Code, it shall be the duty of the police officer to record the following information: 
(1)  The general location of the vehicle; 
(2)  The state license number of such vehicle; 
(3)  The manner in which the violation occurred, and any other facts which may be necessary for a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. 
The police officer shall also attach to such vehicle a notice to the owner or operator thereof that the vehicle has been parked in violation of the provisions of this chapter and to summons such owner or operator thereof to appear before the police justice at police headquarters in regard to such violation. In the prosecution for the violation of any section of this article, relating to the unlawful stopping, standing and parking of any vehicles, proof that such vehicle was unlawfully stopped or standing shall be prima facie evidence that the registered owner of such vehicle was operating the same at the time of such violation or, in case of parking overtime, that the registered owner parked the vehicle and caused it to be parked overtime. Leaving a vehicle parked for more than one (1) hour in a parking place where the parking is restricted to one (1) hour shall constitute a violation of this section, and each hour thereafter that the vehicle remains there shall constitute a separate violation. Similarly, where the time restriction shall be more or less than one (1) hour, each multiple of the parking time restriction for that place shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Code 1962, § 23-107; Ord. No. 3662, § 1, 5-18-83) 
Sec. 23-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESIDENT AUTOMOBILE PARKING PERMIT SYSTEM[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3810, adopted Aug. 16, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, its inclusion as Div. 3 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 23-141. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicated a different meaning:] 
(a)  Downtown core: Starting at the intersection of the center line of Fifth Street and the center line of 19th Avenue as the point of beginning; thence proceed northwesterly along the center line of 19th Avenue to the center line of 11th Street; thence westerly along the center line of 11th Street to the center line of 24th Avenue; thence southerly along the center line of 24th Avenue to the center line of Eighth Street; thence Westerly along the center line of Eighth Street to the center line of 26th Avenue; thence Southerly along the center line of 26th Avenue to the northern right-of-way line of the IC&G Railway; thence Easterly along the northern right-of-way line to the center line of 18th Avenue; thence North along the center line of 18th Avenue to the center line of Fifth Street; thence Westerly along the center line of Fifth Street to the point of beginning. 
(b)  Resident parking permit: A permit issued to a bonafide resident of the downtown core by the city, in the form of a uniquely numbered sticker to be displayed on the left side of the rear bumper of a vehicle, owned, leased or operated by such resident. 
(c)  Proof of residency: Any two (2) of the following indicating a residential address in the downtown core: 
(1)  Lease or mortgage documents; 
(2)  Proof of payment of Lauderdale County land or personal property taxes; 
(3)  Vehicle or personal property insurance policy; 
(4)  Proof of payment of a security deposit or paid rent receipt; 
(5)  Driver's license or vehicle registration; 
(6)  Affidavit by applicant of facts and circumstances indicating such residency. 
(d)  Bona fide residence: A physical address of a dwelling unit within the downtown core, for which an occupancy permit has been issued by the building official, indicating that the dwelling unit meets all the current standards required of such residential use. 
(e)  Building. Any structure having a roof supported by columns walls and intended for the shelter, housing or enclosure of any individual, process equipment, goods or material of any kind or nature. 
(Ord. No. 3810, § 1, 8-16-88) 
Sec. 23-142. - Resident parking permitted. 
    A person occupying a bona fide residence in a building within the downtown core, who owns, operates or leases a motor vehicle, including a motorcycle, used and under his control while occupying the unit may, if the vehicle has a current valid resident parking permit sticker properly displayed thereon, park the same in a parking space in the downtown core within three hundred seventy-five (375) feet of their residence without regard to the time restrictions on parking otherwise in effect for such designated parking space. No more than four (4) permits per building will be issued to residents in any given building during a calendar. 
(Ord. No. 3810, § 2, 8-16-88) 
Sec. 23-143. - Permit application; fees. 
(a)  A person residing in the downtown core shall make application for such resident parking permit on forms provided by the city requiring the information forming the basis for grant or denial of the permit. 
(b)  After approval of the permit, the same shall be issued, upon payment of a yearly fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). No fee shall be required for anyone sixty-five (65) years of age or older. 
(Ord. No. 3810, § 3, 8-16-88) 
Sec. 23-144. - Eligible vehicles receiving permits. 
    The resident must present to the city proof of ownership or control of the motor vehicle and a paid personal property tax receipt for the current year if such vehicle is owned by applicant or present evidence that he operates a leased or company-owned vehicle regularly parked and used by the resident in the down-town core. 
(Ord. No. 3810, § 4, 8-16-88) 
Sec. 23-145. - Change of vehicle. 
    Permit holders changing vehicles must remove the residential parking permit sticker from the vehicle to which it was issued and bring the fragments thereof, along with proof of ownership or control of another vehicle to the city at which time the old permit will be voided and a new permit issued upon payment of a five dollar ($5.00) fee. 
(Ord. No. 3810, § 5, 8-16-88) 
Sec. 23-146. - Violations. 
(a)  False information. No person shall falsely represent himself as eligible for a parking permit, or shall furnish false information in an application for a permit. 
(b)  Wrong vehicle. No person shall use or display or allow the use or display of, a valid residential parking permit on a motor vehicle other than that for which the permit was issued. 
(c)  False display. No person shall knowingly use or display a facsimile or counterfeit parking permit in order to evade time limitations on parking applicable in the permit-designated area. 
(d)  Sold vehicle. No person shall sell or otherwise dispose of a vehicle with a parking permit without removing that permit, and no subsequent owner of the vehicle shall use a permit issued to a previous owner. 
(e)  Other. No person shall knowingly commit any act prohibited by ordinance, rule or regulation, or aid or abet another to do so. 
(Ord. No. 3810, § 6, 8-16-88) 
Sec. 23-147. - Penalties. 
    Violations of any provisions herein shall be punishable by a penalty not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) and each days violation shall be a separate offense. 
    Upon conviction of a violation, the offender shall, in addition to the penalty above provided, be denied a resident parking permit for a period of one (1) year from such conviction and any permit theretofore issued to such offender shall be voided and the fragments thereof seized by the city. 
(Ord. No. 3810, § 7, 8-16-88) 
Secs. 23-148-23-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PARADES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate or prohibit processions on streets, Miss. Code 1972, § 63-3-211. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-161. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Parade Ordinance of the City of Meridian, Mississippi." 
(Code 1962, § 23-121; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-162. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Parade is any parade, march, ceremony, show, demonstration, exhibition, pageant, or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public place in the city. 
    Parade permit is a permit as required by this article. 
(Code 1962, § 23-122; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 23-163. - Duties of permittee. 
    A permittee under this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1962, § 23-131; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-164. - Possession of permit. 
    The parade chairman or other person leading or heading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Code 1962, § 23-132; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-165. - Public conduct during parades. 
(a)  Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
(b)  Driving through. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicle or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(c)  Parking on route. The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 23-133; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Secs. 23-166-23-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 14. 

Sec. 23-176. - Required; exceptions. 
    No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form, or start any parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the mayor. This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1962, § 23-123; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-177. - Application; contents. 
    A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the mayor or his authorized agent on forms provided by such officer: 
(1)  Filing period. An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the mayor or his authorized agent not less than five (5) days nor more than ten (10) days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(2)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade; 
b.  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organizations; 
c.  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct; 
d.  The date when the parade is to be conducted; 
e.  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point; 
f.  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals and description of the vehicles; 
g.  The hours when such parade will start and terminate; 
h.  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
i.  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade; 
j.  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas; 
k.  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade; 
l.  If the parade is designated to be held by, and on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the mayor or his authorized agent a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf; 
m.  Any additional information which the mayor or his authorized representative shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(3)  Late applications. The mayor or his authorized representative, where good cause is shown thereunder, shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder, which is filed less than five (5) days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(Code 1962, § 23-124; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-178. - Standards for issuance. 
    The mayor or his authorized agent shall issue a permit as provided for hereunder when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city; 
(3)  The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto; 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas; 
(5)  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of fire-fighting equipment en route to a fire; 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route; 
(8)  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(Code 1962, § 23-125; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-179. - Notice of rejection of application. 
    The mayor or his authorized agent shall act upon the application for a parade permit within three (3) days after the filing thereof. If the mayor or his authorized agent disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant within three (3) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. 
(Code 1962, § 23-126; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-180. - Appeal of denial of application. 
    Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to the city council. The appeal shall be taken within ten (10) days after notice. The city council shall act upon the appeal at its next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(Code 1962, § 23-127; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-181. - Alternate. 
    The mayor or his authorized agent, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within one (1) day after notice of the action of the mayor or his authorized agent, file a written notice of acceptance with the mayor or his authorized agent. An alternate permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. 
(Code 1962, § 23-128; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-182. - Notice to city and other officials upon issuance. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, the mayor or his authorized agent shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)  The city attorneys; 
(2)  The fire chief; 
(3)  The city engineer; 
(4)  The postmaster; 
(5)  The general manager or responsible head of each public transportation utility, the regular route of whose vehicles will be affected by the route of the proposed parade. 
(Code 1962, § 23-129; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-183. - Contents. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time; 
(2)  Minimum speed; 
(3)  Maximum speed; 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade; 
(5)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade; 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; 
(7)  Such other information as the mayor or his authorized agent shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 23-130; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Sec. 23-184. - Revocation. 
    The mayor or his authorized agent shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued hereunder upon application of the standards for issuance as herein set forth. 
(Code 1962, § 23-134; Ord. No. 3240, 3-2-65) 
Chapter 24 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 24-1-24-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS, LIMOUSINES AND SHUTTLES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority over taxicabs generally, Miss. Code 1962, §§ 21-27-131-21-27-141. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3801, adopted Apr. 5, 1988, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1, 2, 10-14, 16, 17 as §§ 24-15, 24-18, 24-27, 24-24, 24-26, 24-21; 24-22, 24-23 and 24-19, respectively, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 24-15. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Baggage. Parcels, bags, packages, suitcases and all other items which are hauled in connection with the transportation of a for-hire passenger. 
    Company. Wherever used in this chapter the term company shall mean any person, firm, partnership, corporation, association or other organization owning or operating or proposing to operate a taxicab business or shuttle business. 
    Cruising. The driving of a taxicab on the streets, alleys or public places of the city in search of or in solicitation of prospective passengers for hire. 
    Exclusive use of taxicab. The sole use of a taxicab by a passenger at the passenger's request. 
    Holder. A company to whom a certificate of public convenience and necessity has been issued. 
    Limousine. A multipassenger nonmetered "stretched" vehicle carrying passengers for hire and operated by a taxidriver. 
    Luxury sedan. A Luxury sedan vehicle-for-hire shall provide the transportation of persons limited to a luxury sedan; and shall be leased, rented or charged upon a minimum time period of one (1) hour; and with the fare determined on an hourly basis and not by a meter or mileage for the use of the vehicle; and pre-arranged or arranged through a third party. A "luxury sedan" shall further be identified as being recognized by the industry as a full-sized luxury sedan, such as a Lincoln or Cadillac and seating five (5) passengers or less excluding the driver. 
    Meter rates. The rates according to a taximeter installed and operated in a taxicab. 
    Rate card. A card to be displayed in each taxicab showing the rates of fare in force. 
    Ride sharing. The practice by taxicab companies and drivers of improving vehicle efficiency by combining passenger trips between the same general area. 
    Shuttle. A motor vehicle regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire which has the word "shuttle" prominently displayed on both sides and which may make intermediate stops and pickup additional passengers at any place and time. 
    Taxicab. A motor vehicle regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire, and not operated on a fixed route or as a "shuttle" or limousine. 
    Taxicab advisory board. The official board composed of the chief of police, the director of public works, the director of administration, or designated deputies thereof, and two (2) members appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council according to state law, empowered to execute the authority described herein. 
    Taxicab stand. A place alongside a street, or elsewhere, which has been designated and assigned as a space for taxicabs and shuttles to park while waiting for passengers. 
    Taxidriver. The individual driving a taxicab, shuttle or limousine whether as owner, employee, lessee or lessor of the vehicle. 
    Taximeter. A meter instrument or device attached to a taxicab which records the fare based upon the distance and the travel and waiting time. 
    Waiting time. The time when a taxicab is not in motion from the time of acceptance of a passenger to the time of discharge, excluding however, any time that the taxicab is not in motion due to any cause other than the request, acts or fault of a passenger. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 1, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 3826, § 1, 3-7-89; Ord. No. 4186, 6-5-2001) 
Sec. 24-16. - Vehicle registration required. 
    The owner of every motor vehicle operated for the transportation of passengers for hire in the city shall, before causing or permitting the same to be so operated, register such motor vehicle with the city clerk in the name of the owner, giving the make type, motor number and number of license tag for that year of such motor vehicle and shall reregister such motor vehicle with the city clerk annually. The city clerk shall keep such registration in a book kept for that purpose and shall assign a number to each motor vehicle so registered. 
(Code 1962, § 24-23; Ord. No. 3826, § 5, 3-7-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-27-139. 
Sec. 24-17. - Display of registration number, name of company. 
    Every registrant shall cause to be painted or stenciled on the front doors of said vehicle in numerals at least four (4) inches in height the registration number assigned to him as provided by section 24-16. The name of the taxicab company shall be painted or stenciled on the front doors of such vehicles in letters at least three (3) inches in height. All taxicab vehicles shall be equipped with toplights and the same shall be operating at all times while occupied by a licensed taxicab driver. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, operate or cause to be driven or operated any such motor vehicle in the city until the same shall have been registered and the above specified numerals and letters stenciled thereon. 
    Luxury sedans shall display their trade name on the front license plate of the vehicle-for-hire and the approved city vehicle registration number shall be on the front and rear bumpers. 
(Code 1962, § 24-24; Ord. No. 3826, § 6, 3-7-89; Ord. No. 3908, § 1, 5-7-91; Ord. No. 4186, 6-5-2001) 
Sec. 24-18. - Taxicab advisory board created; duties. 
    There is hereby created a taxicab advisory board (hereinafter sometimes referred to as "board") composed of the chief of police, the director of public works, the director of administration, or their officially designated deputies and two (2) members appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council according to state law. The two (2) appointed members shall serve four-year terms with the initial appointments being made for two (2) and four (4) years respectively. The board shall hold hearings on applications of those who seek a certificate of public convenience and necessity for operation of taxicabs and shuttles and shall make recommendations to the city council concerning issuance of such certificates. 
    In making its recommendations, the board shall consider: The number of taxicabs and shuttles in operation, whether existing transportation facilities are adequate, the effect of increased service on traffic conditions, the experience and responsibleness of the applicant and the condition of the applicant's equipment. The board shall cause all vehicles to be periodically inspected as to their physical condition and shall cause complaints regarding condition and operation to be investigated. The board shall, from time to time, report to the city council the number of taxicabs, limousines and shuttles required for the public convenience and necessity. The board shall approve color schemes for holders. The board shall perform other duties as set forth hereinbelow. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 2, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 3809, § 1, 7-19-88) 
Editor's note- Section 20 of Ord. No. 3801, adopted Apr. 5, 1988, repealed former §§ 24-18 and 24-19, which sections pertained to registration fee and liability insurance and derived from Code 1962, §§ 24-25, 24-26; and Ord. No. 3609, § 1, adopted Aug. 4, 1981. 
Sec. 24-19. - Ride sharing. 
    It shall be the public policy to encourage and permit ride sharing to increase vehicle efficiency and to reduce the costs of operations. In cases where the passenger specifically requests the sole use of the taxicab, a fare applicable to the exclusive use of the taxicab may be charged. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 17, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 3908, § 4, 5-7-91) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 24-18. 
Sec. 24-20. - Transfer of ownership of taxicab. 
    If a taxicab registered as required by section 24-16 of this chapter shall be sold, hired or otherwise transferred, the registration of such taxicab shall automatically be cancelled without notice and the taxicab may not thereafter be driven or operated in the city for the transportation of passengers for hire until the new owner, lessee, bailee or transferee shall reregister the taxicab in his name as such new owner, lessee, bailee or transferee and furnish the city clerk either with proper endorsement to existing insurance policies showing a continuance of such insurance in the name of the new owner, lessee, bailee or transferee or with new insurance policies as required by section 24-19 of this chapter. 
(Code 1962, § 24-27) 
Sec. 24-21. - Insurance. 
    Each company, person, firm, corporation or partnership operating a taxicab, limousine, shuttle or luxury sedan business in or over the streets of the city shall file with the city clerk a liability insurance policy executed by an insurance or surety company, authorized to do business in the state, in the minimum amount of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) combined single-limit coverage for bodily injury and property damage with uninsured motorist coverage of not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the death or injury to any one (1) person subject to said limit for one (1) person, twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) total liability for any one (1) accident and five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for property damage. 
    The insurance herein required shall be maintained so long as such motor vehicle is being so operated and a certificate of insurance shall be delivered to the city clerk prior to the expiration of the then existing insurance. If the insurance on such motor vehicle is canceled, permitted to lapse or, for any reason, is not maintained, or if the certificate of insurance is not delivered to the city clerk as herein required, the registration of such vehicle shall automatically be canceled, without notice. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 13, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 3801, § 3, 3-7-89; Ord. No. 4186, 6-5-2001) 
Editor's note- Section 20 of Ord. No. 3801, adopted Apr. 5, 1988, repealed former §§ 24-21-24-24, which pertained to driver's permits and derived from Code 1962, §§ 24-28-24-30 and 24-33, respectively. 
Sec. 24-22. - Refusal to answer calls or render service prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for a driver whose vehicle is not presently engaged to refuse, without good cause, transportation to anyone legitimately entitled to such. It shall be unlawful for any holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity to refuse to accept a call anywhere in the city at anytime when such holder has available vehicles or to refuse to render overall service to any person desiring to use his vehicle. Any person who operates a vehicle service regulated by this Ordinance shall answer all calls received by him for services inside the corporate limits of the city as soon as he can do so and, if such services cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, he shall then notify the prospective passengers how long it will be before the call can be answered and give the reason therefor. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 14, 4-5-88) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 24-21. 
Sec. 24-23. - Solicitation, acceptance and discharge of passengers generally. 
(a)  No taxidriver shall personally solicit passengers for a taxicab, limousine or shuttle except when sitting in the driver's compartment of such vehicle or while standing immediately adjacent to the side thereof. The taxidriver shall remain in the driver's compartment or immediately adjacent to his vehicle at all times when such vehicle is upon the public street, except that, when necessary a driver may be absent from his vehicle for not more than sixty (60) consecutive minutes. Nothing herein shall be held to prohibit any taxidriver from alighting to the street or sidewalk for the purpose of assisting passengers into or out of such vehicle. 
(b)  No taxidriver shall solicit patronage in a loud or annoying tone of voice or by sign or in any manner that annoys any person or obstructs the movement of any person nor shall follow any person for the purpose of soliciting patronage. 
(c)  Taxidrivers shall not receive or discharge passengers in the roadway, but shall pull up to the right-hand sidewalk side of the road and there receive or discharge passengers, except upon one-way streets where passengers may be discharged at either the right or left sidewalk, or side of the roadway in the absence of a sidewalk. 
(d)  No taxidriver, owner, or operator shall solicit passengers at the terminal of any intracity carrier, nor at any intermediate points along any established route or any intracity carrier. 
(e)  No taxidriver shall permit more persons to be carried in a vehicle than the designed seating capacity thereof. A child in arms shall not be counted as a passenger. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 16, 4-5-88) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 24-21. 
Sec. 24-24. - Taxidriver's permit-Required; application qualifications; investigations; examinations; appeals; contents; display. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall drive a taxicab, limousine, shuttle or luxury sedan on the street of the city without first having obtained a taxi driver's permit from the city clerk. 
(b)  Contents of application. Application for a taxidriver's permit required by this section shall be made to the city clerk, on forms provided by the city and such applications shall be verified under oath and contain the following: 
(1)  The name, age, sex, weight, height, color of eyes and hair, residence address; 
(2)  The experience of the applicant in driving automobiles, transporting passengers, and the nature of his or her former employments; 
(3)  The names and addresses of two (2) reputable adult citizens who have known the applicant for a period of at least one (1) year, who shall vouch for the general good character of the applicant; 
(4)  Whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony, a misdemeanor or municipal ordinance violation in any court, giving particulars of each conviction, if any; 
(5)  An examination by a reputable physician of the city, which examination shall include: 
a.  Heart action, evidence of fainting attacks and epilepsy; 
b.  Evidence of narcotic or alcoholic addiction; 
c.  Vision to meet the standards of a commercial driver's license; 
d.  Hearing to meet the standards of a commercial driver's license; and 
e.  Any person who now holds a permit to drive a taxicab, limousine or shuttle in the city who does not meet the physical requirements set forth herein, in the discretion of the taxicab advisory board, may be recommended for a permit provided that, in the opinion of the board his or her experience will justify an exception and that he or she will not as a taxidriver endanger the life, property, or welfare of the persons in the city. 
(c)  Qualifications . In order to be qualified to receive a taxi driver's permit under the provisions of this section, an applicant must be at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(d)  Investigation and examination of applicant; issuance or denial. 
(1)  The taxicab advisory board shall cause an investigation to be made of the facts set forth in the application as required by this section and shall not recommend the issuance of a license to any person whose general reputation for integrity and responsibility or whose previous record as a law violator is such as to render the applicant unfit for such occupation, or who is not physically fit to drive or operate a taxicab, limousine or shuttle in the city. 
(2)  The board shall also cause each applicant for a taxidriver's permit to be examined as to his or her knowledge of the provisions of this ordinance [article] and the traffic regulations and geography of the city, and if the applicant fails to show a reasonable knowledge of such matters, he or she shall not be recommended for driver's permit. 
(3)  If, upon due inquiry, the board is satisfied as to the qualifications of the applicant the board shall recommend to the city council the granting of a permit. 
(e)  Contents, display. The taxidriver's permit issued under the provisions of this section shall contain a two-inch by two-inch head photograph of the operator, to be furnished by the applicant, and shall be displayed in a prominent place on the inside of the taxicab, limousine or shuttle in such a way that it shall be immediately visible to passengers therein. The permit shall have impressed on the face thereof the seal of the city, affixed by the city clerk, in such a manner that a portion of both photograph and permit shall be covered by the seal. 
(f)  Term, renewal. The taxidriver's permit required by this section shall be in force and effect for a period of one (1) year from the date of issuance and shall be renewed annually. 
(g)  Fees. A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) each shall be charged to each person obtaining a permit and fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each badge. An annual fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for renewal of the permit is required. 
(h)  Suspension or revocation; appeal. 
(1)  The board may suspend or revoke a taxidriver's permit issued under this section for a taxidriver's failing or refusing to comply with any provision of Ordinance No. 3801; being convicted of any crime of moral turpitude by any municipality, state or the federal government; or being found guilty of any of the following offenses: 
a.  Driving a vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. 
b.  Disturbing the peace while operating a taxicab, limousine or shuttle. 
c.  Reckless driving or violating the speed limit laws of the city or state. 
d.  Knowingly transporting intoxicating liquor. 
e.  Carrying concealed weapons in violation of the law. 
f.  Knowingly transporting persons for the purpose of gambling or prostitution. 
g.  Knowingly driving his taxicab, limousine or shuttle in a mechanically unsafe condition. 
h.  Contributing to the delinquency of a minor. 
i.  Violating the controlled substances laws of any municipality, any state or of the federal government. 
(2)  Appeal. After such suspension or revocation, the person may appeal to the state courts. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 11, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 4186, 6-5-2001; Ord. No. 4404, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 24-21. 
Cross reference- Denial of driver permit for conviction of felony, § 24-56. 
State Law reference- Driver's permit requirements, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-27-131; suspension, revocation of drivers' permit, Miss. Code 1972, § 21-27-137. 
Sec. 24-25. - Same-Revocation for discontinuing driving. 
    Any person who shall discontinue the driving or operation of such taxicab shall, within thirty (30) days after such discontinuance, return the badge and permit to the city clerk and treasurer and his permit shall thereupon be automatically revoked. 
(Code 1962, § 24-34) 
Sec. 24-26. - Badge to be worn; nontransferable. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any taxicab, limousine, shuttle, or luxury sedan in the city to operate a vehicle without having displayed at all times a city-issued metallic badge containing a number exclusive to that particular taxi driver. It shall be unlawful for the taxi driver to transfer such badge to any other person or for any person to use the badge of another while driving or operating a motor vehicle for hire on the streets of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 12, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 4186, 6-5-2001) 
Editor's note- Section 20 of Ord. No. 3801, adopted Apr. 5, 1988, repealed former §§ 24-26 and 24-27, which pertained to drivers' badges and fees for drivers' badges and permits, and derived from Code 1962, §§ 24-31, 24-32, and Ord. No. 3610, § 1, adopted Aug. 4, 1981. 
Sec. 24-27. - Central place of business to be maintained. 
    A holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall maintain a central place of business and keep the same open twenty-four (24) hours a day for the purpose of receiving calls and dispatching vehicles. However, for Christmas and Thanksgiving holidays, the taxicab advisory board, under rules, regulations and stipulations imposed by it, may permit any certificate holder to suspend any or all operations on either or both Christmas and Thanksgiving holidays, as long as necessary and convenient service is maintained during such period. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on a public right-of-way and the same shall not be parked within a twenty-foot radius of the intersection of the right-of-way lines of any public streets. No disabled vehicle shall be parked for longer than forty-eight (48) hours at any such office location. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 10, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 3894, 10-16-90) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 24-26. 
Sec. 24-28. - Duties of driver involved in accident. 
    In case of an accident the operator of any taxicab or other vehicle as aforesaid, shall immediately stop, give his name, his number, the name of the owner of the car, and shall make report thereof to the police department of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 24-35) 
Sec. 24-29. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 24-29 was repealed by § 20 of Ord. No. 3801, adopted April 5, 1988. Such former section pertained to the prohibition on exceeding seating capacity and derived from Code 1962, § 24-37. 
Sec. 24-30. - Disposition of property left in taxicabs. 
    Whenever any package, article of baggage or goods of any kind shall be left in any taxicab or in the custody of the driver of any such vehicle, such driver shall, upon the discovery of such package or article, forthwith deliver the same to the company's main office and into the hands of the management in charge thereof and receive from such manager a receipt for same, unless such package or article shall be sooner delivered to the owner thereof on the order of such owner. 
(Code 1962, § 24-38) 
Sec. 24-31. - Deceiving passengers prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of any taxicab to deceive, misinform or mislead any passenger who may ride or desire to ride in such vehicle as to the passenger's destination or the price to be charged for conveying such passenger. 
(Code 1962, § 24-39) 
Sec. 24-32. - Duty to follow shortest route. 
    Any taxicab driver employed to transport passengers to a definite point shall take the shortest and most direct route possible that will carry the passenger to his destination safely and expeditiously. 
(Code 1962, § 24-40) 
Secs. 24-33-24-42. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RATES AND FARES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3801, adopted Apr. 5, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 18, 19 and 15 as §§ 29-43-29-45, respectively, was at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 24-43. - Rates of fare. 
    The fares indicated by taximeters to be charged by holders of certificates of convenience and necessity shall be as follows: 
(1)  For the first one-half (1/2) mile, a fare of three dollars ($3.00). 
(2)  For each and every one-tenth ( 1 / 10 ) mile fraction after first one-half (1/2) mile, a fare of twenty-five cents ($0.25). 
(3)  For each hour of waiting time, a fare of twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(4)  For second passenger going to the same destination, a fare of one dollar ($1.00) each. 
(5)  For each passenger over two (2) going to the same destination, a fare of one dollar ($1.00) each. 
(6)  For each piece of baggage, a fee of fifty cents ($0.50). 
    A person, company or holder who shall charge a passenger in excess of the rate of fare provided by this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 18, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 3846, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 3861, § 1, 4-17-90; Ord. No. 3900, § 1, 12-18-90; Ord. No. 3908, § 2, 5-7-91; Ord. No. 4249, § 1, 7-6-2004; Ord. No. 4461, § 1, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 24-44. - Taximeter; fares and charges. 
(a)  Taxicabs to be equipped with taximeters. After May 1, 1991, all taxicabs operating within the city shall be equipped with taximeters. No such vehicle shall be permitted to operate after such date, unless the same is equipped with a standard taximeter of such type, style and design as may be approved by the taxicab advisory board. It shall be the duty of every holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity for taxicab service to keep such taximeter in perfect condition so that such taximeter will at all times correctly and accurately indicate the legal charges for the distance traveled and waiting time. 
(b)  Placement of taximeter and illumination of dial. Every taximeter hereafter placed on a taxicab to be operated within the city shall be so arranged that the dial thereof is in plain view of the passenger while riding in such vehicle. Each taximeter shall be equipped with an illuminated dial as to enable the passenger or passengers engaging and using such taxicab to read the figure and fares indicated thereon. 
(c)  Rates of fares. No person, firm or corporation now licensed by the city as a taxicab business or a company hereafter granted a certificate of convenience and necessity for such operation shall fix or charge a greater or lower fare than those established by the city council effective May 1, 1991. 
    No additional charge shall be made for the second passenger on any trip going to the same destination but an additional fifty cents ($0.50) shall be added for each passenger over two (2). For each piece of baggage over three (3) pieces there may be an additional charge of fifty cents ($0.50) 
    No charge shall be made for time lost or for inefficiency or breakdown of the taxicab or for time consumed by premature response to a call. The charges fixed above shall cover all luggage transported. 
(d)  Charges to be fixed by taximeter only. All charges for transportation of passengers in taxicabs operated in the city, except when hired on a per-hour basis or under private long-term contract, must be based on the charges indicated on such taximeters. No owner, taxidriver or operator of any taxicab shall charge any passenger or passengers any sum in excess of or less than the sum indicated on such taximeter, however, any voluntary discounts to the elderly and handicapped shall be posted in a prominent place on the inside of the taxicab so as to be immediately visible to passengers therein. 
(e)  Display of taximeter flag. Taximeters installed under this section shall indicate the charge by means of legible figures which are electronically lighted each time the taximeter flag is thrown from a nonearning or an earning position. At all times, while the taxicab is engaged, the flag of the taximeter shall be thrown into position to register charges for mileage or into position to register charges for waiting time. It shall be unlawful for any taxidriver while carrying passengers to display the flag attached to the taximeter in such a position as to denote that such vehicle is unemployed or to fail to throw the flag of the taximeter to a position indicating that such vehicle is employed at the termination of each and every service. The flag shall not be changed to the non-earning position until after the fare is paid. 
(f)  Operation of taximeter when vehicle not employed. No taxidriver while transporting for hire shall display the taximeter flag in any position other than the position recording a fare, and no taxidriver, unless carrying passengers or parcels for hire, shall operate such vehicle unless the taximeter flag is in an upright position indicating that the cab is not engaged or hired. If the vehicle is occupied by more than one (1) passenger and they are not to be discharged at the same destination, the first passenger leaving the vehicle shall be chargeable for the amount of fare shown on the taximeter and before proceeding to transport the remaining passenger or passengers to his or their destination the flag shall again be placed in earning position so as to designate the beginning of a new and separate trip as to the remaining passenger or passengers in such taxicab and such process shall be repeated each time a passenger reaches his destination and alights from the vehicle so that the remaining passenger or passengers leaving the vehicle shall be chargeable with such fare appearing upon the taximeter upon leaving the taxicab. 
(g)  Tampering with taximeter. Tampering with a taximeter so as to cause an inaccurate reading of the fare shall be a misdemeanor and subject any holder or taxidriver to revocation, respectively, of the certificate or permit. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 19, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 3908, § 3, 5-7-91) 
Sec. 24-45. - Refusal to pay fare prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any taxicab, limousine or shuttle service. It shall be unlawful for any person to hire any such vehicle with the intent to defraud the taxidriver thereof of the value of such service. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 15, 4-5-88)
