Sec. 24-47. - Maximum fares established. 
(a)  Zone fares. The zone fares shall be as follows: 
    Zone 1 ..... $1.50 
    Zone 2 ..... 1.75 
    Zone 3 ..... 2.00 
    Zone 4 ..... 2.50 
    Zone 5 ..... 3.00 
    Zone 6 ..... 3.50 
    Zone 7 ..... 4.00 
    Zone 8 ..... 4.50 
    Zone 9 ..... 4.75 
    Zone 10 ..... 5.00 
    Zone 11 ..... 5.25 
(b)  Maximum fares. The maximum fare for any trip shall be determined by the following: 
(1)  For each trip which crosses both transportation routes constituting a pair, the fare shall not exceed a sum determined by adding the zone fare for the zone of origination of the trip to the zone fare for the zone of destination of the trip. The fact that a trip may cross more than one (1) pair shall not increase the fare. 
(2)  For each trip between any point which is south of 12th Street and west of 35th Avenue and any point which is north of 12th Street and east of 26th Avenue, whether or not both transportation routes constituting a pair are crossed, the fare shall not exceed a sum determined by adding the zone fare for the zone of origination of the trip to the zone fare for the zone of destination of the trip. 
(3)  For each trip between any point which is south of 12th Street and west of 35th Avenue and any point which is north of 40th Street and west of 26th Avenue and which does not cross both transportation routes constituting a pair, the fare shall not exceed a sum determined by taking the zone fare for the zone of origination of the trip or the zone fare for the zone of destination of the trip, whichever is larger, and adding thereto the sum of one dollar ($1.00). 
(4)  For each trip between any point which is south of either "E" Street or St. Andrew Street and east of 27th Avenue and any point which is west of 31st Avenue and north of the main line of the Southern Railroad, the fare shall not exceed a sum determined by adding the zone fare for the zone of origination of the trip to the zone fare for the zone of destination of the trip. 
(5)  For each trip between any point which is south of the main line of the Southern Railroad and east of 27th Avenue and any point which is west of 35th Avenue and north of the main line of the Southern Railroad, the fare shall not exceed a sum determined by adding the zone fare for the zone of origination of the trip to the zone fare for the zone of destination of the trip. 
(6)  For all trips not hereinbefore described, the fare shall not exceed the zone fare for the zone of origination of the trip or the zone fare for the zone of destination of the trip, whichever is higher. 
(7)  In addition to the charge for the first passenger, fifty cents ($0.50) shall be charged for each additional passenger on any trip going to the same destination. For each passenger for whom any fare is charged, one (1) child under five (5) years of age can ride without additional charge, but otherwise each child shall be considered a passenger. 
(8)  For each additional stop within two (2) blocks of direct route, there may be an additional charge of fifty cents ($0.50), and for all over one (1) piece of baggage there may be an additional charge of fifty cents ($0.50). 
(9)  For each trip between any point within the city of Meridian and the Meridian Naval Air Station the fare shall be five dollars ($5.00) per passenger with a ten dollar ($10.00) minimum charge and no additional charge shall be made for baggage. 
(c)  Prohibited practices. The foregoing rates are the maximum rates authorized to be charged for regular taxicab service. It shall be unlawful for the operators of such taxicabs which charge the foregoing rates to display the words "Shuttle," "Shuttle Service" or words of similar import anywhere on the taxi vehicle. 
(d)  Shuttle service. There is hereby established a separate class of public transportation service to be known as "Shuttle" service and each vehicle engaged in that service shall have the word "Shuttle" prominently displayed on both sides. Shuttle service vehicles may make intermediate stops and pick up additional passengers at any time. Maximum rates for each passenger for shuttle service within the city shall be fifty cents ($0.50) less than the maximum rates provided herein for a similar trip by regular taxicab service. The maximum rate for shuttle service between the Naval Air Station and any point within the city (including Key Field) shall be five dollars ($5.00) per person. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle bearing the word "Shuttle" to charge more than the shuttle rates provided in this paragraph. 
(Code 1962, § 24-47; Ord. No. 3208, § 1, 9-17-63; Ord. No. 3369, § 1, 11-18-70; Ord. No. 3454, § 1, 12-19-73; Ord. No. 3461, § 1, 4-17-74; Ord. No. 3539, § 2, 6-6-78; Ord. No. 3564, § 2, 1-2-80; Ord. No. 3615, § 1, 9-1-81; Ord. No. 3655, § 1, 12-7-82; Ord. No. 3826, § 7, 3-7-89) 
Sec. 24-48. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 5 of Ord. No. 3908, adopted May 7, 1991, repealed former § 24-48, which pertained to the posting of the map of zones and rates of fare, and derived from Code 1962, § 24-48, and Ord. No. 3208, § 1, adopted Sept. 17, 1963. 
Sec. 24-49. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 24-49, "Excess charges prohibited," was repealed by Ord. No. 3801, § 20, adopted April 5, 1988. Such former section derived from Code 1962, § 24-49. 
Secs. 24-50-24-52. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3801, adopted April 5, 1988, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 3-9 as §§ 24-53-24-59, comprising a new Div. 3, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 24-53. - Required; contents of application. 
(a)  No person, firm, association, corporation or company shall operate a taxicab or shuttle owned or controlled by it on the streets of the city without first having obtained a certificate of public convenience and necessity from the city. 
(b)  Any application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be sworn to and include: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers; 
(3)  The financial status of the applicant, including the amounts of all unpaid judgments against the applicant and the nature of the transactions or actions giving rise to such judgments; 
(4)  The number of taxicabs and shuttles the applicant desires to operate; 
(5)  Make, model, year, body type, and physical condition of all vehicles to be operated as taxicabs or shuttles; 
(6)  The color scheme to be used to designate the taxicab or shuttle of the applicant; and 
(7)  Such further information as the board may require. 
(c)  A certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be issued only to an applicant operating or proposing to operate five (5) or more shuttles and taxicabs. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 3, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 3826, § 2, 3-7-89) 
Sec. 24-54. - Hearing. 
    Upon the filing of an application with the city clerk for a certificate of public convenience and necessity, the application shall be immediately referred to the taxicab advisory board which shall fix a time and place for a public hearing thereon. Notice of such hearing by United States Postal Service shall be given to the applicant and to all companies who then hold a certificate of public convenience and necessity and to the general public by publication of a notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least fifteen (15) days before the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 4, 4-5-88) 
Sec. 24-55. - Investigation and consideration of application; issuance of denial. 
    Upon completion of the hearing provided for in section 24-54, the taxicab advisory board shall make the following findings: 
(1)  Whether further taxicab or shuttle service in the city is required by public convenience and necessity, and 
(2)  Whether the applicant is fit, able, and otherwise qualified to perform such public transportation and to conform with the provisions of this article. 
    In making these findings, the taxicab advisory board shall take into consideration the number of taxicabs and shuttles in operation, whether existing transportation facilities are adequate, the effect of increased service on traffic condition, the experience and responsibleness of the applicant, and the condition of the applicant's equipment. Such findings shall be reported to the city council within a period of ten (10) working days from the hearing, with the recommendation of the board whether the certificate should be granted or not. Such findings shall be reviewed by the city council at its next scheduled regular meeting and the certificate issued or denied at such meeting. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 5, 4-5-88) 
Sec. 24-56. - Denial of certificate and driver permit for conviction of felony. 
    No person may be a holder or driver of a taxicab, limousine or shuttle who, within the past five (5) years immediately proceeding the filing of an application for certificate or driver permit, shall have been convicted of a felony whether by any state or federal government. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 6, 4-5-88) 
Cross reference- Drivers' permit required, § 24-24. 
Sec. 24-57. - Annual franchise fee. 
    No certificate required by this article shall be issued or continued in effect unless the holder thereof has paid an annual franchise fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00). Such fee shall become due and payable on the first day of April of each year, and shall be in addition to any license fees or charges established elsewhere herein, or by proper authority and applicable to the holder or the vehicle under its operation and control. The purpose of this franchise fee is not to raise revenue, but to defray expenses incurred in enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 7, 4-5-88) 
Sec. 24-58. - Not transferable. 
    No certificate of public convenience and necessity required by this article may be transferred, sold, encumbered, or assigned. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 8, 4-5-88) 
Sec. 24-59. - Suspension and revocation; hearing and appeal. 
(a)  A certificate issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked or suspended by the taxicab advisory board if the holder thereof has: 
(1)  Violated any of the provisions of Ordinance No. 3801; 
(2)  Failed to correct deficiencies in equipment and operations found to exist after investigation by the board; 
(3)  Discontinued operations for more than thirty (30) days; 
(4)  Violated any provisions of the City Code or laws of the United States, or of the state, the violation of which reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the holder to offer public transportation; or 
(5)  Refused to answer a call or provide overall service as provided in section 24-22. 
(b)  Prior to suspension or revocation, the holder shall be given notice of the proposed action to be taken and shall be given an opportunity to be heard before the board, and shall have the right of appeal as provided by the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 3801, § 9, 4-5-88) 
Sec. 24-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AMBULANCES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency medical services, Miss. Code 1972, §§ 41-59-1-41-59-61; state license and permit required, § 41-59-9; licensee to conform with local laws and regulations, § 41-59-21. 

Sec. 24-61. - License-Required. 
    No person shall operate an ambulance upon the streets of the city without first having made application for and obtained a license to operate such service, and having paid all license fees and privilege taxes that might be required from time to time by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1962, § 24-50; Ord. No. 3292, § 1, 3-7-67) 
Sec. 24-62. - Same-Application. 
    Applications for licenses under this article shall be made upon blank forms prepared by the city, addressed to the city tax collector, and shall contain: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner of the ambulance. 
(2)  The description of the ambulance, including the make, model, year of manufacture, state license number for the current year, motor and chassis numbers, the length of time the ambulance has been in use, and a list of the emergency or first aid equipment regularly carried on such ambulance. 
(3)  The location and description of the place or places from which it is intended to operate. 
(4)  Such other information as the tax collector shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether the terms of this article have been complied with. 
(Code 1962, § 24-51; Ord. No. 3292, § 2, 3-7-67) 
Sec. 24-63. - Same-Investigation of application; prerequisites to issuance. 
    Within five (5) days after receipt of an application as provided for in this article, the tax collector shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and of his proposed operation. The license officer shall issue a license hereunder when he finds: 
(1)  Public convenience and necessity. That the public convenience and necessity require the proposed ambulance service of which application has been submitted. In making such determination, the tax collector shall consider: 
a.  Whether the public is, at the time, adequately served. 
b.  The financial responsibility of the applicant. 
c.  The number, kind and type of equipment; provided, however, that, no application will be approved unless the applicant has two (2) or more ambulances which were designed and manufactured for ambulance purposes. 
d.  The applicant will provide twenty-four-hour service. 
e.  Such other facts as the tax collector shall consider relevant. 
(2)  Requirements for owners, operators. That the owner and operators of such ambulances meet the following requirements: 
a.  Above the age of twenty-one (21) years and morally fit. 
b.  Sound physique and no infirmity of body or mind which might render him unfit for the sole operation of the ambulance. 
c.  Able to speak, read and write the English language. 
d.  Is clean of dress and person and not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors or narcotics. 
e.  Has successfully completed the American National Red Cross standard first aid course or its equivalent. 
(3)  Qualifications of attendants. Attendants, who are not drivers, shall possess all of the qualifications of operators except they shall be at least seventeen (17) years of age. 
(4)  Insurance. That insurance policies as required by this article have been procured. 
(5)  Fitness of applicants, attendants. That the applicant and all attendants and drivers are fit and proper persons to conduct or work in the proposed business. 
(Code 1962, § 24-52; Ord. No. 3292, § 3, 3-7-67; Ord. No. 3332, § 1, 2-10-69) 
Sec. 24-64. - Determination of suitability of vehicles. 
    In determining whether or not the vehicles designated in the application hereunder are suitable from the standpoint of health and sanitation for the conduct of an ambulance business, the tax collector shall consider whether or not such vehicles are equipped for the administering of oxygen and whether such vehicles can accommodate the giving of blood transfusions and medications by intravenous drips. He shall also consider whether such ambulances are of sufficient size to permit the seating of an attendant alongside an injured, disabled or ill person being transported therein, and whether or not the cots or beds provided for such injured, disabled or ill persons are securely anchored to such ambulances. 
(Code 1962, § 24-53; Ord. No. 3292, § 4, 3-7-67) 
Sec. 24-65. - Insurance requirements. 
    The applicant hereunder shall file with the tax collector proof that each and every ambulance owned, operated or leased by the applicant is covered with an ambulance emergency insurance policy providing insurance coverage for injury to or death of persons and acts or events resulting from any cause which the owner or operator of said vehicle would be liable on account of any liability imposed upon him by law regardless of whether the ambulance was being driven by the owner, his agent or lessee, and as against damage to the property of another including personal property under like circumstances, which insurance policy shall provide minimum coverage of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any individual personal injury or death and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for personal injury or death occurring in any one (1) accident as well as twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) property damage. Every insurance policy required hereunder shall extend for the period to be covered by the license applied for and such policies shall require the insurer to give no less days notice in writing to the city than it is required by the terms of such policy to give to the assured before any cancellation or termination thereof earlier than its expiration date. The cancellation or other termination of such policy shall automatically revoke and terminate the licenses issued for the ambulances covered by such policy unless another insurance policy complying with the provisions of this section shall be provided and be in effect at the time of such cancellation or termination. 
(Code 1962, § 24-54; Ord. No. 3292, § 5, 3-7-67; Ord. No. 3444, § 1, 8-22-73) 
Sec. 24-66. - Information to be furnished regarding employees. 
(a)  At the time of making application for license as provided hereunder the applicant shall furnish to the tax collector the following information regarding all persons who will be engaged in the operation, including attendants, of such ambulance: 
(1)  Full name, present place of residence, places of residence for five (5) years previous to moving to its present address. 
(2)  Age, marital status, height, color of eyes and hair. 
(3)  Whether he has ever been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor. 
(4)  Whether he was previously licensed as a driver, chauffeur or attendant, and, if so, where and when and whether his license has ever been revoked or suspended and for what cause. 
(b)  If a licensee employs a new or additional operator or attendant for any ambulance licensed under this article during the period that such license is in effect, such licensee shall supply the information regarding such new operator or attendant to the tax collector as is provided in this section. 
(c)  If any licensee permits an ambulance to be operated or attended by any person other than as to whom such information has previously been furnished to the tax collector, he shall be subjected to having such license forfeited. 
(Code 1962, § 24-55; Ord. No. 3292, § 6, 3-7-67) 
Sec. 24-67. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. Furthermore, any person holding a license under this article convicted of violating any provision hereof shall have such license immediately forfeited. 
(Code 1962, § 24-56; Ord. No. 3292, § 7, 3-7-67) 
Secs. 24-68-24-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WRECKER SERVICES 

Sec. 24-76. - Definitions. 
    City means the City of Meridian, Mississippi. 
    The city limits of Meridian shall be a wrecker zone. 
    City official means the chief of police or other employee designated by him/her for the purpose of the administration of this policy. 
    Owner or vehicle operator means owner or operator of a motor vehicle. 
    A non-preference (rotation) wrecker service is called by the Meridian Police Department in those instances in which the owner or operator of a vehicle requires a tow or pick-up and has no preference as to who tows or picks up the vehicle, or is incapable of indicating a preference, or is not present to make a choice of wrecker service to call for a tow or pick-up, including those vehicles to be towed because of alleged parking violations. 
    Wrecker, for the purposes of this policy, means and includes all vehicles of one-ton capacity or more, having one (1) or more dual-wheel rear axles and used for hauling, towing, pushing or pulling any automobile or other vehicle of every kind, nature, and description, regardless of whether such vehicle is being hauled, pushed, pulled or may be self-propelled. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 1, 3-6-2012; Ord. No. 4453, § 1, 2-3-2015) 
Sec. 24-77. - Non-preference (rotation) wrecker service call list established. 
(a)  There is hereby established a non-preference (rotation) wrecker service call list to be maintained and kept on file at the Meridian Police Department and/or Central Dispatch. Any wrecker service desiring to be placed on the non-preference (rotation) call list must meet the following minimum standards, in addition to any other state or federal regulation, which may apply: 
(1)  Must provide twenty-four (24) hour-per-day wrecker service from a properly zoned location and must be licensed and permitted. 
(2)  Must provide a secure place of storage within five (5) miles of the city limits hauled by the wrecker service. A secure place of storage is considered one which meets the following minimum requirements. 
(3)  Area surrounded by a six-foot fence and capable of being locked to prevent casual access. 
(4)  The area must be capable of storing a minimum of twenty (20) vehicles. 
(5)  A wrecker service will notify dispatch at 601-484-6845 at any time their wrecker will be unavailable to respond to calls for a lengthy period of time due to vacation, sickness etc. 
(6)  When a wrecker is unable to respond, the next wrecker in the rotation list will be utilized. 
(7)  A wrecker service will be available twenty-four (24) hours a day seven (7) days a week. 
(8)  No wrecker service will "cover" (take calls) for another wrecker service. 
(9)  Two (2) or more wrecker companies will not share an impound yard. 
(10)  An on scene wrecker service may request assistance from another wrecker company. This request will be documented by dispatch and will not be dictated by the Meridian Police Department or 911. 
(11)  The closest wrecker will be utilized in extreme emergency situations. Such decisions will be made by the on scene officer. 
(12)  The owner will provide a photo copy of titles of each wrecker that will be utilized by his/her company. It will be placed on file at the police department and/or dispatch. All wreckers titled to the same person will carry the same name permanently marked on each door. 
(13)  No magnetic signs will be allowed. 
(14)  The owner of a wrecker service will provide a photo copy of the driver's license of any and all individuals utilized in the operation of said wrecker. 
(15)  Each wrecker is required to have broom, shovel, oil dry, and any other equipment as needed to clean and clear an accident scene. 
(16)  All wreckers will clean up their portion of a wreck scene. Failure to do this will result in their being called back to do so. Failure to clean up after a recall to the scene will result in removal from the rotation list. 
(17)  There will be no additional fee for the cleaning up of contaminated areas. 
(18)  A receipt with will be given to any person where money is received for services rendered through the Meridian Police Department for towing and/or storage. These receipts will be kept on file for a period of one (1) year and available for inspection by the Meridian Police Department upon request. 
(b)  All wrecker companies shall comply with the following procedures concerning service: 
(1)  No wrecker operator shall proceed to the scene of an accident without being requested to do so by the Meridian Police Department. 
(2)  No wrecker operator shall solicit business at the scene of an accident. 
(3)  No wrecker operator shall speed or drive recklessly or disobey any traffic control device, sign or signal while answering a call, nor shall he approach the scene of an accident to begin towing or salvage operations, interfere with or impede the flow of traffic without approval of the officer on the scene. 
(4)  Authorization permits shall be considered personal to the holder thereof and shall be issued only to some definite legal entity which is operating an approved wrecker. The permits shall not be subject to lease or transfer to another in any manner. The holder of the permit shall not allow the exercise by another in any manner of the rights and privileges granted therein. Authorization permits are void if the business address or location of the facilities has changed, or if ownership changes. 
(5)  No wrecker company shall use the amber light in route to or when making a service or wrecker call. The use of the amber flashing or rotating light is authorized at the scene of an accident and when towing the vehicle from the scene, or when the operator has been specifically authorized by the department to do so in an emergency situation. 
(6)  Each wrecker company shall furnish the Meridian Police Department with one (1) telephone number to be used when requesting service during normal business hours and one (1) telephone number for after hours. Any change in the aforementioned telephone number shall be immediately transmitted to the Meridian Police Department. Call forwarding, which provides immediate contact with the owner or operator is permitted. However, answering services shall not be permitted. Two (2) or more wrecker companies shall not use the same telephone number. 
(7)  Each wrecker service shall provide twenty-four-hour service within the city limits of Meridian. 
(8)  A wrecker company shall not accept a call for service unless the operator has a wrecker immediately available to answer the call or perform the requested service. 
(9)  No wrecker operator shall be on the rotation list who has been convicted of a felony. 
(10)  No wrecker operator shall be on the rotation list who has been convicted of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude within five (5) years prior to applying for placement on the wrecker rotation list. 
(11)  No wrecker operator shall respond to a call if under the influence of alcoholic beverages or drugs. 
(12)  The wrecker company owner shall furnish the Meridian Police Department with a list of all drivers and their driver's license numbers. 
(13)  No person shall drive or be allowed to drive any rotation wrecker for hire unless such driver has a valid, properly endorsed Mississippi driver's license. 
(14)  Wreckers dispatched must arrive at the scene within twenty-five (25) minutes during normal business hours and within twenty-five (25) minutes after hours. If the time exceeds the time limit and the wrecker company has not notified the department of a valid reason for the delay, then the wrecker company shall be subject to cancellation of the call and suspension from the rotation list. 
(15)  The wrecker company will be responsible for cleaning up all debris which fell, leaked, or was caused by any vehicle which is being towed. Any wrecker company called in rotation which responds with a wrecker not registered with the city shall be denied the call and subject to suspension from the rotation list after an investigation by the chief of police or designee. Only one (1) wrecker company shall be called to an accident involving a single car. If any additional equipment or recovery vehicles are needed to adequately complete a tow (i.e., tractor-trailer rollovers or a difficult car recovery), the officer on the scene should use discretion in deciding what and whose additional equipment will be required. The severity of the situation and the estimated response time of the additional equipment will be considered by the officer on the scene who has the authority to decide these matters. 
(16)  When any police officer arrives at the scene of any accident or other emergency, and in the exercise of his or her discretion as a police officer believes that an emergency exists requiring the immediate service of a wrecker in order to protect the life, health, welfare, safety or property of the owner or occupants of the vehicle involved in the accident or emergency, or other vehicles parked or stopped upon the street at or near the scene of the accident or emergency, then the city may dispatch the closest available wrecker to the scene whether or not said wrecker company is on the rotational list. 
(17)  All special request or special equipment wreckers (large wreckers, cranes, etc.) will be logged on the special request wrecker log. 
(18)  If a wrecker company wishes to be unavailable for any length of time, they will, in writing, notify the Meridian Police Department of the reason they will be unavailable. All rotation calls missed during this time will be lost. Upon the wrecker company wanting to be placed back on the active rotation list, they will notify the Meridian Police Department in writing to be reactivated. 
(19)  Wrecker operators who fail to answer a call will lose the call. If two (2) calls are missed, an investigation will be initiated by the chief of police designee and suspension or removal of the wrecker company from the rotation list will be considered. 
(20)  Wrecker companies refusing to answer a call or who fail to respond promptly may be removed from the rotation list. 
(21)  The chief of police shall promulgate wrecker and storage rates. No wrecker company shall exceed these rates. Any requested change in rates shall be forwarded to the chief of police. 
(22)  The chief of police (or person he designates) shall remove from the rotation list any wrecker company whose tow rates are excessive. 
(23)  The vehicle owner/operator shall be responsible for payment of towing and related service charges. Payment shall be rendered prior to delivery or release of the vehicle unless this condition is waived by the wrecker company. 
(24)  Hold orders placed by Meridian Police officers on vehicles stored for any reason shall be honored by the wrecker company. When no hold order has been placed on the vehicle, the vehicle shall be released to the owner, operator or insurance company upon proof of ownership or authorized release. 
(c)  Suspension from wrecker rotation list. 
(1)  Failure to meet or maintain the minimum wrecker specifications and other requirements and regulations as outlined in this order may result in an indefinite suspension. 
(2)  An indefinite suspension of the wrecker company from the rotation list may result from other factors or actions. Such other considerations may include, but are not limited to, the following: 
a.  Flagrant, repeated or serious failure to cooperate with an officer at the scene of an accident; and 
b.  Charging exorbitant rates for services. 
(d)  Towing and storage fees and regulations. 
(1)  The maximum fees that may be charged, with the exception of special equipment wreckers, for the towing of motor vehicles and for the storage and, when specifically authorized by this section, the retrieval of such towed vehicles are as follows: 
a.  For the towing of a motor vehicle, the maximum fee shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); 
b.  For the storage of a towed motor vehicle, the maximum fee for each twenty-four-hour period of storage, or portion thereof, shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00); and 
c.  For the retrieval of a towed motor vehicle during hours other than 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, and 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m., Saturday and Sunday, the maximum fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to charge a towing fee, storage fee or retrieval fee that exceeds the fees established by subsection (a). 
(3)  If the owner and/or operator of a motor vehicle is present and capable of removing the vehicle before it is removed by a tow vehicle operator, the vehicle shall not be towed; provided, that in such an event, the owner and/or operator of the vehicle shall be liable for a reasonable fee, not to exceed one-half (1/2) of the regular towing fee, in lieu of towing, payable to the tow vehicle operator. This fee shall only apply if the tow truck is on scene and prepared to attach to the offending vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 2, 3-6-2012; Ord. No. 4453, § 2, 2-3-2015; Ord. No. 4455, § 1, 3-5-2015) 
Sec. 24-78. - Separate list maintained-Heavy-duty wrecker. 
    The chief of police, or his/her designee may implement a separate rotation call list to govern the calling of heavy-duty wreckers used to tow or pick up large commercial vehicles requiring a heavy-duty wrecker and to require the owner-operator to maintain adequate accessory equipment to effect damage-free recovery of wrecked and/or disabled vehicles, to be otherwise governed by the provisions and procedures of this policy. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 3, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-79. - Right to express preference as to wrecker. 
    Owners, vehicle operators, or passengers involved in an accident or situation may express their preference of a wrecker service and that wrecker service shall then be called by the Meridian Police Department, provided that the wrecker service specified can deliver the service in a similar fashion of a registered and permitted non-preference (rotation) wrecker service. An owner, vehicle operator, and/or passenger(s) taken into custody may express a preference as to wrecker service where they are verbally capable of requesting said wrecker. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 4, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-80. - Registration, permit prerequisite to operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own or operate any wrecker which is subject to a call for service by any city department or agency within the city limits unless such wrecker shall have been registered and such owner and operation shall have been issued a registration permit (privilege license). 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 5, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-81. - Application for registration permit. 
(a)  Any person, owner or operator of a wrecker desiring a registration permit to do business as a non-preference (rotation) wrecker service shall make application to the chief of police or his/her designee before beginning operation. The information required for such registration shall be: 
(1)  The name of the wrecker business. 
(2)  The wrecker's make, model, motor or vehicle identification number and license tag number for the current year. 
(3)  A certificate of ownership of such wrecker by the person requesting registration. 
(b)  Such application shall also be accompanied by a records check completed by the Meridian Police Department, consisting of the owner-operator's and/or driver's criminal history, if any. Any owner-operator or driver that is on parole or probation for any felony conviction or under indictment for any felony shall not be granted a registration permit and shall not operate or drive said wrecker or wreckers. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 6, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-82. - Liability insurance or bond prerequisite to operate; amount, conditions. 
(a)  The owner or operator of any wrecker to be used as a non-preference (rotation) wrecker shall, before operating the same, present to the chief of police, or his/her designee, a public liability insurance policy or policies or bonds written by an insurance or bonding company authorized to do business in the State of Mississippi for each wrecker operated on the non-preference (rotation) list; and there shall be an insurance policy or policies or bonds presented to the chief of police for coverage of property damage or loss to or from any vehicle while being towed or stored by the wrecker owner or operator. 
(b)  Such insurance policy, policies or bond shall be conditioned for the payment of any final judgment against said wrecker owner or operator for personal injury or property damage or loss resulting from or arising out of the use, maintenance, operation, or any related action of the wrecker owner or operator while towing or storing said vehicles, provided, however, that the amount of the public liability policy or bond required on any non-preference (rotation) wrecker shall in no case be less than seven hundred fifty thousand dollars ($750,000.00), combined single limit automobile liability coverage or insurance or bond of split limit liability automotive coverage of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for the death or injury of any one (1) person and subject to said limit for one (1) person; three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) total public liability for any one (1) accident; and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage for any one (1) accident; and any non-preference (rotation) owner or operator of a "light duty" and/or "medium duty" wrecker shall present evidence that insurance is in force that will provide recompense to the owner of a towed vehicle if the said vehicle is damaged or suffers property loss from it while in tow or in the storage facility of the wrecker's owner or operator; and in no case shall the insurance coverage be less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for each individual vehicle while in tow, with one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) deductible, and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) coverage for the combined number of vehicles placed in storage by the owner or operator through the non-preference (rotation) list. 
(c)  All insurance policies or bonds shall contain a provision or endorsement to the effect that the same shall not be canceled for any cause by either party thereto unless or until thirty (30) days' written notice thereof shall be given to the city clerk by registered mail, with a copy thereof mailed in the like manner to the chief of police of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 7, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-83. - Certificate of inspection prerequisite to issuance of registration permit. 
    Before a registration permit may be issued, the owner or operator of the wrecker shall have the wrecker inspected for property equipment and accessories. The storage yard shall be inspected by the chief of police or his/her designee to determine if it meets all the requirements of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 8, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-84. - Same-Required annually; duties of the police department. 
    Duties of the Meridian Police Department. It shall be the duty of the chief of police, or his/her designee from time to time to inspect the mechanical condition and other required equipment on all such wreckers and to inspect storage areas used by the owner or operator of such wrecker service. If any such equipment and/or area are defective, the chief of police or his/her designee will notify the owner or operator that the wreckers and the storage yard have been inspected and they will have thirty (30) days to make sure all problems have been corrected. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 9, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-85. - Operation of wrecker without proper registration, inspection and insurance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owners or operators to operate or cause to be operated such wreckers as a non-preference (rotation) wrecker without having all proper equipment, facilities, registration, inspection and insurance. This applies at first registration and at all other times such wrecker is doing business as a non-preference (rotation) wrecker service for the Meridian Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 10, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-86. - Records of registration permits, inspections, and insurance to be kept. 
    The chief of police or his/her designee shall keep a file for the recording of all registration permits, inspections and insurance policies which have been issued. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 11, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-87. - Transfer of registration permit. 
    No owner or operator with a non-preference (rotation) wrecker shall transfer such registration permit. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 12, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-88. - Suspension or revocation of registration permit. 
    Any registration permit issued under the provisions of this article may be suspended or revoked by the chief of police or the assistant chief of police upon reasonable proof of violation by the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 13, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-89. - Appeals by persons aggrieved by judgment or decision. 
    Any person aggrieved by judgment or decision rendered by the chief of police in the interpretation or enforcement of any provision or requirement may appeal such judgment or decision within ten (10) days from the date thereof to the Mayor or City Council of the City of Meridian. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 14, 3-6-2012) 
Sec. 24-90. - Rates and charges. 
    Rates and charges are to be reasonable and be no more than the average rates of wreckers doing business in the State of Mississippi, and if any such rates or charges should be found excessive or unreasonable, the chief of police or the assistant chief of police may permanently revoke the permit of such wrecker owner or operator. Initial rates are to be furnished to the chief of police or his/her designee and any changes thereto must be submitted to the chief of police or his/her designee in advance of implementation and must continue to be reasonable and be no more than the average rates of wreckers doing business in the State of Mississippi. If any such rates or charges should be found excessive or unreasonable, the chief of police or the assistant chief of police may permanently revoke the permit of such wrecker owner or operator. 
(Ord. No. 4403, § 15, 3-6-2012) 
Chapter 25 - WATER AND SEWERS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Water and sanitary sewerage systems combined; department established. 
    The water system and the sanitary sewerage system of the city shall be combined and shall hereafter be operated as a combined water and sanitary sewerage system, including the existing waterworks system, water supply system, the existing sanitary sewerage system, sanitary sewerage disposal system, the entire water system and the entire sanitary sewerage system of the city, together with all improvements and extensions hereafter constructed, but not including the storm and drainage sewer system of the city. The public works department of the city shall operate, manage, administer and govern the combined water and sanitary sewerage system. 
(Code 1962, § 25-2; Ord. No. 3612, § 1, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 1, 5-18-93) 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 25-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3955, § 53, adopted May 18, 1993, repealed § 25-2, employee classifications to be as in former water department, which derived from § 25-3 of the city's 1962 Code as amended by Ord. No. 3612, § 2, adopted Aug. 4, 1981. 
Sec. 25-3. - Right of employees to inspect water installations; discontinuing service for violation of regulations. 
(a)  Any employee of the public works department, at the time of turning on water to any consumer, shall watch the meter to determine the possibility of an opening in any line, e.g., broken line, faucet turned on, or any indication from the meter that an unusual amount of water is passing through the meter under the circumstances. If it appears that an unusual amount of water is passing through the meter, the employee may conduct a visual inspection of the premises outside any building to look for evidence of water leakage without permission from the consumer or owner if different from the consumer; provided, however, the employee shall not enter into or upon any buildings or structures. If such evidence is found and the employee can correct it, e.g., turning off an outside faucet, the employee shall do so. If such evidence is found, e.g., water from a broken line or coming from under a structure, and the cause cannot be corrected by the employee, the water shall be turned off and a report immediately made to the public works department who shall notify the consumer as quickly as possible. 
(b)  In other situations, after giving reasonable notice under the circumstances to the consumer and owner of the premises, if different from the consumer, the director or other duly authorized personnel of the public works department, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall have free access at any reasonable hour to all parts of the premises supplied with water from the waterworks system of the city for the purpose of examining into the conditions or uses of water on the premises as may be reasonable or necessary to determine whether conditions exist which may impair or threaten the safety, integrity or quality of the water system itself or the water provided by the city, or to determine whether conditions exist which may threaten or endanger the safety, health and welfare of any consumers of the system including, but not limited to, the uses to which the water is applied, the condition of fixtures, service pipe installations and other equipment, presence of lead, copper, chlorine or other pollutants or to investigate or respond to any report or complaint from a consumer. 
(c)  Refusal to allow inspection may immediately be followed by a discontinuance of the water supply which shall not be restored, if discontinued, until inspection is allowed and proper damages paid. Should it be found that the water is being used contrary to the rules, rates and regulations or provisions of this chapter, the supply may be shut off and not restored until a proper accounting has been made and all claims paid. 
(d)  The person making the inspection shall prepare a concise written report of each inspection containing, as a minimum: 
(1)  The basis for determining the need for the inspection; 
(2)  Notice given or efforts made to give notice; 
(3)  The date and time of the inspection; 
(4)  The findings of the inspection; 
(5)  The other persons present, if any, during the inspection; and 
(6)  The conclusions and recommendations for action, if any. 
(Code 1962, § 25-4; Ord. No. 3612, § 15, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 2, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-4. - Authority to shut off water in emergencies. 
    The water supply to all of the city may be shut off by the public works department at any time the necessity may arise, or any shutoff may be confined to a smaller area of the city, governed by the location of the valves. Employees of the public works department shall, promptly after determining the need to implement the shutoff, make every reasonable and appropriate effort to notify all consumers affected by a shutoff to advise the consumer of the shutoff and to advise the consumer to take necessary steps to provide a temporary water supply and adopt safety measures; such notice may be made by personal contact or by leaving notice on the door of the most appropriate entryway to the residence, office or structure if within a limited area or through the media if affecting a larger area of consumers. The notice shall include a general statement of the type of actions and precautions the city advises the consumers to take to avoid injury to person or property including, but not limited to, opening hot water faucets, quenching fires under boilers and in stoves or furnaces, shutting off gas heaters and such other action as may appear to the city employees to be necessary and shall contain a very clear statement that these suggestions are not inclusive and are not intended to include every possible type of action or precaution. The statement shall further advise the consumers to consider their specific circumstances and additional actions or precautions they may need to take to avoid injury to person or property. It shall be the sole responsibility of the consumer to implement any measures for temporary water supply and safety of person and property, and the city shall not be responsible or liable for the failure of the consumer to do so or to do so in an appropriate or effective manner. 
(Code 1962, § 25-5; Ord. No. 3612, § 34, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 3, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-5. - Duty of consumers to maintain, protect water pipes, fixtures. 
    Users of water shall keep their water pipes and fixtures in good repair and properly protected from freezing and breakage. When it is discovered that this section is being violated, the water supply may be shut off and not turned on again until satisfactory settlement and repair is made. The settlement shall be worked out by the city administration and the user. Any judgment entered into shall be subject to the provisions of section 25-16.*** 
(Code 1962, § 25-6; Ord. No. 3612, § 20, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3862, § 1, 4-17-90; Ord. No. 3955, § 4, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-6. - Wasting of water prohibited; restrictions or limitations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any consumer of water supplied by the municipality to wilfully waste the water so supplied, or to permit the same to waste, by leaving open any faucets, cocks or stops, either to prevent freezing or for any other purpose. This prohibition shall not apply to opening faucets, cocks or stops if so recommended or required by the city in response to weather or other conditions if so done according to the time limitations and conditions suggested or required by the city. 
(b)  The city may impose restrictions or limitations on the amount of water allowed to be consumed or used and/or the purposes for which water is allowed to be consumed or used in all or part of the city. Such restrictions or limitations shall be reasonable under the circumstances. Timely and appropriate notice of such restrictions or limitations shall be given to all consumers subject to the restrictions or limitations. Such notice may be made by personal contact or by leaving notice on the door of the most appropriate entryway to the residence, office or structure if within a limited area or through the media if affecting a larger area of consumers. The notice shall include a statement of the restrictions and limitations and the penalty for violation thereof. 
(c)  Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1962, § 25-7; Ord. No. 3955, § 5, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-7. - Polluting water prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, in violation of applicable federal, state or local laws, rules or regulations, to corrupt, pollute or make impure, by any means or agency or in any manner whatever, the water supplied or intended to be supplied to its consumers by the city. Any person convicted of a violation of this section, in addition to any other punishment authorized or imposed by federal or state law, shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1962, § 25-8; Ord. No. 3955, § 6, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-8. - Trespassing on, loitering around water facilities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except employees of the public works department and the officials of the city, to trespass or go upon the grounds of or loiter near the freshwater treatment plant and the wastewater treatment plant without having permission of the director of the public works department or his designee; provided that, this section shall not apply to any person who may be, in good faith, delivering supplies or services to such plant for the use of the public works department of the city. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1962, § 25-9; Ord. No. 3955, § 7, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-9. - Damaging water facilities, wrongfully turning on water prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully, in any manner, molest, impair or damage any of the fixtures, machinery, appliances, equipment or property of the city freshwater treatment system, or for any person other than an employee of the public works department or an employee of the fire department, or other person especially employed for such purpose by the public works department, to cut off or turn on water at any cutoff or curbcock or connecting pipe supplied with water by the freshwater treatment system or to cut off or turn on water for the purpose of flushing hydrants or to otherwise commit any unnecessary waste of water supplied through the pipes of the city freshwater treatment system. 
(Code 1962, § 25-10; Ord. No. 3955, § 8, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-10. - Dropping substances into water facilities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except employees of the public works department, to throw, drop or place, or attempt to throw, drop or place, any substance whatever in the facilities of the freshwater and wastewater treatment systems or any of the mains or pipes of the freshwater source and supply system, the freshwater distribution system or the wastewater collection system of the city, without having written permission so to do signed by the director of the department or his designee. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1962, § 25-11; Ord. No. 3955, § 9, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-11. - Improperly using, tampering with meters, stopcocks. 
    Water shall be shut off for any improper use or for tampering with the meter, meter box or the stopcock or attempting to do so by any consumer or by or with his consent or connivance. It shall be the duty of the consumer to prevent any infraction of this section that may come to his knowledge by promptly reporting same to the police or public works department. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 25-12; Ord. No. 3612, § 21, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 10, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-12. - Stealing water from public property; city employees to report leaks. 
    No person shall be allowed to take and carry away water from any public school fixtures, public buildings, grounds, parks or fountains. It shall be the duty of all city employees to report promptly any infraction of this section to the police or the public works department. It shall also be the duty of the above named employees to report promptly the existence of any leak in the fixtures or pipes at such buildings, parks and grounds to the public works department. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 25-13; Ord. No. 3612, § 36, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 11, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-13. - Turning on water after service discontinued. 
(a)  No person, not authorized by the public works department, shall turn on the water supply after it has been shut off by the department for nonpayment, violation of the rules and regulations or provisions of this chapter or of the department or for any other cause. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(b)  Any charges for the use of services in violation of this section be a tenant or tenants at a service location, after service has been shut off by the department, are the responsibility of the property owner. 
(Code 1962, § 25-14; Ord. No. 3612, § 37, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 12, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4194, 9-18-2001) 
Sec. 25-14. - Fee for turning on water after shutoff for violation; meter reconnection. 
    When the water supply of any customer is shut off or the meter is locked for a violation of the rules, rates and regulations or provisions of this chapter, a reconnection charge of thirty dollars ($30.00) for the expense of turning off and then on shall be collected before the supply is restored, except that if the meter has been removed, the reconnection fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Code 1962, § 25-15; Ord. No. 3337, § 3, 8-13-69; Ord. No. 3612, § 38, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 13, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4383, § 1, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 25-15. - Permit required to use fire hydrants. 
(a)  No person, except employees of the city authorized so to do, shall be allowed to remove water from the fire hydrants of the city without a written authorization or receipt signed by the public works department. When such an authorization or receipt is issued, it shall be constantly in the possession of the person using the hydrant in order that it may be inspected by policemen or employees of the public works department. Prior to such person removing water from a fire hydrant, a meter shall be attached to the hydrant to measure the amount of water used, and the person shall pay the city for the water according to the applicable rate, or the person shall pay the city a minimum charge, whichever is greater. Before a meter is so attached, such person must post a security deposit, which deposit will be returned, without interest, to such person, when such person discontinues his use of said meter, provided such person has paid for all water he used and provided also that the meter has not been damaged. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(b)  The mayor and city council, by resolution or order duly adopted and placed on their minutes, may waive the provisions of this section for fire protection purposes. 
(Code 1962, § 25-16; Ord. No. 3612, § 35, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 14, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4194, 9-18-2001; Ord. No. 4383, § 2, 4-5-2011) 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 9-21 et seq.; licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 25-16. - Fluoridation authorized. 
    Upon receiving the written consent and approval of the state board of health, and until the further action of the city council, there is hereby authorized and directed to be introduced into the water furnished by the city to the users thereof approximately one (1) to one and two-tenths (1.2) parts of fluoride to every million parts of water being distributed in the water supply system of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 25-17) 
Sec. 25-17. - Obstructing gutters, drains, sewers prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any water meter, gutter, ditch, drain or sewer of the city with any lumber, brick, wood, dirt or other building material or with any ashes, paper, trash, grass or vegetation, rubbish or substance of any kind. 
(Code 1962, § 25-18; Ord. No. 3955, § 15, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-18. - Prevention of discharge upon violation. 
    In addition to any penalty prescribed for the violation of any provision of this chapter, the public works department, on such violation, may order and require the drain through which substances are discharged, which are liable to injure the sewers or obstruct the flow of sewage, disconnected from the sewerage system or otherwise prevent the discharge of such substance into the public sewers. 
(Code 1962, § 25-19.3; Ord. No. 3547, § 3, 10-18-78; Ord. No. 3612, § 49, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 16, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-19. - Minimum specifications for polyvinyl chloride (PVC) water and sewer pipe to be used in city. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to use or install any polyvinyl chloride (PVC) water pipe for the transportation of potable water in the city which does not meet or exceed the following minimum specifications: 
(1)  Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) water pipe: 
a.  Scope: This specification covers the furnishing and installation of PVC pressure pipe in nominal diameters four (4) inches through twelve (12) inches for potable water distribution projects as designated on project drawings. 
b.  Pipe: The pipe shall be fabricated in accordance with AWWA Standard C900 for "Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) Pressure Pipe, Four (4) inch through twelve (12) Inch for Water." All pipe shall be a minimum pressure class of one hundred fifty (150) with cast iron pipe equivalent outside diameters unless otherwise indicated. 
c.  Joints: Shall be gasket, push-on type conforming to AWWA C900 and to the pipe design. Lubricant shall be as recommended by the pipe manufacturer and shall not adversely affect the potable qualities of the water to be transported. 
d.  Markings: All PVC pipe shall be clearly marked in accordance with AWWA C900. Intervals shall not exceed five (5) feet. 
e.  Approvals: PVC water pipe shall be approved by the National Sanitation Foundation (NSF), Underwriters Laboratory (UL), and Factory Mutual (FM). 
f.  Tests and reports: The contractor shall provide tests and reports duly certified by the manufacturer's testing facility or an approved testing laboratory of full compliance with AWWA Standard C900. Pipe may be rejected for failure to comply with any requirements of this specification. 
(2)  Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) water pipe design and installation: 
a.  Pressure class: All PVC water pipe shall have a pressure class (PC) rating of the minimum static pressure that exceeds by ten (10) percent the anticipated working pressure for the pipe section being designed or replaced. "Working pressure" is defined as the maximum sustained operating pressure. 
The pressure class (PC) ratings listed in AWWA C900 provide a minimum allowance for surge pressure based on an instantaneous velocity change of two (2) fps. If surge pressures are expected to be of greater magnitude, an additional allowance shall be made by reducing the pipe's marked PC rating accordingly. (Refer to AWWA C900, Appendix A-"AWWA Design Requirements and Criteria for PVC Water Pipe.") 
b.  Embedment requirements: The embedment requirements for PVC water pipe shall be in accordance with AWWA C900, Appendix A.6, "Installation." Minimum depth of cover for unencased water pipe shall be thirty (30) inches. 
c.  Service connections: All service connections to PVC water pipe shall be made with tapping sleeve or saddle in accordance with the recommendations of AWWA No. M23, "PVC Pipe-Design and Installation." 
(3)  Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) water pipe post-installation test requirement: 
a.  Pressure and leakage: A simultaneous pressure and leakage test shall be performed on the installed system. No installation will be accepted if the leakage is greater than that determined by the formula: 
L = ND 

      

7,400 
L is the allowable leakage, in gallons per hour; N is the number of joints in the length of pipeline tested; D is the normal diameter of the pipe, in inches; and P is the average test pressure during the test, in pounds per square inch gauge. 
The duration of each test shall be two (2) hours, unless otherwise specified. During the test, the main shall be subjected to a pressure equal to one hundred fifty (150) percent of the anticipated normal working pressure at the point of test, but not less than one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of the normal working pressure at the highest elevation or a minimum testing pressure of one hundred (100) psi. All test procedures shall be in accordance with Section 4, "Hydrostatic Testing" of AWWA Standard C600. 
b.  Sterilization: Upon completion of the system or any part thereof, the contractor shall flush the system until all foreign material is removed and sterilize such system with chlorine in accordance with the state board of health requirements. It will be the responsibility of the contractor to coordinate the sterilization and sampling with the state board of health, and the system will not be deemed acceptable until the engineer receives notification from the state board of health that the system is free of organisms and material. Test procedures shall conform to AWWA Standard C601. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to use or install any polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer pipe or corrugated high density polyethylene (CHDPE) sewer pipe for the transportation of sewage in the city which does not meet or exceed the following minimum specifications: 
(1)  Thermoplastic sewer pipe and fittings: 
a.  Scope: This material specification covers the furnishing and installation of thermoplastic sewer pipe in nominal diameters four (4) inches through fifteen (15) inches and the furnishing and installation of CHDPE sewer pipe in nominal diameters of four (4) through eighteen (18) inches for use in sanitary sewer projects as designed on project drawings. 
b.  Pipe: Sewer pipe shall be manufactured in accordance with one (1) of the following standard specifications: 
1.  ASTM D 3034 "Standard Specification for Type PSM Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) Sewer Pipe and Fittings." 
2.  ASTM D 2751 "Standard Specifications for Acrylonitrile-Butadiene-Styrene (ABS) Gravity Sewer Pipe and Fittings." 
3.  AASHTO M 252 and AASHTO M 294, Type S, for Corrugated High Density Polyethylene Pipe with Thermo-molded PVC fittings meeting ASTM F 1336. 
c.  Joints: All pipe joints shall be gasket, bell, and spigot, push-on type conforming to ASTM 3212, "Standard Specification for Joints for Drain and Sewer Plastic Pipes Using Flexible Flastomeric Seals," and the pipe design. Lubricant shall be as recommended by the pipe manufacturer. 
d.  Fittings: Fittings for gravity sewer pipe shall be fabricated or molded from material meeting the respective ASTM pipe standard. The wall thickness of the waterway and bell of molded fittings shall be no less than the respective minimum thicknesses for the equivalent pipe. All fittings shall be compatible with the pipe to which they are attached. 
e.  Markings: All pipe shall be marked in accordance with the applicable ASTM or AASHTO standard specification as may be required or appropriate. Intervals will not exceed five (5) feet or ten (10) feet as may be required or appropriate. 
f.  Test and reports: The contractor shall provide the reports duly certified by the manufacturer's testing facility or an approved testing laboratory of full compliance with the applicable ASTM or AASHTO standard specification, as may be required or appropriate. Pipe may be rejected for failure to comply with any requirement of this specification. 
(2)  Sewer pipe design and installation requirements: 
a.  Pipe stiffness: The standard dimension ratio (SDR) for nominal four-inch through fifteen-inch will be SDR 26. The pipe stiffness for four-inch through twelve-inch CHDPE pipe shall be one hundred fifteen (115) psi. For pipe diameters larger than twelve-inch, the pipe stiffness shall be as shown in the applicable AASHTO specification. 
b.  Permitted uses: Thermoplastic sewer pipe may be used only as collector lines in areas where corrosive environment is not anticipated. 
c.  Embedment requirements: The method for calculating loads and determining embedment requirements for sewer pipe shall be in accordance with the latest published edition of ASCE Manual No. 60/WPCF Manual FD-5, "Gravity Sanitary Sewer Design and Construction," and STM D-2321. No thermoplastic sewer pipe may be installed at a depth of cover less than three (3) feet or more than twenty (20) feet. 
(3)  Sewer pipe post-installation performance test requirements: 
a.  Leakage: All sewers shall be tested for excessive leakage. This may include appropriate water or low pressure air testing. The leakage outward or inward (exfiltration or infiltration) shall not exceed two hundred (200) gallons per inch of pipe diameter per mile per day for any section of the system. An exfiltration or infiltration test shall be performed with a minimum positive head of two (2) feet. The air test, if used, shall as a minimum conform to the test limits published by Mr. Roy E. Ramsier in the April, 1972, issue of the WPCF Journal. Alternatively, air testing may be conducted in accordance with "Recommended Practice for Low-Pressure Air Testing of Installed Sewer Pipe" (UNI-B-6-82) as published by the Uni-Bell PVC Pipe Association. The testing method selected shall properly consider the existing groundwater elevations during the test. Any pipe which fails the test for excessive leakage shall be replaced by the contractor at no additional cost to the city. 
b.  Deflection: After completion of the backfill, the engineer may require that a deflection test be performed. Any pipe which fails the test for excessive deflection shall be replaced or repaired by the contractor at no additional cost to the city. Deflection tests may be conducted using a go/no-go mandrel constructed of aluminum, steel or stainless steel. The mandrel's outside dimension shall be sized to permit no more deflection than authorized by the state regulatory agency. The percentage of deflection shall be established from the base inside diameter of the pipe. The mandrel shall be approved by the engineer prior to use. 
(Ord. No. 3706, §§ 1, 2, 4, 2-5-85; Ord. No. 3955, § 17, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4194, 9-18-2001) 
Secs. 25-20-25-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RATES[2]

Sec. 25-36. - Water meters required; free water prohibited. 
(a)  All water shall be supplied through meters installed or authorized by the public works department and no application for water, to be served by flat rate, shall be received. No crossover connection with the water main shall be allowed as a substitute for a meter. 
(b)  There shall be no free water to any user except the government of the city; provided, however, the city council and mayor, subject to any prohibitions or restrictions in state law or any applicable water and/or sewer bond documents, by order or resolution duly adopted and recorded on the minutes of the city council, may approve free water or reduced rates for water for any governmental entities whose boards or commissions are appointed in the manner provided by law by the mayor and the city council for general purposes or for any other governmental entities or agencies for water used for fire protection purposes only. 
(c)  All applicants for new service must produce state-issued photo identification. If the applicant cannot produce state-issued photo identification, he/she may provide photo identification and one (1) credit reference. Service may be refused at the discretion of the director or his designee if the new applicant is found not to have sufficient credit references or proof of identification. No application for services shall be accepted from an applicant who is less than eighteen (18) years of age at the time of application, except at the discretion of the director or his designee, upon a case-by-case basis, where sufficient credit reference has been established to the satisfaction of the director or his designee. 
(Code 1962, § 25-56; Ord. No. 3612, § 14, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 18, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4194, 9-18-2001; Ord. No. 4383, § 3, 4-5-2011)

Sec. 25-38. - Charge for water when meters defective. 
    Where meters have been found to have gone dead or become inoperative or sluggish during any one (1) billing period, the properly authorized officials of the public works department shall have the right to render to the consumer an estimated bill based upon the consumption charged to this account during the same billing period one (1) year previous; provided, however, that the conditions of consumption are the same for both periods of consumption. Each estimated bill shall be stamped, properly explaining that the bill has been estimated in accordance with the rules and regulations or provisions of this chapter governing the billing of water, and if the consumer is dissatisfied with such an estimation, it shall be incumbent upon him to prove to the public works department by affidavit that his use of water, during the period for which the bill was estimated, was less than the corresponding period for the year previous. Upon the presentation of such satisfactory proof, the proper officials of the department shall be authorized to proceed to readjust this bill upon any basis that they may deem equitable and just to the consumer and to the city jointly, as, for example, rendering an average bill based upon the consumption for the previous three (3) months, or rendering a bill based upon an average of the preceding month and subsequent month. 
(Code 1962, § 25-58; Ord. No. 3612, § 24, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 19, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-39. - Testing, replacement of water meters. 
    Meters shall be tested upon application of the consumer. If the meter is found to be inaccurate to the detriment of the consumer or the city, it shall be replaced with an accurate one. If the meter is found to be within two (2) percent correct, either way, it shall be considered correct. Directions for correctly reading meters shall be furnished to consumers who may, by this means, accurately test meters without assistance from the public works department. 
(Code 1962, § 25-59; Ord. No. 3612, § 25, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 20, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-40. - Water rates. 
(a)  Established. The following rates shall be charged and collected for water service: Four dollars and sixty-six cents ($4.66) per one thousand (1,000) gallons with a minimum charge of nine dollars and thirty-two cents ($9.32) for the first two thousand (2,000) gallons and a rate of five dollars and six cents ($5.06) per one thousand (1,000) gallons over the first two thousand (2,000) gallons.

(c)  Outside city. Customers outside the city limits shall pay double the monthly charges for water and sewer and all connection and other service fees. 
(d)  Adjustments. 
(1)  Leakage adjustment. In the event the amount of a consumer's monthly statement exceeds the average of the amount of the two (2) monthly statements immediately preceding by fifty (50) percent or more, the public works department may reduce the amount of such monthly statement to the average of the two (2) months immediately preceding if the consumer submits (i) a statement from a plumber licensed by the city that the excessive amount of water metered for that month was caused by a leak or broken water line or fixture and that the cause has been repaired and (ii) a paid receipt from a plumber licensed by the city for parts and labor to repair the cause of the leak or broken line or fixture. Excessive amounts of water being metered where the cause is other than a leak or broken line or fixture may be made on a case-by-case basis, but no adjustment shall be made for any cause if the monthly statement does not exceed the average of the two (2) months immediately preceding by less than fifty (50) percent. Only one (1) such adjustment, regardless of the cause, may be made for a consumer during the calendar year of January 1 through December 31. 
(2)  Other adjustment. In the event a consumer's monthly statement exceeds the average of the amount of the two (2) monthly statements immediately preceding by fifty (50) percent or more, and the cause of the excessive use of water is confirmed to be other than a leak, a broken line or fixture, request for an adjustment shall be directed to the public works department and it will be considered on a case-by-case basis. 
(3)  Number of adjustments. Regardless of the cause of excessive use, only one (1) adjustment may be made for a consumer during any one (1) calendar year, however, one (1) additional adjustment may be made at the discretion of the director or his designee as the circumstances warrant on a case-by-case basis. 
(e)  The rates established in subsections (a) and (b) may be adjusted by way of increase or decrease by written order of the mayor or his designated representative, no more often than once every three (3) months, and in a total aggregate percentage which does not exceed ten (10) percent of the amount set in subsections (a) and (b) for the fiscal year in which said rate adjustments are adopted.
