Sec. 25-44. - When bills due, payable; discontinuing service to delinquents. 
(a)  All meters shall be read one (1) time per month and, to the extent practicable, shall be read in the same consecutive order each month. Statements shall be mailed out once per month. 
(b)  All billings and collections for water and sanitary sewer service shall be made by the public works department, and all charges for water and sewer service shall be billed to each consumer on a combined monthly bill. The combined bill shall list thereon the separate charges for each service, and the total combined water and sewer bill shall be paid as hereinafter provided, and it may be permissible to accept the payment of less than the amount of the combined bill. 
(c)  All water and sanitary sewer bills shall be due monthly and shall be paid to the city clerk at the city hall, and the failure of any consumer to pay his combined water and sanitary sewer bill within fourteen (14) business days after the bill date shall constitute default and incur a late fee of five dollars ($5.00). The public works department may shut off and discontinue all water service to any consumer who fails to pay his combined water and sanitary sewer bills within such time. The deposits provided for herein shall not be used in automatic settlement of current water and sanitary sewer bills, but shall be applied only in payment of past due water and sanitary sewer bills in cases where default has been made and water supply has been shut off by reason of default. No further water service shall be supplied to any consumer in default until all past due bills and the charge hereafter provided have been paid in full and total amount of the deposits required hereunder has been reestablished. A collection fee, as allowed by law, may be made for the special handling of each bad check. An additional collection fee may be added to any consumer's bill each time it is necessary that a city employee or bill collector employed or retained by the city must call upon such customer or otherwise make an effort to collect a bill more than thirty (30) days delinquent. 
(d)  Hold agreements: Once a final notice has been issued on an account the entire amount is due. No "hold" will be placed on delinquent accounts except under the following circumstances. If a customer has extenuating circumstances, such as a death in the family, the loss of a job or illness, which will prevent full payment before the cutoff date, the customer or his/her official designee may come to the office and request payment arrangements, hereinafter described as a "hold" agreement. No "hold" agreement will be made over the phone. The customer or his/her official designee must appear in person at the department's business office to sign the "hold" agreement. The director or his designee shall have the discretion to make or refuse such a "hold" agreement based upon the extenuating circumstances on a case-by-case basis, considering each customer's prior request(s) for such an agreement and any prior abuse of the system by that customer. The following minimum guidelines will be used in determining payment arrangements, if any: (a) length of time account has been established, (b) date of last payment, and (c) payment history. Any member of the department's business office staff is authorized to enter into a "hold" agreement for accounts up to seventy-five dollars ($75.00) and up to ten (10) days past the due date. Any request for the extension of such an agreement past the initial ten-day period or respecting an amount in excess of seventy-five dollars ($75.00), must receive prior approval by the director or his designee. If the customer does not perform the "hold" agreement as promised, penalties and service charges as otherwise outlined in this chapter shall apply. 
(Code 1962, § 25-64; Ord. No. 3612, § 28, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 24, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4194, 9-18-2001; Ord. No. 4383, § 5, 4-5-2011; Ord. No. 4440, § 1, 6-17-2014; Ord. No. 4454, § 1, 3-5-2015) 
Secs. 25-45, 25-46. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3955, §§ 56, 57, adopted May 18, 1993, repealed §§ 25-45 and 25-46, which pertained to charge for multiple water service through one meter and rate for circuses, other extraordinary uses of water, respectively, and derived from §§ 25-65 and 25-66 of the city's 1962 Code as amended by Ord. No. 3612, §§ 30, 31, adopted Aug. 4, 1981. 
Sec. 25-47. - Rates to be uniform; discrimination prohibited. 
    The water rates provided by this chapter shall apply to all consumers alike, and no employee of the public works department shall grant any reduction therein to any consumer or make any discrimination in rates or service except as otherwise authorized by city ordinance or this chapter. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1962, § 25-67; Ord. No. 3612, § 33, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 25, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-48. - Delinquent using name of another to obtain water prohibited. 
    Water shall not be supplied to any premises, either directly or indirectly, when the occupancy is in arrears at the place then occupied. This section is intended to prevent the use of another's name, by subterfuge, in order to obtain a water supply by a delinquent. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1962, § 25-68; Ord. No. 3612, § 17, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 26, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-49. - Supplying water to sublessee when original tenant in default prohibited. 
    Water shall not be turned on or supplied for a sublessee of any premises when the original tenant is in default for water supplied to the same premises so long as the premises or any part thereof are occupied by the person in default. 
(Code 1962, § 25-69; Ord. No. 3612, § 16, 8-4-81) 
Sec. 25-50. - Temporary offs. 
    When the water supply of any consumer is shut off on a temporary basis, at the consumer's request, a charge of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be collected in advance for the total expense of turning off and restoring the water supply. 
(Ord. No. 4383, § 7, 4-5-2011) 
Secs. 25-51-25-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWER USE REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 25-66. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain shall mean that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building official shall mean the officially designated building official of the city, or his authorized deputy, agent, or representative. 
    Building sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    City engineer shall mean the officially designated city engineer of the city or his authorized deputy, agent, or representative. 
    Combined sewer shall mean a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    Garbage shall mean solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Industrial wastes shall mean the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade, or business as distinct from domestic sanitary sewage. 
    Natural outlet shall mean any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    pH shall mean the common logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Properly shredded garbage shall mean the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer shall mean a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
    Sanitary sewer shall mean a sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface, and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage shall mean a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface, and storm waters as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant shall mean any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
    Sewage works shall mean all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage. 
    Sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Shall; may. "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive. 
    Slug shall mean any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration of flows during normal operation. 
    Storm drain (sometimes termed "storm sewer") shall mean a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Suspended solids shall mean solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    User shall mean any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of sewage into the sewage works. 
    Watercourse shall mean a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. I, §§ 1-4, 6-10, 12-25, 5-1-84) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 25-67. - Unlawful deposits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of such city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. II, § 1, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-68. - Discharge to natural outlets restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. II, § 2, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-69. - Damage to sewerage works. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest and punishment in accordance with section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. VI, § 1, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-70. - Right of entry for purposes of inspection, testing, etc. 
(a)  Authorized. The director of public works or employees of the city authorized by the director bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. The director or his representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(b)  Observance of safety rules; waiver of liability. While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in paragraph (a) of this section, the director or employees of the city authorized by the director shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company. The company is responsible for access as required in section 25-121. 
(c)  Properties over which city holds easement. The director and employees of the city authorized by the director bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties over and across which the city holds an easement for the purposes of, including, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the wastewater treatment system lying within such easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on such easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. VII, §§ 1-3, 5-1-84; Ord. No. 3955, § 27, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-71. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Notice of violation. Any person found to be violating any provision of this article except section 25-69 shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in paragraph (a) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be punished in accordance with section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. Each day in which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. Additionally, chronic violation of the terms of this article may result in termination of the sewer disposal permit. 
(c)  Liability to city. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. VIII, §§ 1-3, 5-1-84) 
Secs. 25-72-25-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 25-86. - Permits-Required. 
    No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the building official. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 1, 5-1-84) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 25-87. - Same-Classes; application; accompanying documents; fees. 
(a)  There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential and commercial service, and 
(2)  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
(b)  In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the building official. 
(c)  A permit and inspection fee of four dollars ($4.00) for a residential or commercial building sewer permit and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for an industrial building sewer permit shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(d)  As a condition for authorization to dispose of industrial wastes through the municipal system, the industrial applicant for a sewer permit shall provide the city with information describing wastewater constituents and characteristics, and the type of activity and quantity of production. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 2, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-88. - Owner to bear costs of installation and connection; to indemnify city for loss; damage. 
    All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 3, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-89. - Separate sewers required; exception. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except by special permit from the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 4, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-90. - Use of old sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the building official, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 5, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-91. - Standards for size, slope, alignment, materials, etc. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench, shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) and the Water Pollution Control Federation (WPCF) Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 6, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-92. - Elevation. 
    Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 7, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-93. - Connection to roof drains, other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to building sewer. 
    No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 8, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-94. - Standards to be followed in connections to public sewer. 
    The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and the WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the building official before installation. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 9, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-95. - Inspections; supervision of connection to public sewer. 
    The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the building official when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the building official or his representative. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 10, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-96. - Excavation safeguards; restoration of public area surface. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to prevent the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. IV, § 11, 5-1-84) 
Secs. 25-97-25-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - USE OF THE PUBLIC SEWERS 

Sec. 25-111. - Required. 
(a)  All owners of property in the city, any part of which is located on streets where a sanitary sewerage main is located or within a distance of one hundred (100) feet from such main, shall have installed one (1) or more sanitary water closets connected with such sewerage system if there is sufficient fall to provide gravity flow from the property to such sewerage system. 
(b)  All owners of property which do not come within the provisions of the preceding paragraph of this section shall have installed a properly constructed septic tank which meets the specifications and is approved by the county health department or a mechanical lift station approved by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. II, § 4, 5-1-84; Ord. No. 3955, § 28, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-112. - Discharges to comply with federal, state and local standards. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge to the sewer system any pollutant except in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to the Clean Water Act, and any more stringent state and local standards. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. II, § 5, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-113. - Prohibited discharge to sanitary sewer. 
    No person or user shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 1, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-114. - Designation of sewers for stormwater, other unpolluted drainage. 
    Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the building official. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the city engineer and the bureau of pollution control of the state, to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 2, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-115. - Prohibited discharges to public sewers. 
    No user shall contribute or cause to be contributed, directly or indirectly, any pollutant or wastewater which will interfere with the operation or performance of the sewage works. These general prohibitions apply to all such users of sewage works whether or not the user is subject to national categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements. Users which are subject to the national categorical pretreatment standards shall contact the state department of natural resources, bureau of pollution control for further directions. A user may not contribute the following substances to the sewage works: 
(1)  Any liquid, solids or gases which, by reason of their nature or quantity, are, or may be, sufficient, either alone or by interaction with other substances, to cause fire or explosion or be injurious in any other way to the sewage works or to the operation of the sewage works. At no time shall two (2) successive readings on an explosion hazard meter, at the point of discharge into the system (or at any point in the system) be more than five (5) percent nor any single reading over ten (10) percent of the lower explosive limit (LEL) of the meter. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides, sulfides, and any other substances which the city, the state or the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has notified the user is a fire hazard or a hazard to the system. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant, including, but not limited to, cyanides in excess of 0.05 mg/l as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer. 
(3)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 6.0, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works. 
(4)  Solid or viscous substances which may cause obstruction to the flow in a sewer or other interference with the operation of the wastewater treatment facilities such as, but not limited to: grease, garbage with particles greater than one-half inch in any dimension, animal guts or tissues, paunch manure, bones, hair, hides or fleshings, entrails, whole blood, feathers, ashes, cinders, sand, spent lime, stone or marble dust, metal, glass, straw, shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grains, spent hops, waste paper, wood, plastics, gas, tar, asphalt residues, residues from refining, or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, mud, or glass grinding or polishing wastes. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 3, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-116. - Discharge of certain wastes restricted. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the city engineer that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the city engineer will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and other pertinent factors. The substances prohibited are: 
(1)  Any substance which will cause the sewage treatment plant to violate its national pollution discharge elimination system and/or state disposal system permit or the receiving water quality standards. 
(2)  Any substance which may cause the sewage treatment plant effluent or any other product of the treatment facility such as residues, sludges, or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with the reclamation process. In no case, shall a substance discharged to the sewage treatment plant cause the plant to be in noncompliance with sludge use or disposal criteria, guidelines or regulations developed under Section 405 of the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251, et seq.; any criteria, guidelines, or regulations affecting sludge use or disposal developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act, or state criteria applicable to the sludge management method being used. 
(3)  Any wastewater having a temperature which will inhibit biological activity in the sewage works resulting in interference, but in no case wastewater with a temperature at the introduction into the sewage works which exceeds forty (40) degrees Celsius (one hundred four (104) degrees Fahrenheit). 
(4)  Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease, or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l or containing substances which reach a viscosity of fifty-five (55) cps at twenty-five (25) degrees Celsius. 
(5)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of 3/4 horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the city engineer. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not. 
(7)  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, and similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the city engineer for such materials. (For industrial process wastes, see section 25-117.) 
(8)  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the city engineer as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters. 
(9)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the city engineer in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(10)  Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of 9 or below 6.0. 
(11)  Materials which exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fullers earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate). 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions). 
c.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works. 
d.  Any pollutant, including oxygen demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.) released at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which a user knows or has reason to suspect will cause interference to the sewage treatment works. In no case shall a slug load have a flow rate or contain concentration or qualities of pollutants that exceed for any time period longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration, quantities, or flow during normal operation. 
(12)  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(13)  Any waste prohibited by environmental protection agency standards as set out in the United States Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 403. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 4, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-117. - Pretreatment requirements. 
    All industrial and commercial process wastewater shall be pretreated prior to discharge to the public sewers, if necessary, in accordance with the provisions of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the bureau of pollution control, and/or the city, whichever is more stringent. The minimum pretreatment requirements are as follows: 
(1)  Compatible pollutants:

As a condition for authorization to dispose of industrial wastes through the municipal system, the industrial user shall provide the city with information describing wastewater constituents and characteristics, and the type of activity and quantity of production. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 5, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-118. - Action of city upon discharge of waste having deleterious effect upon sewerage works, etc. 
(a)  If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in sections 25-116 and 25-117 of this article, and which in the judgment of the city engineer may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the city engineer may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges. 
(b)  If the city engineer permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the city engineer and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances, and laws. 
(c)  Upon notification by the city that user is in violation of one (1) or more of these pretreatment requirements, the user shall submit a plan of compliance to the city engineer within thirty (30) days after receipt of such notice. Implementation of compliance shall proceed according to the compliance plan bearing the approval of the city engineer. If implementation does not proceed according to the compliance plan, then the user shall be in violation of this article and shall be subject to the penalty as set out in section 25-71 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 6, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-119. - Interceptors. 
(a)  When required. Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the city engineer, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that, such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. 
(b)  Type, capacity and location. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the city engineer and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 7, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-120. - Maintenance of preliminary treatment facilities. 
    Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 8, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-121. - Control manholes. 
(a)  Generally. For all new construction, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer as are necessary to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurements of the wastes. 
(b)  Location, construction. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city engineer. 
(c)  Installation, maintenance. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(d)  Measuring devices. Unless an industrial or commercial user obtains all water used from the city and agrees to use water meter readings as sewage flow, or estimate of flow made by the city engineer, the user shall install an approved flow measuring, indicating, totalizing and recording device in each control manhole. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 9, 5-1-84; Ord. No. 4012, § 3, 5-2-95) 
Sec. 25-122. - Measurements, tests and analyses. 
(a)  Standards. All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this article, shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association. 
(b)  Where determined. All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this article, shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. If no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. 
(c)  Sampling methods. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. (The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four-hour composite of all outfalls of a premise is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD, suspended solids, TKN and oil and grease analyses are obtained from twenty-four-hour composites of all outfalls whereas pH's are determined from periodic grab samples.) A composite sample, representative of the total discharge, shall be used for laboratory analysis. Where an industrial batch process is utilized, samples shall be taken during the dumping of the batch. Reports of laboratory analysis of results shall be submitted to the city engineer monthly, or at a frequency as determined by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 10, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-123. - Special agreements with industrial concerns. 
    Nothing contained in this division shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor, by the industrial concern. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. V, § 11, 5-1-84) 
Secs. 25-124-25-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 25-136. - Construction, maintenance of facility prohibited; exception. 
    Except as provided in this division, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. II, § 3, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-137. - When required. 
    Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available under the provisions of section 25-111, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. III, § 1, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-138. - Permit-Required; application. 
    Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the building official. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications, and other information as are deemed necessary by the building official. A permit and inspection fee as required by the building official shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. III, § 2, 5-1-84) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 25-139. - Same-When effective; inspection. 
    A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the building official. He shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of completion and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the building official when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made promptly after receipt of notice by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. III, § 3, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-140. - Type, capacities, location and layout. 
    The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the bureau of environmental health of the state. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities unless approved by the county health department. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. III, § 4, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-141. - Abandonment of private facilities. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article within sixty (60) days, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned, cleaned and filled with suitable material. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. III, § 5, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-142. - Maintenance of private system. 
    The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. If an on-site pressure system is required for use of the public sewer facility, the operation costs of the pressure system shall be the responsibility of the owner or user. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. III, § 6, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 25-143. - Additional requirements. 
    No statement contained in this division shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. 
(Ord. No. 3691, Art. III, § 7, 5-1-84) 
Secs. 25-144-25-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SERVICE AND CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 25-161. - Application required for service. 
    All persons desiring water and sanitary sewer installation and service shall file a written application with the public works department. Such application shall be signed by the owner of the property to be served or his duly authorized agent and shall state the purposes for which the water and sanitary sewer is to be used and all other facts and information as the public works department requires. Such applicant shall agree in writing to abide by all existing or future ordinances, regulations and rules or provisions of this chapter and the public works and all applicable regulations, existing or future, which have been or may be adopted and promulgated by the Mississippi Board of Health under the authority of and pursuant to the Mississippi Safe Drinking Water Act of 1997 (Section 41-26-1 through Section 41-26-101, Mississippi Code of 1972, Annotated) and the applicant shall pay the fees and deposits as prescribed at the time of filing such application. 
(Code 1962, § 25-31; Ord. No. 3612, § 3, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 29, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4114, § 29, 11-17-98) 
Sec. 25-162. - Applications for service outside city; cost of installation. 
    Persons desiring water or sanitary sewer installation and service outside the city shall submit the application as required by section 25-161 hereinabove, which application shall be first approved by the city council before the same is granted by the public works department. The applicant shall pay all required fees and deposits and shall pay all costs of such installation to the public works department prior to installation. However, any applicant for such water or sanitary sewer installation and service outside the city may, subject to the approval of the public works department, employ their own plumber and make their own water or sanitary sewer line installation, provided such is made in accordance with the plans and specifications of the public works department and provided such work is done under the supervision of the department and is approved by the director thereof. After installation is provided, no tap shall thereafter be made on such installed water line except by the public works department, or on such installed sanitary sewer line except by a licensed plumber. 
    After such line is laid and connected to the city water and sanitary sewer system, it shall become the property of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 25-32; Ord. No. 3612, § 4, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 30, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-163. - Using water without proper application prohibited. 
(a)  Should any person move into premises or buildings and find the water supply turned on without having been applied for by him, he shall immediately report the fact to the public works department office for attention and correction. Use of the water without making proper application for such subjects the violator to prosecution. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(b)  Any charges for the use of services in violation of this section by a tenant or tenants at a service location, after service has been shut off by the department, are the responsibility of the property owner. 
(Code 1962, § 25-33; Ord. No. 3612, § 18, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 31, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4194, 9-18-2001) 
Sec. 25-164. - Using water for unauthorized purposes prohibited. 
    No consumer shall use, or permit to be used, water from the city's system except for the purposes stated in the application, nor shall he supply water to any nonconsumer for any purpose without a written permit, which permit shall state for what purpose the water is to be used and for how long. The consumer shall not permit nonconsumers to use the hose attachments, nor leave them exposed for use by nonconsumers even though the water supply comes through a meter. A violation of this section may subject the offender to a discontinuance of the water supply and to penalties otherwise provided. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, § 25-34; Ord. No. 3612, § 19, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 32, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-165. - Deposit required for water, sewer service. 
(a)  In order to guarantee the prompt payment of all amounts due the city; to reimburse the city for all unpaid accounts due and to assist in replacement of damaged or missing meters, a deposit shall be made by each applicant for water and/or sanitary sewer service at the time application is made and in the amount corresponding to the size of the consumer's water meter, as follows: 
Meter Size 
(Inches) Amount of Deposit    5/8 $  75.00   3/4 75.00   1 100.00   11/2 175.00   2 225.00   3 250.00   4 500.00   6 1,000.00   8 1,500.00 Fire hydrant meter 100.00  
(b)  A deposit in the amount of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) shall be paid by each residential customer requesting a sewer connection and not using city water. Commercial and industrial accounts shall be required to put up a deposit for use of the sanitary sewer when not using city water and the deposit shall be set by the public works department based on usage. 
(c)  The public works department may require an amount higher than the above herein if it is deemed necessary by past experience to insure the city against loss of revenue. 
(d)  A deposit is not required on a second meter for water use only at the same service location for such usage as a lawn sprinkler (a "yard" meter) as long as the applicant's primary account has been paid in full and on a timely basis for the past three (3) months. 
(e)  A deposit is not required from the following users: Lauderdale County Government, the Meridian Housing Authority, the Air or Army National Guard at Key Field, the Meridian Public Schools, Meridian Community College, and Mississippi State University. 
(f)  When there is only one (1) master meter servicing multiple units at a single service location, each account for services shall remain in the name of the owner of that location. 
(g)  Deposits will be returned, without interest, when the consumer discontinues his use of water and/or sanitary sewer service, provided that the consumer has paid for all water and/or sanitary sewer service and also that the meter has not been damaged. 
(Code 1962, § 25-35; Ord. No. 3337, § 2, 8-13-69; Ord. No. 3497, § 1, 11-19-75; Ord. No. 3612, § 27, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 33, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4012, § 4, 5-2-95; Ord. No. 4194, 9-18-2001; Ord. No. 4383, § 6, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 25-166. - Costs paid by applicant for water for sprinkler system. 
    All applicants for water service connections for the purpose of sprinkler systems shall pay the costs of all labor and materials plus ten (10) percent of such installation from the water main to the property line of applicant. 
(Code 1962, § 25-36; Ord. No. 3612, § 32, 8-4-81) 
Sec. 25-167. - Water and sewer connections to be made by city; maintenance, etc. 
(a)  The city shall install water and sewer mains, lines and connections in and under the streets and a distance from such mains to the property line of the consumer. 
(b)  The city shall maintain, at its expense, water mains, lines and connections in and under the streets and a distance from such mains to the property line of the consumer. 
(c)  However, the city shall maintain, at its expense, only the sewer mains, to include a broken or faulty lateral, and the consumer shall be responsible, at his expense, for maintenance of the sewer lines and connections in and under his property and further to the lateral connection to the sewer main. In the event a consumer shall employ a plumber who shall determine the problem to be caused by the lateral, the plumber shall expose and cut the lateral connection and mark in the street the location of the breakage or other problem. The city will then replace the lateral at no cost to the consumer, but the consumer shall be responsible for tying the consumer's sewer lines into the lateral and completing the necessary plumbing and ground restoration work. 
(d)  Provided, however, if another ordinance of the city requires such water or sewer mains, lines or connections to be so installed by a builder, contractor or subdivider, the provisions of that ordinance shall be followed with regard to the party responsible for the installation of the mains, lines and connections. 
(Code 1962, § 25-37; Ord. No. 3612, § 5, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 34, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-168. - Installation of mains, lines, connections in streets. 
    No water mains, lines or connections and no sanitary sewer mains, lines or connections shall be installed in or under the streets of the city other than by the public works department unless special permission is obtained, in writing, signed by the director of the public works department or his designee; provided, however, if another ordinance of the city requires such water or sewer mains, lines or connections to be installed by a builder, contractor or subdivider, the provisions of that ordinance shall be followed with respect to the party responsible for the installation of the mains, lines or connections. 
(Code 1962, § 25-38; Ord. No. 3612, § 6, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 35, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-169. - Tapping charges for water, sewer connections. 
(a)  For tapping or making service connection to water mains inside the city, the charges shall be as follows: 
Meter Size (inches) Tap Size (inches) Tap Cost ?" 3/4" $700.00 3/4" 3/4" $750.00 1" 1" $875.00 11/2" 11/2" $1,400.00 2" 2" $1,600.00  
(b)  Charges for making all taps larger than two (2) inches shall be the total cost of installation. 
(1)  Cost of labor for these projects and any other projects, such as, line extensions, installation of manholes, and fire lines shall be at the rate of three hundred fifty-two dollars ($352.00) per hour. 
(2)  For all commercial projects or taps requiring meters one and one-half (11/2) inches or larger, the contractor shall furnish the meter in accordance with the City of Meridian's specifications. 
(c)  For tapping or making service connections to water mains outside the corporate limits of the city, except for property owned by the city, the tapping fee shall be two (2) times the in-city rates. 
(d)  For tapping or making service connection to sanitary sewer mains inside the city, the charges shall be as follows:

    An additional charge of three hundred and fifty dollars ($350.00) will be made for cutting and replacing asphalt for each water and/or sewer tap. 
(e)  For tapping or making service connections to sanitary sewer mains outside the corporate limits of the city, the tapping fee shall be two (2) times the in-city rates. This fee is to be paid at the same time as the water tap fee if sanitary sewer is available. 
(f)  The fees established in subsections (a), (b) and (d) may be reviewed and adjusted by way of increase or decrease by written order of the Mayor or his designated representative, no more than once per fiscal year and not to exceed more than ten (10) percent of the amounts set forth in subsections (a), (b) and (d) for the fiscal year in which adjustment is adopted. 
(Code 1962, § 25-39; Ord. No. 3337, § 1, 8-13-69; Ord. No. 3547, § 1, 10-18-78; Ord. No. 3612, § 7, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3624, § 1, 10-21-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 36, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4012, § 5, 5-2-95; Ord. No. 4059, § 3, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 4474, 8-16-2016) 
Sec. 25-169.1. - Water and sewer services in fire districts recognized by city. 
    Charges for water and sewer services provided by the city within designated fire districts recognized by the city shall be equal to those charged within the corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. 3822, § 1, 11-15-88) 
Sec. 25-170. - Maintenance, ownership of connections; when tapping charge paid; additional charges. 
    The tapping charges shall be paid for the privilege of connection with the main and shall not convey ownership in any of the material furnished by the public works department. The tapping charges shall be paid when the application is made, and the work shall not be done or allowed to be done until such charges are paid in full; but once paid, no further tapping charge shall be made except for the installation of an increased size tap on application of the owner. Tapping charges for new construction shall be paid in full at the time the application is made. 
(Code 1962, § 25-40; Ord. No. 3612, § 8, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 37, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4474, 8-16-2016) 
Sec. 25-171. - When taps in large mains authorized; large taps. 
    Taps in water mains larger than one (1) inch shall not be made unless the demand for water, as shown by the application for service installation, shall exceed the capacity of that size. When the need for a larger size tap is indicated by the application, the proper size thereof may be designated and authorized by the public works department in writing. 
(Code 1962, § 25-41; Ord. No. 3612, § 9, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 38, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-172. - Material for service pipes, stopcocks. 
    All service pipes in the streets and sidewalks shall be of the best grade of galvanized iron, copper or polyethylene tubing of a size and construction described in this chapter or approved by the public works department, not less than five-eighths of an inch in diameter. All service stopcocks shall be of the best grade of brass. 
(Code 1962, § 25-42; Ord. No. 3612, § 10, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 39, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-173. - Cooling towers for air conditioning required. 
    All air conditioning units or systems used to cool a space of more than two hundred (200) square feet, hereinafter installed, using water, shall be equipped with suitable water cooling towers. 
(Code 1962, § 25-43; Ord. No. 3612, § 29, 8-4-81) 
Sec. 25-174. - Unauthorized installations on water lines prohibited. 
    No person, except an employee of the public works department authorized so to do, shall install or open any curbcock or make any installation of any kind on any city-owned water lines. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1962, § 25-44; Ord. No. 3612, § 11, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 40, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-175. - Extending service to other premises prohibited; multiple meters on three-quarter-inch taps prohibited. 
    No pipe shall be extended from the original service or premises to other premises, whether owned by the same person or not. There shall not be more than one (1) meter on any three-quarter-inch water tap. 
(Code 1962, § 25-45; Ord. No. 3612, § 12, 8-4-81) 
Sec. 25-176. - Indebtedness to be paid before transferring service. 
    Applicants for transfer from one (1) location to another shall pay all indebtedness due the city for the premises vacated or to be vacated before the water is turned on at the premises for which the application for transfer is made, and no water shall be turned on at the new connection until all indebtedness is paid. 
(Code 1962, § 25-46; Ord. No. 3612, § 13, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 41, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-177. - Extension of lines. 
(a)  Cost borne by city. The public works department will hereafter extend, lay or construct all necessary and feasible sanitary sewer and water mains to serve any given lot or tract of land a distance of one hundred (100) feet or less including the front footage of the lot or tract of land to be served. 
(b)  Cost borne by applicant. 
(1)  Where the property for which any person desires either or both sanitary sewer and water connections is located more than one hundred (100) feet, including the front footage of the lot or tract of land for which the service is desired, from existing sanitary sewer and water mains, the director of the public works department or other designated official shall specify the size and type of pipe to be laid and cause an estimate to be made of the total cost of the extensions. 
(2)  The city council, in its discretion, may waive all or part of such costs upon finding and declaring that such extension beyond the distance of one hundred (100) feet will: 
a.  Improve and enhance the city's water and/or sewer system; or 
b.  Promote the health, safety and welfare of the residents within the area of the extension or within the city in general; or 
c.  Extend the system into an area having been annexed into the city; or 
d.  Improve and enhance the potential of the area into which the extension is made for its development for business, economic, commercial or industrial purposes; or 
e.  Any combination of the foregoing. 
(3)  In the event the costs of making such extension are not waived in whole or in part, it is hereby declared to be the policy of the city that the costs assessed shall be the minimum amount required to extend the system and maintain it adequately without unnecessary costs for a design or for materials which are beyond the needs of any adequate system operating in a good and satisfactory manner. Unless the costs are waived in whole as provided in subsection (2)c hereinabove, the person or persons requesting such extensions shall then pay to the city clerk, in cash, the total amount of such estimated cost, less any amount waived and less the estimated cost per foot of one hundred (100) feet of such extensions before the public works department will make such extensions; provided, however, in the event the actual cost of such extension, less any amount waived, is less than the estimated cost, the director of the public works department shall certify such fact to the city clerk who shall refund all such excess to the person or persons who paid same. If the actual cost, less any amount waived, is in excess of the estimate, the person or persons requesting such extension shall immediately pay the amount of such excess cost to the city clerk within thirty (30) days after being notified in writing of such excess, failing in which, any connections made to such extensions for the person originally advancing the estimated cost shall be immediately disconnected by the city, and no service shall be rendered such person from such extensions until such excess costs have been so paid. 
(c)  Become property of city. All sanitary sewer and water main extensions, regardless of whether the costs thereof were waived in whole or in part, made as herein provided shall be the sole property of the city immediately upon their installation, and it shall be a part of the consideration of the city making such extensions that such ownership shall be in the City of Meridian. 
(d)  Right of city to refuse. Nothing herein contained shall be construed so as to require the city to make such extensions, regardless of whether the costs thereof are eligible for waiver in whole or in part, if there are no funds available or to make any such extensions where they are not feasible because of topographical or other like reasons. 
(Code 1962, § 25-47; Ord. No. 3612, §§ 42-45, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 42, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-178. - Multiple connections to sewers. 
    Not more than one (1) building shall be connected with the city sewerage system through any one (1) drain except by special permit from the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 25-48; Ord. No. 3547, § 3, 10-18-78; Ord. No. 3612, § 55, 8-4-81) 
Sec. 25-179. - Notice by consumers wanting to discontinue water service. 
    Consumers wishing to discontinue the use of water shall give notice of same before vacating the premises named in the application. Failure to do so shall subject such consumers to the usual charge until knowledge has reached the public works department otherwise. 
(Code 1962, § 25-49; Ord. No. 3612, § 22, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 43, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-180-25-195. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RESERVOIRS 

Sec. 25-196. - To be open for fishing, recreation; swimming prohibited. 
    All the lakes comprising the water reservoir system of the city shall be open to the public for fishing and recreational purposes; provided, however, that the use of boats upon the lakes shall be prohibited except as hereinafter provided, and provided, further, that no swimming shall be permitted in any of the lakes except in designated areas. 
(Code 1962, § 25-76; Ord. No. 3955, § 44, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-197. - Consulting forester. 
(a)  The mayor is hereby authorized to retain for the city the services of an experienced forester upon a consulting and part-time basis who shall: 
(1)  Inspect at regular intervals the properties belonging to the city which surround the water reservoir system of the city as a protection against trespassing, dumping, erosion or any other circumstances detrimental to such lands. 
(2)  Prepare a plan for the protection of the properties from fire and train the present employees of the city now engaged in and about the water reservoir system of the city in the proper use of fire tools. 
(3)  Prepare a plan for the continuous growth and harvesting of timber on the properties, select the areas in need of cutting, mark the trees to be cut, assist the mayor in advertising such timber for sale and inspect the timber sale area during the logging to ensure that it is being done correctly. 
(4)  Prepare a plan for the recreational use of the lands surrounding the Long Creek Reservoir in order that proper tree planting may be undertaken. 
(5)  Prepare a plan for the planting of trees to prevent erosion wherever necessary and supervise the planting. 
(6)  Prepare adequate maps of the entire watershed in detail. 
(7)  Prepare and forward to the mayor every month a written report of his activities which shall include the forester's recommendations in connection with his services. 
(8)  To consult generally with the mayor and other officials of the city at such times and upon such problems relating to his services as may be required. 
(b)  For such services as above outlined, the forester shall receive such compensation as the council may direct. Such compensation shall be paid from the funds of the water and sewer department of the city since such services are directly concerned with the properties surrounding the water reservoir system of the city and connection therewith. 
(Code 1962, § 25-77) 
Sec. 25-198. - Mayor to designate picnic grounds. 
    The mayor shall designate by signs, or other appropriate means, such areas around the lakes or within the reservoir properties of the city which may be used for picnics and it shall be unlawful to use an area not so designated. 
(Code 1962, § 25-78) 
Sec. 25-199. - Camp fires. 
    The building of fires on any of the property surrounding the lakes and owned by the city is hereby prohibited except at such places as may be designated by the mayor for such purposes, and then only with special equipment; provided that, even in the places so designated, no fuel of any kind shall be used except charcoal, and provided, further, that all such fires shall be fully and completely extinguished by the persons starting the same before leaving the premises. 
(Code 1962, § 25-79) 
Sec. 25-200. - Disposal of garbage, trash. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave paper, paper napkins, paper plates or cups, food containers, garbage, trash or debris of any kind upon the grounds of the area and all such items shall be completely gathered and removed from the premises by the person bringing such items into the area. 
(Code 1962, § 25-80) 
Sec. 25-201. - Firearms prohibited. 
    The possession of firearms of any type, loaded or unloaded, within or upon any of the city-owned properties is hereby prohibited; provided, however, that the city council may designate an area used by the city police department for weapons training. 
(Code 1962, § 25-81; Ord. No. 3955, § 45, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-202. - Damaging, destroying plant life prohibited; hunting, trapping, etc.; use of all-terrain vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to damage, remove or destroy any of the plant or animal life in the area of the lakes. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to hunt, trap or otherwise kill or capture animals within the area of the lakes property or to discharge any firearm or other weapon thereon. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to use or operate, or permit to be used or operated, any motor vehicle known or described as an "all-terrain vehicle," except those owned by the city and used or operated by designated employees of the city, within the area of the lakes property, however, that it is lawful to operate a motor vehicle known or described as an "all-terrain vehicle," which term shall also include all "off-road" vehicles, within such area or areas of the lakes property that may be designated for such purpose by the city and also provided that the operator of such vehicle complies with all rules, regulations, and conditions which the city may impose concerning the operation of such vehicle in such area or areas of the lakes property. 
(Code 1962, § 25-82; Ord. No. 3955, § 46, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4086, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 25-203. - Boats-Size motors; general regulations for use. 
(a)  Boats may be used for fishing and recreation on the Long Creek Lake and on the Bonita Reservoir. Motorized boats shall not travel in excess of idle speed leaving no wake, except during sanctioned boating events conducted as part of the State Games of Mississippi during the specified calendar period of the State Games of Mississippi. 
(b)  All occupants of any boat upon such reservoir shall carry a life jacket, the type of which is approved for use by United States Coast Guard, with them at all times while in such boats. Racing between boats in any form shall be prohibited. Any disturbance of others who may be fishing either from other boats or from the shoreline is hereby declared to be unlawful. All boats passing another shall do so at a speed and distance sufficient to prevent any disturbance of the boat being passed. 
(Code 1962, § 25-83; Ord. No. 3243, § 1, 4-6-65; Ord. No. 3523, § 1, 6-22-77; Ord. No. 3863, 4-17-90; Ord. No. 3955, § 47, 5-18-93; Ord. No. 4133, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 25-204. - Same-Use by children under fifteen restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of fifteen (15) years to enter, ride in or occupy a boat unless accompanied by a person over the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(Code 1962, § 25-84) 
Sec. 25-205. - Same-Time limits. 
    The use of all boats shall be limited to use during the period beginning one (1) hour before sunrise and ending one (1) hour after sunset. 
(Code 1962, § 25-85; Ord. No. 3955, § 48, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-206. - Fish limits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take or kill in any one (1) day from the lakes game fish in excess of the limits established therefor by the state department of wildlife conservation; provided, however, the city council and mayor, by ordinance duly adopted, may impose stricter limits. Prior to such ordinance imposing the stricter limits becoming effective, it shall be published at least one (1) time in The Meridian Star, and the stricter limits shall be conspicuously posted at each gate or entrance to the lakes properties. 
(Code 1962, § 25-86; Ord. No. 3247, 8-3-65; Ord. No. 3955, § 49, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-207. - Sport fishing permitted; trot lines, nets, traps, etc., prohibited. 
    All types of sport fishing from the shoreline may be engaged in at all of the lakes and from boats in the two (2) lakes described above; provided that fishing by the use of trot lines, traps, seines and nets is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1962, § 25-87) 
Sec. 25-208. - Hours fishing permitted; when areas closed to public. 
    All fishing shall be limited to fishing during the period beginning one (1) hour before sunrise and ending one (1) hour after sunset, and all areas shall be closed to the public from the period beginning 10:00 p.m. and ending one (1) hour before sunrise. 
(Code 1962, § 25-88; Ord. No. 3955, § 50, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-209. - Concessions-Allowed; bids required. 
    The city may sell the following concessions to the highest and best bidder: 
(1)  To furnish and rent boats and outboard motors and to rent and sell fishing equipment at either or both the Long Creek Lake or the Bonita Reservoir. 
(2)  To rent or sell fishing equipment and to sell soft drinks, food, tobacco and sundries at either or both the Long Creek Lake or the Bonita Reservoir; provided that the sale of beer shall not be permitted. 
(3)  Such other concessions which may be of benefit to the public as approved by the city council on recommendation of the mayor. 
(Code 1962, § 25-89; Ord. No. 3955, § 51, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-210. - Same-Liability insurance required. 
    Before any person may enter upon the operation of a concession, public liability insurance and policies of such other insurance as may be required by the city, covering the full operations of such concession and such other matters or areas as may be required by the city, shall be purchased by the concessionaire from a reliable insurance company licensed to do business in the state, in such amounts, providing such coverages, containing such provisions and designating such insured as may be required by the city. The premium on such policies shall be paid in advance for at least one (1) year, and the policies, together with the premium receipts, shall be filed with the city clerk prior to the operation of such concession. 
(Code 1962, § 25-90; Ord. No. 3955, § 52, 5-18-93) 
Sec. 25-211. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code, and, in addition, may be denied admission into any of the areas of the water reservoir system of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 25-91)
